687,"The intervention (MIE  = mechanical insufflation-exsufflation)  is to be used at 8 to 12 h intervals in ICU patients 2 times or 14 x per day. MI-E is currently not part of the standard care in all ICUs in Denmark. The intervention is not intended as an alternative to routine therapy, but should be performed in addition to and if possible not simultaneously  with suctioning (=routine therapy) of the endotracheal tube or manual hyperinflation. A patient should only  receive the intervention if the ICU care team  is convinced that the patient has the potential of receiving MIE therapy and not necessarily in all days of the ICU stay.

The outcome of efficacy is to establish whether the intervention will reduce the incidence of Ventilator Associated Pneumonia (VAP)  and  duration on mechanical ventilation.  Furthermore, the outcome of safety is to evaluate whether MI-E  is safe.
Part 1 is a small sample trial of 60 patients investigating the feasibility  of implementing MI-E in ICUs in Denmark.

Part 2 is a subsequent randomized clinical trial of MI-E in 1000 patients  within the same cohort of ICUs. If MI-E is not safe or feasible in Part 1 or Part 2, or if the effect on VAP is not significantly different, then the trial will stop recruiting. We will however assess the effect of MI-E on the duration on mechanical ventilation and ICU mortality.

Economic analysis of MI-E therapy: The cost of MI-E will be compared with the cost of ICU care in general  in patients with an expected duration of mechanical ventilation of more than 48 hours. It will also include the  cost in the non-intervention group.
Besides Part 1 and 2 the following outcomes will be assessed:
Measuring the amount of time needed to perform MI-E (feasibility)

Assuming the prevalence of VAP around 20% and a clinically relevant reduction  of 20% reduction in VAP between  treatment and control group MI-E is associated with a number need to treat (NNT)  of  5 if VAP occur in 20% of the patients. This means that in total  5 patients must be ventilated and then treated with MIE for 4 weeks (14 sessions).

In the preliminary study  we observed that  the median  duration of  invasive mechanical ventilation was 7.2 days  (IQR 4.7-15.7) for patients intubated with endotracheal tubes for more than 48 hours.

Assuming  the prevalence of VAP around 20% and a clinically relevant reduction  of 20% reduction in VAP between  treatment and control group MI-E is associated with a NNT of  5 if VAP occur in 20% of the patients. This means that in total  5 patients must be ventilated and then treated with MIE for 4 weeks (14 sessions).

Mortality is not an outcome related to mechanical interventions, but is necessary to obtain statistical power to detect a meaningful difference in the effect of MI-E and to provide information on the safety of the intervention.

The following patient characteristics will be assessed: demographic characteristics, SAPS 2 score at admission, Acute Physiology Score (APS)  at inclusion and severity of illness at each day while on mechanical ventilation (based on vital signs, laboratory results and organ dysfunctions)
Severity of lung injury: Lung injury score (LIS) and PaO2/FiO2 ratio (P/F)
ICU-acquired weakness (ICU-AW)  assessed by the Medical Research Council (MRC) sumscore.

691,"15 patients undergoing surgery are assigned randomly to one of the two treatment groups: a treatment group receiving conventional premedication consisting of diazepam 10 mg 45 minutes before surgery and a placebo group receiving normal saline 45 minutes before surgery. The aim of the study is to determine whether the addition of a selective histamine H1-receptor antagonist to premedication attenuates the severity of postoperative pain. The following parameters will be recorded for each patient: maximum pain score within 48 hours postoperatively, additional analgesic requirements within 48 hours, degree of nausea, degree of anxiety, adverse events and patient satisfaction. To ensure random allocation, a computer-generated randomization list is used. This process is performed by an investigator who is not involved in the analysis or presentation of the results and is not aware of the patient's allocation. The allocation will be concealed by placing the participants in identical white envelopes that are numbered in case they are accidentally opened. The only exception to this rule is in case of emergency treatment or when a serious adverse event occurs. After randomization, the patients are given their study medication in accordance with the treatment assignment. Pain is measured on a numerical rating scale ranging from 0 to 10 (with 0 being no pain and 10 being severe pain), and additional analgesic requirements are assessed by the clinical staff. Nausea and anxiety are measured on four-point Likert scales, and adverse events are recorded in the patient's medical record. After the surgery, the patients are asked to complete a satisfaction questionnaire. The questionnaire asked patients to rate the quality of their surgical experience on a scale of 1 to 5 and to specify whether they would recommend the same procedure to a friend or family member. A score of 1 indicated that they were highly satisfied with their surgery, while a score of 5 indicated that they were not satisfied or recommended the same procedure to someone else. Study results: The main finding of our study is that the addition of a selective histamine H1-receptor antagonist to conventional premedication attenuates the severity of postoperative pain. Specifically, patients who received the selective histamine H1-receptor antagonist had less pain 48 hours postoperatively compared to the control group. In addition, patients who received the selective histamine H1-receptor antagonist had lower postoperative analgesic requirements and fewer adverse events compared to the control group. However, there were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of nausea, anxiety or patient satisfaction. Our results support the use of selective histamine H1-receptor antagonists as an adjunct to conventional premedication for reducing postoperative pain with minimal adverse events in patients undergoing surgery. In conclusion, our study provides evidence that the addition of a selective histamine H1-receptor antagonist to conventional premedication reduces the severity of postoperative pain in patients undergoing surgery. This finding has important implications for clinical practice and could lead to the development of new treatments for postoperative pain."

692,"A cross-sectional sample of 347 individuals with depression, schizophrenia, or bipolar depression was recruited as part of the Molecular Neuroimaging of Mood Disorders (MONMD) naturalistic open and uncontrolled multi-site trial. At baseline and week 12 (clinical follow-up), patients diagnosed with major depression were followed as part of a mood disorder naturalistic open and uncontrolled multi-site trial, while bipolar disorder patients were followed as part of a naturalistic open and uncontrolled study. Functional MRI data were acquired for 215 subjects from 3 centers.
BiospecimenCollection & Archiving:: Not collect nor Archive

Study Population Description:: Study subjects were recruited from outpatient, inpatient, and residential treatment programs. The following requirements apply for all study subjects. A study subject must be at least 18 years of age. A study subject must have a reliable primary treatment team and have agreed to provide a copy of the treatment team's notes, as well as the results of the psychosocial and neuropsychological assessments performed by the treatment team prior to entering the study. A study subject must have been on a stable SSRI regimen for at least 8 weeks prior to entering the study, or willing to be on an SSRI regimen throughout the study period, to minimize the influence of antidepressant treatment on study results. A study subject must have an established diagnosis of major depression (with or without panic disorder), bipolar disorder type I or II, or schizophrenia, as determined by the treating physician based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, fourth edition (DSM-IV) criteria and/ or the patient's clinical history in the medical records.

A study subject must not have a significant history of head trauma or known evidence of neurological or neuropsychiatric disorders, substance abuse disorder, physical disabilities that would exclude study participation, or a lifetime history of cognitive impairment and/or psychosis. A study subject must not have been implanted with a metal device, e.g., pacemaker, drug infusion/delivery device, magnetic implants, or have claustrophobia, which would limit his/her ability to enter the MRI scanner.

693,"PROSPER is a pilot randomized controlled Trial (RCT) and a qualitative study to assess the feasibility and acceptability of Problem Management Plus (PM+) as an intervention for Dutch prisons and for developing the interventions (i.e. supervision, training and fidelity) for future implementations. Problem Management Plus (PM+) is a brief, psychological intervention program that will be adapted to the Dutch prison context. It is an evidence-based program that targets anxiety, depression, stress, and self-identified problems among the target population. PM+ is a transdiagnostic program, meaning that it is effective in addressing multiple different mental health conditions in a single intervention. To date PM+ has been tested to be an effective intervention across a wide number of different settings (e.g. primary health care, public mental health services, university/school campuses). While PM+ is a brief program, a large body of research demonstrates that it can substantially reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression. However, the present study will be the first RCT outside the United Kingdom and Australia (where PM+ was developed). PROSPER is a mixed methods study. This means that we will be conducting both an RCT (study phase 2) and qualitative studies to assess whether PM+ (1) is feasible to implement and whether staff and participants (2) find the intervention beneficial and acceptable."

694,"α-Naphthyl acetate (α-NAA) is a naturally occurring chemical that has been shown to reverse or block drug resistance in a variety of cancer types in preclinical model systems. Xevinapant is a prodrug analog of α-NAA which can be converted to α-NAP to target the drug transporter called p-gp. Xevinapant has several attributes that make it an attractive therapy: 1) it is taken orally in capsule form and does not require intravenous (IV) delivery; 2) it may overcome p-gp resistance, allowing for more effective uptake of other cancer therapies; 3) it is safe and well tolerated; and 3) it will be developed in combination with an existing p-gp inhibitor, the targeted therapy enzastaur (TAK-779/Ensartin®), which is FDA-approved for treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Based on preclinical studies, we hypothesized that xevinapant (in capsule form) in combination with radiation and platinum- or taxane-based chemotherapy will be safe and effective for treating selected patients with unresectable HNSCC.

We will evaluate xevinapant in combination with radiation and platinum- or taxane-based chemotherapy in patients who have non-metastatic stage III or IV locoregionally advanced head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (SCCHN). We will examine the effect of increasing doses of xevinapant on the occurrence of side effects and effectiveness of treatment.

Abbreviations: NCI, National Cancer Institute; NOPO, Not otherwise specified; EGFR, Epidermal growth factor receptor; PD-1, Program death 1; HNSCC, Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma; p-gp, P-glycoprotein; AML, Acute myeloid leukemia; AP-1, Activator protein1; PKB, Protein kinase B; LC-MS/MS, Liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry

This is a Phase I/IIa, open-label, sequential dose escalation and cohort expansion study of xevinapant in combination with carboplatin, paclitaxel, and radiation therapy in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The study design is illustrated in Figure 1. In the initial dose escalation phase of study, the investigator will determine the maximally tolerated dose (MTD) or highest dose evaluated in this study. This will be accomplished via the administration of increasing doses of xevinapant in combination with carboplatin and paclitaxel on days 1-14 of a 21-day cycle, and radiation therapy 3 times per week for approximately 7 weeks, in patients with nonmetastatic head and neck cancer. A dose finding phase will determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D), which will then be evaluated in a dose expansion phase of study. Participants will begin xevinapant treatment at a lower dose than MTD, which will then be increased up to the MTD/RP2D dose in 28-day cycles. The dose will be increased until the occurrence of an unacceptable toxic effect or when 3 or more participants in a dose cohort have a dose limiting toxicity (DLT) which is defined as 2 or more toxicities that are thought to be related to xevinapant and are CTCAE grade 4 or worse within 28 days of dosing. The MTD/RP2D for xevinapant will be defined as the maximum dose studied that does not meet the above criteria for DLT.
Determination of xevinapant dose to be administered
Following treatment with radiation and chemotherapy, participants will continue with standard of care xevinapant therapy (N =60) for 3 cycles in the expansion phase of study.

Eligible patients must have histologically confirmed head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (SCCHN of the oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, hypopharynx, nasopharynx, or sinuses). The National Cancer Institute (NCI) version 1.0 clinical staging system will be used to define eligibility based on the stage of head and neck disease (T, N, M).

697,"BACKGROUND: Major depression is one of the leading causes of disability in the Danish population. It is estimated that 170,000 Danes have current major depression. In addition, about 15-20% of patients with depression show treatment resistant patterns following the initial period of treatment. Patients that show treatment resistance can show a number of problematic clinical patterns, including high co-morbidity, frequent and severe suicide attempts, frequent episodes of depression, and low responsiveness to pharmacological and psychological treatment. Patients with chronic treatment resistant depression often seek treatment in the secondary health care sector and the majority are in need of long-term pharmacological treatment. Clinical experience from treating chronically depressed patients has found that many of them have problems with poorer-than-expected response to pharmacotherapy, poorer-than-expected long-term prognosis and lack of focus on quality of life improvements, and show psychological and personality patterns that are often difficult to change with standard depression treatment. One such pattern is the development of avoidant, passive and hopeless personality traits in response to adversity, which may interfere with psychotherapeutic engagement and compliance. Treatment of this patient group can be a challenging prospect for therapists. There is currently no established treatment of choice for patients with treatment resistant depression. There are a number of promising approaches that claim to be more effective than standard treatments for depression, including schema therapy, but studies are mostly open label. A recent systematic review found that treatment for patients in the secondary level health sector who are treatment resistant can improve the patients' quality of life but has unclear effects on symptomatology. However, the review did not take into account the severity of depression as a moderator of treatment response. There are promising alternatives, such as schema therapy, that can benefit from randomized controlled treatment effect studies. The study is designed as a randomized controlled multicenter trial. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The study will include 400 adult participants with chronic mild to moderate treatment resistant depression (defined as a 12-months history of treatment resistant current major depression), who will be randomly assigned to receive either a prolonged period of schema therapy or extended standard treatment as usual in the secondary level mental health sector. The primary objective is to determine whether schema therapy affects depression symptomatology better than standard treatment as usual at 12 months after baseline. The primary outcome for depression symptomatology will be the reduction of symptomatology after 12 months on the clinician-rated Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D6). Secondary objectives and measures will include the effect of schema therapy compared to standard Depression treatment as usual on patient-defined improvements, quality of life, avoidance of medication, avoidance of inpatient setting and improvement related to health services use. Additional secondary measures will include the effect of schema therapy on negative expectancies, patient-centered outcomes of quality of life and personal recovery, psychological functioning, health-related quality of life, symptom avoidance, health-care resource use, subjective therapeutic response and outcome expectancies.

A number of novel outcome measures will be tested in relation to the patient's motivation towards psychotherapy and psychological wellbeing. Finally, a number of proposed modifications of the standard Minimal Stressor and the Major life Stressor questionnaires will be tested regarding ease of use, usefulness as a diagnostic tool and reduction of the number of missing values when participants are asked to provide data about events happening in the previous 12 months rather than in the previous 12 years. The findings are expected to give more insight into the mechanisms of change in psychotherapy for treatment resistant depression and will provide preliminary information about possible subgroups responding differently to schema therapy. If schema therapy is found to be superior to standard Depression treatment as usual, the study will provide a basis for the design of future studies that further establish schema therapy as the treatment of choice for treatment resistant depression.
Depression, psychosocial disorders, Mental and Behavioral Disorders
Mental Health, Mental Health, Mental Health

699,"2.1.1.1 Health condition or problem(s) studied: For many, living with and managing a chronic disease is difficult - requiring complex treatment, medical monitoring and other activities - and can have significant impacts on quality of life and self-management. This is particularly true for complex health issues like chronic kidney disease (CKD) characterized by gradual renal function decline over time. In this study, the investigators propose to expand our understanding of the psychological processes that impact CKD self-management, in a randomized controlled trial of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) among Black patients with chronic kidney disease. This study aims to examine and understand the psychosocial mechanisms that link MBSR treatment to improvements in CKD self-management and quality of life. 2.1.1.2 Objective of the trial: 1. Evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) in improving chronic kidney disease (CKD) self-management for Black patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). 2. Uncover the mechanisms underlying improvements in chronic kidney disease (CKD) self-management and health-related quality of life. 2.1.1.3 Trial contains a sub-study: No

Bone fractures are the most common injury presenting to emergency medicine departments in the United Kingdom. In 2018/2019 over 233,000 patients were admitted to hospital with musculoskeletal injuries, and these are the second largest cause of mortality in this age group. Fracture diagnosis is based on clinical history and examination, supplemented by imaging. Fractures are most commonly diagnosed on plain X-ray imaging. In orthopaedic trauma clinics, there is an ongoing emphasis for clinicians to increase the rate of diagnosis of fractures. The addition of artificial intelligence (AI) to X-ray image interpretation improves fracture diagnosis. AIM
The primary aim is to assess the performance of the AI algorithm in diagnosing fractures on plain X-rays compared to two musculoskeletal consultants acting as reference standard.

Multicentre interventional study, using blinded cases to be reviewed with and without the AI tool overlaid. Ground-truth will be obtained via the reference standard of two musculoskeletal consultants whose interpretation will be considered the gold-standard. Secondary aims will assess the impact of the AI tool on the detection of fractures.

Anonymised X-rays of adult skeleton and pelvic bone regions from up to 18 clinical sites will be reviewed by 18 participants in each reading session. Each reader will review 500 X-ray cases in each round (with and without AI assistance).

The AI tool Gleamer Boneview will overlay fracture detection over images using deep-learning. Participants will review 500 X-ray cases in each round. Each participant will independently review all cases, without knowledge of the other participantâ€™s interpretations. In the second phase, the AI results will be overlaid on the X-ray, and participants will then review the cases without knowledge of their interpretations from the first phase. Case selection will be done by a research nurse (non-radiologist) as part of the project work. This project will recruit emergency medicine doctors (consultants, middle grade), trauma and orthopaedic surgeons emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapists, clinical radiologists and radiographers. All participants in both reading phases will provide informed consent for the use of their results in both rounds of review.

Performance of AI algorithm: sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value, and area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve. Performance of AI algorithm over time. Performance of readers with vs without AI assistance: sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value, and area under the ROC curve. Reader speed with vs without AI assistance."

702,"Specific Learning Disorder (SLD or dyslexia) is a neurodevelopmental disorder in which the individual has difficulties in reading, written expression, and/or mathematics, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders – 5 (DSM-V). SLD; According to DSM-5, the academic difficulties experienced are explained in detail by dividing them into three subgroups. These are dyslexia, dyscalculia, and dysgraphia. The incidence of SLD is approximately 33% in girls and 67% in boys between the ages of 6-12. The etiology of SLD is multifactorial. It is associated with multiple genes and environmental risk factors. Structural imaging studies in children with SLD have revealed that grey matter is reduced. As a result of low grey matter, early literacy education seems to be negatively affected, and fine motor skills such as writing play an important role in this influence. Writing is a complex activity that includes perceptual, motor, and cognitive processes. Writing activities require a high level of fine motor coordination, postural control, adjustable grip strength, visual perception, and language skills. Considering the studies, it is stated that children who go to primary school spend 31%-60% of their academic days with tasks involving fine motor skills, and most of them do activities such as writing and painting. In addition to their academic and writing performances, children with SLD perform differently in daily life compared to their healthy peers. In general, they have difficulties during self-care activities such as tying shoes, clipping their nails, buttoning/zipping, shaving, and performing activities that require sequencing. At the same time, children with SLD have difficulties in sensory processing, balance, and postural control. Difficulties in sensory processing, balance, and postural control seen in children with SLD affect proximal stability. When proximal stability is poor, distal movements cannot be performed in good quality. Therefore, adequate postural control and proximal stability are essential prerequisites for many activities of daily living. In the literature, it has been shown that grip strength and anthropometric characteristics of the upper extremity affect distal fine motor skills. In a study by Anakwe et al., it was shown that grip strength increased as the forearm circumference measurement value increased. In a study examining the relationship between hand grip and finger strength and anthropometric measurements, it has been concluded that grip strength increases as arm and forearm measurements increase. It has been proven that grip strength increases as arm and forearm measurements increase. In the light of our current knowledge, no study has been found that comprehensively examines the fine motor functions, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with SLD. The primary aim of this study is to examine the fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with SLD compared to those of healthy children and to investigate their relationships with each other. The second aim of our study is to examine the effect of fine motor skills on quality of life and participation in activities at home, school, and community environment of children with SLD compared to their healthy peers.

704,"5-day HFRT results in equivalent local control and rates of major wound complications compared to CFRT. Preoperative HFRT could address disparities in access to care associated with CFRT, such as the burden of daily travel and time away from work or caregiving. HFRT has not been directly compared to CFRT in a prospective randomized trial, and therefore, efforts to develop such a trial would face challenges."

705,"Hip replacement surgery has been considered one of the most successful surgical procedures in orthopedic surgery. It is used in the management of hip osteoarthritis, dysplasia and avascular necrosis of the hip. According to national surgical statistics, the number of hip replacement surgeries performed in South Korea has been rapidly increasing and the total hip arthroplasty (THA) volume has reached approximately 80,000 in 2016. The purpose of hip replacement surgery is to reduce chronic or acute pain caused by degenerative joint disease and to improve patient mobility. As the proportion of aged people in the global population increases, the demand for joint implants is also growing. Most patients require surgical intervention to correct their hip dysfunction. An increasing amount of postoperative pain has been identified in patients following THA. Inappropriate management leads to a delay in postoperative recovery, and pain and lack of effective treatment may lead to prolonged hospitalization. Currently, most patients' pain after hip replacement surgery is managed postoperatively by providing intramuscular acetaminophen boluses 4-8 hours or morphine intravenous bolus 1-4 hours. However, these conventional analgesic methods have drawbacks such as a risk of respiratory depression, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and urinary retention. Therefore, analgesic methods using peripheral nerve blocks for the treatment of lower extremity joint surgeries such as total knee arthroplasty have been widely recognized. In the case of PENG BLOCK and LFCN BLOCK, not only postoperative pain can be alleviated but it also has fewer side effects such as nausea and vomiting. Furthermore, this method reduces the consumption of sedatives or analgesics that have been known to prolong the recovery times in orthopedic surgical patients. Therefore, through this study, we aimed to compare the analgesic effect and side effects between two analgesic methods using PENG block and lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block combined with pain management using patient-controlled analgesia in patients who underwent hip replacement surgery.

column1: 706,"OBJECTIVE: To determine if a dynamic MRI cine sequence is reproducible to quantify the mobility of pelvic organs and potentially detect variations in such mobility in women with and without endometriosis.STUDY DESIGN: Observational prospective descriptive study in patients with endometriosis and those without endometriosis.SETTINGS: University hospital (CHU de Québec).METHODS: Patients with endometriosis, who are referred for diagnostic MRI and who have not received treatment in 3 months and those without endometriosis, who are referred for routine pelvic MRI in this setting, will participate in the study. Diagnostic MRI evaluates endometriosis using an endometrial thickening index of ≥2 cm. Dynamic MRI is performed with a cine sequence, a sagittally oriented acquisition sequence, a 3D T1 sequence, and a 2D T2 sequence. The cine sequence parameters are adapted to the patient's anatomy and weight. Measurements of vertical displacement between pushing effort and rest will be performed manually on the initial dynamic MRI of each patient and with the 3D-Viewer Toolkit software. Analysis of the cine sequence parameters including slice thickness, matrix size, repetition time, echo time, and the number of phases will be made. Patients will be followed for six weeks to document the effect of treatment, when relevant, on symptoms and mobility. The objective is to quantify the variation between these elements and to statistically assess their correlation.RESULTS: The study began on December 2, 2021.CONCLUSION: The preliminary results of this study, combined with results from previous studies on the subject, will show us if dynamic MRI is reproducible in each setting and if the measurements obtained are representative of the movement of the organs. Such knowledge could serve to determine if dynamic MRI is useful in evaluating patients with endometriosis to better personalize treatment.

707,"A Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccination (LAIV) has been offered to children through a rolling national program in England since 2013. Influenza-related Healthcare Resource Use in England is measured up-to-June 2020 in this study. The study provides evidence on children vaccinated with LAIV over a 10-year time period, and whether the vaccination reduces GP consultations for Influenza-like-illness and admission to hospital, with a view to optimizing annual healthcare resource use associated with the flu vaccination program.
Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida

708,"Tang poems are not only for language learning but also induce people's happiness. Traditionally, some Chinese parents teach the very young kids to recite Tang poems even before the kids know how to read and write. Tang poems sound musical and should be easier to remember and recite than other texts. Learning and reciting poems at home could be happy and fun family activities in Chinese families. Whether using fun activities on small groups of kids in a community setting to promote Tang poem reciting and happiness could have the same effects of Tang poem reciting in Chinese kids is unknown for non-Chinese.

This is a pilot pre-interventional trial with no controls, with 10-20 South Asian children in Grade 3-5 (age 8-10) being recruited. Students who received an invitation to join a 4-hour fun activities for improving happiness and learning Tang poems will be offered to join our 4-hour fun activities. Parents give written consent if they agree for their children to participate. Students will receive stamp/sticker collection books and be rewarded for their achievements. The fun activities will incorporate some typical elements of the standardized curriculum, including language, grammar, poems, lyrics, history, and art. Experienced instructors from Bestreben Drama Association Limited will lead each session, and adherence to the protocol will be assessed by independent reviewers. A final session will include a 15-minute assessment of poem recitation skills, followed by a performance session where students can recite any Tang poem. Family members are encouraged to participate in the final session. A follow-up assessment will be conducted 12 weeks after the baseline to evaluate the sustainability of outcomes. Parents will complete questionnaires for themselves (Part II) and assisting their children (Part I). Parental presence and support will be acknowledged through supermarket coupon incentives. The feasibility outcomes will be reported descriptively and narratively, including the recruitment rate, duration, and retention rate. Descriptive statistics will be reported for the secondary outcomes.
Fun Activities for Reciting Tang Poems to Promote Happiness in Primary Schools Grade 3-5 South Asian Minority Students in Hong Kong
Acculturation, Happiness, Well-Being, Psychological, Ethnic Minority
* Behavioral: Fun activities for reciting Tang poems

Inclusion Criteria: South Asian students in Grade 3-5 of primary schools Age 8-10 Being able to communicate using either simple Cantonese or English Willing and able to complete all follow up assessments Exclusion Criteria: Physically or mentally unable to communicate Unwilling to participate regardless of parental consent Being involved in other similar activities or research Already proficient in Tang poems, being able to recite more than one poem

column1: 709,"The purpose of this proposal is to (a) develop an advanced, digital risk assessment and monitoring platform for clinicians, called Vira, which integrates existing passive data collection tools, like the EARS app, with a novel cognitive interface, and (b) conduct a pilot pragmatic RCT (with a wait-list control group) to test Vira as an adjunctive tool in the clinical management of youth who are admitted to an intensive outpatient setting because of their suicidal ideation, high risk for suicide, or a history of self-harm, and who also present with psychopathology and anhedonia. The primary clinical hypothesis is that, compared to the standard treatment approach of intensive outpatient treatment + passive risk monitoring and feedback via the EARS app, Vira will increase overall adherence to treatment by approximately 15% (i.e., greater than 3 additional appointments), help decrease suicidal ideation and impulsivity, and support better clinical outcomes for youth at high risk for suicide and mental health disorders."
710,"5 Meals a Day? A Pilot Study on the Effects of Eating Frequency on Metabolism and Physiological Functions

Emerging evidence suggests that circadian disruption may play an important role in the onset of metabolic diseases. Studies in animals fed ad libitum show that eating at night leads to adipose tissue expansion, whereas eating exclusively in the day appears to have the opposite effect. Although these findings are compelling, the majority of human studies looking at the effects of meal timing on metabolism have not separated the effects of eating frequency from those of eating timing. A recently reported pilot study in mice suggests that metabolism is impaired by the ingestion of six versus four meals per day. This study aimed to determine the metabolic impact of eating frequency by quantifying the respiratory metabolites in response to eating 4 versus 6 meals per day. Here we present a pilot study in humans examining the effects of meal frequency on energy expenditure, appetite, satiety and physiological functions using a two-way crossover design. This study will be used to determine a sample size for a larger future study. It is hypothesized that eating more frequently, despite matched total nutrient intake, will lead to greater resting energy expenditure (REE) and increase fat metabolism, without affecting whole-body or body composition metabolism as compared to eating a larger number of meals within the same set of hours.
5 Meals a Day? A Pilot Randomized Crossover Trial on the Effects of Eating Frequency on Metabolism and Physiological Functions

Inclusion: male and female, 18 to 35 y.o., healthy BMI (21-27.5) Exclusion: night-shift worker, sleep disorder, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, taking medications that affect body weight, shift worker, smoking, pregnant, breast-feeding or planning pregnancy within the next 4 months

column1: 711,"We are evaluating a new parenting program, called Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA). IPSA was developed as an educational parent training program for parents with ADHD who have children that experience social and/or behavioral problems. The program aims to help parents learn strategies for changing daily routines and improving their children’s behavior. This program is delivered in group format to provide social support and peer modeling. Parents first receive eight sessions of occupational therapy to learn strategies to improve their own skills and reduce the stress they experience with their child. Then they participate in ten sessions of parent training with a family therapist and occupational therapist. As part of the study, we are evaluating the impact of this program on parenting, child behavior problems, and parents’ feelings of stress. We will also explore the program’s effectiveness in reducing household disorganization and improving time management and organizational skills. Lastly, we will measure if the program was delivered as intended (treatment integrity)."

712,"This study will pilot a technology-based app that addresses the interrelated topics of substance use and risky sex practices, within the context of personal relationships. Pilot data will be used to determine the extent to which a randomized controlled efficacy trial is feasible.

Exclusion Criteria: none

713,"372 Million people live with a neurological disorder worldwide. In Canada, someone is diagnosed with a neurological condition every minute. Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is the most prevalent neurological disease in Canadians aged 15 to 44. MS is a chronic, autoimmune, and inflammatory disease of the central nervous system, characterized by demyelinating lesions caused by the body’s own immune system. About 12% of people with MS have the primary progressive form (PPMS), which is characterized by steady progression of physical disability from the beginning of the illness. Current therapies for progressive MS are only marginally effective. At present, there is no known cure for MS, and there are few therapeutic options for disease progression. The investigators believe RIC is ideally suited to be tested as a therapy for progression in MS. Recent clinical trials in vascular disease have shown that daily RIC can be performed for up to a year and suggested an all-cause mortality benefit. In a recent (RICAMIS trial, 2022) multicenter, randomized trial of people with acute ischemic stroke (> 1,000 participants), 14-day RIC treatment led to improved functional outcomes at 6-months. No serious side effects were reported, and tolerability was good. This important study was the first phase III trial to find a protective effect for RIC in neurological disease, and highlights the timeliness and potential for re-purposing RIC as a therapy for MS. In this trial, the investigators will investigate whether RIC treatment can prevent disability worsening in people with Primary Progressive MS (PPMS). The primary objective of this trial is to demonstrate non-futility of RIC for reducing progression of disability, as measured with the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW), in people with PPMS. This is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial. The study will follow the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies."

We performed a single-center prospective study of patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis (AH), including early liver transplantation (ETI) recipients, to evaluate whether early prothrombin time (PT) could predict response to standard medical treatment (SMT).

At admission, the mean age of the 200 studied patients (97 men; mean age, 54 y) was 54 years; they had mean values of 2,51 ± 1,79 IU/L for AST and 5,68 ± 8,83 IU/L for ALT. The total Maddrey’s discriminative function (MDF) score was 39.9 ± 5.3 at admission, and the 133 patients with an MDF score of ≥32 (M53) received 1200 mg/d methylprednisolone for seven days and were the subjects of the primary analysis. At day 7, the proportion of patients with a response (Lille score <6.6 or failure to progress) was 32.6% in the total M53 population; however, a response was observed in 71.8% of M53 patients with an initial PT >45.0 s and 25.8% in those with a PT ≤45.0 s on admission.

A multivariable discriminant analysis showed that an initial PT ≤45.0 s (odds ratio, 62, p <0.0001) and a score of ≥6.6 on the Lille score (odds ratio, 31, p <0.0001) were the only independent significant factors associated with lack of response to treatment (AUC, 0.868).

For the primary analysis, 40 ETIs were performed from day 0 of admission; however, only 4 (10%) were performed on days 1 to 7, and the remaining 36 (90%) from day 8. Only M53 patients with an initial PT ≤45.0 s were eligible for ETIs; the Lille score was, however, not associated with the decision to perform ETIs (p = 0.81). The authors concluded that an initial PT ≤45.0 s was a strong predictor of lack of response to SMT. It did not appear to be useful to stratify AH patients eligible for standard medical care based on the Lille score, whereas it could be useful to consider PT at admission to guide therapeutic decisions with regard to liver transplantation and to improve outcomes of patients with severe AH."

715,"Cerebral palsy (CP) is the most common physical disability in childhood. Spasticity is the most common motor impairment in children with CP is associated with limited range of motion (ROM). Several treatment options, including therapeutic exercises and functional electrical stimulation (FES), have been used to limit spasticity and improve gait. However, some studies have indicated that FES does not improve gross motor function and balance in children with spastic CP compared to traditional interventions to improve motor abilities of the CP children, such as balance training.
The purpose of this work is to compare the use of FES with the common functional therapeutic exercise program in reducing hypertonia and improve balance in CP children.

The study will be conducted on 10 CP children who will be randomly assigned to two groups; FES group that will receive 8 weeks cycle and conventional therapeutic exercise group who will receive 8 weeks functional therapeutic exercise with conventional physiotherapy for 1 hour duration per day. Both groups will be evaluated at baseline and after 8 weeks in terms of gross motor function (GMFM) and balance (Pediatric Balance Scale) and ROM (goniometer).

The hypotheses are that the use of FES together with the conventional therapeutic exercise program will be more effective than the conventional therapeutic exercise program alone in improving gross motor function, balance and ROM and that the conventional therapeutic exercise program with additional physiotherapy will provide better results in improving gross motor function, balance and ROM than conventional therapeutic exercise program alone.
Minimal Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level 1
Satisfaction in informed consent form from patient mother and child.
Patients with deformities like scoliosis and pelvic, oblique, and hip deformity
Visual impairment Mental retardation Exclusion criteria Age more than 16 years
GMFCS score. Timepoint: Before intervention and after 8 weeks of intervention. Method of measurement: GMFCS (Gross Motor Function Classification System score).
Goniomete and Pediatric Balance Scale, Timepoint: Before intervention and after 8 weeks of intervention Method of measurement: Pediatric Balance Scale and Goniomete"

716,"This research aimed to identify the correlation of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) to the outcome of surgical primary correction of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF). This was a retrospective study on tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita. A total of 77 patients diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot and underwent primary repair were included in the study. Patients were divided into three groups, including patients who required a redo operation (Group I), died after the operation (Group II), and had satisfactory surgical outcomes (Group III). The following variables were examined: patient's age, gender, body weight, oxygen saturation, body mass index (BMI), associated congenital cardiac anomalies other than ToF, and the laboratory examination of complete blood count and differential count in the same hospital admission. The preoperative laboratory examination included leukocyte count, the percentage of neutrophil, the percentage of lymphocyte in the absolute number, thrombocyte count, neutrophil lymphocyte ratio (NLR), and thrombocyte lymphocyte ratio (TLR). The data for each group are compared. Patients with more significant differences in NLR, ALC, and TLR at least at the 5% level were considered statistically significant. The data obtained were entered in and analyzed using STATA 15.0 (Stata Corporation, College Station, Texas, USA).

Prognostic value of neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte to lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting the outcomes of primary repair for tetralogy of Fallot

Surgical primary correction of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) is associated with a considerable rate of morbidity and mortality. We hypothesized neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte to lymphocyte ratio (TLR) could predict the outcomes after surgical primary correction. Therefore, this study aimed to determine the association of NLR, ALC, and TLR on the outcome of surgical primary correction of ToF. This research was a retrospective study on ToF primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita from Januari 2020 until December 2022. A total of 77 patients diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot and underwent primary repair were included in this study. Patients were divided into the early redo surgery group (Group I), post-primary redo surgery group (Group II), and those who had satisfactory surgical outcomes (Group III) as the outcome. The following variables were examined: patient's age, gender, body weight, oxygen saturation, body mass index (BMI), associated congenital cardiac anomalies other than Tetralogy of Fallot, and the laboratory examination of complete blood count and differential count in the same hospital admission. The preoperative laboratory examination included, leukocyte count, the percentage of neutrophil, the percentage of lymphocyte in the absolute number, thrombocyte count, neutrophil lymphocyte ratio (NLR), and thrombocyte lymphocyte ratio (TLR). The data for each group were compared. Patients with a more significant difference in NLR, ALC, and TLR at least at the 5% level were considered statistically significant. The data obtained were entered in and analyzed using STATA 15.0 (Stata Corporation, College Station, Texas, USA). The result of this study will elucidate the importance of laboratory markers in predicting surgical outcomes."

717,1 in 7 women use an IUD as their primary birth control. This form of birth control does not require adherence by the woman and can provide contraception for 3-12 years. IUDs have significant benefits but can cause pain during the device placement. A previous pilot study was conducted to examine the use of lidocaine prior to device placement. The results showed a 72% decrease in post-procedure pain and patients who received lidocaine were more likely to request a follow IUD insertion. This study is randomized and double blinded to allow for comparison between those who receive lidocaine and those who do not regarding post-procedure pain and satisfaction. This study will also evaluate the use of lidocaine for those with history of trauma and those who prefer no lidocaine.

718,"2021 is an historic year for public health. COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of early detection of chronic diseases to prevent the risk of developing adverse conditions such as diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and immunological diseases and to avoid an undesirable health outcome. Universal capillary screening for celiac disease, type I diabetes and cardiovascular risks, performed through an effective outreach campaign, could play a pivotal role in reducing healthcare-related costs, thanks to early diagnosis and treatment and to the identification of risk factors. The scientific rationale is to investigate whether screening protocols are acceptable and feasible at population level in order to provide useful information to Public Health Department and Policy maker decision on disease risk assessment implementation. The proposed trial is a single center prospective study that enrols a population living in the same town. The investigators aim to enroll 1900 participants (10% of the population). Participants will undergo an educational and informative session about diseases included in the screening program (celiac disease, type I diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases), and capillary sampling will be performed. All results and information about diseases will be available within a few days for participants.

In the absence of a cure, the main focus in the management of PD is the prevention and management of PD complications. PD patients have a 50% increased risk of developing respiratory tract infections (mainly viral, but also bacterial) and infections are a common cause of death in this population. The risk of developing COVID-19 related complications (for example infections and acute respiratory distress syndrome) is substantially increased in COPD and PD patients. Therefore, during SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, guidelines suggest that COPD and PD patients should limit social contact as a measure of primary prevention. This can affect patients mental health and quality of life and therefore it is currently unknown if the guidelines are feasible and how well they are adhered to.

The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of social isolation on anxiety and depression scores, measured by the HADS scale, in PD patients. By combining the experience of the treating neurologist and the clinical assessment of the patients, the study's investigators hypothesize the following: patients affected by neuropsychiatric co-morbidities will show a higher increase in anxiety and depression scores in comparison to those not affected by these co-morbidities. Furthermore, they believe that the increase in anxiety and depression scores in neuropsychiatric co-morbidity-free patients is positively correlated with the duration of social isolation. To this aim, between June 2020 and January 2021, every Parkinson's patient affected by social isolation and followed at the Neurological Clinic of Lodi Hospital (Italy) will be involved in the proposed study. Every patient will undergo clinical follow-up; each visit will include an independent assessment of cognitive and neuropsychiatric health and a specific scale will be used: the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). Patients' clinical information, in particular cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms, will be collected prospectively.
Effect of Social Isolation on Neuropsychiatric Comorbidities of Parkinson's Disease Patients During the COVID-19 Pandemic: a Prospective Cohort Study

Inclusion Criteria: age >18 years patients with a confirmed diagnosis of PD according to the MDS-PP and/or UK Parkinson's Disease Society Brain Bank criteria and follow-up with at least one visit in the first 4 months of 2020 and between June 2020 January 2021 (when COVID-19 social restrictions were active in Italy). Exclusion Criteria: patients with moderate-severe cognitive impairment according to MMSE score, with dementia (according to the criteria of the Movement Disorders Society Consensus Conference) or with delirium (according to the CAM-ICU criteria)

719,"5,000 participants (aged 18-70) will be given a set of smart sensors (to monitor steps, heart-rate, body temperature, air quality, carbon dioxide) as well as a set of lifestyle surveys and asked to wear the sensors and complete the surveys for 6 months. Participants will share their data via the app, in return they will receive their personalised health insights. The study will examine the feasibility, usability and efficacy of using a digital health platform for improving public health. Participants with poor health will be given feedback on how to improve their health, and subsequently invited to clinical trials to test new experimental treatments. The study will help to reduce the huge public burden ($2.8 trillion/year) related to poor mental and physical health.
1. Primary outcome: Health status measured using a clinical questionnaire. Secondary outcome: Health status measured using a clinical questionnaire.
2. Secondary outcome: Health status measured using a clinical questionnaire."

721,"The study will investigate the pharmacokinetic profile, tolerability, and safety of JHT202/T21K when administered as a single dose in a liquid formulation in healthy adult subjects. This study will assess the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of JHT202/T21K when administered as a powder for oral solution.
The specific aims of the study are:
1) To evaluate the safety and tolerability of JHT202/T21K in healthy adults.
2) To evaluate the pharmacokinetics of JHT202/T21K in healthy adults.
3) To evaluate the effect of food on the pharmacokinetics of JHT202/T21K in healthy adults.

A Phase II, Open-Label, Multicenter Clinical Study to Evaluate the Safety, Effectiveness and Pharmacokinetic Parameters of Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine in the Treatment of Resting Legs Syndrome Secondary to End-Stage Renal Disease

The study is to document primary effectiveness endpoints of the investigational drug Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine and to identify a dose for clinical development, as well as to compare the investigational product Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine with a reference product Levodopa, and to assess drug disposition of the investigational product Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine and the reference product Levodopa in healthy subjects. After the screening, only subjects (N = 60) who meet the inclusion criteria will enter the study. The trial includes a dosing phase, and then a follow-up visit is arranged to follow the safety and treatment of the participants to be followed for 7 days.

Study drug Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine (BAY84-985) is a single-ingredient drug with a combination of levodopa (200mg/100mg) and fesoterodine (5.6mg/2.8mg) in a fixed-dose combination that is administered orally in a single tablet per day, and it dissolves well in water. Levodopa is an effective therapy for alleviating the symptoms of Parkinson's disease. The combined use of levodopa and fesoterodine may be better than levodopa alone for the treatment of Parkinson's disease. Fesoterodine is a non-selective monoamine oxidase inhibitor that is used as a levodopa-saving treatment for Parkinson's disease. The combination of Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine has not been approved for any disease. It is currently undergoing clinical trials.

1) To document primary effectiveness endpoints of the investigational drug Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine and to identify a dose for clinical development, as well as to compare the investigational product Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine with a reference product Levodopa, and to assess drug disposition of the investigational product Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine and the reference product Levodopa in healthy subjects;

2) To evaluate the safety and tolerability of Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine in healthy subjects, and to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine and Levodopa in healthy subjects and to identify plasma exposure multiples for the assessment of the pharmacokinetic dose-efficacy relationship of Zydis Levodopa Fesoterodine (i.e., the dose-proportionality relationship of AUC and CMAX).

Inclusion Criteria: All subjects must meet all of he following inclusion criteria in order to be screened into the study: Subjects must be able to swallow tablets and solution. Subjects must be able to participate in the study, to understand and comply with all study activities, and to provide independent, informed consent (where applicable, subjects with visual impairments must be fully capable of reading and writing). Women of childbearing potential must agree to use highly"

722,"The aims of this proposal is to demonstrate that:  (i) 3D brain mapping can be significantly improved by adding scalp electroencephalography (EEG) to ultra-high field functional MRI (fMRI), as a means to measure brain activity on the scale of individual neurons, and (ii) EEG and fMRI can be combined for high-resolution neuroimaging of normal brain networks and neuropsychiatric abnormalities.

Specifically, we will conduct brain-mapping experiments using EEG-fMRI, fMRI and structural MRI in multiple subject groups: (i) healthy participants; (ii) psychosis patients; (iii) essential tremor patients; and (iv) patients with epilepsy.

All imaging will be conducted at high resolution (3×3×3 mm3), that enables detailed mapping of the brain. Additionally, we will have a large number of volunteers with normal functional connectivity (as determined by structural connectomes), representing a ‘normal age range’ of healthy individuals, who can be matched to patient groups, and serve as controls. Importantly, the MRI scanner used throughout is an ultra-high field scanner (7 Tesla), which enables much higher spatial resolution and higher signal levels (SNR). This is particularly important for brain mapping, as it will enable our study to reach a level of spatial resolution not attainable even by the latest non-invasive neuroimaging tools, which are routinely used in scientific and clinical practice. Our proposed research will result in the first high-resolution maps of individual thalamocortical connections in the brain, and will advance scientific understanding of the mechanisms underlying brain connectivity and function in health and disease. Our research is interdisciplinary and will involve researchers with multiple scientific backgrounds. The proposed collaboration is highly complementary and aims to strengthen the neuroimaging research at the University of Zurich (USZ). The new techniques and methods developed in this project will have numerous applications in both science and society. First, the resulting high-resolution brain maps will provide more detailed insights into normal brain function, normal brain network development, and pathological changes in disease states such as psychosis. Second, these brain maps may be helpful in improving the design of neurosurgical interventions for the treatment of epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, deep brain stimulation and tumour ablation. Third, these high-resolution brain maps may assist in the early diagnosis and in the more accurate clinical evaluation of neurological and psychiatric patients."

723,"1/2 the patients in each group will receive a subpopulation analysis by 16s rRNA sequencing to analyze the variation of gut microbiota in different nutritional interventions. Additionally, by doing so, we could have an understanding that would allow to link gut microbiota and hepcidin levels in obese patients with iron deficiency treated with weight loss. The change in body weight and fat mass between different nutritional interventions will be performed with multifrequency electrical bioimpedance. In the future the data obtained will allow to design nutritional recommendations in obese patients who suffer from iron deficiency."

724,"1.742 women gave birth in 2016-2019 at the OHC. The investigators need to recruit a total of 1911 women who will be prospectively included: at least 464 women with a vaginal birth after eCTG monitoring (vaginal birth rate is 95,1% in 2016-2019). In order to strengthen the comparison between the two groups (eCTG and standard treatment), additional data from 1400 women who received standard treatment in 2014-2019 will be collected retrospectively. An overview of the study design is provided in the attached scheme. 2.1.1 Perinatal mortality: The investigators will include incidence of perinatal mortality in the composite outcome because they found a high correlation between NFMS and UA. 2.1.3 Intrauterine growth retardation: The investigators will include incidence of intrauterine growth retardation in the composite outcome. This is because of the increased chance of periventricular leukomalacia and neonatal seizures in fetuses with growth retardation and the increased chance of neonatal morbidity in this group. 2.2.1 Maternal morbidity: The investigators want to include complications of pregnancy known in the literature to assess their risk in eCTG-monitored pregnancies 2.2.1.2 Maternal mortality: The investigators will include death of the mother that is related to the pregnancy. 2.3 Other neonatal morbidity not listed in the primary outcome: This includes: •IVH grade 1-2•PVL grade 1•Mild BPD•NEC grade 1•ROP necessitating laser therapy•Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy•Neonatal seizures•Neonatal sepsis (culture proven)•Need for intubation on the delivery room•Mechanical ventilation within the first 72 hours after birth•Antibiotics within the first 72 hours after birth•Spontaneous intestinal perforation (SIP) necessitating surgery•Surfactant treatment•Apgar score <7 after 5 minutes•Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.05 and base deficit ≥12mmol/L).

2.5 Patient satisfaction: Patient satisfaction will be evaluated by an independent researcher, asking the woman to fill out the questionnaire at the end of her admission. The investigators will assess patient satisfaction of both the vaginal birth after eCTG monitoring and the caesarean section after eCTG. 2.4 Caregiver satisfaction: Caregiver satisfaction is measured by Browns survey, this assessment tool is provided by NEMO Healthcare. The survey will be completed by the obstetrician and midwife at the end of the trial (after 12 months). 2.6 Obstetric interventions: This includes planned caesarean section, emergency caesarean section, and admission to the NICU (neonatal intensive care unit). 2.8 Statistical analysis plan.
The NIEM-O High Risk Birth Cohort: The impact of continuous eCTG monitoring and patient characteristics on NFMS quality measures

725,"The purpose of this research is to look at genes that are associated with rare and severe infectious diseases. To do this, DNA samples from patients will be compared to DNA samples from their relatives. The samples from both groups will come from the patient’s blood.

ICD10:: A41 - Dengue, chikungunya and other arboviral feversB35 - Bacterial diseases of the upper respiratory tract (of any site) with influenza-like illnessB37 - Other bacterial diseases of the lower respiratory tractC18 - PneumoniaB39 - Other bacterial diseases of intra-abdominal organs without mention of liverB40 - Acute cholecystitis with suppurative complicationC34 - Bacterial diseases of the liver without mention of hepatocyte disordersR80 - Other infections and infestations, unspecified

Outcome: Genome and exome sequencing to identify pathogenic mutations in genes whose loss of function has been reported or suggested in cellular models to impair innate immunity to viruses, bacteria, fungi, or parasites. Method: The DNA sample from each patient will be extracted from a blood sample taken from the patient. Comparative sequencing of the patient’s genome or exome will reveal differences to their relatives’ genomes. This will lead to mutations in the patient’s genome.

Outcome: Identification of regions with an increase in homozygosity, which include disease-associated genes, in patients and their relatives. Method: Analysis of homozygosity across the genome and on microarrays covering each of the patient’s chromosomes."

727,"Adipose tissue and bone marrow are promising sources for cell-based therapy in non-union fractures and musculoskeletal diseases such as osteoarthritis. Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC), an adult stem cell, can be obtained from both tissues.

The effectiveness of MSC-based therapies depends on their ability to improve local microenvironment and thus alleviate the symptoms of osteoarthritis. The most common treatment for osteoarthritic knees is knee surgery or knee arthroplasty.

Although this type of treatment is effective in relieving symptoms, it has a disadvantage associated with a high recurrence rate. This recurrence rate increases with age, but it also increases with the severity of osteoarthritis. OA is a highly prevalent musculoskeletal condition that has a major social and economic impact due to the number of people affected and by the burden of treatment. The aim of this study is to evaluate if the therapeutic effect of intra-articular injection of BMAC is comparable to the effect of intra-articular injection of MM-AT in patients with symptomatic knee OA."
728,"100 participants will have cognitive and functional brain testing within sessions 1 and 2 of the study. Imaging will be performed on a research grade 3T MRI scanner.

A total of 150 participants will be randomized to one of four groups for the duration of the study: C-0, C-75, C-150 or Placebo. Development of a Prospective Observational Cohort, and a Cross-Sectional and Observational Trial on the Efficacy and Safety of CBD TPM Capsules in the Treatment of Chronic Pain in Adults

CBD TPM Capsules, also known as Epidiolex, are a prescription medication currently approved in Australia as a treatment for epilepsy. It has been approved for the same indication in many countries worldwide, including in over fifty states of the USA, but not elsewhere in Europe. TAK-937 is Takeda Pharmaceuticals' proprietary CBD manufacturing process. Cannabidiol (CBD) is a well-known substance that is extracted from the hemp plant. It has long been used in people with pain. However, until recently, CBD products were not pharmaceutical grade nor approved in Australia as products that are used to treat a medical condition. The purpose of the research is to conduct two studies that will evaluate CBD TPM Capsules' efficacy and safety in people with chronic pain that is poorly controlled by existing pain treatments. The first study will gather information on the effects of CBD TPM Capsules on pain, fatigue, mood and overall quality of life. The participants will receive either CBD TPM Capsules or a placebo capsule and provide information over an 8 week period. In the second study, participants who continue to be in chronic pain at 8 weeks, will be switched to CBD TPM Capsules or continue with the placebo. Once the second study is complete, the participants will be invited to join the continuation observational cohort to receive CBD TPM Capsules or placebo and will provide information over a 52 week period. The research aims to evaluate CBD TPM Capsules' efficacy and safety in people with chronic pain that is poorly controlled by existing pain treatments. The first study will be a single arm, open-label study in 240 subjects who will continue for 8 weeks. The study outcome will be a composite score derived from four core measures (WOMAC, PGIC, FP, MFI). In the second study, participants who continue to be in chronic pain at 8 weeks, will be switched to CBD TPM Capsules or continue with the placebo. The study will be a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. 6 participants who are recruited at the St Vincent's Hospital Sydney site will continue for 52 weeks for the continuation observational cohort study. The continuation observational cohort will be extended to up to 180 weeks for those who wish to continue on CBD TPM Capsules. The studies will be conducted over an 18 month period at 4 sites in Australia and New Zealand. Data will be compared to data from the two prior studies (the 'Early Trials') that was conducted in 500 patients with chronic pain.

Part 1 - Single-arm, open-label study of cannabidiol TPM capsules in chronic pain: To evaluate CBD TPM Capsules' efficacy and safety in patients with chronic pain that is unresponsive to opioid therapy. There will be two parts to this part of the study. CBD TPM Capsule: Participants will receive 75 mg CBD TPM Capsules once-daily for 8 weeks. Safety: Safety will be assessed by Adverse Events (AEs), Physical Examination (PE), Vital signs, Electrocardiogram (ECG), Blood pressure, Respiratory rate, Concentration of CYP3A4 metabolizing enzyme, Pregnancy test (as needed), and Laboratory tests (hematology/biochemistry). Participants will also be asked to answer questions about the experience of taking the medication. The study outcome will be a composite score derived from four core measures (WOMAC, PGIC,"

729,"20 samples  will be used to construct 10 training-test pairs to ensure validity. The 10 pairs will each be composed of 100 bootstrap (random) sample replications of each study dataset. For each pair, the training dataset is used to construct an ELN classifier model. Then a test dataset in the pair will be used to obtain predicted probabilities for all samples in the pair, and prediction accuracy is measured for those samples. The validation is based on the ELN classifier. The ELN classifier is evaluated by its predictive performance to determine whether it is capable of predicting the risk of HCC from metabolic profiles."

730,The goal of this investigation is to compare anatomic and clinical success in eyes treated with scleral buckling and vitrectomy for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment to those that undergo sole vitrectomy and to further compare the performance of sulfur hexafluoride vs perfluoropropane gas tamponade.

731,"The increasing use of opioids for perioperative and chronic pain has been associated with complications that have negative impacts on quality of life and health care expenditures. Opioid-related complications include hyperalgesia, postoperative nausea and vomiting, respiratory depression, tolerance and addiction, urinary retention, pruritus, and sedation. Furthermore, local anesthetics can potentially reduce opioid consumption, prevent opioid side effects, and have the potential to be useful for chronic pain management. In the present study, we will evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset and duration of the sensory block, postoperative pain scores, and opioid consumption, in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia. We hypothesize that the use of 1% ropivacaine for ankle blocks will result in a longer sensory block duration compared to the use of 0.25% and 0.5% ropivacaine in patients having forefoot surgery and therefore potentially reduce the need for postoperative opioids and reduce the opioid-related complications. In conclusion, we will evaluate the potential of ropivacaine for treating chronic pain by studying its effects on acute somatic pain and postoperative opioid consumption and side effects in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia."
732,"In this study, it will be evaluated whether compression stockings that are routinely applied to patients to support healthy pregnancies will decrease the severity of RLS in pregnant women.
In the study, 40 pregnant women with RLS, age 18-40, at least high school graduate, 27-34-week pregnant will be included.

The patients will be divided into three groups in the study; a group that will wear compression stockings, a group that will wear knee socks, and a group that will not apply any socks for 3 weeks. We plan to compare them with Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, Restless Legs Severity Rating Scale, WHO-Qol-breastfeeding module scores, and blood parameters. The patients will be evaluated by all forms every week during week 3.

The data to be collected from the questionnaires will be obtained in electronic format. The program where the information will be collected will be secured by a password and it will be decided who has access to these data by providing passwords to the members of the research group."

733,"60 healthy adults will be recruited and randomly assigned into two groups: Control group/Intervention group, with a ratio of 1:1. The intervention group will practise daily home-based exercise snacking for 12 weeks. The exercise snacking programme will utilise Tai-chi snacking, resistance snacking and power snacking. Participants will complete an exercise log to record the exercise bouts duration, type, and intensity (RPE), and the number of repetitions completed. Participants will also complete the TEFANA exercise test at baseline, week 10, and week 22. The test will consist of maximal cycling test and strength testing.

Intervention Description:: The exercise programme is progressive and has three levels. Each bout of exercise and Tai-chi snacking consists of 5 exercises. Each exercise is performed for one minute with one minute rest in between. For exercise snacking movements (including leg exercise, shoulder exercise, single leg exercise, arm exercise, and ankle exercise), participants are encouraged to complete as many repetitions as possible of that exercise in that minute. For Tai-chi snacking movements (including single leg squat, trunk rotation, single leg stand, hip and knee exercise, and ankle mobility exercise), participants are encouraged to complete repetitions of each exercise at a self-selected pace that is comfortable for them to maintain for the full minute, with the aim being to complete the movements as accurately and smoothly as possible (based on correct posture and proper alignment).

Phase2-Intervention-1:: The exercise programme is progressive and has three levels, each consists of five minutes exercise snacking. Each bout of exercise and Tai-chi snacking consists of 5 exercises. Each exercise is performed for one minute with one minute rest in between. For exercise snacking movements (including leg exercise, shoulder exercise, single leg exercise, arm exercise, and ankle exercise), participants are encouraged to complete as many repetitions as possible of that exercise in that minute. For Tai-chi snacking movements (including single leg squat, trunk rotation, single leg stand, hip and knee exercise, and ankle mobility exercise), participants are encouraged to complete repetitions of each exercise at a self-selected pace that is comfortable for them to maintain for the full minute, with the aim being to complete the movements as accurately and smoothly as possible (based on correct posture and proper alignment).

Phase2-Intervention-2:: Control group/Intervention group, with a ratio of 1:1. The intervention group will practise daily home-based exercise snacking for 12 weeks. The exercise snacking programme will utilise Tai-chi snacking, resistance snacking and power snacking. Participants will complete an exercise log to record the exercise bouts duration, type, and intensity (RPE), and the number of repetitions completed.

Phase2-Intervention-3:: The intervention group will work with our sports scientist via Zoom in order to learn the exercise snacking protocols and safety guidelines. This will happen after the baseline measurements to ensure that all participants are physically capable of executing the exercises. Participants will practice home-based exercise snacking for 12 weeks through an exercise instructional video and progress at their own pace.

Phase2-Intervention-4:: Participants will follow a self-imposed exercise snacking protocol as shown in Appendix 1. Participants are also asked to log their activities in a log book and will record the exercises and RPE for each session they complete.
Phase2-Intervention-5:: Follow up period: after 12 weeks.
Arm Description:: The control group will receive no intervention.

Arm Description:: The intervention group will practise daily home-based exercise snacking for 12 weeks. The exercise snacking programme will utilise Tai-chi snacking, resistance snacking and power snacking.

734,"1. Background: Postoperative pain is one of the most common complaints and is also associated with many complications. Perioperative opioids, though relieve pain but hampers consciousness, increase PONV and delays mobilization. Pre-operative nerve blocks can alleviate postoperative pain, facilitates early mobilization, decreases nausea and vomiting, decreases post operative opioid consumption, improves patient satisfaction and decreases hospital length of stay. The optimal nerve block for spine surgeries remains undetermined. Caudal epidural block places the needle through the sacral hiatus into the epidural space to deliver medications. It can be performed as ultrasound guided procedure with very high successful rates. Single shot caudal block with local anesthetic provides analgesia for 2-4 hours but this can be further prolonged by adding adjuvants like opioids, steroids, ketamine, alpha 2 agonists, adrenaline etc. Ropivacaine is a long-acting amide local anesthetic agent which is less lipophilic, less cardiac and central nervous system toxicity with similar duration of analgesia, has lesser motor blockade and can be given safely to parturing patients. This study evaluates the role of adding dexamethasone to ropivacaine in caudal block for postoperative pain relief in spine surgeries.
Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida
caudal epidural block, nerve block, acute pain management, ropivacaine, dexamethasone, preemptive analgesia"

737,"136 women diagnosed with Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI) and chronic non-specific Low Back Pain (LBP) will be enrolled. The primary outcomes is urinary leakage episodes reported in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF).The secondary outcomes are pain, as reported with the Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and postural stabilization in static positions, as reported with the MOS.
