739,"Acute cholangitis (inflammation and infection in the biliary tract) is a disease that can cause severe mortality and morbidity. Treatment of the primary cause, i.e. bile duct obstruction, is required to optimize outcome, but the duration of antibiotic treatment is still controversial. For instance, short-course antibiotic therapy (one day) in acute cholangitis is often considered as safe as standard-course therapies (7 days). However, no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have shown this is true.

The primary objective of the present trial will be to investigate whether a very short-course (one day) of antibiotic therapy is noninferior to the commonly used standard course (7 days) in acute cholangitis after adequate biliary drainage.

Arm 1:: In the experimental group, duration of antibiotics after adequate biliary drainage will be 24 hours. The duration of antibiotics is 24 hours and will be according to the local hospital's antibiotic guideline (e.g. dosage form, dosage, frequency)and/or the national Dutch SWAB guidelines. In the experimental group treatment duration with ABT after ERCP will be 1 day.

Arm 2:: In the comparator group treatment duration with ABT after ERCP will be according to previously used known guidelines (Tokyo guidelines) and the national Dutch SWAB guidelines. This means that the type of ABT, dosage and frequency will be comparable to the experimental group. In the comparator group treatment duration will be 4 to 7 days.
Primary outcome:: clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30 (definition see in outcome measure).

Secondary outcome:: Rate of adverse drug events by day 14, rate of all-cause 90-day mortality, rate of relapse of cholangitis and other adverse drug events by day 30, rate of relapse and subsequent infections by day 90, health-related quality of life, health utility and cost-effectivess/-utility.
Control:: Active control (effective treatment of control group)

740,"2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency: A Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo Controlled, Dose Escalation Study

This randomized, double blind, placebo controlled, dose escalation study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SBI-301 in patients with 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency. SBI-301 is an oral medicine that is intended to be used in combination with coenzyme A (CoA), which is produced naturally in the human body. In patients with 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency, SBI-301 is expected to act as a new substrate for pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) in order to improve metabolic processes through enhancement of PDH activity.

Lay Summary:: 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency (2HG-D) is a mitochondrial disease that affects the production of energy by the body. This disease is caused by a genetic mutation in the 2HG-D gene. SBI-301 is an oral medication designed to improve the function of pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) by providing alternate substrates for the enzyme to catalyze. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of SBI-301 in treating 2HG-D. Eligible participants will receive SBI-301 or placebo in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-escalation trial.

This is a Phase 2a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-escalation study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SBI-301 in patients with 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency.
A Phase 2a, Multiple-Schedule, Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo Control Dose Escalation Clinical Trial of SBI-301 in Subjects With 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency

Inclusion Criteria: Participants must have signed an informed consent form approved by the Ethics Committee of the participating site Participants or their legal representative must be able to comply with all trial-related procedures as judged by the investigator. Participants must be positive for the 2HG-D gene mutation, based on the results of the genetic analysis. Participants in the screening period aged less than 18 years with a parent, guardian, or legally acceptable representative available to provide informed consent/authorization for the participant to participate and to provide assent. Participants in the screening period aged 18 years and above or their legally acceptable representative and the participant must be capable of signing an informed consent form (as applicable). A female participant is eligible to enter and participate in the trial only if she is sexually mature (assess based on Tanner stage) and at least one of the following conditions is fulfilled: Women of child-bearing potential who are not pregnant or breastfeeding, and agree to remain abstinent or use contraception (e.g., hormonal contraceptives, intrauterine device (IUD), diaphragm with spermicide or condom plus foam/cream/jelly, sexual abstinence) during the trial and for at least 8 weeks after the last dose of study drug. Participant must have a diagnosis of 2-Hydroxyglutaric Acid Dehydrogenase Deficiency based on the criteria of the United States National Institutes of Health (NIH) Neurogenetics Research Consortium. Participants willing to disclose any concomitant medications to the investigator and should be willing to record all medications taken during the course of the study in the subject's diary and in the Investigator Site File. Participant should be willing and able to attend all scheduled onsite visits in the trial. Participant must have a confirmed 2-Hydro"

743,"1.0% xylocaine solution will be used to perform a gastroduodenoscopy and to locate the pylorus. Pyloric ring will be revealed by air insufflation. The pyloric ring will be circumscribed with a hemostatic clip marker. The mucosal incision will be performed with a needle-knife endoscope. A sphincterotome introducer (the endoscope insertion tube will be changed to a sphincterotome insertion tube) will be inserted in to the mucosal flap at the opposite side of the pyloric ring, and the pyloromyotomy will be created using a sphincterotome over the wire. A longitudinal incision will be performed with the tip of the sphincterotome in a circular direction (single pyloromyotomy group) or in a longitudinal direction (double pyloromyotomy group) at 6 or 7o'clock position to expose the submucosal plane. We will inject normal saline solution with methylene blue over the wire and verify the integrity of the mucosal surface. A submucosal tunnel will be created with dissection technique from the pylorus to the duodenal bulb. The tunnel will be expanded with a sphincterotome and verified using a hemostatic forceps. Then the subepithelial tunnel will be closed by a clip-plate or a clip-clip technique. Finally, the scope will be withdrawn from the duodenum and the pylorus will be checked for integrity."
744,"1. Basic information: The total planned sample size for the study is 30, which the investigators believe is feasible to complete within the study design.

2. Study design (see diagram below): The study will be a single-arm, open-label study, with 1 group and the duration of the study was up to 4 weeks. In the study, subjects will be required to take the study product every day for a period of 4 weeks.
3. Study objectives and scope of the study: The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the yeast drink in improving hemoglobin levels.

In addition to the primary objective, the study also evaluated changes in hemoglobin levels, ferritin levels, superoxide dismutase (SOD) levels, glutathione (GSH) levels, and facial skin condition before and after treatment.
4. Main measurement indicators and endpoints: The main efficacy indicators were the following:
(1) Comparison of the serum ferritin concentration before and after medication
(2) Comparison of the hemoglobin concentration level before and after medication
(3) Comparison of the superoxide dismutase (SOD) concentration level before and after medication
(4) Comparison of the glutathione (GSH) concentration level before and after medication, measured against normal ranges.
1. Comparison of the lines/wrinkles on the face;
2. Comparison of the skin texture, including wrinkles on the back of the hand, skin moisturizing and skin elasticity;
3. Comparison of the amount of skin melanin before and after administration.
5. Efficacy and safety outcomes, and main data analysis methods: The investigators will conduct a safety evaluation while the subjects are taking the study product, which includes:
(1) recording adverse events during the period of taking the study product;
(2) conducting an overall safety evaluation based on the occurrence of adverse events;
(3) evaluating the safety of skin and gastrointestinal conditions after treatment."

There are many factors that influence the level of recovery after an acute injury to the spinal cord including age, level of injury, mechanism of injury, as well as rehabilitation interventions. A variety of rehabilitation interventions have aimed to improve functional outcomes and quality of daily life in patients with spinal cord injury. However, no single intervention has been able to significantly alter either the immediate or long-term trajectory of recovery after an acute injury to the spinal cord. Furthermore, the mechanisms (i.e., pathways) by which these interventions impact functional restoration are largely unknown. Transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation and acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH) applied in concert, may enhance sensorimotor plasticity in humans with chronic spinal cord injury. Single-day sessions of AIH and/or transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation is considered non-invasive and safe and is associated with significant improvement in cardiovascular health and endurance, skeletal muscle strength, muscle growth and functional recovery in animal models of spinal cord injury. If successful, the study findings will guide the development of a novel, non-invasive, rehabilitative intervention for individuals with chronic spinal cord injury to improve functional outcomes, quality of life, and cardiorespiratory health."

The purpose of anesthesia is to ensure patient safety as well as a good quality of intraoperative anesthesia. During the intraoperative period, maintenance of a stable physiological state of the patient is critical to avoid hemodynamic or metabolic fluctuations associated with a higher risk of complications, including cerebrovascular disease, bleeding or thrombosis, myocardial ischemia, and cardiac dysrhythmias. These fluctuations primarily depend on the effects of the drug and the patient’s individual responses to the drug. Currently, the assessment of the effects of anesthetic agents on a patient’s physiological condition is mainly based on invasive monitors such as blood pressure, ECG, and cardiac output. However, these parameters provide relatively imprecise information about what is happening to the patient’s brain during anesthesia. To improve the quality of intraoperative anesthesia, it is critical to have access to brain-specific information that can guide clinical interventions based on the patient’s individual response to anesthetic agents.

The brain is highly sensitive to the impact of environmental changes, including drug effects. A primary function of the brain is to integrate and process sensory information from multiple sources in real-time. During normal conditions, the brain is constantly receiving sensory inputs which are necessary for a variety of essential tasks such as maintaining homeostasis, initiating movements and posture, and adapting to environmental changes. Disruption in any of these functions can lead to serious health diseases. The brain is also in constant communication with the rest of the body to maintain homeostasis, which is why we often refer to the brain as the “central controller” of all bodily systems such as cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. The loss of brain activity can lead to severe hemodynamic and metabolic derangements. During severe diseases or injuries resulting in brain disruption, the brain is unable to maintain the complex homeostasis required for normal functioning and, for this reason, cerebral homeostasis is often used as a surrogate measure for overall functional outcome.

For many years, the brain is typically assessed based on the patients’ clinical outcome in the postoperative period. However, this method is inadequate because many patients with significant brain injuries during the intraoperative period may be able to mask potential neurological deficits in the perioperative period. Even though many intraoperative interventions are made to avoid neurological damage associated with the administration of drugs such as anesthetics, vasoactive drugs, or cardiovascular drugs, the intraoperative brain monitoring technique often used is still limited to observing the patient’s overall condition (e.g., neurological function, blood pressure, heart rate, etc.). Therefore, it is not surprising that an increasing number of studies have shown a significant risk of neurological complications even when the patients did not have any pre-existing neurological conditions. In particular, most stroke cases after elective cerebrovascular procedures, such as carotid endarterectomy, happen during anesthesia in 15% to over 80% of patients. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the intraoperative brain monitoring technique during anesthesia for stroke and other neurological patients.

In 2018 we have developed a revolutionary brain-specific monitoring device that can accurately measure cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism with the potential to dramatically change the approach to intraoperative monitoring. To demonstrate its feasibility and significance, we have designed a clinical research study using this novel brain-specific monitoring device (called trNIRS/DCS) to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of anesthesia management in relation to the hemodynamic and metabolic response of the brain during surgery.
Theoretical and Practical Rationale of this Study

Many patients in the United States undergo surgery under general anesthesia every year. During the intraoperative period, the patient’s physiological condition is constantly monitored to ensure that no harmful effects occur. The key parameters used to evaluate patients’ responses to anesthesia include heart rate and rhythm, the level of sedation or consciousness level, arterial pressure (for systemic assessment), respiratory rate, and body temperature. During general anesthesia, the circulatory system is at risk to develop undesirable consequences such as excessive changes in heart rate and blood pressure, excessive fluid accumulation to maintain cardiac output, or excessive loss of blood volume to provide adequate oxygen delivery to the myocard"
747,"The main objectives of RaDoCo project are:
1: To determine the prevalence of IDs in the Parisian region and their biological, phenotypic and clinical characteristics.
2: To identify the most frequent (maternal) mutations and their molecular variability in French women giving birth to children with IDs.
3: To determine the genetic and biological determinants of IDs susceptibility to MAs.
4: To identify the early-onset MAs and their relationship with IDs.

The RaDoCo (Risques d'Apparition des Detresses OCculaires, des Cancers et des Complications Métabolique et Cardio-vasculaire à proximité d'un patient atteint d'un syndrome imprimé) is an observational, cross-transversal study with a cohort (all patients with IDs) and control population (healthy subjects). Prospective and multicenter, the study will be conducted in different centers.

The RaDoCo (Risques d'Apparition des Detresses OCculaires, des Cancers et des Complications Métabolique et Cardio-vasculaire à proximité d'un patient atteint d'un syndrome imprimé) is an observational, cross-transversal study with a cohort (all patients with IDs) and control population (healthy subjects). Prospective and multicenter, the study will be conducted in different centers.

There is no pre-determined number of patients enrolled in the trial. All patients with IDs admitted to the participating centers will be enrolled in the observatory. It will be carried out over a 1-year period. Patients included in the study will give the investigators their informed consent in writing. For minors, their parents will give their informed consent.

For all the patients involved in the study, a complete medical history and clinical assessment, physical examination, and ophthalmological and echocardiographic examination will be carried out. Blood samples will include laboratory tests (blood cells count, renal function tests, liver function tests, blood metabolism, hemostasis) and hormonal dosage (thyroid, adrenal, gonads, and growth hormone and IGF1).

Blood extracellular vesicles study (microRNA, epigenetic markers), metabolomic profil (methylation, metabolites), metagenomic profil (gut microbiota), transcriptomic profil, proteomic profil, and genetic study will be performed on the blood sample of the study participants. Blood samples will be stored after extraction of nucleic acids (DNA, RNA, microRNA) at -80° C.

All patients included in RaDoCo observatory will benefit from the necessary and conventional care in the treatment of their disease and the prevention of late complications. The patients will be followed according to the standard rules of the local hospitals and the patient can contact them for care after enrollment in the study.
Participation in the study will not influence the therapeutic decisions of the caregiver, who will be independent of the ID clinical investigation. There is no risk for the volunteer.
No harm is expected from this work given the non-interventional nature of the trial.
Data collection, processing and data analysis:

Data is stored on the servers of the CNRS of ENS. After the end of the study, data will be accessible only to the Principal Investigators and members of the study team who have signed the specific confidentiality agreement provided by the CNRS before having access to the data.
Data from the trial will be analysed by a joint working group of the members of the RaDoCo consortium. Patient data will be stored for a period of at least 10 years, to enable long-term follow-up"

This is an observational multicenter study aiming to evaluate whether unipolar interlocking results in faster consolidation than bipolar interlocking in patients with humeral shaft fracture requiring intramedullary nailing. The hypothesis is that there will be a statistically significant difference in the proportion of patients achieving radiologically assessed complete consolidation at 12 months between unipolar and bipolar interlocking. Since this is an observational trial with no intervention from the research personnel, the investigator has decided to investigate the following primary outcome measure: The proportion of patients with radiologically assessed complete solid callus and cortical apposition as recorded by CT scan at 12 months after injury. Since the investigator aim to compare two groups of patients, unipolar and bipolar interlocking, respectively, this study also includes secondary outcomes and is therefore a cluster randomized trial. The aim of these outcomes is to identify differences from a functional, subjective and complications perspective. For all secondary outcomes, the investigator does not have an explicit hypothesis on an effect between the two treatment arms. However, the investigator hypothesize that there are some benefits in the bipolar system, including faster bone healing.

Humeral shaft fracture is the second or third most common fracture in adults following the forearm, depending on the incidences of hand fractures and wrist fractures. It is a common injury in people 65 years of age or above and are known to be under reported. The cost of these types of fractures is in the range of the 10 most expensive fractures and is substantial. It is further reported that these injuries will probably become more frequent due to changes in the average age of humans. One of the most common treatments of humeral shaft fractures is intramedullary nailing. Unipolar and bipolar interlocking systems have been used clinically in the intramedullary nail fixation for several decades, and more recent studies have compared the stability and radiological healing with these nailing systems. To date, there have been no studies investigating bone healing when comparing the two nailing systems. The investigator have therefore designed a study to evaluate bone healing in unipolar and bipolar interlocking intramedullary nailing fixation.

This is an observational multicenter study aiming to evaluate whether unipolar interlocking results in faster consolidation than bipolar interlocking in patients with humeral shaft fracture requiring intramedullary nailing. The hypothesis is that there will be a statistically significant difference in the proportion of patients achieving radiologically assessed complete consolidation at 12 months between unipolar and bipolar interlocking. Since this is an observational trial with no intervention from the research personnel, the investigator has decided to investigate the following primary outcome measure: The proportion of patients with radiologically assessed complete solid callus and cortical apposition as recorded by CT scan at 12 months after injury.

Since the investigator aim to compare two groups of patients, unipolar and bipolar interlocking, respectively, this study also includes secondary outcomes and is therefore a cluster randomized trial. The aim of these outcomes is to identify differences from a functional, subjective and complications perspective. For all secondary outcomes, the investigator does not have an explicit hypothesis on an effect between the two treatment arms. However, the investigator hypothesize that there are some benefits in the bipolar system, including faster bone healing.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed complete consolidation at 12 months. Complete consolidation will be defined as stable solid callus with complete cortical apposition as recorded by X-ray. Consolidation will be assessed by CT scan at M6, and patients who do not have a consolidated fracture by CT will be assigned a second scan at M9 or M12, depending on the clinical status and progress of consolidation.

The secondary outcomes are: (a) Range of motion (active flexion and extension) (range -105-0 degrees) assessed by a goniometer at M9, and then again at M12 if consolidation is not obtained in all patients at M6.
(b) Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) questionnaire at M9 and then if necessary at M12. .

Early psychosis interventions have improved but cognitive deficits remain a core impairment, and motivation is often impaired. Interventions that target both will likely be better able to address core factors in psychosis that may be responsible for the poor prognosis and treatment response that many see. While effective cognitive training exists, it has not been tested in the EPP cohort. This is a multi-site, randomized controlled trial to compare an extended course of cognitive training plus a behavioral intervention (PRIME) vs. treatment as usual (TAU) for young people with schizophrenia-spectrum disorders in an early phase of treatment. The outcomes of this study will be broadly disseminated and will impact how early psychosis intervention programs evolve as we learn more about treatment approaches that optimize and extend gains seen in early intervention."

750,"1. Background and rationale Aims The aims of this study are to see if the use of heartrate trackers when prescribing moderate intensity aerobic exercise using a heart rate zone to patients undergoing pre-operative exercise and rehabilitation improves physical activity levels compared to patients prescribed the same programme but who are required to self-monitor their exercise intensity based on a rating of perceived exertion (RPE). Exercises prescribed using Heart rate zones are intended to provide a more accurate measurement of exercise intensity than RPE whilst maintaining the overall convenience. The use of heartrate trackers in pre-operative rehabilitation may enable patients to complete more moderate intensity exercise before their procedure, which has previously been demonstrated to be beneficial in terms of improving outcomes. It may also enable home-based exercise programmes, which are shown to be more accessible to patients and are a more cost-effective way of delivering pre-operative exercise programmes. If the intervention is successful, this may have the potential to improve patient care by enabling more patients to meet minimal levels of aerobic exercise recommended before surgery, reducing unnecessary hospital visits and providing an additional way for health care professionals to monitor patient safety and compliance. Hypothesis The use of heartrate trackers when prescribing moderate intensity aerobic exercise using a heart rate zone to patients undergoing pre-operative exercise and rehabilitation improves physical activity levels in comparison to patients prescribed moderate intensity aerobic exercise using a heart rate zone but not using heartrate trackers. Ethics This research has been approved by the NRES committee West Midlands - Black Country (Ref: 21/WM/0055) Study design and approach This is a prospective study utilising a 1:1 Randomised Controlled Trial (RCT) design. Random allocation sequence Patients referred for prehabilitation will be offered recruitment and participation in the study. If interested a member of the prehabilitation team or the principal investigator (PI), who will be responsible for screening suitability, will provide further information as well as a copy of the patient information sheet (PIS) and consent form. If consent is received a unique study number will be generated and all subsequent data will become associated with this number. All patients enrolled into the study will then be sent both a heart rate tracker (Fitbit Charge 4) and a blood pressure monitor (Withings), free of charge. Once the patients' fitness tracker has been assigned to them and they have paired it with their smartphone they will be invited to attend one more meeting with a member of the research team at which they will be introduced to the study app and the prehabilitation programme. The assigned device will be tested to ensure it is working. They will be provided with a demonstration of the app, shown how to download and use it and asked to set up their account with the app. Once the patient has completed this, they will be randomly assigned to Group A or Group B through a random number generation via a secure spreadsheet created within the Microsoft Office suite of programmes. All subsequent data will become associated with their assigned group. Intervention and measurements The Fitbit Charge 4 (Fitbit, Inc) which will be provided to each participant will be used to continuously record heart rate and steps taken. Participants' heart rate data (beats/minute) will be transferred from their wearable fitness tracker to a central database via the Fitbit app (Fitbit Inc). Step count will be displayed on each patient's Fitbit and will not be recorded on a central database. Data on both variables will be compared between groups. The Withings Blood Pressure Monitor (WIFI BP Monitor, Withings) will also be provided to enable patients in both groups to monitor their blood pressure, which will be used to assist patients making decisions about their exercise programme.

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
No Intervention: Group A - Exercise to Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) - Control Group
Participants prescribed moderate intensity aerobic exercise using their rating of perceived exertion (RPE) with a goal of sustaining an intensity level of 12 to 14 for their prescribed duration.

Experimental: Group B - Exercise to a Heart Rate (HR) Zone - Intervention Group
Participants prescribed moderate intensity aerobic exercise using personalised heartrate zones with a goal of sustaining an intensity level by maintaining their heartrate above 5"

column1: 751,"In a population of 2,000 young Dutch males, 1 in 60 develops pilonidal sinus disease (PSD) within their lifetime, half of whom is younger than 30 years and a quarter younger than 20 years. PSD does not improve without surgical treatment. Conventional surgical techniques provide good results, but are associated with significant morbidity, especially in young and obese patients with poor wound healing capacity, who are at risk of developing infective complications. In addition, the extensive and poorly planned incisions may result in permanent visible scarring, which may have a detrimental psychosocial effect on the young patients. It was recently shown that minimally invasive pit-picking surgery (PP), in which the pits are extracted and an 'inconspicuous' wound closure technique is used, has good results with a relatively low complication rate. However, a substantial proportion of patients develop recurrent disease later in their lives. Although PP was initially thought to have no residual pits and thus lower recurrence rates than traditional wide surgical excisions, this is not the case as microscopy analysis showed that pits are frequently left behind during the procedure. To improve the results of this minimally invasive treatment, we hypothesize that pits and sinuses may be closed by applying a radial diode laser probe before wound closure, which will leave a 'flat' scar, and which may lower recurrence rates.

The primary objective of this study is to assess whether PSD laser-assisted treatment [SiLaC®] improves the healing rate at 1 year's follow-up, compared to pit-picking therapy alone. A total sample size of 144 subjects (72 per group) is needed to detect a significant 25% benefit of treatment with laser (80% power and a two-sided alpha of 0.05).

The protocol described below is compliant with the requirements for a national quality register (Netherlands Medical Register Act) and is approved by the Medical Research Ethics Committee (METC) of the Netherlands. Approval for this protocol was obtained from the METC (NL57760.029.16) on 25 July 2016.
PSD, Pilonidal Sinus, Pilonidal Disease, Pilonidal Sinus of Natal Cleft, Pilonidal Disease of Natal Cleft
* Procedure: Pit-picking surgery with Sinus Laser assisted Closure

Inclusion Criteria: All patients aged 12 years and older who present with primary pilonidal sinus disease; Type 1b and 3 of the Dutch staging system (11), see Figure 1 Obtained written informed consent by the patient and/or legal representative/parent Sufficient understanding of the Dutch written language (reading and writing) Exclusion Criteria: Asymptomatic (Type 1a), recurrent (Type 4; except those patients who only have had drainage of their abscess and no other surgical treatment), or chronic wounds (hypergranulating) after PSD surgery (Type 5) of the Dutch staging system Patients with known underlying or concomitant medical conditions that may interfere with normal wound healing (e.g. systemic skin and connective tissue diseases, any kind of congenital defect of metabolism including insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, Cushing syndrome or disease, scurvy, chronic hypothyroidism, congenital or acquired immunosuppressive condition, chronic renal failure, or chronic hepatic dysfunction (Child-Pugh class B or C), severe malnutrition, or other concomitant illness which, in the opinion of the investigator, has the potential to significantly delay wound healing) Severe drug abuse (and therefore protocol deviation can be expected) Patients expected not to comply with the study protocol (including patients with severe cognitive dysfunction/impairment and severe psychiatric disorders) Patients with insufficient knowledge of the Dutch written language who are thus unable to answer the questionnaires Patients that are unable or not willing to give full informed consent

753,"1. The immune checkpoint inhibitors durvalumab and tremelimumab are known to produce durable anti-tumor effect in combination with radiation therapy against different cancer types, thus the combination may have abscopal effect in treating HCC. 2. The investigators hypothesize that the combination regimen may produce abscopal effect in treating metastatic, unresectable HCC. The goal is to establish a robust evidence that immune checkpoint inhibitors with radioembolisation is effective in treating metastatic HCC, which may be a useful treatment option in the future. The study will last for about 3 years (1 year of recruitment, 2 year of treatment, 2 years of follow-up)."

column2: The number of study participants in which treatment with IBI302 will be reported as feasible.
column3: Feasibility is defined as percentage of patients (n=12) in which the participant can be treated, meaning: 1. Drug can be safely administered, 2. Participants tolerate the study drug, and 3. The tumor can be safely biopsied or has to be surgically removed, according to the protocol. Feasibility will be graded as: 1. Not feasible, 2. Feasible, and 3. Probable feasible. Not feasible will describe a situation when all of the criteria are not met. Probable feasible will refer to a situation when 1 or 2 criteria are met. Feasibility will be analyzed only in the monotherapy arm.

column2: The number of study participants presenting dose limiting toxicity.
column3: A dose limiting toxicity (DLT) is defined as any event assessed as related to treatment and which meets one of the following criteria: 1. Any grade 3 or higher non-hematological toxicity, with the exception of fatigue and hair loss, OR 2. Any grade 4 (life-threatening) non-hematological toxicity, excluding nausea and vomiting, OR 3. Any febrile neutropenia (ANC ≤ 1000/mm3 for ≥ two consecutive measurements in the absence of documented infection) lasting > 7 days, OR 4. Any hematological toxicity grade 4 with WBC < 1000/mm3 and platelet count < 50,000/mm3 that will continue > 14 days on therapy despite rescue medications or > 28 days and requiring rescue medications, OR 5. Any other grade 3 or greater toxicity that is considered unacceptable at the dose level in question and is not related to a previously defined non-hematological toxicity.

column1: Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida

The extremity artery is the peripheral blood vessel of the whole body, and it is often involved early in the diseases that are easy to damage the small vessels, such as atherosclerosis and connective tissue diseases. Early lower limb atherosclerosis mainly occurs in the dorsal foot artery, which is commonly seen in people with diabetes and long-term smoking. Connective tissue diseases such as systemic sclerosis and systemic lupus erythematosus also mainly involve small blood vessels, and vascular lesions may appear earlier than those of other specific organs such as heart and lung. Because of its shallow location, the extremity artery can be better used as a screening site for vascular diseases, and it is the window for early reaction of vascular diseases.

However, the early stage of extremity artery disease is easy to be ignored, and patients often have pain and numbness of the affected limb. When the disease is severe, it can lead to ulcer not healing, and even limb gangrene and amputation, which greatly affects the quality of life and brings huge troubles and economic pressure to the patients. Therefore, early diagnosis of extremity arterial lesions is of great significance for early diagnosis of microvascular injury diseases such as atherosclerosis and connective tissue diseases, reducing the incidence of complications, and reducing the rate of amputation and mortality. Ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging technique widely used in clinic. In recent years, with the development of ultrasound technology, the frequency of ultrasonic probes has been increasing. Because of its higher resolution, high-frequency ultrasound can clearly display the superficial vascular structure and blood flow, detect vascular lesions early, and accurately quantify the degree of stenosis, providing a new and beneficial tool for clinical observation of the structure and blood flow of the extremities. The purpose of this multi-center clinical study was to establish the normal value of high frequency ultrasound for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults, and to explore its influencing factors, so as to provide a quantitative reference for the early diagnosis, degree evaluation and curative effect observation of the structure and blood flow of the extremities.
1.2 Clinical value or problem to be solved by the technology

Extremity artery is an important peripheral blood vessel of the human body, which has an important role in maintaining blood flow and supply to the lower limbs. The disease of extremity artery is often characterized by the phenomenon of decreased or decreased blood flow and blood supply to the extremities, and then the extremities are caused by necrosis and bleeding in severe conditions, which may lead to the aggravation of the disease and cause serious harm to the human body. Therefore, it is necessary to observe the blood flow and blood supply situation of the extremities as soon as possible in the initial stage of extremity artery symptoms, so as to judge the condition of the disease, so as to timely take measures to give early medical treatment according to the disease condition, and avoid causing serious harm to the human body through a series of complications caused by the disease.

756,"This study evaluates the clinical and microbiological effects of STERIFY GEL in combination with SRP, in a parallel, split-mouth, randomized, controlled clinical study with two sequential sites of periodontitis. The study is designed to test the non-inferiority hypothesis that STERIFY GEL is able to control bacterial populations with efficacy at least 50% greater than SRP alone.

The main objective of the study is to determine the effectiveness of STERIFY GEL associated with SRP compared to SRP alone in the treatment of grade III and IV chronic periodontitis on the depth of periodontal pockets.
Clinical and bacterial evaluations (by means of qPCR) will be conducted at baseline, after one month, and 3 months."

758,"64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans in patients with suspected or confirmed cardiac sarcoidosis and acute lymphocytic myocarditis will be compared to 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans in patients with neuroendocrine tumors without prior history of inflammatory heart disease. Additionally, the number of patients with adverse outcomes will be compared between patients with cardiac sarcoidosis and acute lymphocytic myocarditis."

759,"1. Aim: The aim of this study is to determine whether the probiotics regimen could reduce the incidence of Immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea (immune rejection of kidney), in participants with renal transplantation. A pre-post design will be used to study any significant changes in inflammatory markers, microbiota, and diarrhea frequency. This study will also compare the changes with the control group. 2. Methods/Design: The researchers will enroll 90 eligible subjects (a total of 180 subjects, to account for drop-outs) who will be allocated randomly into Probiotics Group or Placebo Group. Both groups will be treated and followed by the same treatment protocol. The subjects who received the probiotics treatment will receive one capsule per-day and those who received the placebo capsule will receive one capsule per-day for six months. All the measurements will be collected both pre and post within six months in order to detect the difference. 3. Expected Outcome: The researchers will be able to determine whether the probiotics regimen could reduce the incidence of Immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea and if it can also affect the gut microbiome or inflammatory markers. If the treatment is successful, this research will have the potential to help reduce the incidence of post-surgical diarrhea and its associated complications in renal transplant patients.
Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida
immunosuppression, probiotics, gut microbiome, fecal microbiome, immunosuppressive drug-associated diarrhea"

760,"28-day PaO2/FiO2 ratio > 300 and a LIPS equal to, or greater than, 4 (Appendix D)105. At enrollment, the investigators will perform a randomization with allocation in a 1:1 ratio (using block of 4 for randomization) and the patient will be assigned either to the intervention group (inhaled sedation with sevoflurane) or the control group (intravenous sedation). This assignment will remain non-informative for the patient, the patient's family, attending nurses, and attending intensivists. The investigators will collect the following data: LIPS, duration of ICU stay and duration of assisted breathing, number of ventilator-free days, ICU mortality, development of acute kidney injury, occurrence of supra-ventricular tachycardia, occurrence of air leak syndrome, occurrence of nosocomial events (such as nosocomial pneumonia or central-line related bloodstream infection) on the day the patient is switched to pressure-support ventilation if within 5 days since randomization, occurrence of delirium, length of ICU stay (with the number of patients transferred out of the ICU and the duration of each ICU transfer out) and length of hospital stay. LIPS, Lung Injury Score, consists of 5 items designed to assess whether the ICU patient has one or more risk factors for developing acute lung injury or the ARDS (Appendix D). In this trial, the investigators will determine if the early inhaled use of sevoflurane in ARDS patients could have beneficial effects on clinical outcomes such as PaO2/FiO2 ratio and prevention of the occurrence of ARDS."

761,"60 patients with massive rotator cuff tendon tear and secondary symptoms will be followed for two years. It is determined intra-operatively whether the tear is reparable or not. If possible, the tendon(s) will be anatomically repaired. For irreparable tears intra-operative urn randomization takes place - either partial repair or partial repair with SCR using the LHBBT. The operative and follow-up protocol will be the same for each of the three groups. Goutallier classification (1994) will be used pre- and post-operatively to measure muscle fatty infiltration. MRI study will be performed to evaluate tendon healing pre- and post-operatively. At 6-month, 12-month, and 24-month timepoints, pre-operative radiography will be repeated in order to measure: AHI (acromio-humeral index), CSA (critical shoulder angle), acromion type and shoulder arthrosis (Hamada). Clinically important variables to be assessed are shoulder functional status, pain score, quality of life, kinesiophobia score and emotional well-being score. Functional status will be assessed by scoring according to Constant–Murley scale, American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons score and Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand score. The study aims for patients with massive rotator cuff tear to have lower risk of developing shoulder instability and glenohumeral arthrosis than the general population of patients with massive rotator cuff tear (who decline to undergo surgery) and to evaluate effectiveness of different surgical treatments."

762,"Background: Persons who inject drugs (PWID) have increased rates of death and hospitalization compared to those who do not inject drugs. PWID experience high rates of stigma and discrimination in healthcare settings, which contribute to a fear of judgment and poor continuity of care. Poor access to healthcare can lead to delayed and incomplete treatment for injection-related infections and adverse health outcomes, including death. The Injection-related InfectiousS (IRIS) Program is a community/practice-based program that promotes early diagnosis and treatment of injection-related infections (IRIs). The program includes a streamlined injection-related infection diagnosis and treatment protocol and provides additional supports to promote successful treatment outcomes and ongoing infection prevention education. The goal of the IRIS Program is to optimize treatment of people who inject drugs who experienced injection-related infections.
We will conduct a cohort study of individuals treated with the intervention and a matched group of individuals who received standard care and their health outcomes will be compared.

Objectives: The primary aim of this study is to assess outcomes of individuals who received IRIS treatment. Secondary outcomes will include, but not limited to, assessments of individual participants for changes in the following:
Eligibility: Study participants will be adult PWID (16+). Participants who have been discharged from hospital with one or more IRI diagnosis will be eligible for program enrolment.

Intervention: Individuals will be provided with a one-stop, low-barrier combined care model to address their injection-related infections. Specific program components will include: (1) Diagnosis and treatment of injection-related infections; (2) Substance use treatment (3) Peer support; and (4) Care coordination/systems navigation.

Study Design: This is a cohort design where outcomes will be compared to a matched control group who did not receive the IRIS intervention. A sample size of at least 350 patients with a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection in each group will be calculated, allowing for a 10% loss to follow-up rate.
Sample Size: We aim to recruit 700 participants in two years. We anticipate that the IRIS Program will have a reach of at least 35% (>250).

Study Duration and Data Collection: Participants will be enrolled in the IRIS Program over a two-year period. Data (de-identified) will be collected immediately before participation, at discharge from IRIS after three months, and after six months, 12 months, and 18 months. Data will be collected using standardized assessments, and clinical data will be retrieved from Electronic Medical Records.

Outcome measures: The primary outcome of this study will be the proportion of individuals with at least one emergency department visit or hospital readmission within 90 days of IRIS enrolment. Secondary outcomes will include the rate of program drop-out and reasons for discontinuation, the number of new initiations or record of continuation of substance use treatment, and mortality rates.

Conclusions: This project will be the largest integrated infectious disease/substance use disorder intervention in Canada, and we will study the effectiveness of this approach to optimize care to people who inject drugs."

763,"1. Rationale: This project will enable a rigorous comparison of two distinct modes of survey delivery (mobile app based vs. web-based) and assess the usability, preferred method, and overall experience when reporting AEs following immunization. This information will help to inform future development of both modes of communication, including the development of a standalone vaccine event notification app (not part of this study) 2. Aims and Objectives of the project: Influenza is a significant public health threat, a disease that causes an estimated 3 million to 5 million severe illnesses worldwide and up to 650,000 respiratory deaths due to seasonal influenza infection each year. Vaccination remains the best strategy for reducing seasonal influenza illness in the general population. In Canada, the influenza vaccine is distributed free of charge through mass immunization campaigns and the healthcare system. Despite a comprehensive vaccine distribution and delivery program, less than 50% of Canadian adults receive an annual influenza vaccination. This poor adherence is likely due to a number of factors including vaccine efficacy, perceptions on who needs to be vaccinated, fears pertaining to the potential side effects, and vaccine safety. Immunization registries and vaccine reporting tools are an important piece in the public health response to enhance vaccine confidence by allowing for increased reporting of adverse events following immunization (AEFI's). This has the potential of improving understanding of the overall safety profile of influenza vaccine through early detectable safety signals. 3. Objectives: The objectives from this project will include: i) A user-friendly version of the original online questionnaire adapted to a mobile app-based platform capable of performing longitudinal cohort surveillance on vaccine safety; ii) A comparison of the mobile app-based survey platform compared to a web-based platform with respect to user acceptability and usability; and iii) Comparisons of users recruited in the mobile app-based survey versus the web-based survey regarding the reporting of potential influenza vaccine adverse events. 4. Methods: This project is a mixed-methods, randomized control trial that will compare the use of a mobile app platform compared to a web-based platform. 5. Primary Researcher: TBD"

column3: Measure Description

The scale developed by Spielberger et al. aims to measure state and trait anxiety levels separately.The scores obtained from the scale vary between 20-80, and the total score between 20-39 indicates mild anxiety, between 40-59 indicates moderate anxiety, and between 60-79 indicates severe anxiety.

The scale, which was developed by Kolcaba in 2006 and has a total of 28 questions as 'Refreshing (9 items), Relaxation (9 items) and Overcoming Problems (10 items), consists of three sub-dimensions.The lowest value that can be taken is 1, which indicates low comfort, and the highest value, 6, indicates high comfort.
It is aimed to determine the level of pain.0 means no pain and 10 means maximum pain

766,"Achalasia is a motor disorder of the esophagus and usually occurs under the age of 50. As a result of a malfunctioning of the esophageal sphincter due to damage of the esophageal musculature and nerves, there is severe difficulty in swallowing. Per-oral endoscopy myotomy is a minimally invasive procedure to cut the esophageal sphincter and open the outlet of the esophagus.
Our study evaluates the risk of hemodynamic fluctuation in patients who underwent PEM under general anesthesia according to the presence of dysautonomia.

767,"Çocuklarda derhal alım işlemi gerceklestirirken VR inme gözlük kullanılır mı?

The prevalence of bronchiolitis in the United States, Australia, and Europe has risen to 750-1300 admissions per 10,000 children to under 5 years. In our country, 40.000 outpatients and 20.000 patients are hospitalized annually in bronchiolitis. Since bronchiolitis is the most common cause of hospitalization for children under the age of 2, it affects the workload in emergency departments and pediatric departments. Bronchiolitis is an infection of the bronchioles and is usually caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). In our study, we determined that 35% of the children diagnosed with bronchiolitis in our hospital were exposed to screen in the last month and that the duration of their screening session was 4.5 hours. It was reported that 48% of children under the age of two spent more than two hours a day in front of the screen. The same study in our country showed that the average daily screen time was more than two hours in 13-36 months old infants. This study shows that excessive screen exposure will affect the age group of bronchiolitis as a result of the increase in children's screen exposure in our country. For this reason, when bronchiolitis is diagnosed in our hospital, screen exposure is prevented in the family with the awareness of the parents, and the treatment is carried out with the help of toys, books, and music. However, inhaler treatment still causes discomfort and anxiety in children, and VR glasses can be an alternative to distract children and make them feel distracted during treatment. For this reason, we planned to compare the effectiveness of VR glasses in children during inhaler treatment.

Children who meet the selection criteria in our hospital are included in the study, the group in which the child will be included in the study is determined randomly, and the treatment is performed and the treatment results are evaluated. The main purpose in our study is to prevent screen exposure, which is 1.25-2.25 hours per day, during inhaler treatment in our country. However, it is expected that VR glasses will act as a distraction method during inhaler treatment. The aim of this study is to test the effectiveness of VR glasses during inhaler treatment in children and to determine whether VR glasses can help prevent stress and anxiety during inhaler treatment. The method used for the evaluation of the effectiveness of VR glasses during inhaler treatment in our study was to compare the children who did not use VR glasses during inhaler treatment with the children who used VR glasses during their treatment. VR glasses are not limited to a fixed method and are not expected to have any side effects as long as they are used in the specified age range and mode. There has been no study in the literature on the use of VR glasses in children during inhaler treatment, and the possibility of VR glasses negatively affecting children is very small. However, due to the high cost of VR glasses, no study has been found in the literature that investigates the use of VR glasses during inhaler treatment in children. During the study period (November 2022 - April 2023), 913 children received inhaler treatment in our hospital. Children who did not meet the inclusion criteria (such as chronic disease or severe bronchiolitis) and were not suitable for their age (such as under 2 years old, over 5 years old) were excluded from the study. Of the 224 children who met the inclusion criteria, 89 were excluded because they refused to participate in the study. The children to be included in the study were determined by a single researcher. The first investigator identified the children who met the inclusion criteria, noted the FLACC and MYPAS score, as well as the RR, SpO2, and HR values, and referred the child to the other investigator. The second investigator divided the child into his group using the randomization method, and determined the duration of crying and effective treatment, along with the duration of treatment, with a double chronometer during treatment. At the end of the treatment, the family and the child were re-directed to the first researcher on the condition that they did not tell the first researcher which group they were in. Thus, it was ensured that the first investigator did not know which group the child"

768,"280 children and adolescents, aged between 6 and 20 years are expected to suffer from a psychiatric disorder in Sweden as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic (Gullberg et al., 2022). Children and adolescents with psychiatric disorders can experience emotional and behavioral problems at home and in school, and this can complicate their learning development, social functioning and well-being in the long term (Jarvholt et al., 2000; Kjellgren et al., 2018; Rydelius et al., 2000). A number of studies point to the importance of early intervention. However, early identification is difficult and in many cases there is a long waiting time for care (Ratcliffe, 2014). It has also been shown that the need for care has decreased since the pandemic began (The National Board of Health and Welfare, 2020, 2020b). The reason for this is that the children have instead been cared for in a variety of ways. These support programs can be group or individual interventions that help children develop coping strategies and adapt to new situations. This way of working can be seen as preventive work and prevent the development of mental illnesses such as anxiety and depression and thus reduce the risk of future psychiatric problems. This proposal aims to evaluate the possibility of developing and structuring support groups, which then help to solve emotional and behavioral problems among students with difficulties. The support programs will be offered in the fifth grade, and the students in these groups will also participate in the evaluation. The evaluation will provide answers to questions about the content, organizational design and process of the support program, as well as what consequences the program brings for the students, their families and school personnel. The purpose is to create an evidence-based intervention model which can prevent psychiatric disorders in the long term. The project is based on the needs in society and the experiences of the students. The project is run by the Södertälje municipality in collaboration with the university. In addition to the students, a number of teachers, school managers and school representatives are involved in the project. The research team will help to evaluate and develop the intervention. The project will start in the autumn and run until the end of the school year. One support group, including 15 children, will be recruited. The purpose is that all students who are in danger of developing anxiety and depression problems or other emotional or behavioral problems will be able to participate in such a group. The support groups will consist of 10 sessions with a time span of approximately 1 h per week. The group sessions will be followed by a series of 5 individual meetings with a school psychologist or a school counsellor. These meetings are intended to help the students in need with the problems they experience. During the meetings, the students should be encouraged to talk about their experiences and feelings, and to develop coping strategies. If more individual meetings are needed, arrangements will be made with the school psychologist or school counsellor. The support groups will be evaluated using questionnaires, interviews and observations. The aim is to gain a deeper understanding of how the support groups affect the students' well-being, behavior and learning development, and to identify any problems that may occur during the intervention. The results of the evaluation will be presented to the school staff and will be used as the basis for a future redevelopment of support groups for students in this population and age group. The evaluation will also contribute to an increased understanding of how to prevent anxiety and depression problems among students. The work is expected to take about six months, starting in the autumn and ending in the spring. This is, of course, a pilot study, but it is hoped that it will provide a good starting point for developing and organizing such support groups in the future. The results of the study will also be important for creating preventive support programs for children with disabilities and emotional and behavioral problems. Key questions are: Which students are in need of support? What does support look like? How is support organized? What are the consequences of support? The data will be analyzed using SPSS and will lead to practical recommendations for the implementation of support programs in schools. The overall goal is to identify problems at an early stage and to support the students in a preventive and holistic way. The hypothesis is that this will prevent the development of mental illnesses such as anxiety and depression in the long term. The proposed study has great potential for generating new knowledge and improving the way support programs are organized in schools. In the short term, this is expected to lead to better academic outcomes and reduced emotional and behavioral problems among students in the fifth grade. In the long term, it is hoped that this will also help to prevent the development of anxiety and depression problems in the future. Therefore,"

769,"10-20 neonates who require surfactant therapy through Less-Invasive-Surfactant-Administration (LISA) will be prospectively enrolled in the PALISA study. At the same time a total of 80 LISA treatment will be performed at our hospital. Thus, LISA treatment per week is expected to be 5. Preterm infants are a vulnerable patient population, the most vulnerable being infants, who are born more than two months prematurely. The symptoms of pain are difficult to assess. However pain management is part of the routine care of preterm infants. In our institution, we use the standard pain scale, as approved by the German Society for Neonatology (Fachärztekammer für Neonatologie). However, in view of the limitations of the pain scale, video-recordings and Skin Conductance (SC) monitoring are gaining interest. SC monitoring measures the conductance of the skin, which is regulated by the sympathetic nervous system. A baseline sympathetic activity can be considered as a sign for adaptation and stress tolerance. Therefore, we hope to identify significant changes in the sympathetic nervous system by using the SC measurement in a large cohort of preterm infants. The aim is to identify SC patterns that correlate with various stress factors during the LISA procedure and during intubation. A correlation could then be used as a biomarker for identifying infants who are highly stressed during these procedures."

770,"24 months - Baseline: assessment of eligibility and informed consent; assessment of depression, depressive suicide risk, stigma, health conditions, sociodemographic data and socio-cultural resources . Monthly trial visits (or contacts through a telephone number) throughout the first 2 months; delivery of intervention at 1-month post randomisation or earlier based on clinical concerns about suicide risk or poor adherence to medication. Participants who withdraw from the intervention can choose to continue receiving routine mental healthcare at the study site. After month 2: monthly trial visits (or contacts through the telephone number) throughout the second 2 months to monitor symptoms and evaluate study outcome measures; End of Trial: trial visit at 4-months post randomisation."

Knee ligament tear is one of the most common sports injuries and 61% of people who ruptured their ACL eventually have an ACL reconstruction surgery. The ACL is comprised of mainly collagen and glycoproteins and is considered vital for knee stability. Thus a complete rupture results in a decrease of stability and joint pain as well as an increased risk of osteoarthritis.

The conventional treatment is to replace the ruptured ACL by an artificially-generated tendon graft, most frequently taken from the hamstrings (i.e. semitendinosus and gracilis tendon). An essential criterion for a good outcome after ACL reconstruction surgery is the strength of incorporation between the graft and bones. In particular, the tibial graft integration is crucial because the tibial bone tunnel often presents with a larger diameter than the femoral bone tunnel.
If the bone tunnels are not stable, there is a risk of widening, resulting in decreasing graft integration.

Bone tunnel widening (BTW) can occur after both primary and revision ACL surgery. A BTW was observed in about 15% of patients in the first 6 months after surgery. A study with a follow-up of 10–12 years showed a stable BTW over time with BTW measurements decreasing from 21% to 1.7% after 10–12 years. In addition to the negative effect for graft integration it has been shown that an increased BTW is a reliable predictor of decreasing knee function over time. In addition, patients with BTW showed a significantly increased risk of revision ACL surgery; one study showed that 30% of patients who underwent ACL revision surgery presented with widening of >3mm and another study showed that for 22.4% of patients widening of >4mm was evident.
Several factors have been identified to influence bone tunnel widening, e.g. the amount of bone tunnel preparation, tunnel geometry, sex, age and bone mineral density.

In the present project, we will investigate whether an insertion of bone/platelet-rich-plasma (PrP) composite at the bone tunnel entry points in order to prevent or at least minimize bone tunnel widening will increase graft maturity and integration, as well as knee function, within the first two post-operative years.

Previous studies have shown a superior effect of platelet-rich-plasma (PrP) on tendon healing and the present project aims to investigate the clinical and biological effectiveness of the combination of osteoinductive bone matrix in a PrP composition for the prevention of bone tunnel widening after ACL reconstruction. Preclinical studies have shown a positive effect of platelet-rich-plasma (PrP) on tendon healing.

To evaluate less tibial tunnel widening when a bone/PrP-composite is applied directly in the tibial tunnel compared to the same surgery without using the composite, measured with CT and MRI, as well as  the ability of adding a PrP/Bone-Matix to a current ACL reconstruction protocol to enhance bone tunnel healing and integration.

To evaluate less femoral tunnel widening, femoral graft integration, graft maturity and knee function when a bone/PrP-composite is applied directly in the tibial tunnel compared to the same surgery without using the composite, as well as  the ability of adding a PrP/Bone-Matix to a current ACL reconstruction protocol to enhance bone tunnel healing and integration as well as knee function.

The hypothesis that motivates the project, is that augmenting the area between the bone tunnel and the graft with osteoinductive bone matrix in a composition with autologous PRP will increase the number of stem cells with osteogenic capacity available in this area, to increase graft integration, graft maturity and improve knee function.
A 1:1 randomised controlled non-blinded superiority study (see section 5), in two parallel cohorts of 53 patients per cohort, each will undergo MRI and CT in the year after surgery.
The study has been approved by Ethics Committee Northwest and SWISSMEDIC. The study is conducted according to the ICH-GCP principles.

1. Rapid sequence induction (RSI) is a popular practice in anesthetic management in children and infants.

2. RSI is a technique of inducing general anesthesia without pre-oxygenation, usually by rapid intravenous administration of an induction agent followed by rapid intubation and the use of a muscle relaxant. This technique is used in emergency situations and in the presence of a full stomach.

3. Adequate oxygenation during tracheal intubation  is critical to ensure the well-being of the patient. Intubation results in apnea, which combined with anesthesia-induced hypermetabolism can lead to dangerous arterial oxygen desaturation (SpO2) (50%) and hypoxaemia (PaO2 < 60 mmHg) that can cause life-threatening brain damage and cardiovascular deterioration. Therefore, the ASA guidelines  recommend preoxygenating pediatric patients with a high fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) for at least 3 minutes at 100% oxygen prior to anesthesia induction in order to avoid SpO2 declines during the procedure.
RATIONALE FOR HIGH FLOW NASAL CANNULA (HFNC)
High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) provides high-flow humidified oxygen.
1. HFNC was first described for neonatal respiratory failure in Australia in 2004.
2. In the literature review, we found only a few randomized controlled trials about the use of high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) in pediatric  patients during rapid sequence induction (RSI).
3. Routine use of non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV) and high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is still uncertain and recommendations are lacking.
1. The aim of the trial is to investigate the use of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) in pediatric patients during rapid sequence induction (RSI).
2. The aim of the trial is to investigate the use of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) in pediatric patients during rapid sequence induction (RSI) comparing to standard face-mask preoxygenation.
1. To evaluate whether the use of HFNC and standard face-mask preoxygenation differs in regard to arterial oxygen desaturation during preoxygenation and anesthesia induction.

2. To explore whether the use of HFNC and face-mask preoxygenation differs in regard to anesthesia induction and intubation success rates, the incidence of complications and the incidence of difficult intubation.
1. Do the use of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) differs in regard to arterial oxygen desaturation during preoxygenation and anesthesia induction comparing to standard face-mask preoxygenation?

2. Do the use of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) + standard face-mask preoxygenation differs in regard to anesthesia induction and intubation success rates, the incidence of complications and the incidence of difficult intubation comparing to standard face-mask preoxygenation only or HFNC only?

The use of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) in pediatric patients during rapid sequence induction (RSI) does not differ in regard to arterial oxygen desaturation, anesthesia induction and intubation success rates, the incidence of complications and the incidence of difficult intubation as compared to standard face-mask preoxygenation.

To evaluate the long-term safety and tolerability of a combined treatment of pozelimab (R396), an anti-CD59a monoclonal antibody, and cemdisiran, an antisense oligonucleotide targeting C3, in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) patients with high or residual risk (C3d+) on a stable dose of eculizumab

OUTLINE: This is an open-label, multi-center, extension study. Patients who complete the parent study (NCT03818643) may continue or restart treatment with pozelimab combined with cemdisiran up to 10 years.

Patients will receive pozelimab intravenously (IV) over 30 minutes on days 1 and 15. Patients will also receive cemdisiran IV over 15 minutes on day 1. Treatments will repeat every 28 days for up to 72 cycles in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Cycles 29, 57, and 73 repeat at 48 days.

Pozelimab, a humanized monoclonal antibody (mAb), specifically depletes antibody-sensitized CD59a-deficient cells such as PNH erythrocytes, granulocytes, and platelets from the blood. Cemdisiran, an antisense oligonucleotide (ASO), binds to messenger RNA (mRNA) of C3 and inhibits production of C3 complement proteins.
After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up for up to 30 days.

An Open-Label, Multi-center Protocol, to Further Access to the Combination of Pozelimab and Cemdisiran in Adult Patients With Severe or Moderate Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), With C3d+, Including Patients Who Did Not Complete 36 Weeks in the R396-419-201 Study

Inclusion Criteria: Patients who completed the R396-419-201 study or are eligible to participate in the R396-419-201 study and have signed the new consent form are encouraged to participate in this open-label extension study. Eligible subjects must have: Received all study required assessments per R396-419-201 protocol Completed 36 weeks of treatment with pozelimab + cemdisiran + eculizumab and have received all infusions of pozelimab + cemdisiran + eculizumab for at least 28 weeks during their participation in R396-419-201 Must have at least 1 of the following at Week 34 of the R396-419-201 study (week 15 of the open-label extension): Positive C5 inhibitor (C5i) assay Negative C5i Negative ADAMTS13 activity LDH must be within normal limits Must have 1 of the following at Week 68 of the R396-419-201 study (week 33 of the open-label extension): A normalized C5i assay; C3d positive Assessed as having been treated for at least 32 weeks Exclusion Criteria: A major organ is not functioning adequately. Subjects with liver disease with elevated AST or ALT, not meeting protocol-defined clinical eligibility criteria (ie, > 5 x upper limit of normal [ULN] for age and sex) at Week 34 are excluded. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. Chronic kidney disease with eGFR < 60ml/min/1.73m2 Unstable coronary artery disease Unstable angina pectoris Myocardial infarction < 6 months Active infection with HIV or HBV A major adverse cardiovascular"
