775,"1.5 million women conceive every year in Europe. Pregnancy is a unique and critical time both for women and their unborn child. During pregnancy hormone changes that lead to the physical changes to the body and the mental challenges to the mind happen. Exercise, depression and sleep quality were selected as primary outcomes of interest in this study. 1.5 million women conceive every year in Europe. Pregnancy is a unique and critical time both for women and their unborn child. During pregnancy hormone changes that lead to the physical changes to the body and the mental challenges to the mind happen. Exercise, depression and sleep quality were selected as primary outcomes of interest in this study. Objective: The objective of this study is to assess the effect of aerobic and pilates exercises as a treatment strategy in depression and sleep quality management in primigravida females. Study design: This is a double blinded randomised control trial study which aimed to assess the effect of aerobic and pilates exercises on sleep quality and depression in primigravida female, This study will be conducted in  Children Hospital Sheikhupura and Mehmooda Hospital Sheikhupura. In this study two groups would be formed by using simple random sampling (lottery method). All participants will be required to provide written informed consent before participating in the study. The study will consist of total 42 primigravida female aged between 18 to 35 years enrolled. The first will receive aerobic exercise and other will receive Pilates exercise. Inclusion criteria:- Primigravida females between 18 to 35 years old. Minimum gestational age of 26weeks and maximum gestational age of 33weeks. First pregnancy (primigravida) Single pregnancy  Women without previous miscarriages history. Women with gestational diabetes and pregnancy induced hypertension will not be included. Women having previous surgical procedure to correct uterine abnormalities Women who has placenta previa, antepartum hemorrhage and preterm labor would not be enrolled. Randomization: The randomization will be done by using computer generated random number lists. Data collection: After getting informed consent from all participants, data would be collected. Outcome measures Questionnaires: Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression (CES-D) scale, which will be used to measure depression level. This 20 item questionnaire is used to assess major depressive episodes with high specificity with the use of a standard cut off score of 16 or more to distinguish between depressed and non depressed subjects. Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI) is a self-rated questionnaire developed in 1989 by Buysse, Reynolds, Monk, Berman, and Kupfer. This tool consists of seven areas including: subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, sleep efficiency (the percentage of sleeping time during the time in bed), sleep disturbances (nighttime waking), use of sleeping medications, and daytime dysfunction (distress and impaired daytime functioning). Scoring of answers was based on a scale of 0 to 3 (total score of 21). Higher scores indicate poorer sleep quality. The validity of this questionnaire has been supported by its correlation with other polysomnographic measures of sleep quality. The use of sleeping medication was excluded while answering these questionnaires to provide more valid information. Intervention group: will receive aerobic exercise. 16 sessions will conducted in a 8 weeks period (2 sessions per week). This exercise will be guided through a physiotherapist who will explain all the exercises in detail to participants. All participants will be trained to keep the same pace. Intervention group: will receive pilates exercises. This group will also receive 16 sessions within 8 weeks. This exercise will be conducted by a physiotherapist/ instructor who will be fully trained. The exercises will be held over 8 weeks period (2 sessions per week). Both group will attend 2 sessions per week, and data will be collected before the first session and after 8^{th} session. Statistical analysis: Data will be analyzed by using SPSS (version 25) and Stata (version 15) will be used for statistical analysis. Data would be analyzed in descriptive and inferential statistics. The descriptive statistics of frequency, percentage, mean and standard deviation will be analyzed. In addition, the inferential statistics such as independent t test, paired t test and one way analysis of variance (ANOVA) would also be applied in addition to the other appropriate tests to analyze the data."

776,"Objective: This study aimed to evaluate whether swaddling, inhaling mother's breast milk odour and applying a combination of both reduce the infants' pain and comfort levels during the insertion of peripheral intravenous catheter.
Study Design: This experimental study was conducted on the 1st of October 2021 after obtaining the approval of the local ethics committee (protocol number: 21-01-04).
Setting: This was a single-centre study conducted at Karadeniz Ereğli State Hospital, Neonatal Intensive Care Unit.

Materials and Methods: The study was conducted to investigate the effect of swaddling and inhaling mother's breast milk odour on the pain and comfort of newborn infants during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter. The infants were included in the study voluntarily and their guardians signed the informed consent form after being given the required information about the study. The sample size was calculated as 120, while the randomization numbers were provided by statistical assistance office. A total of 150 patients, who met the inclusion criteria and whose parents were willing to participate in the study, were enrolled initially. As a result, 30 infants, not fitting the experimental design by statistical analysis, were excluded, and a total of 120 infants remained in the study. Each infants were assigned a code number from 1-30 to protect the information. During the catheterization of peripheral intravenous catheter, the infants in the 1st experimental group (swaddled) were swaddled, the infants in the 2nd experimental group (inhaling mother's breast milk odour) were made to inhale the mother's breast milk odour, the infants in the 3rd experimental group (a Both swaddled and made to inhale mother's breast milk odor) were both swaddled and made to inhale mother's breast milk odour, and the infants in the control group were not subjected to any intervention. Infant Descriptive Information Form, Neonatal Infant Pain Scale and Newborn Comfort Behavior Scale were used to collect data."

777,"The aim of the present study was to demonstrate the efficacy of medication therapy, psychotherapy, and a combination of medication therapy with psychotherapy, specifically utilizing IPT in patients with depression. Simultaneously, the investigators will conduct comprehensive fNIRS assessments on all patients to evaluate changes in their brain function and determine the level of effectiveness of psychotherapy. The investigators will also employ standardized psychological assessments to evaluate patients, allowing for a comparison of the effectiveness of fNIRS assessments and providing clarity on the efficacy of psychotherapy in patients with depression, as the investigatorsll as the differential efficacy of different treatment approaches, and establishing the biological markers of psychotherapy. Additionally, the investigators will collect blood samples, cranial magnetic resonance images, and electroencephalograms from patients before and after treatment, which will contribute to further exploration of treatment mechanisms in the future."

778,"111In-Panitumumab is approved for use in radioembolization for liver cancer with no currently approved use in imaging for evaluation of other solid tumors. The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and effectiveness 111In-Panitumumab will be used as an imaging drug for sentinel lymph node (SLN) detection prior to neck dissection.
BiospecimenCollection & Archiving:: Not collect nor Archive
1. Male or female patients who have been diagnosed with localized invasive prostate cancer (confirmed by histological analysis);
2. Age: 18 to 90 years (inclusive) at the time of study inclusion;
3. Patients with any risk group for prostate cancer: risk group 1 or risk group 2 according to the Dutch guidelines(1) ;
4. Patients for whom surgery (a radical prostatectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection) is advised in the context of curative treatment;
5. Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status ≤ 1;
7. Ability of the subject to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent.

1. Any known hypersensitivity to monoclonal antibodies or to any excipients in the product. Patients with anaphylactic reaction to one or more amino acid constituents of monoclonal antibodies are not excluded;
2. Any previous or concomitant malignancy (other than basal or squamous cell skin cancer or in-situ cervical cancer that has been definitively treated);

3. Patients with known brain metastases or a psychiatric illness/social situation and/or any other medical condition (including alcohol or drug abuse) that, in the opinion of the investigator, would interfere with the ability of the patient to participate in and complete this study;
4. Patients with renal impairment or a creatinine clearance of < 60mL/min (defined using the Cockcroft Gault equation);
5. Patients with a history of interstitial pneumonitis or pulmonary fibrosis;
6. Patients with a history or presence of clinically significantly abnormal respiratory tests including pulmonary function tests;

7. Patients with an unstable angina, myocardial infarction (MI), congestive heart failure (CHF), uncontrolled arrhythmias, prolonged QT (> 480 milliseconds [msec]) or other cardiac illnesses according to the investigator’s assessment;
8. Patients with severe renal disease or anuria;
9. Patients who are pregnant or breastfeeding;

10. Patients who are treated with a strong organic base-transporting (OCT) inhibitor such as ketoconazole, itraconazole, ritonavir, telithromycin and other drugs that are strong inhibitors of OCT (e.g., saquinavir, nelfinavir, erythromycin);
11. Patients who are treated with any non-prescription medication, vitamin or herbal supplement that may interfere with the evaluation of study drug.
12. Patients with a known deficiency in dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD).
13. Patients with a history of hepatic impairment or evidence of serious liver injury or cirrhosis;
14. Patients who have participated in the study that is being performed immediately before this study."

779,"The 8-channel transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulator is composed of two groups of stimulation electrodes, with an internal connection of 8 independent channels. The electrodes are separated at a distance of 3 mm. The stimulus generator has a 3.5-inch TFT LCD touch screen with a memory of up to five sets of treatment parameters. The device uses wireless transmission technology, using a wireless Bluetooth-enabled charging station or a 4-m long magnetic docking board. The 8-channel transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulator stimulates the vagus nerve bundles directly through the neck skin using safe and effective low frequency electrical stimulation.
2. Diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-IV) diagnostic criteria;
4. The total score of the Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) was >= 14;
6. Sign and date the Informed Consent Form, indicating a clear understanding of all parts of the Informed Consent Form.
1. Patients with acute psychosis or severe mental impairment;
2. Severe neurological diseases such as cerebral vascular accident, cerebral hemorrhage, Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, etc.;
3. Patients with severe cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, including hypertension, coronary heart disease, atrial fibrillation, etc.;
5. Currently diagnosed or participated in vagus nerve stimulation therapy;
6. Currently participating in transcranial magnetic stimulation or transcranial direct current therapy;

7. Patients with known electrode allergy, or patients with skin ulcers in the treatment region, allergies to any components of the stimulator or electrode, or skin conditions that are contraindicated for ECT."

780,"This study is a prospective study. All the patients were diagnosed as NLDO, including postacute dacryocystitis, chronic dacryocystitis, and primary NLDO, had recurrent or persistent and symptomatic epiphora. The primary outcome was the cumulative success rate of DLDI within 2 years follow-up. The secondary outcome measures include incidence of postoperative complications, quality of life score, recurrence status, and subjective symptoms. The results showed that cumulative success rates at 12 months, 18 months and 24 months were 57.5, 74.3 and 89.8%, respectively. The recurrence rates of DLDI within 2 years, and at the longest time of follow-up at 23.1 and 21.1 months were 18.3%, respectively. Subjective symptoms of epiphora and tearing were improved in DLDI patients after treatment, regardless of stent removal 6 months after DLDI."
Immediate Effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation With Lower Leg Kinesiotaping on Ankle Dorsiflexion, Gait and Functional Mobility in Patients With Chronic Stroke
Study population (sample size): 35 Participants (15 in each group) will be included in the study.
Study setting (hospital/institution): Stroke patients are included from neurology department.
Diagnosed with hemiplegia due to hemorrhagic or ischemic stroke for more than 6 months.
Able to walk independently for over 10 m without assistive device.
Ability to comprehend simple instructions (Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score above 24.
Insufficient ankle dorsiflexion during the swing phase of the gait cycle and less than 8 degree of ankle dorsiflexion range of motion on the affected side during gait.
2. Spasticity with a Modified Ashworth Scale score of 3 or more.
3. Musculoskeletal pain and other acute injury that interfere with the study measures.
Duration of treatment: 1 session per day.

Treatment procedure: To assess if the immediate effects of lower leg kinesiotaping and lower leg kinesiotaping with proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation on ankle dorsiflexion, gait and functional mobility is better than proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation alone in patients with chronic stroke.

Study tools: To assess if the immediate effects of lower leg kinesiotaping and lower leg kinesiotaping with proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation on ankle dorsiflexion, gait and functional mobility is better than proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation alone in patients with chronic stroke. The following tests will be used for data collection:

Time up and go test: To determine fall risk and measure the progress of balance, sit to stand and walking. Subjects are asked to rise from a standard armchair, walk to a marker 3 m away, turn, walk back, and sit down again.The test is a reliable and valid test for quantifying functional mobility. Scores of ten seconds or less indicate normal mobility, 11-20 seconds are within normal limits for frail elderly and disabled patients, and greater than 20 seconds means the person needs assistance outside and indicates further examination and intervention.

2. Barthel Index: The Barthel Scale/Index (BI) is an ordinal scale used to measure performance in activities of daily living (ADL). Ten variables describing ADL and mobility are scored, a higher number being a reflection of greater ability to function independently.Total score of 100 with proposed guidelines for interpreting Barthel scores are that scores of 0-20 indicate total dependency, 21-60 indicate severe dependency, 61-90 indicate moderate dependency, and 91-99 indicates slight dependency.

3. Motor Assessment scale: The Motor Assessment Scale (MAS) is a performance-based scale used to assess level of impairment and everyday motor function in patients with stroke. The 9 items assessment evaluates 5 Mobility and 3 Upper Limb activities, and 1 the severity of involuntary movements UMN lesions (clonus). Each of the items is scored on a 7 point hierarchical difficulty scale. A score of 0 indicates the individual is unable to complete any of the tasks within a category. A score of 6 implies the individual is not only able to perform the most difficult task, but also all lower scored tasks.
4. Dynamic gait index: The DGI assesses individual's ability to modify balance while walking in the presence of external demands. • The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) was developed"

782,"2 or 3 times a week, an individual semi-directive explanatory interview of 30 to 60 minutes is conducted at the center with a team of healthcare professionals (nurses, specialized nurses and physicians) who have not participated in the co-construction of the algorithm. A second judgment grid is completed at the end of phase 2 to allow the collection of the judgment criteria (excluding the patient feelings) related to the implementation of the A-DIVA Score alone. The interviews are audio-recorded, transcribed and analyzed using qualitative analysis software (QSR NVivo). The analysis will be conducted by researcher from the Care team and the investigator/study manager to triangulate our results. A description of the professionals' characteristics, their perception of the current situation and their expectations and their potential willingness to change will be provided to the intercenter working group. The objective is to provide the context of care to facilitate the co-construction of the algorithm in this working group. The collection of data related to the isolated implementation of the A-DIVA Scale: This will provide the data for evaluating the impact of the implementation of the A-DIVA Scale alone (versus no score / phase 1) on practitioners 'approaches compared to phase 1. Each operator filling out the judgment criteria after vascular puncture will fill in the A-DIVA Score. In addition, at the end of each catheter placement care, the operator may add comments, such as: a) difficulties encountered by the operator in managing the patient's pain (aesthetics), nausea, anxiety or fear about the catheter, e.g. (patient refused to receive the catheter, too scared to be able to receive it, too scared, but accepting it, too scared to be able to be treated); b) difficulties encountered by the operator in performing the catheterization with the type of catheter used, a) difficulties encountered by the operator in performing the catheterization with the techniques used (insertion techniques), e.g. (needed to use other techniques, the first attempt not successful, used other techniques or changed its type to continue the insertion); c) difficulties encountered by the operator in selecting the type of catheter used, e.g. (no catheter of the necessary format (french, double lumen)) was accessible on site, no catheter of the necessary format (french or double lumen) was accessible on site). The data will be collected and analyzed by analyzing the judgment criteria collected after each catheterization and by analyzing qualitatively the data (using NVivo qualitative analysis software) collected at the end of each catheterization on the feeling of the operator and the feeling of the patient. The main objective is to recognize the potential appearance of changes in practitioners' practices through the implementation of a score for evaluating DIVA (compared to the initial practices clarified in phase 1). A satisfaction questionnaire will be proposed to professionals to measure their experience related to the implementation of the A-DIVA Scale (use of the A-DIVA Score score in isolation) and if applicable, its evaluation (e.g., feasibility, acceptability). The data collection for phase 2 will end when there are a minimum of 80 vascular punctures per center (except one center with 40). At the beginning of phase 3, the data collected during phase 2 will be analyzed to determine whether there are changes (or not) in the practices related to the peripheral venous catheter care strategy of the centers after implementing the A-DIVA Score. This preliminary analysis will be done in order to complete the data collection in phase 2, to clarify the data related to the implementation of a specific tool in the context of peripheral venous catheter care (here to the implementation of the A-DIVA Score). Moreover the working group will review the data collected in phase 1 and phase 2 to guide the reflection leading to the development of the algorithm. Phase 3: evaluation of the algorithm: As phase 2, the data collection for phase 3 will be analyzed at the individual level. Intervention at the individual level: Patients will benefit from specific treatment according to local policy for each center (taking into account the needs of each patient). These are the patients for whom an operator uses the algorithm. Systematic collection of the A-DIVA Scale with identification of the patient's risk group, systematic rating of pain and evaluation of overall comfort. • In terms of vascular punctures, two data sheets will be completed: a) A numerical data sheet for each intervention (each time an operator uses the algorithm) will collect the following data from each operator: number of patients for whom the algorithm is applied, number of attempts to place"

The purpose of this study is to evaluate safety, efficacy and patency of the new shunt graft, known as the STARgraft-3, when compared with the traditional AVG grafts used for hemodialysis. The STARgraft-3 graft is designed to improve function and longevity of hemodialysis access sites, thus offering greater patient flexibility in terms of use and reducing the number of invasive procedures performed on access sites. The graft is designed to maintain high blood flow levels, and to enable the access sites to be used more frequently without the development of severe narrowing in the arms' blood vessels."

784,"114 patients were included in the study with 92 patients starting treatment randomly allocated to either POET or supportive treatment, and 22 patients withdrawing from treatment. A majority of patients (79%) did not have any anxiety diagnosis prior to treatment, and 96% of patients did not have any anxiety diagnosis at start of treatment. 35% of patients had a diagnosis of ADHD, and 50% of patients had a diagnosis of emotional problems or disorder. In total, 60% of patients had a single diagnosis while 40% of patients had two or more co-occurring disorders. More than half of the parents, i.e., 54% reported that their child had been exposed to one or more stressful life events prior to treatment. 75% of patients in the POET group and 60% in the supportive treatment group were in favor to continue treatment, and 96% of patients in both conditions reported that the treatment was in some extent helpful. Patients in the POET group reported the treatment to be more helpful compared to patients in the supportive treatment group (r = 0.42; 52% vs. 35%; p < 0.01). Patients on average was 15.99 years old, and 67.3% were females, 43% reported having a diagnosed mental health problem while 87% of the parents reported that their child had been exposed to one or more stressful life events prior to treatment. 74% of patients had not sought any previous treatment for their mental health problem, the average number of years with a mental health problem was 1.82 years, and 66% of patients had previously experienced a suicide attempt. Patients in the POET group reported the treatment to be more helpful compared to patients in the supportive treatment group (r = 0.26; 53% vs. 34%; p < 0.05). Both interventions showed significant improvements on the CGI-S, C-GAS and WSAS after treatment. All pre-specified secondary outcomes was significantly improved at post-treatment in the POET group, while 4 of the 7 pre-specified secondary outcomes was significantly improved at post-treatment in the supportive treatment group. Two pre-specified secondary outcomes in both conditions was significantly improved at a 3 months follow-up and 12 months follow-up, while 3 pre-specified secondary outcomes in POET and 2 pre-specified secondary outcomes in supportive treatment was not significantly improved at these follow-up time points.

Overall, the primary objective of the study is to establish a treatment program that reduces the severity and distress caused by mental health problems in adolescents. Specifically, the overall hypothesis is that the POET (Primary Care Online Emotions Regulation Treatment) treatment program improves mental health problems more than a comparable control condition of supportive treatment, and that this improvement is mediated by better emotion regulation skills. This will be examined in a randomized controlled trial (RCT). Within the POET group, the hypothesis is that improvements in emotional distress will be related with improvements in emotion regulation. Within the supportive treatment group, it is hypothesized that the active components, i.e., attention and empathy from the therapist, promote self-reflection and behavioral changes that in turn promote reductions in mental health problem (primary outcome) and improvements in other secondary outcomes. The secondary objectives will examine the efficacy of the POET treatment program both within and between the conditions in relation to change in measures of emotion regulation and secondary symptoms. Other specific aims are to examine the moderating impact of several individual demographic characteristics and the feasibility of offering the POET treatment program in Primary Health Care (PHC). Additionally, an economic evaluation will be conducted to provide information on the costs and benefits of the intervention (see details under subheading A.3.1 ). Thus, the general aim of this trial is to: Establish if POET will yield a greater reduction in mental health problems compared to a similar control condition of supportive treatment. Establish the factors that explain the change in mental health problems and how these factors change during the intervention. Examine if the intervention affects several secondary outcomes of emotional and behavioral functioning. Examine the impact of the intervention on costs, and on distal outcomes at 30, 120 and 360 days follow-up. Explore if adolescents and their parents prefer the intervention to supportive treatment. Examine if the intervention is acceptable and feasible to implement by caregivers in PHC."
785,The objective of this study is to assess the comparative efficacy of two modalities of Radiotherapy over surgery alone on local tumor control in older patientswith NMSG3.

786,"The goal of this protocol is to examine the influence of age related decline on the ability of the small intestine to absorb nutrients during intraduodenal feeding.  We will test the hypothesis that with increasing age, small intestinal (SI) motility is impaired and small intestinal nutrient transport efficiency is reduced.  The aim of this protocol is to assess SI nutrient transport efficiency in response to intraduodenal, pH-controlled feeding during enteral nutrition.  This research will directly assess if SI epithelial-mediated absorption of key nutrients (carbohydrate, lipid, and amino acid) is altered with aging.  Aging will also directly affect SI nutrient absorption through SI motility.  The central hypothesis tested in this study is that with aging, SI nutrient absorption efficiency is reduced by reduced mucosal proliferation, an age-related change in SI motility, and increased duodenal pH.  By testing this overarching hypothesis, we will establish if age-related change in SI mucosal proliferation, SI motility, and alkaline duodenal pH results in malabsorption of essential gut nutrients and provide quantitative measures of the clinical impact on health and function.

Intervention Description:: 14 test subjects will be recruited to participate in the study.  Each subject will undergo baseline SI measurements and blood tests.  Subjects will be randomized to one of two study arms with 7 subjects in each arm.  The first study group will be fed by intraduodenal feeding (IDF) at 100 mL per hour.  The second study group will be fed by intrajejunal feeding (IJF) at 100 mL per hour. Subjects will be fed a 100 mL enteral nutrition (EN, Peptamen® 1.5%) solution with glucose measured at 100, 150, 200, and 250 minutes.
Arm Description:: Test subjects will be randomized to the IJF or IDF experiment in a 1:1 ratio.  The test group will undergo intraduodenal or intrajejunal feeding at 100 milliliter per hour.

Description:: Inclusion criteria to include all eligible age ranges are as follows: The subject is between 18 and 89 years of age.  Subject has no underlying medical conditions to include gastrointestinal disease, kidney disease, or significant heart and lung disease.  Subject has agreed to the experimental procedures and is willing to participate in the study. The subject is able to provide informed consent.
1. Any subject with a history of medical disease that would significantly affect either SI function or their ability to tolerate intraduodenal and/or intrajejunal feeding.
2. Subjects who are unable to provide informed consent.
3. Subjects with gastrointestinal disease (e.g. inflammatory bowel, gastroparesis).

1. Outcome Measures: The change in SI proliferation and small intestinal motility in response to intraduodenal and intrajejunal feeding during enteral feeding. Outcome Measure: Change in luminal transport in response to intraduodenal and intrajejunal feeding in the duodenal mucosa during enteral nutrition. Outcome Measure: Change in duodenal pH in response to intraduodenal and intrajejunal feeding.

1. Outcome Measures: The response of SI luminal nutrient transport in response to intraduodenal and intrajejunal feeding during enteral feeding. Outcome Measures: The change in duodenal transit and motility in response to intraduodenal and intraje"

787,"70.% of adult heart surgery patients present with elevated serum levels of troponin. In this study, the investigators will examine if it is possible to predict the response of a troponin-elevating patient with an easy and low-cost diagnostic test. A total of 30 subjects will be included in the study with each individual donating a saliva sample, three blood samples, and one urine sample. All samples will be analysed for circulating tumour cells using the CellSearch® System. The presence of tumour cells in a blood or urine sample has been shown to present with a good diagnostic value for several different types of cancer. The investigators believe that if they can show that these cells respond differently than the rest of the cells during a heart surgery procedure, we may be able to identify a mechanism of troponin elevation that may help guide a more targeted approach to the diagnostic work-up for these patients.

Intervention Description:: Single-arm, open-label study. Patients who meet the inclusion criteria will receive doxorubicin hydrochloride as primary systemic treatment for refractory angina due to CAD. Doxorubicin (15 mg/M2) will be administered intravenously (IV) over 30 minutes in combination with the antianginal agents diltiazem and atenolol. Doxorubicin will be dosed at 15 mg/M2 q. w/w for three doses at an interval of two weeks.

Arm Description:: The aim of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a new treatment for women suffering from breast cancer. The treatment combines exercise, lifestyle changes, and education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the first phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete an 8-week exercise program. The program will consist of two classes per week, each lasting 1 hour. The classes will focus on aerobic exercise, strength training, and flexibility. Participants will also be asked to complete daily home exercises. In the second phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. The program will focus on improving participants' diet, sleep habits, and stress management. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the third phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete an 8-week exercise program with two classes per week, each lasting 1 hour. Participants will also be asked to complete daily home exercises. In the fourth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. The program will focus on improving participants' diet, sleep habits, and stress management. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the fifth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the sixth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the seventh phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the eighth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the ninth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the tenth phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment. In the eleventh phase of the study, participants will be asked to complete a 4-week lifestyle change program. Participants will also be given education about breast cancer and its treatment.
Arm Label:: Doxorubicin hydrochloride and atenolol as primary systemic treatment for refractory angina due to coronary artery disease

788,"Sloane Project is a breast cancer screening programme for women aged 40-49 years. The 10-year cumulative frequency of non-invasive breast disease (i.e. ductal carcinoma in situ, and atypical hyperplasia of the ductal and lobular epithelium of the breast) has been estimated. The Project has been designed to be highly efficient for detecting these diseases, at a lower cost/benefit ratio than the current guidelines for mammographic screening in this age group. In the Sloane Project, digital MLO mammography, followed by ultrasound and a breast MRI where needed, is used as primary modality for detection of non-invasive breast disease.

This study will use the unique Sloane database to analyze the genetic determinants underlying breast development and morphology as well as the molecular and genetic bases for the evolution and progression of non-invasive breast disease."
789,"24-month open label study to investigate the safety and efficacy of tirzepatide in type 1 diabetes patients.
Tirzepatide is an investigational drug at this time.

Currently there is no pharmaceutical therapies approved for the treatment of obesity in people living with type 1 diabetes. Insulin resistance is a feature of T1D and is associated with obesity, hyperglycaemia, hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, renal impairment and an overall increased risk of macrovascular and microvascular complications. This study will investigate the use of tirzepatide in individuals with T1D and obesity to determine the impact of this medication on metabolic parameters and overall body weight.
A Multi-centre, Double-blind, Randomised, Parallel Group Phase 2a Study of the Concurrent Treatment of Obesity and Type One Diabetes Mellitus With Tirzepatide in Adults

Inclusion Criteria: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (clinical diagnosis within < 12 months) Insulin treatment for ≥3 months to achieve glycaemic control HbA1c ≤ 10% Body Mass Index (BMI) ≥ 30kg/m2 Ability to independently inject subcutaneous tissue with a NovoPen 6 or similar insulin delivery device Capable of performing finger prick glucose measurements and is willing to share them in a phone app or provide written consent to share device data for the study duration Capable and willing to self-inject tirzepatide once per week (with a pen device) Informed written consent by themselves or by a legally authorised representative, obtained and documented prior to study-specific screening procedure. Able and willing to use Easy Diet Diary (available as both a smart phone or web-based application) is available from Ghent University and registered participants receive automatic access, or willing to keep an exercise log (manually completed at home) Willing to allow access to real-time continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) data if already using real-time CGM at study entry. Exclusion Criteria: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (clinical diagnosis > 12 months) Non-insulin-dependent Type 1 Diabetes Obesity that is induced by other endocrine disorders Pregnancy History of chronic or acute pancreatitis, uncontrolled hypertension, acute cardiovascular condition within 3 months Known gastric emptying abnormality History of severe hypo- or hyperglycaemia History of diabetes-related complication requiring acute treatment (such as diabetic ketoacidosis, stroke, congestive heart failure class III or IV) History of malignancy requiring chemotherapy, surgery or radiation (within 5 years of trial period)

column1: 790,"With the widespread administration of cancer chemotherapy, the side effect profile of each drug has become increasingly important to the oncologist. Paclitaxel is used frequently in the treatment of breast cancer and ovarian cancer. Nerve pain, neuropathy, is a well-described and serious side effect of this drug. Our goal is to evaluate the efficacy of an oral medication, Losartan, that has been shown in previous animal and human studies to prevent the onset and attenuate nerve damage caused by Paclitaxel. Losartan belongs to a class of medications called angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). These medications are used to lower blood pressure, in part by a direct effect on nerves."

791,"2 months after enrollment, MCI patients were randomly assigned to the experimental group for 6 months of intervention. Intervention group-Ginkgo Ketone Ester Tablets combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment group, the treatment was Ginkgo Ketone Ester Tablets (Styron), taken orally, 3 times a day, 0.5g each time. The control group was the control group, which was treated with conventional hypoglycemic agents. Duration of intervention: 6 months (2 months pre-examination, 4 months examination after intervention). Cognitive evaluation was conducted in the experimental group two months after intervention.

DNA was extracted from 200 μl of peripheral blood and stored at -80 ℃ for use. Real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) was used to detect the mRNA expression levels of 17 candidate genes related to cognitive impairment. Differences in changes in mRNA expression levels between the experimental group and the control group after intervention were statistically analyzed."

794,"The purpose of this study is to understand long-term safety and efficacy of the investigational product MPC-06-ID in combination with standard-of-care therapy versus standard-of-care therapy alone in patients with myelofibrosis.

Inclusion Criteria: Voluntary written informed consent of the patient or authorized representative prior to any study specific procedures Patients should, as a minimum, be able to comply with the patient treatment contract for the duration of the study Able to comply with all study requirements, including clinical assessments, study medication administration, sample collection, and patient treatment monitoring ECOG performance status 0 to2. Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status is a tool used in clinical research to evaluate a patient's self-reported overall health status on a spectrum from normal (0) to severely ill (4). Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent document Adequate hematologic function defined as ANC > 1.0 K/mcl, platelets ≥ 50 K/mcl, hemoglobin ≥ 9g/dL (may be treated with erythropoiesis stimulating agents [ESAs] to achieve this level) Adequate hepatic function defined as: total bilirubin ≤ 1.5 times upper limit of normal, AST(SGOT)/ALT(SGPT) ≤ 2.5 times upper limit of normal, unless liver involvement by progressive myelofibrosis (MF) is suspected, and AST(SGOT)/ALT(SGPT) ≤ 5 times upper limit of normal Adequate renal function defined as creatine ≤ 1.5 times upper limit of normal, unless creatinine clearance can be accurately measured by the institution, in which case calculated creatinine clearance must be ≥ 30 mL/ min Able to swallow and retain oral medication Male or female patient of reproductive age must agree to use adequate contraception (hormonal or barrier method of birth control; abstinence) prior to study entry, for the duration of study participation, and for 3 months after completion of study therapy. Should a woman become pregnant or suspect she is pregnant while she or her partner is participating in this study, she should inform her treating physician immediately Women of child-bearing potential (WOCBP), defined as all women physiologically capable of becoming pregnant, must have a negative serum pregnancy test result within 14 days prior to receiving the first dose of study drug Able to stop use of aspirin, salicylate, or anticoagulants/ antiplatelet agents (such as warfarin, hepain, dabigatran, apixaban, clopidogrel bisulfate, ticlopidine hydrochloride, clonidine, dipyridamole, cilostazol, tirofiban, prasugrel) for the duration of the study, unless it is not recommended that the patient stop due to significant history of thromboembolic events or other reasons. If the patient is currently using any antiplatelet/ anticoagulant agent, at least 7 days must lapse since discontinuation of treatment, and the patient must have a normal PT/INR level prior to start of therapy on study Exclusion Criteria: Active clinically significant infections within 30 days prior to registration, or with ongoing use of antibiotics Patient who in the opinion of the investigator is an unsuitable candidate for this trial because of other concomitant serious medical or psychiatric condition(s) which would impair participation Pregnant (or lactating) women or women of child-bearing age who are unwilling or unable to use effective birth control methods Concurrent treatment with another investigational drug within 30 days prior to registration Active hepatitis B (HBV), hepatitis C (HCV), or human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) based on patient history Presence of cardiovascular abnormalities, including uncontrolled arrhythmias, unstable angina, symptomatic congestive heart failure (NYHA III or IV), severe valve disease, myocardial infarction within 6 weeks prior to registration, or transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) within 3 months prior to registration Ongoing graft versus host disease (GVHD) Known hypersensitivity to MPC-06-ID or any ingredient of the formulation Active second malignancy or prior treatment with radiotherapy or chemotherapy to the bones within 4"
795,"The main objectives this research will be the following:
• To obtain vector population sizes (Adult mosquito collected to estimate vector density and Anopheles infection prevalence using ELISA).
• To measure the entomological inoculation rate (EIR) i.e. the number of sporozoite-infected Anopheles per person per night.
• To evaluate the efficacy of the two next-generation LLINs to reduce pyrethroid insecticides, human landings catches and sporozoite salivary glands.

The primary objective of the NTI Cote d'Ivoire study is to compare the entomological inoculation rate (EIR) and case incidence between the experimental arms and the reference arm. It is expected that this 12-month study will enable a good assessment for the two experimental LLINs, with one of them found to be superior on both entomological and parasitological outcomes. The main outcomes (EIR and case incidence) will be measured every two months.
Net Transition Initiative : Evaluation of Two Next-Generation LLINs for Their Efficacy Compared to Standard Pyrethroid Nets to Reduce Malaria Transmission and Incidence in Côte-d-Ivoire
Malaria, Human infection by vector transmission

Inclusion Criteria: Villages identified for the study will be selected based on malaria transmission intensity, the local population size estimated by the local health authorities and the proportion of insecticide resistance expected to be high in both the main malaria vectors, Anopheles coluzzii and An. gambiae. The participating villages will be spread across all 5 zones of the Bas-Sassandra region, divided over 5 districts, to achieve a good spatial representation. The study population will consist of people of all ages. Data relating to adults aged >18 years will be collected for the study, but we do not plan any age-specific analysis. This will include malaria case incidence prevalence, entomological inoculation rate and vector densities. We will also conduct age and gender specific analyses for the 5 to 10 year old age group. Exclusion Criteria: Villages which are unable to agree to participate in the study (i.e. those which have elected not to participate in the study activities). People who are not willing to be enrolled in the study, particularly the households participating in the cohort, entomological and serological surveys.

column1: 796,"3 fractions of Prostate SBRT (Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy) is an advanced form of radiotherapy (similar to a CT scan) using the world’s first commercially available radiation therapy tracking system (RayPilot). In this study, radiotherapy will be given in daily separate fractions over a period of 3 consecutive days. A RayPilot-tracking catheter will be inserted into the rectum and inflated with fluid before treatment. A continuous movement profile of the prostate is collected by the RayPilot system during the treatment and the beam will be automatically stopped if the device detects that the prostate has moved by more than 2mm. It is anticipated that this approach will reduce the bowel and bladder side effects experienced by men undergoing 5 fractions of prostate Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy due to both less time spent treating the prostate and by ensuring that the full dose of radiotherapy intended for the prostate is actually being delivered. This will be the first trial of this innovative technology in men with prostate cancer anywhere in the world and will require 45 men to be enrolled to determine if 3 fractions of prostate SBRT with RayPilot can safely be recommended as a standard treatment for all men with low or intermediate risk prostate cancer. The clinical trial will require participants to undergo additional scans, radiotherapy planning sessions and treatment sessions above and beyond what is expected to be the new standard of care for prostate cancer patients. This should not affect access to follow-up imaging and clinical assessments through the NHS post treatment."

In the experimental group (LLLT), where a (Ga-Al-As) diode laser, will be used with 808 nm wavelength in continuous mode, 250 milli-Watt power output, 4 Joules/point energy density, 16 s per point. In addition to adjusting the force gauge every 4 weeks until the end of the intrusion stage and reaching normal coverage
Inclusion criteria: the patient should have overbite greater than 4mm and less than 7 mm

Inclusion criteria: the female and male patients, with an age range of 18 years to 32 years, who showed deep overbite (overbite > 4 mm or vertical maxillary excess > 2 mm). (The overbite depth will be measured using the measuring instrument built in software).

The patient should have maxillary anterior crowding of less than 2 mm, the maxillary incisors should be positioned below the functional occlusal plane of not more than 2 to 3 mm and the angle of their display should be not less than 25 °, and the upper incisors should not have a history of any trauma or endodontic treatment (the patient's history is documented), the patient should have normal oral hygiene, and the patient should not have a genetic disease that distorts the normal growth of the jaws or affects the normal development of the teeth.(the patient's history is documented)

If the patient meets the following additional criteria, the patient will be included in the study: The patient has to accept using the two-dimensional orthodontic device made of a cobalt-chromium alloy with a diameter of 0.8 mm (Roth prescription, 7/7) and has to agree on using the headgear night and day until the tooth is in normal coverage in the dental arch. It should also be acceptable for the patient to use a rubber band on each incisor for the purpose of holding the cuff and adjusting its strength accordingly.
The patient should have normal facial growth patterns and should understand what is required of him until the end of the intrusion movement.
The patient exhibited poor oral hygiene.
Patients who are allergic to nickel-titanium alloy.
Patients with a systemic disease that affects the function of the teeth or causes changes in the size of the jaws.
The patient presented an irregular dental arch that would affect the intrusion movement and lead to malocclusion.
Excessive teeth spacing so that the incisors are separated from each other more than 2mm, which is the natural distance between them
Root volume reduction. Timepoint: At the 3 month follow up. Method of measurement: The root volume will be measured using CBCT images employing the Virtuo software."

798,"The number of radical hemicolectomies performed in Italy in recent decades has increased significantly due to the constant progressive increase in detection rates. This increase can be explained by the advancement in diagnostic screening and diagnostic accuracy, but also by the evolution of surgical technique, which has become safer and more efficient. Recent studies have shown the usefulness of carrying out a wide lymphadenectomy in an effort to improve the possibility of eradicating the disease. The hypothesis of this study is to demonstrate that more extensive resection techniques with vascular ligation to the level of the root of the ileocolic artery and vein are associated with decreased postoperative complications."

799,"Balance impairement is common problem in hearing impaired individuals. Sensory organization dysfunction is one cause for balance deficits . Therefore, balance training becomes important to improve the quality of life. The importance of this study was Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises can help to improve the balance and to improve the quality of life by the increase of hearing sensitivity."

800,"The clinical significance of postural changes and pain associated with ankle inversion as experienced by patients presenting at the community emergency room for treatment of ankle sprain. It is hypothesized that these initial manifestations are caused by distal fibular fracture requiring surgical treatment.

The investigators' goal will be to evaluate the incidence and relationship of the ankle inversion pain syndrome to underlying distal fibular fractures. To achieve this goal, the investigators' research team has broken down the treatment of an ankle inversion injury into seven stages. Stage 1 is pre-injury status. Stage 2 is the initial medical assessment. Stage 2 begins immediately in the community and primary care setting or after the patient presents to the hospital emergency room. Stage 3 involves a basic x-ray and physical exam. Stage 3 includes a physician's determination as to the appropriate level of care which can include: a return to the emergency room, return to the office for further evaluation, or transfer to the hospital. (1) Physician's diagnosis of ankle sprain or trauma involving the ankle joint. (2) The physician determines that the ankle sprain did not sustain any other significant osseous or ligament injury. (3) The physician determines that no fractures or major orthopedic injuries to the lower extremity are present. (4) The investigators' intention is to enroll patients in whom the decision to refer them out for further evaluation of their ankle injury has been made. (5) The investigators' expectation is that the decision to refer out the patient was made because of the initial symptoms and pain of the ankle inversion syndrome. (6) In order for patients to be included in the research project, once the patient was in a sitting or supine position, a definitive assessment of the ankle joint should have been done using standard protocols. The patient's history of past injuries is to be recorded. The investigators' expectation is that the patient's pain assessment was recorded using the Visual Analog Scale and / or using the 10-point verbal rating scale for pain intensity. (7) Stage 4 will involve the transfer from the first treating physician in the outlying clinics to the second treating physician in the hospital setting. This transition could be either directly from the community to the surgeon in a clinic setting or as a transfer from the emergency room to the orthopedic surgeon's hospital surgery clinic. Stage 5 is the evaluation of the ankle and potential fracture by the first orthopedic surgeon. The patient will undergo a physical examination. X-ray evaluation of the ankle and knee is to be obtained. If a fracture is observed on the X-ray film, the surgeon will proceed to the next step in the patient's treatment. Stage 6: The surgeon will document the specific diagnosis and discuss the therapeutic options with the patient. Once the decision has been made to treat the patient with a surgical procedure(s), the patient is to be scheduled for surgery at Westchester Medical Center within the next 7 days. Stage 7: Within one month of their initial encounter with the orthopedic surgeon, the surgeon or a designated orthopedist on the medical surgical team will determine whether ankle instability is a likely result of the ankle inversion trauma that resulted in their admission to the hospital or their referral for operative treatment of their injury. If ankle instability has occurred, the treatment for this condition will be surgical repair of the lateral ankle ligaments. If ankle instability is unlikely to occur, then the patient's treatment will be considered to be non-surgical.
The Effects of High Intensity Shockwave Therapy on Perfusion and Vascular Parameters in Diabetic Patients With Critical Limb Ischemia

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column1: 801,"Scientific title: Effect of open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation and bone grafting from the iliac crest to improve functional outcomes, quality of life and cost effectiveness

Background: The incidence of distal radial fractures is increasing and a substantial amount of patients are developing malunions which can cause impaired function and a reduced quality of life. Several treatment modalities exist for a malunited fracture of the distal radius but no treatment consensus exists. An open wedge corrective osteotomy with a plate fixation is associated with a high complication risk if the bone grafts are used to fill the osteotomy gap. Some studies report a lower complication rate for bone graft-free open wedge corrective osteotomy. The present study aims to investigate whether there are any short-time or long-time benefits of bone grafting in patients with malunited distal radius fractures treated with an open wedge osteotomy and plate fixation.

Hypothesis: Postoperative functional outcomes, quality of life and cost effectiveness will not statistically differ between patients with or without bone grafting when receiving an open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation.
Conditions: Malunion of Fracture of Radius
Intervention: Patients will undergo an open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation with or without bone grafting from the iliac crest.

Type of procedure: The surgeon (KMU or LSH) will perform the operation as usual. In brief, the distal radius can be divided according fracture patterns: in the oblique pattern, the fracture line is parallel to the axis of the radius and the cortex is obliquely angled and in the transversal pattern, the fracture line crosses the radial shaft perpendicularly. An open wedge osteotomy will be performed and a locking dynamic compression plate (DCP) used for plate fixation. In both arms the surgical technique can be the same but in the bone grafting arm, a bone graft from the iliac crest could be used if the surgeon considers that the risk/benefit relationship favors the use of bone grafting.

Secondary outcome measures: Subjective functional outcomes using the DASH questionnaire Subjective functional outcome using the PRWE questionnaire Objective functional outcomes Active range of motion Measured in millimeters using a goniometer. Health-related quality of life. The EQ-5D-5L health state questionnaire is a generic instrument which describes healthcare.

The study protocol: After signing the informed consent, patients will be stratified according to surgical indication and randomized into one of two study groups: 1. Patients with symptomatic malunion of distal radius receiving bone grafting, or 2. Patients with symptomatic malunion of distal radius receiving none bone grafts.
Inclusion criteria: Inclusion criteria. Patients aged 25 - 75 years who are candidates for open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation of symptomatic malunion of the distal radius.

column1: 802,"Behavioral problems at school are highly prevalent, leading to academic, social and behavioral problems for the child at home and in school. Teachers may use several support strategies to help the child and reduce their disruptive behaviors in the classroom. The goal of this randomized controlled study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief training for teachers of children with disruptive behavior at school, compared to practice as usual only. The effectiveness of the intervention will be measured on several outcomes, including severity of behavioral difficulties in the classroom that are targeted in the intervention, children's impairment at school associated with their behavioral difficulties, child behavioral difficulties at home, and teacher behavior."

803,"The research hypotheses are (1) that the intervention (tele-rehabilitation) will be feasible and acceptable for patients with chronic non-specific neck pain, (2) that using virtual reality in the rehabilitation of patients with chronic non-specific neck pain increases the efficacy of the intervention as measured by patient-reported outcomes (NDI, NPRS, SUS, and GPE), and (3) that virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education can increase the patient's cervical capacity (measured by cROM).

Feasibility, Acceptability, and Usability of a Tele-rehabilitation Combining Immersive Virtual Reality Exercises and Therapeutic Education for Chronic Non-specific Neck Pain: A Mixed-methods Pilot Study.

Inclusion Criteria: Adults (over 18 years), men or women Chronic (> 3 months) non-specific neck pain (no specific cause responsible for the neck pain), with or without referred pain in the upper limbs or the head Neck Disability Index score greater than or equal to 5/50 Numerical Pain Rating Scale score greater than or equal to 3/10 (average pain over the past week) To speak fluent French and to be able to provide informed consent Exclusion Criteria: Age under 18 years Specific cause responsible for the neck pain (tumor/cancer, fracture, trauma, inflammatory disease, infection, compression or lesion of the spinal cord, surgery of the cervical spine, vascular pathology, neurological pathology, ligamentous lesion of the upper cervical spine, congenital disease of the cervical spine, chronic diffuse pain) Neck Disability Index score less than 5/50 Numerical Pain Rating Scale score less than 3/10 (average pain over the past week) Signs of untreated sensorimotor dysfunction (vertigo, vestibular disorders/pathologies, etc.) that interfere with the use of virtual reality Visual problems (uncorrected myopia, limited vision after correction, eye surgery) that interfere with the use of virtual reality Altered comprehension, significant cognitive impairment, inability to speak French, deafness, pregnancy, inability to provide written informed consent

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
Experimental: Virtual reality and therapeutic education
Multimodal tele-rehabilitation consisting of therapeutic education and immersive virtual reality neck exercises. The duration of the intervention will be 6 weeks, including 5 virtual reality sessions (15-20 minutes per session, without supervision of the physiotherapist) and 1 teleconsultation session with a physiotherapist (30 minutes per session) per week. In addition, participants will receive several brochures to read on their own (therapeutic education). These brochures will be discussed with the physiotherapist during the teleconsultations.
column3:
Device: Virtual reality
* Immersive virtual reality neck exercises targeting relaxation, mobility, control, and speed of movement, using the Pico G2 4K headset.
Behavioral: Therapeutic education
* Several brochures will be given to participants. These brochures will cover the general principles of pain, the persistence of pain, tips for managing chronic non-specific pain, and the use of immersive virtual reality in the rehabilitation of chronic non-specific neck pain. The information provided in the brochures will be discussed with the physiotherapist during the teleconsultations in order to individualize the therapeutic education.

column5: 804,138 children with bilateral Cerebral Palsy will be included at CP-centrum UCLouvain. They will be divided into four groups: 1/2) Classic HABIT-ILE therapy on-site without follow-up 2/2) Classic HABIT-ILE therapy on-site with follow-up 3/2) Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) at home without follow-up 3/2) Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) at home with follow-up The follow-up at home will follow the same principles as the classic HABIT-ILE but is delivered at the patient home with 4 hours per week in autonomy and 1 hour per week under supervision After the two weeks of HABIT-ILE or classic HABIT-ILE (4 hours/day), patients in home therapy will benefit during 6 more weeks of autonomous therapy at home supervised remotely for 1 hour per week. The primary objective is to determine if HABIT-ILE@home is as efficacious (no worse than) as classic HABIT-ILE after two weeks of therapy for 6-18 years old children with bilateral cerebral palsy assessed by the change of the Gross Motor Function -88 questionnaire (GMFM-88) at 3 and 6 months after the end of the HABIT-ILE therapy. In addition, we will evaluate the changes in the functional abilities, independence, and in the quality of life after two weeks of HABIT-ILE therapy for children with bilateral cerebral palsy: - Upper limb motor function (Chew assessment - Unilateral or Bilateral; 6-minute walk test; Activities on a daily life scale: BBT, ABILOC, ACTIVLIM and ESTIMILL) - Jebsen Hand Task (JHT) - Fine motor activity of the hand (ABILHAND) - Quality of life (PROM-29; SF-8) - Changes in daily activities (ABILHAND-Sports, ACTIVLIM-CP, PEDI, PILS, COPM) - Activities during the day (3D sensor) - Lower limbs physical activity (Accelerometry) - Brain changes (Diffusion Tensor Imaging, Resting State fMRI, Mean Diffusivity)"

column1: 805,"1. Background: Prenatal maternal-fetal surveillance is a cornerstone in obstetrics and yet our limited understanding of the pathways leading to successful versus failed surveillance is the driving force behind many stillbirth and preterm birth losses and neonatal morbidity and mortality. When preterm rupture of membranes (PPROM) occurs, clinicians face the challenge of deciding when and how to monitor for adverse fetal or maternal outcomes and the risk associated with each diagnostic option. It is unclear if there is a difference in the risk of chorioamnionitis or neonatal morbidity and mortality associated with speculum examinations during ongoing PPROM compared to digital examinations. 2. Objectives: To conduct a randomized trial comparing the effects on pregnancy latency and fetal outcomes of serial digital versus speculum cervical examinations in the setting of preterm PPROM without labor. 3. Study Design: This study takes place after obtaining Informed Consent from the subject during a clinic appointment to evaluate a PPROM by digital exam. A sterile speculum will then be inserted to visualize the cervix and confirm PPROM. The randomized trial will commence from the date of enrollment. Eligible patients will be randomized to undergo serial digital or speculum examinations. We hypothesize that patients randomized to the digital arm will have improved pregnancy latency and fetal outcomes compared to patients in the speculum arm. 4. Sample Size: The estimated total number of subjects is 80. With an estimate of 20% of patients being randomized (alpha level of 0.05) to undergo digital examinations (arm 2), there will be 15 patients receiving a digital exam and 15 patients receiving a speculum exam with a 0-10 difference in their pregnancy latency. This number allows for a margin of error of ±1.8. 5. Study Duration: The study is expected to have a duration of 6-12 months. 6. Potential Benefits to Subjects: This study aims to determine if speculum examinations in patients with preterm PPROM without labor are associated with adverse fetal and maternal outcomes, compared to digital examinations. Subjects will be provided with knowledge about their ability to make an informed decision to consent to this research study. The knowledge and information gained by patients who participate in this study will hopefully benefit others in the future."

806,"This proposal is for the pilot trial for which the SALT protocol was developed in terms of pretransplant diagnostic assessments, transplantation, donor selection, early complication management and long-term posttransplant follow-up in patients with liver cirrhosis and HCC who met UCSF criteria but were not suitable for whole-organ liver transplantation.

The study is a pilot trial to obtain preliminary information about the SALT protocol, including pre-transplant diagnostic protocol, SALT protocol, early complications and long-term follow-up.  All outcomes, including primary and secondary endpoints, will only be descriptive.  They are: feasibility, donor graft safety, patient and graft survival, tumor-free survival, and safety of early and late complications.
A total of 26 patients with advanced liver cirrhosis complicated with HCC will be enrolled in the study to undergo sequential adult left lateral hepatectomy and liver transplantation.

A Feasibility Study of Sequential Adult Left Lateral Liver Transplantation (SALT) in Patients With Liver Cirrhosis With Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): a Single-center, Prospective, Single-arm Pilot Study
* Procedure: sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT)

Inclusion Criteria: Exclusion Criteria: Child-Pugh A and B with HCC can meet the UCSF criteria of the main liver tumor: 1) Child-Pugh Child-Pugh A and B; 2) The sum of the tumor diameter (<= 58 mm) and the number of the tumor (<= 3) according to UCSF, 3) The degree of differentiation is no worse than moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (grade I).

807,"Degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) is a debilitating condition impacting hundreds of thousands of patients worldwide1. Symptoms are commonly associated with upper extremity function, resulting in weakness and clumsiness that impact performance of activities of daily living (ADL). Assessment of manual dexterity in myelopathy has been challenging due to limited availability and high cost of validated clinical tools designed to measure dexterity. As a result, routine assessment of manual dexterity is not incorporated in the evaluation and treatment of adults with cervical myelopathy. This gap has prompted a need for the development of a valid and reliable tool to specifically assess manual dexterity in this population. A team developed a low-cost dexterity assessment tool consisting of a custom app, designed to be used on a mobile device that measures finger dexterity. The study aims to establish the validity and reliability of this tool in a cohort of individuals with DCM and a cohort of healthy controls.

This cross-sectional study in two cohorts of participants, those with cervical myelopathy (myelopathy cohort) and healthy controls (healthy cohort), will determine the validity, reliability, and internal consistency of the Dexterity Assessment Tool (DAT).

The DAT will first be assessed using the concurrent validity method to determine the extent to which values obtained using the DAT correlate with those obtained using an acceptable standard, the GRASSP-M tool (Graded Redefined Assessment of Strength, Sensation and Prehension-Myelopathy)13. The GRASSP-M is a clinical validated research tool used for assessment of motor, sensory and prehension function in people with myelopathy.

The DAT will then be further assessed using the test-retest reliability method14, followed by the inter-rater reliability method12. For the test-retest reliability assessment, the DAT will be used to measure dexterity in healthy participants at two time points, one week apart. The data from the two time points will be correlated to determine the test re-test reliability coefficient and to determine the stability of DAT scores over time. For the inter-rater reliability assessment, the DAT will be used to measure dexterity in healthy participants with two testers administering the tool one hour apart. The data from the two testers will be correlated to determine the inter-rater reliability coefficient (ICC), and to assess the extent to which measurement errors impact the overall measurement system. The ICC will be calculated with two-way mixed-effects model and an absolute agreement. The ICC can range from 0 to 1, where 1 indicates perfect ICC.

All assessments will be administered by a member of the research team with prior training on data collection. The DAT will be administered in both cohorts, while the GRASSP-M will only be administered in the myelopathy cohort. All participants will provide written informed consent before data collection.
Establishing the Validity and Reliability of a Dexterity Assessment Tool in DCM and Healthy Populations
Myelopathy Cervical, Cervical Spondylosis, Spinal Cord Compression

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with DCM include participants recruited from the Saskatchewan Myelopathy Clinic at Saskatchewan Health Authority in Saskatoon, SK, Canada. Inclusion criteria include: diagnosis of DCM confirmed by MRI or neurophysiological testing; Age between 35-75; can fluently speak and read English; able to sit and work a tablet device; able to provide written informed consent. Healthy controls include participants recruited from the general population in Saskatoon, SK, Canada, through advertisements. Inclusion criteria include: Age between 35-75; can fluently speak and read English; able to sit and work a tablet device; No neurological conditions, including Parkinson's disease; No current medications to affect motor performance; able to provide written informed consent. Exclusion Criteria: Patients with DCM include participants who do not have a diagnosis of DCM or those who are beyond the 75 age threshold. They also include patients who cannot provide written informed consent, and patients without English language fluency. Patients who are unable to sit and work a tablet"

1.Background of the study: Serratus posterior superior block (SPSPIPB) was first described in 2023 by Tulgar et al. by ultrasound imaging guidance. The SPS muscle is located at the level of C7-T2. It is innervated by the lower cervical and upper intercostal nerves. With this block, these nerves are blocked. There was only one cadaveric study on the spread of SPSIPB. It was reported that they spread in 7-10 intercostal levels on the left side only in the superficial fascia of the trapezius muscle. (This does not mean that we can say that this will happen in all patients. Each patient has different anatomical structures that may affect the spread). Also there was limited clinical studies in the literature regarding SPSIPB application. The number of patients in the study was too limited and it was reported that the analgesic effect was not superior to IV PCA. There are studies in the literature that report that SPSIPB can provide analgesia in conditions such as interscapular pain, chronic myofascial pain syndromes, scapulocostal syndrome, and shoulder pain.

1.Background of the surgery in the literature: Pain management is still challenging in patients undergoing mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection (ALND). Because this is a procedure that causes moderate to severe pain requiring the use of opioids for postoperative pain control. If the patient is discharged home when she/he is no longer in any pain, it will ensure a better-quality recovery. In this study, our aim is to investigate the efficacy of US-guided SPSIPB on postoperative pain control in women with mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. Our primary aim is to compare NRS at the postoperative 1st h. Our secondary aim is to evaluate the need for rescue analgesics , block-related complications, dermatome level, and side effects associated with opioid use.
1.Aim of the study: To investigate the analgesic effect of the US-guided SPSIPB on mastectomy and ALND surgery.

1.Study hypothesis: The study hypothesis is that the US-guided SPSIPB will be more effective than saline infiltration of the operation field postoperative pain management in patients with mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
1. Primary objective: To compare NRS scores at the postoperative 1st h.
1. Secondary objectives: To compare rescue analgesics used in the postoperative 24 h.
To evaluate the dermatomal coverage of SPSIPB.
To evaluate adverse event occurrence related to opioid use such as nausea, vomiting, itching and the need for antiemetic therapy.
1. Study design (phase of study) : This study is a randomized, controlled, parallel study of female patients aged 18-65 who will undergo mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
a. To be 18-65 years of age
b. To be ASA-I & II physical status,
c. Not to receive anticoagulant therapy,
e. Patient who consent to participate in the study
f. Patients who will undergo mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection
b. To be receiving analgesics before surgery,
d. To be receiving anticoagulant therapy,
e. Allergy to opioid drugs or local anesthetics,
f. Patients with a history of opioid abuse,
g. Patients with infection of the skin at the site of the block
a. The patient will be administered preoperative IV fentanyl 0.5 mcg/kg in all patients

b. Patients will be administered ibuprofen 400 mgr IV and then every 8 hours in the postoperative period. If the NRS score is ≥ 4, 0.5 mg kg-1 iv meperidine will be administered as a rescue analgesic. Postoperative patient"

811,"80% of deaths in heart failure (HF) patients are related to cardiovascular causes, especially sudden cardiac death (SCD). There is still a significant need for preventive and therapeutic strategies to reduce death, re-hospitalization and the need for heart transplantation. As the cause of death in patients with HF is mostly acute myocardial infarction in the setting of SCD and silent myocardial ischemia preceding myocardial infarction, the role of lipid metabolism including fatty acid accumulation is increasingly appreciated. Although lipid accumulation is considered a protective mechanism, it might also lead to an impairment of the function of the heart and immune system in many patients. To address this issue, the objective of this study is to investigate changes in lipid metabolism following heart transplantation and the potential link with organ rejection. In a clinical approach, we will investigate the role of lipid metabolism after heart transplantation in 4 years follow-up of 40 patients with an endogenous control group of 20 patients, undergoing heart transplantation between the ages of 18 and 65. Furthermore, we will investigate the function of macrophages and the potential link to changes in lipid metabolism. These data should improve our understanding of lipid metabolism in cardiac transplant patients under standardized medical therapy, which should lead to new therapeutic concepts to improve life expectancy, quality of life and treatment options in HF patients."
