Completed adjuvant chemotherapy after achieving NED (e.g. 4-8 cycles of CapOX regimen, 6-12 cycles of FOLFOX regimen, or without receiving adjuvant chemotherapy recently) and evaluated as no disease progression. Last chemotherapy within 2 months from enrollment. 4. The time interval between the last chemotherapy and enrollment does not exceed 2 months; 5. Performance status (ECOG score) ≤ 2 ; 6. Hematology: WBC > 3 × 10^9 / L; PLT > 80 × 10^9 / L; Hb > 90 g/L; 7. Liver function: ALT and AST ≤ 2.5 × ULN; bilirubin ≤ 1.5 × ULN; 8. Renal function: Serum creatinine ≤ 1.5 × ULN or creatinine clearance rate (CCr) ≥ 60 ml/min; 9. Signed informed consent, willingness to undergo treatment according to this protocol, and good compliance with medication. Maintenance therapy with Fruquintinib is recommended as optional treatment for patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis who have undergone radical local therapy and have achieved NED after first-line chemotherapy. Maintenance therapy with Fruquintinib is recommended as optional treatment for patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis who have undergone radical local therapy and have achieved NED after first-line chemotherapy. Fruquintinib is effective in a variety of tumors, including various refractory malignant neoplasms, such as colorectal cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma, pancreatic cancer, gastric cancer, etc. Fruquintinib mechanism of anti-tumor action is based on high affinity binding to vascular endothelial growth factor receptors (VEGFR), leading to inhibition of tumor angiogenesis, reduction of tumor perfusion, and thus starving the tumor and causing cell death. Fruquintinib is mainly distributed in the extracellular space, which explains the high concentration of fruquintinib in the tumor, resulting in relatively high therapeutic efficacy combined with a low incidence of toxic reactions. Fruquintinib inhibits tumor angiogenesis by binding to VEGFR, making vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) unable to bind to receptors and inhibiting their tyrosine kinase activity, thereby preventing tumor vessels from forming, reducing the blood supply of tumor tissues, and enhancing the effect of other chemotherapy drugs. When fruquintinib binds to VEGFR1/2/3 at high concentrations, it prevents signal transduction by inhibiting the phosphorylation of VEGFR downstream signal transduction molecules, such as the Flt-1 receptor tyrosine kinase, preventing tumor vessels from forming, reducing tumor vascular perfusion, and starving the tumor of oxygen and nutrients to cause cell death. The efficacy and safety of Fruquintinib treatment are well confirmed in China and have been approved by many countries around the world, including the United States, and are widely used in clinical practice. Based on the above, we will conduct a prospective, single-arm, phase II study of fruquintinib after first-line chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis who have undergone curative local therapy and achieved NED to explore its efficacy and safety for patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis who have undergone curative local therapy and achieved NED."

column1: 817,"We propose a crossover trial of immediate-release methylphenidate (MPH) and oral placebo (PBO) in a patient population with co-morbid post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and neurocognitive impairment. This is a pilot study in preparation for a larger  RCT  to assess tolerability, safety, efficacy and effects on neurocognition, mood and PTSD symptoms, and identify predictors of treatment response.  We hypothesize that compared to placebo, MPH will result in a greater improvement in PTSD symptom severity, a greater improvement in neurocognitive functioning and will carry less risk of discontinuation events or loss of efficacy .  We will also determine if participants who have a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) experience similar treatment response to those participants without a history of TBI. The specific aims are: 1. To evaluate the efficacy of MPH compared to placebo for reducing PTSD symptoms; 2. To evaluate the effectiveness of MPH compared to placebo for improving neurocognitive functioning; and 3. To compare the response to treatment between participants with and without a history of TBI.  We intend to randomize 35 participants from a pool of approximately 70. Participants will receive MPH in randomized order for 4 weeks, followed by a 1-week washout, followed by placebo in randomized order for another 4 weeks. This trial design is particularly well-optimized for conditions in which a heterogeneous response to treatment is expected.  Additionally, the use of N-of-1 trial design allows for the detection of non-linear/threshold effects of treatment, the incorporation of placebo effects on treatment response and the inclusion of an active comparator (placebo) that will better control for the naturalistic course and fluctuating severity of symptoms of PTSD.

Interventional Model Description: The study compares MPH (intervention) and PBO (control) using an aggregated N-of-1 trial design. N-of-1 clinical trials are multi-cycle, double-blinded, placebo-controlled cross-over trials based on an individual. In aggregated N-of-1 trials, data from a cohort of participants are analyzed together, often to test the efficacy of a treatment whilst controlling for the heterogeneity of response. Our design consists of 2 cycles, with each cycle including 4 weeks of MPH 10mg twice daily and 4 weeks of PBO twice daily, each followed by a 1-week washout. This provides a total of 8 weeks on active drug and 8 weeks on placebo. Order of MPH vs PBO within cycle is randomly assigned and double-blinded.

Input Text: Patient Recruitment For C-NIT
The effect of acne on c-NIT (chronic neuroinflammation theory) will be studied by analysing the level of inflammation in the blood. The effect of acne treatment on inflammation will also be studied.

Acne is a disease of the skin. Some of the symptoms caused by this disease are skin inflammation and scarring of skin. There are three factors that may affect the severity of skin irritation are: 1. Bacterial infection of P.acnes 2. Genetic factors 3. Inflammation triggered by the bacteria and genetic factors. Treatment for acne affects only factor 1. This study aims to investigate if acne causes inflammation which causes worsening of the acne. This study also aims to investigate if inflammation is reduced when antibiotic treatment is given as part of acne treatment. The study's hypothesis is that acne causes inflammation and that treating acne with antibiotics reduces inflammation. Inflammatory biomarkers are measured in the blood of each individual. This is done to see if the inflammation is reduced by antibiotic treatment. This was measured before and after acne therapy. The effect of taking antibiotics has already been clarified in previous studies. By investigating these biomarkers, the effect of taking antibiotics to reduce the symptoms of acne can be evaluated in a clinical study. In a previous study, it was discovered that the patient had symptoms of skin diseases other than acne. Patients had eczema, but when they were studied again, this finding could not be confirmed. Blood tests have been done for some of the tests. The investigators have analyzed and compared the results from different research studies. The investigators will publish an article about this finding. This article will be published in journals such as Dermatology and Cutaneous Surgery. There is a 95 percent chance that the findings will be correct. This is also confirmed by the results from previous studies. There are 22 patients who have participated in the study. The study plan includes a maximum of only 28 people who can participate in the study. There are no previous or ongoing studies of this type. The study is not interfering with ongoing treatment. Participation is not limited. Participation is voluntary with no direct benefit to the participants.
Clinical Study of Adolescent and Young Adults Inflammatory Level of Chronic Neuroinflammation Theory (C-NIT) During Chronic Acne Treatment With Antibiotics
Inclusion Criteria: Acne vulgaris, no inflammatory disorders Exclusion Criteria: Pregnancy, chronic inflammatory disorder

A randomized controlled observational study on gut microbiota during the process of the immune response to HBV vaccination in children with hepatitis B surface antigen positive in the perinatal period.

Introduction: HBV vaccination induces the production of specific antibodies that protect against hepatitis B infection in children with perinatal hepatitis B virus (HBV) seroconversion. However, the mechanism of this immune response remains unclear. Immunization is one of the most important factors that develop the balance in the human intestinal microbiota. Aim: To provide data on microbial colonization, the diversity and structure of bacterial communities in perinatal children from the point of view of the development of the immune response to HBV vaccination. Materials and methods: 70 mothers and infants with positive HBsAg in the perinatal period. The mothers and infants were assigned to two groups. The patients were under a standard vaccine regimen (recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, Dang-khi-Pharmaceutical Joint Stock Company, Vietnam, doses at 0, 6, and 18 weeks old). Before vaccination, and after the third, and the fourth vaccination, 10 mL of venous blood was collected from the subjects, and a sample of feces was taken. The study was conducted between October 2019 and March 2022. Methods: For bacterial analyses, fecal samples were stored at -80°C after collection. DNA extraction was performed from 200 mg of fecal samples using the Qiagen Fecal Microbiota DNA Collection Kit, and 16S rRNA sequencing was performed using the NovaSeq6000 platform. Results: The number of microbial operational taxonomic units (OTUs) in children with successful immunization to HBV vaccine were reduced by more than 40% when compared to the baseline level. The most common OTUs in children with successful immunization to HBV vaccine were Clostridium cluster XIVa and Streptococcus; in children without seroconversion they were Bacteroides and Clostridioides. In the course of vaccination, the structure of bacterial communities significantly changed (p < 0.01). The data of the study obtained on the immunogenicity of HBV vaccine show that microbial structure change is accompanied by a significant increase in the production of antigen‐specific antibodies. In this connection, the need for the development of methods for determining the structure of bacterial communities from early childhood as a key prognostic factor for the development of hepatitis B immunity on the basis of HBV vaccination is indicated."

821,"Asthma is a worldwide chronic disease that has a major impact on patient quality of life, functional status and healthcare costs. Healthcare systems around the globe are beginning to use eHealth to bridge a gap in healthcare access in lower resource regions. At the same time, a major focus is on the need to optimize access to healthcare resources while reducing carbon footprints. It is estimated that metoprolol used for migraines in Canada generates 64% higher emissions of CO2e per head than patients receiving any of the 4 other common treatments (i.e., triptans, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, ergots or combination analgesics), and yet no study has ever been conducted to evaluate if patients are aware of the carbon footprint of their treatment. This project will measure asthma patient awareness of their eHealth care experience, as well as their perception of quality of care and environmental impact among a broader population of asthma patients in order to determine if patient care delivery via telemedicine has any unintended, and potentially negative, impacts on patient care.
Patient, Provider, and System-level Impact of Implementing Telemedicine in the Diagnosis and Management of Adult Asthma

Inclusion Criteria: 1) Newly diagnosed asthma cases. 2) Adult patients receiving ongoing asthma care in the Montreal Chest Institute 3) Patient able to speak and read English or French 4) Patient must be a resident of the Province of Quebec Exclusion Criteria: 1) Children younger than 16 years old 2) Current resident in a long-term care facility 3) Unable to travel to the MCI in person or virtually Exclusion Criteria (Telemedicine patients only): 1) Patients who refuse to participate in follow-up telemedicine consultation

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
TELEMEDICINE
Patients will be recruited during routine clinic follow-up visits in the pulmonary outpatient department and randomized into the telemedicine group, or matched control group. Patients in the telemedicine group will receive a letter at the time of their clinic visit inviting them to receive their clinic visit, medication refills and other follow-up appointments via telemedicine without requiring any physical presence at the clinic. Patients will attend their clinic visit followed by one-time initial telemedicine consultation.

CONTROL
Patients in the control group will continue to attend clinic follow-up visits in person, and receive their medications as required. All patients in the control group will then undergo a follow-up telemedicine consultation at 6 months to capture any changes in care delivery as a result of exposure to the telemedicine consultation (cross-over).

column3: Measure Description

column2: Impact of implementing telemedicine on asthma patient-provider communication by comparing number of asthma action plans (AAP) generated per patient between the telemedicine group and matched control group.
column3: Measured via electronic medical records by identifying number of AAPs generated for all patients in the study, using each AAP as a unit of analysis.

824,"Purpose: The goal of this study was to assess the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer.

Design: A systematic review was carried out to examine the effectiveness of neoadjuvant therapy with Trastuzumab and chemotherapy in achieving pCR in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. A search of the Medline, Embase, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials databases was conducted to identify relevant clinical trials. Eligible trials were those that included patients with breast cancer confirmed to be HER2 positive and that utilized neoadjuvant therapy consisting of Trastuzumab and standard cytotoxic chemotherapy. The primary outcome of interest was the pCR rate, with secondary outcomes including breast-conserving surgery rates, 5-year disease-free survival rates, and 5-year overall survival rates.

The authors identified nine eligible clinical trials, all of which utilized different chemotherapy and Trastuzumab regimens. Among the 1209 enrolled patients, the overall pCR rate was found to be 42%. The investigators presented a detailed summary of the design and characteristics of each clinical trial. They also provided information about patient demographics, disease stage, and response rates (5-year breast-conserving surgery rate, 5-year disease-free survival rate, and 5-year overall survival rate). Key findings from the study include that Trastuzumab significantly improves pCR rates in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer who undergo neoadjuvant therapy. However, the investigators caution that these findings are based on a small number of studies and that larger randomized trials are needed to confirm these effects. They also note that further studies are needed to determine the long-term safety and efficacy of this treatment approach.
Neoadjuvant Therapy With Trastuzumab and Chemotherapy and the Resultant Pathologic Complete Response Observed in HER2 Positive Breast Cancer;a Systematic Review
If HER2+ breast cancer is being treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and trastuzumab. Will this combined treatment increase the pathological response rate as compared to chemotherapy alone?
Study participants were selected from the following criteria:

All nine studies included in this study were assessed to determine their eligibility for inclusion. A patient was considered a candidate for inclusion if they met all of the following criteria: A patient was eligible for inclusion in this study if he or she demonstrated the presence of HER2-positive breast cancer and underwent neoadjuvant therapy with Trastuzumab and chemotherapy.
All of the studies reported the pCR rate as one of the outcomes.

Study participants were excluded from this study if they demonstrated any of the following criteria: A patient did not qualify for inclusion in this study if he or she demonstrated any of the following criteria:
The outcome of pCR on the basis of HER2 status.

The pathological complete response (pCR) rate was 42% for patients treated with neoadjuvant therapies that included Trastuzumab. In four trials, the proportion of T0/is was 48%. When we evaluated the pCR rate in the nine different trials utilizing different chemo regimens, we found that the 42% of patients with pCR is similar to those described in previous studies.

The pCR rate after neoadjuvant chemotherapy plus trastuzumab ranges from 25% to 60%. According to studies conducted between 2015 and 2021, the pCR rate following trastuzumab therapy was found to range anywhere between 53% and 67% (table 2).

The pCR rate in the HER2-positive cohort was found to range anywhere from 32% to 42%. The pCR rate in the HER2-positive cohort varied from 32% to 42%, which was similar in all of the studies included in this systematic review."

825,"Athlone is the capital of Co. Roscommon, located at the meeting point of the Shannon and River Suck. With a population of under 20K, it is home to the largest industrial park in Ireland. In the last 17 decades, Athlone has seen substantial growth in the areas of employment, commercial property, and housing as a result of its growing economic success. However, this rapid development, while providing opportunity for the town, has brought with it stress and strain. The overall aim of this pilot study is to evaluate the feasibility of a coach-led technology solution in an urban population (i.e. Athlone population), to enable us to collect and share the necessary data to inform the design and delivery of a full scale study in the future. The primary goal of the pilot study is to determine the feasibility and acceptability of the recruitment process, the digital platform technology itself, and the intelligent coaching service. Secondary outcomes include the impact of the digital platform on the wellbeing and healthy lifestyle practices of study cohort. The outcomes of this pilot study will inform the design and development of the second phase of the research.
Assessing the Feasibility of a Coach-led Digital Platform Using an Intelligent Coaching Assistant: A Community Pilot Study
Outcome Measure: Recruitment process reach. We will use an established list of community mailboxes provided by the Irish College of General Practitioners.
Outcome Measure: Adoption measured as uptake of the digital platform as a percentage of total recruited
Outcome Measure: Engagement as behaviour will be measured as the number of logins to the digital support platform

Outcome Measure: A representative sample of study participants will be interviewed by a member of the research team. Interviews are to be conducted using Zoom conferencing platform on an individual basis with individual subjects. All interview questions will be developed in consultation with pilot study stakeholders.
Outcome Measure: Changes in the perceived stress with the PSS
Outcome Measure: Changes in wellbeing with the PERMA-NHL Profiler
Outcome Measure: Changes in healthy lifestyle practices, using the American College of Lifestyle Medicine ACLM-SF assessment.
Description: Any citizen who lives in Athy.
Agreements: An exclusion list will be maintained by the recruiting team in the form of a master list.
Free-living population - healthy subjects - not applicable"

827,"This was a prospective, multicenter, single-blinded, non-inferiority, observational follow-up trial on intravascular ultrasound, ultrasonic flow ratio, and fractional flow reserve in the evaluation of de novo coronary artery lesions in patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, and after the acute phase of myocardial infarction admitted to 21 hospitals between January 1, 2019, and November 30, 2020.
The aim of the study was to determine the functional diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio at the patient and vessel level, compared to fractional flow reserve.

Eligible patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or after the acute phase of myocardial infarction aged 18 years or older were studied. The patients performed three index coronary examinations using fractional flow reserve, ultrasonic flow ratio, and intravascular imaging (mainly ultrasound). Functional assessment was performed on 292 (26.7%) of 1091 lesions and 474 of 1158 coronary artery segments using fractional flow reserve. Ultrasonic flow ratio and ultrasound imaging data were obtained for 456 (40.8%) of 1123 lesions and at 573 (50.0%) of 1145 segments. The primary endpoint, based on the evaluation of 468 patients, was to demonstrate non-inferiority of UFR regarding sensitivity and specificity compared to FFR. The secondary endpoint, based on the evaluation of 523 patients, was to determine the diagnostic accuracy of UFR at the patient level. The study met its primary endpoint; compared to FFR the UFR had comparable diagnostic accuracy at the patient level (sensitivity: 77.1% vs 79.0%). A total of 241/294 segmental FFR values for UFR were ≥0.80 (sensitivity: 78.7%) and 31/31 segmental FFR values for UFR were ≤0.80 (specificity: 96.8%).

Abbreviations: ACC, American College of Cardiology; AHA, American Heart Association; ADVISECOR, ADvanced Intracoronary VErtical Stenting to Evaluate Carotid Stenting Outcome and RIsks; CE, coronary event; CFR, coronary flow reserve; CORE trial, Comparison of Outcomes of revascularization and pharmacological Treatment after Acute Coronary Events; FFR, fractional flow reserve; FRAME study, Fractional Flow Reserve Versus Angiography for Multivessel Evaluation; GPβM, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antagonist; HTA, high-resolution transcranial Doppler; HVD, high-velocity Doppler; IVUS, intravascular ultrasound; LFNC, left-front necrosis; POBA trial, Prevention of Obstructive Renovascular Disease; PROMISE study, Prospective Multicenter Imaging Study for Evaluation of Chest Pain; RCT, randomized clinical trial; RSVP trial, Revascularization Strategies for Patients with Left Main Disease (ACCOUNTS) and Randomized Study of
PCI Versus CABG in Patients with Left Main Stenosis (ROCKET); SAPPHIRE trial, The Saphenous Vein Graft Ablation Pivotal Study; UFR, ultrasonic flow ratio; VHM trial, Vascular Health Management

However, the clinical success rate is significantly lower when the entire treatment segment is covered by the stent (in-segment lesion).1,2,3 In most cases, de novo lesions are treated using a ‘stepwise’ approach, which involves initial assessment of the treated segment in order to ascertain whether it is necessary to treat additional lesions.4,5,6 The assessment and characterization of coronary artery lesions involves many different imaging modalities, which have undergone significant developments over the last decades, such as x-ray-based angiography, optical coherence tomography (OCT"

828,"Introduction: Burnout and emotional exhaustion among nursing and healthcare leaders, resulting from stress and overwork, have a negative effect on nursing leaders’ self-efficacy and productivity.
Objective: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Balint group as a psychological intervention on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in china.

Methods: We will invite registered Nurse Leaders in Department of Cardiovascular Diseases, Department of Neurology, Department of Gastrointestinal Oncology, Department of Gynaecology, Department of Nephrology and Department of Emergency Medicine in Tianjin Medical University Cancer Institute and Hospital as the participants. A total of 40 volunteers will be randomly divided into an intervention group (n=20) and a control group (n=20). Participants in the intervention group will complete Balint group activities. Participants in the control group will receive routine information. Both groups will receive interventions over three months. We will use the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey to measure participants’ emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and self-efficacy at baseline, three-month, and six-month. Finally, the change from baseline to six-month will be calculated.
Discussion: The results of this study will provide a psychological intervention strategy for nurse leaders in the future."

830,"75% of cancer patients are metastatic at initial diagnosis, and 80% will eventually have failure of standard therapy. A multitude of cell type-specific therapies (e.g., monoclonal antibodies and small molecule inhibitors) are becoming available to fight cancer. However, as each tumor is unique, the physician often must choose among multiple treatment options. The investigators will seek to understand how physician and Molecular Tumor Board (MTB) feedback influences their decision-making processes for managing cancer patients, as well as how the use of Cellworks reports impacts patient outcomes. The goal is to identify strategies that can be applied across the board to help physicians and MTB's make the best treatment decision for their patients."

Breast Cancer, Counseling, Nurse, Education, Follow-up"

833,"İn this study, the simulation-based training program designed for the 3rd year midwifery students of the Health Sciences University, Istanbul Hamidiye Faculty of Health Sciences, Midwifery Department to learn early postpartum hemorrhage management. The aim was to determine the effectiveness of computer-assisted randomization on the educational outcomes. This study was planned based on the theory of planned behavior of İbrahim Çakıroğlu. The research population consisted of 3rd grade students who took the Risky Birth and Postpartum Period course, studying at the Department of Midwifery, Hamidiye Faculty of Health Sciences, in the spring semester of the 2021-2022 academic year (N:82). Students who volunteered to participate in the study were included in the study. In the study, the entire target population was reached, except for the 4 students who were absent from the Risky Birth and Postpartum Period course (N:78). Computer-assisted randomization will be used in the study, and random assignment was made to the intervention (n:39) and control (n:39) groups by entering the number of cases through the program whose URL address is https://www.randomizer.org. An introductory information form was applied to all groups, and informed consent was obtained from the students before the applications. The students were given information about the introduction of the simulator and the model, the flow chart of the training plan, the content of the training plan, the environment, the locations of the materials. Before the application, all groups were given theoretical information about postpartum hemorrhage management for 2 hours with a power point presentation. Student Satisfaction and Self-Confidence Scale in Learning and Self-Efficacy Scale were applied as a pre-test after the information. Intervention group students were given practical training on postpartum hemorrhage assessment and management in the basic skills laboratory, accompanied by an adult standard patient care model, with a high-reality Gaumard Scientific brand, product code: S550.100 Noella simulator in the simulation laboratory of the Midwifery department. After the application, Student Satisfaction and Self-Confidence in Learning Scale, Self-Efficacy Scale and Early Postpartum Hemorrhage Management Skill Assessment Form were applied to all students as a post-test, and Scale for Evaluation of Simulation-Based Learning to the intervention group. Four weeks after the training, the Early Postpartum Hemorrhage Management Skill Assessment Form and Self-Efficacy Scale were applied to the students again as a follow-up test. After the research was completed, postpartum hemorrhage management was applied to the control group students with a high-reality simulator, accompanied by a scenario, so that all students could benefit from the benefits of simulation-based education. At the end of the simulation applications, an analysis session was held for the students accompanied by the video recordings taken during the applications. During the debriefing session, it was aimed to help students see their mistakes and organize their practices without judging by using a constructive language."

834,"This study focus on the effect of mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people who affected by the disaster in Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The main hypothesis to prove is the weight of the older people would be increase after consumed the mangrove sword bean food bar.

In detail, the study focus on the effect of mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people who live in Sumedang District, West Java Province. The study uses the experimental approach and the sample size was calculated by the G*Power software. The treatment group received 50g/day mangrove sword bean food bar (treatment intervention) and the control group received 50g/day sword bean food bar (control intervention) for 15 days. The data will be performed on descriptive analysis, chi-square, t-test and analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) to achieve the objectives of the study. The data will be taken from the questionnaires for the demographic data, the basic nutrition knowledge questionnaires and the basic food intake recall sheet. Besides, the anthropometry data will be collected through the weight measurement using digital weighing SECA by the trained members. The hypothesis that the weight of the older people will be increase after consumed the food bar will be proven.

This is a study of the effect of a mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people who affected by the disaster in Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The study population is the older people who affected by the disaster in Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The study type is an experimental study, using the randomized controlled trial design. The data collection is done by questionnaires and weight measurement of the study subjects using digital weighing SECA by the trained data collectors.

Treatment group received 50g/day mangrove sword bean food bar each day during 15 days. Control group received 50g/day sword bean food bar each day during 15 days. Both groups obtained balanced nutrition of older people education once at the first week of study. Compliance monitoring to control the food compliance by the subjects at two groups through home visit, weight measurement, three days food recall, and food bar distribution checking by trained enumerators."

835,"Pain is a complex phenomenon, with physical and psychological aspects. 25% of the current population experience persistent pain. Most of the time, the patient is not adequately treated, with negative consequences on their psychosocial health; this can lead to reduced effectiveness of the treatment. In recent years, it is being understood that treating only one of the two aspects, the physical or pain, does not guarantee pain relief in the long term. A holistic treatment plan is needed to have effective pain reduction. The proposed project aims to implement an innovative digital and tele-health platform that monitors and assesses, throughout the day, multiple clinical and non-clinical variables (physiological, psychological, social, clinical) simultaneously. It is intended to develop and assess such a system to objectively measure the different components of pain, including pain chronification using wearable technology, questionnaires, and other digital tools. In addition, it is intended to extract relevant information for the analysis of the pain trajectory (e.g., chronicity, intensity, location), the factors involved in its maintenance or reduction, and its impact on general health (i.e., quality of life). The proposed project aims to improve pain management, in collaboration with clinicians and other stakeholder. The objective is to deliver a more individualized treatment protocol, with better patient satisfaction and a reduced overall cost of treatment.
Unveiling Physiological and Psychosocial Pain Components With an Artificial Intelligence Based Telemonitoring Tool (pAIn-sense)

838,"1. Research background This study will investigate how robust and how comfortable the Earswitch device and algorithms are for people with assistive needs. It will also investigate whether there is a difference between the accuracy of TT movements for those with assistive technology needs and those who do not require assistive technology. 2. Aims and objectives These aims will be addressed in a single session on the same day which will be composed of a combination of questionnaire-based and technology-based tasks involving the Earswitch technology and software. Participants will be asked to complete a series of tasks to evaluate the robustness of the Earswitch technology, and to answer some general questions about their assistive technology needs to better understand how the software might be integrated with existing assistive technology to maximise usability. 3. Research questions The primary research question will investigate the robustness of the Earswitch device and software in detecting TT contractions as measured by the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve, and the area under the ROC curve (AUC) which will be calculated using manually labelled data provided by experts. While there currently is no standard objective performance measure for TT contractions we will also investigate whether there is a difference in the performance metrics to give an indication of the comparability between participants with and without assistive technology needs. It is anticipated that there will be no statistical difference in the performance metrics between a control group and those who have assistive technology needs. This means that we will not need to stratify the participants' data based on their assistive technology needs when calculating these metrics, and we will therefore be able to use the data of all participants to maximise the power of the statistical models. The secondary research questions will investigate if participants with assistive technology needs can accurately perform TT contractions compared to healthy participants, and to investigate how comfortable and easy participants find the Earswitch when they are performing TT movements. While we predict that there may be a statistical difference between the participant groups in terms of their ability to perform accurate TT movements, we suspect that there may not be a difference in the comfort and ease-of-use of the Earswitch device, and therefore there will not be a requirement to have two different control groups depending on whether someone with assistive technology needs requires an alternative fitting for the Earswitch. The outcomes of these research questions will inform and support the on-going development of the Earswitch product. 4. Participants: We will recruit a mixed healthy control group and people with assistive technology needs to participate in the study. The total number of participants is up to 400 people, with a mixture of healthy participants and patients with assistive technology needs. 5. Safety issues / expected adverse reactions and side effects for this study: It is anticipated that there will be minimal discomfort experienced during the study, as the participant will be able to remove the device at any time without any lasting adverse effects. If the participant experiences discomfort during the study they will be invited to complete an additional questionnaire regarding the source and intensity of the discomfort. If they experience any lasting adverse effects following their participation in the study, they will be able to contact the researchers directly to seek advice and/or follow-up. 6. Methods The study will take place in two different environments: a) either the participants' homes where they will receive a visit from a member of the research team who will set up the equipment based on a pre-defined schedule, and b) an equivalent lab-based setup that follows exactly the same schedule with the exception of the setting. This allows us to collect data from a wide range of participant characteristics in different locations, and to provide the best experience for the patients involved. The study will be divided into four parts: PART 1: Pre-study survey which will be conducted via telephone or video call with the participant and their carer. The participant will be asked about their typical daily routines, how they use their existing technology (including their main assistive technologies such as Communication Aids or Augmentative and Alternative Communication - AAC - devices), and how they would prefer to interact with the Earswitch when it is inserted into their ear. The survey will aim to answer the following research questions: • What types of assistive technology do our participants currently use? • What are the limitations and main frustrations with these devices? • How comfortable are people with their current assistive technologies? • How can we best integrate the Earswitch with the participants' existing assistive technology devices? • Do people like voice output in addition to head movement to send commands to their current assistive technology devices? • How easy do people find using the QTW switch scanning method, and how often do they use it? 839,"47 is a Randomized Control Trial evaluating the effect of 47% carbon dioxide administration supplemented with anesthetic on postoperative respiratory parameters in 200 high-risk patients undergoing elective abdominal surgery. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of high-risk patients undergoing elective abdominal surgery. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of the high carbon dioxide concentration in high-risk patients in improving postoperative outcomes. The secondary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of the high carbon dioxide concentration in high-risk patients in improving postoperative outcomes. To meet this objective, the investigators will employ a statistical test to compare the two study groups.

The investigators hypothesize that patients receiving high-carbon dioxide concentration will experience lesser post-operative respiratory complications as compared to the standard carbon dioxide concentration.

column1: 840,"In this study, we would like to compare 2 common procedures for the knee in general and for cartilage specifically. We want to do 2 things: first, we want to see if patients who have a cartilage defect between 2 and 5 centimeters treated with high tibial osteotomy, in combination with microfracture or autologous adipose tissue, have better outcomes at one year compared to the patients who receive high tibial osteotomy alone. Second, we would like to see whether any of the interventions, including high tibial osteotomy alone, improves patients function 12 months after surgery. To do this, we will measure your pain, function of the knee, and how well you can move your knee, with scores on a form known as the International Knee Documentation Committee Form. This form measures pain by asking you to rate how much discomfort you have, while moving, on a scale from 0 (no pain) to 100 (severe pain). The form also measures the change in how much you are able to move your knee joint. It is expected that at the conclusion of study, at twelve months post surgery, the patients receiving one of the treatment options (cartilage surgery) for cartilage defects will have better scores than patients having only high tibial osteotomy."

841,"İt is well-established that physical activity has many benefits to health, including reduction of the risk of non-communicable diseases including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome. According to the guidelines for exercise in healthy adults, at least 60 minutes of physical exercise spread throughout 5 or more days of the week at moderate to high intensity is recommended. However, it is suggested that 100-150 minutes of daily exercise or 2 to 3 hours more than the current guidelines may be essential to see these important health benefits. For individuals and groups of people who need to increase their daily physical activity (e.g., military and police personnel, athletes who have lost their physical exercise intensity and duration), this higher volume of exercise may be challenging to achieve. If the benefits of exercise could be achieved with a shorter total duration of daily training, a better adherence to exercise prescription could be expected.

Reducing total daily training time might influence some exercise-induced adaptations, such as improvements in skeletal muscle mass and fat oxidation. As a result, it is possible that shorter daily training periods may reduce the benefits that could be achieved with a daily training of at least 60 minutes. However, there are a number of possible mechanisms by which a lower total daily training time may lead to better performance, such as improved blood flow to the exercising muscles due to increased metabolic demand, which makes it possible to increase the training volume without over stressing the muscle. In addition, a recent study found that muscle damage caused by strenuous exercise may be reduced by increasing the time duration between sets of exercise. However, it is still largely unknown to what extent a reduction in daily exercise (with a total training time of 30 minutes) influences immuno-metabolic and performance adaptations in comparison with regularly exercising, and to what extent the time duration between sets of training (i.e., the recovery ratio) may be a mechanism that allows for optimal utilization of exercise training time.

Moreover, there is a lack of information about the effects of different recovery strategies during exercise training on the immune system and the health benefits derived from it. As a result, the aim of this study is to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery strategies to improve physical performance and health indices.
Input Text: Clinical Trial on a New Treatment in Patients With Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)

This is a Phase Ib/IIa, randomized, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and activity of rucaparib + tremelimumab versus sorafenib of first-line therapy for patients with unresectable HCC. In the Phase Ib, patients with HCC who have failed to standard liver preservation therapy or have a history of HCC with portal vein thrombosis will be treated to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the dose limit of Rucaparib with Tremelimumab. In the Phase IIa, patients with HCC will be assigned to receive rucaparib + tremelimumab or sorafenib according to the result of Phase Ib study to evaluate the efficacy and safety.

This is a Phase Ib/IIa, randomized, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and activity of rucaparib + tremelimumab versus sorafenib of first-line therapy for patients with unresectable HCC. In the Phase Ib, 6 patients with HCC who have failed to standard liver preservation therapy or have a history of HCC with portal vein thrombosis will be treated to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the dose limit of Rucaparib with Tremelimumab. In the Phase IIa, 65 patients with HCC will be randomly assigned to receive rucaparib + tremelimumab or sorafenib according to the result of Phase Ib study to evaluate the efficacy and safety.

A Phase Ib/IIa, Randomized, Open-Label, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Safety and Activity of rucaparib + tremelimumab Versus sorafenib of First-Line Therapy for Patients With Unresectable Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) (BATMAN-SOLO-1)
843,"Osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee is characterized by wear and tear of cartilage.
Currently, the gold standard for measuring cartilage health is micro-computed tomography (micro-CT), but these scanners are expensive and not widely available.

Conventional MRI provides information on the joint space. The joint space is the cavity between two surfaces of the articular cartilages. Joint space narrowing is associated with cartilage cartilage degradation, which is characteristic of OA.

However, during an MRI scan, patients lie still, either in the supine (flat on your back) or prone (on your stomach) position, without placing any weight on the hip or knee joints being imaged. We hypothesize that the position in which imaging is done influences joint volume. This implies that the assessment of joint space narrowing is position-dependent and can therefore not provide reliable information for diagnosis.
We recently found that joint volume is 30% larger when scanned in the weight-bearing vs non-weight-bearing position with the knee at full extension.
In view of this we hypothesize that joint volume is not only position, but also knee flexion dependence.
In this study with weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing scans and in flexion vs. extension of the knee.
We will assess the MRI signal of the bone marrow using Quantitative Fat Saturation (QFs).
Bone Marrow has a higher water content compared to bone, which results in a higher MRI signal. The higher the QFs, the worse the cartilage quality.

Healthy volunteers (n=14) and patients with knee OA(n=28) will participate in this study. All participants will perform four MRI scans in a single session, in which 3 position and flexion parameters will be varied: weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing together with a neutral, extended, and flexed knee position."

844,"Dysphagia, or disordered swallowing, is prevalent in almost all neurodegenerative conditions and results in the inability to effectively protect the lower airways from foreign (i.e., food/liquid) and endogenous (i.e., saliva) material [1-3]. An unfortunate consequence of dysphagia is aspiration pneumonia, which is a leading cause of death in Parkinson's disease (PD) [4-6]. Swallowing therapy has proven to be effective for the management of dysphagic symptoms in PD. Treatment is most often delivered in clinics once/week over short time periods with the expectation that exercises be completed at-home. However, these paradigms lack biofeedback to assess the accuracy and strength of the prescribed exercise and accountability to ensure completion of the exercise program. Without biofeedback or opportunities for long-term therapeutic intervention at-home, patients often regress to baseline levels [7-9]. The proposed research project seeks to test the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with PD. The significance of this project lies in the fact that dysphagia is expensive in terms of patient quality of life, health outcomes, and healthcare costs [10, 11] often increasing hospital costs by approximately 40% [12]. Thus, a targeted swallowing therapy system with biofeedback that can be utilized at-home may reduce hospitalizations secondary to dysphagia, help maintain therapeutic gains, and reduce the burden that dysphagia places on our healthcare system. sEMG is a therapy tool that has been used in rehabilitation practice for decades. Use of sEMG during swallowing therapy involves placement of electrodes under the chin (overlying the anterior belly of the digastric, mylohyoid and geniohyoid muscles) [13]. While the patient completes a swallowing task, electrodes detect collective muscle contractions associated with hyolaryngeal excursion - a biomechanical event critically important to airway safety and swallowing efficiency [14]. The patient can then see the waveform of the swallow displayed on a computer monitor. Measures of swallowing strength are derived from the amplitude of the waveform. sEMG hardware and associated software available in the marketplace today is cost prohibitive and thus, in the United States, only available for office-based swallowing intervention. sEMG provides external biofeedback regarding swallowing parameters by activating neural networks controlling both motor execution and imagery of the act of swallowing including the pre- and postcentral gyrus, inferior frontal gyrus, basal ganglia, insula, and cerebellum [15]. Research has shown that exercise programs incorporating biofeedback promote significant physiologic change that is maintained over time in patients with dysphagia [14, 16-18]. Patients with PD benefit greatly from biofeedback exercises for respiratory muscle strength and lingual strengthening programs and have even been found to maintain the gains made in therapy with at-home programs [7, 16, 19]. A limitation of the currently available sEMG programs is that research studies have solely focus on the strength aspects of the swallowing (amplitude of the waveform) while failing to address the dynamic, skill-based parameters such as timing and volitional initiation that is captured in waveform morphology. Skill based swallowing training focuses on the precision of movements; and this is especially important for patients with PD [14]. Additionally, traditional sEMG systems in the US lack the ability for clinicians to modulate swallowing targets during tasks, which, according to principles of neuroplasticity, is essential for maximizing therapeutic results. The BiSSKiT program is a well-researched office-based biofeedback system that adheres to principles of neuroplasticity and incorporates skill training in addition to strength training [14]. Developed in New Zealand and recently approved by the US FDA, this program has been converted into an affordable and accessible home-based application for tablet computers. This hybrid BiSSKiT system incorporates clinical visits and home-based skill/strength training and shows promise to change current therapy delivery models. Although exciting, there is a paucity of data regarding the use of the BiSSKiT with daily home therapy focused on strength and skill based swallowing training on changes to swallowing safety and efficiency in people with PD. This study seeks to evaluate the impact of this device on swallowing outcomes compared to traditional swallowing therapy"

column1: The use of cognitive functions such as memory is essential for the execution of daily activities and represents a crucial element for autonomy maintenance during aging. It is known that the physiological cognitive decline associated with aging also involves memory and can significantly impact the older person’s independence. According to the Alzheimer’s Association, 5.8 million Americans are living with Alzheimer’s, and this number is expected to increase up to 14 million by 2060. In the same period, the number of Americans aged 65 and older is expected to double from 54 to 116 million. The rapid increase in the number of people affected by cognitive decline represents a great concern from a public health point of view, as there is still no known cure for this condition. These data emphasize the need for more effective preventive and treatment strategies for older adults to reduce their disability and help them to remain functional and autonomous in the long term. Previous researches have shown that the majority of cognitive impairment cases remain undetected. Furthermore, the most commonly used evaluation tools are often insufficient in assessing the cognitive potential of an individual. The subjective cognitive decline (SCD) is a relatively new concept that has emerged from the recognition that, for most people, cognitive changes appear to precede the onset of objective cognitive impairment. SCD refers to the subjective experience of cognitive decline that the individual cannot explain with a physical disease or substance use. The SCD might represent the transition between a healthy cognitive status and the onset of mild cognitive impairment (MCI). MCI is considered a prodromal state for the onset of dementia, representing a mild condition in which individuals may experience cognitive impairment.

Different treatment options for the SCD have been considered in the last years, such as pharmacological, surgical, cognitive-behavioral, and computer-based interventions. However, it appears that several interventions such as transcranial brain stimulation and cognitive training seem to delay the development of MCI and dementia in older adults. In particular, this study will assess the effect of combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) combined with 5 weeks of strategic memory training in healthy older adults or subjects with subjective cognitive decline (SCD). Methods: A randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trial will be conducted. This study is based on the hypothesis that the application of non-invasive brain stimulation (online tDCS) during memory training can enhance memory training efficacy in older adults with SCD. The intervention protocol consists of 5 sessions from Monday to Friday, of 2/3 sessions per week (1 hour/day), and the intervention will be carried out for 5 weeks. Participants randomized into the experimental group (n = 29) will receive active tDCS (2millA, 20 minutes/day). Participants randomized into the control group (n = 30) will receive sham tDCS (0millA, 20 minutes/day). The following tests will be administered immediately before (T0) and after the intervention program to assess memory performance: associative learning; list learning; word-pairs learning; name face learning; place learning, text learning, and grocery learning.

Inclusion Criteria: BMI between 18-28 MMSE ≥ 24. GDS < e uguale 11. Age between 65 and 85 years. Educational level ≥ 5 years. Exclusion Criteria: Pre-existing cognitive impairment (e.g. aphasia, neglect). Dementia. Severe disturbances in consciousness. Concomitant severe psychiatric disease or other neurological conditions (e.g. depression and behavioral disorders). Motor or sensory diseases that may interfere with test execution or strategic memory training.

847,"1.3 million people are living with heart failure in the UK and it causes 70,000 deaths a year. There is high disease burden which can be further compounded by the difficulties in accurately identifying high-risk populations due to the lack of a validated prediction model and high false positive test rates. 2. This study aims to develop and validate a prediction model using a for predicting new onset heart failure in the UK. The investigators will develop and validate a prediction model (algorithm) for predicting heart failure within primary care health electronic health record system (EHR). It will consist of a set of pre-determined variables drawn from the population electronic data source. The data from the data source will be anonymised and all personal identifiable information will be removed before it is encrypted with a custom symmetric and asymmetric cryptography methods. A random sample from the data source (1% to reduce burden) will be used to develop predictive algorithms and validate their predictive performance. A novel prediction algorithm will be developed through machine learning algorithms to identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new onset heart failure within a specific time window. The predictive performance of all algorithms will then be compared under the same conditions to identify the best performing model. The investigators also plan to compare the performance of the selected model with the Framingham predictor. 3. The model will use all available data collected in the EHR to predict the risk of new onset heart failure among patients in the following risk groups: (i) patients with known chronic coronary disease or hypertensive cardiovascular disease; (ii) patients with chronic and/or severe kidney or liver disease; (iii) patients aged above 60 years old; and (iv) patients who experienced a non-cardiac hospital admission in the last 6 months. The EHRs contain large amounts of anonymized and real-time data which can be processed and analyzed to identify trends and patterns. The investigators will use a random sample of patients to develop the model. To validate the model, the investigators will use 11 independent population EHR systems in different UK research networks. The validation will be carried out on an independent cohort of patients based on a 5-year risk prediction window."

848,"1. Context of the study: the FSFI® score decreases after hysterectomy, but so far no recommendations exist as to when to resume sexual intercourse after hysterectomy. In 2022, the French government is introducing a healthcare insurance refund policy for the hysterectomy procedure for patients with a benign gynecological disease. In the future, patients undergoing conservative and non-conservative hysterectomy operations in the Groupe Hospitalier Est Marseillois (GHEM) department will be asked whether they want to benefit from this refund policy. 2. Purpose of the study: we will compare two groups: one, whose postoperative instructions will indicate a resumption of sexual activity from 4 weeks after the operation and the other from 8 weeks postoperatively. Our goal is to determine the recommended time to resume sexual intercourse after hysterectomy for sexually active patients without a previous history of postoperative complications. The primary endpoint is the FSFI® score. 3. Patients: using a randomization, we will create a database of patients undergoing hysterectomy operations eligible for this study with patients included over a two-year period (30 patients per month). Inclusion and exclusion criteria: 3.1. Inclusion criteria: the patient is 18 years of age or over the patient is Francophone patient is sexually active, patient agrees to not have an operation within the next two years, patient agrees to not have an elective endocrine or surgical treatment in the next two years, hysterectomy is performed for benign pathology, informed consent is signed. 3.2. Exclusion criteria: previous history of pelvic inflammatory disease, previous history of postoperative complications, previous history of sexual assault or trauma, patient refuses to answer the questionnaire. The patient group has been chosen for its homogeneity (similar age, socio-economic status, etc.). 4. Main analysis: the results will be analyzed by the intention to treat principle. We will compare the FSFI® scores and the time to resumption of sexual intercourse in the two groups of patients depending on the recommended time. 5. Statistic evaluation Criteria: The results will be analyzed by the intention to treat principle. We will compare the FSFI® scores and the time to resumption of sexual intercourse in the two groups of patients depending on the recommended time between 226 and 250 days of amenorrhea. The primary outcome will be analyzed with a parametric unpaired t-test (if the data is normally distributed) otherwise with the Mann-Whitney test. The secondary outcomes will be analyzed with McNemar's chi-squared test. 6. Discussion: the lack of available data makes the identification of the appropriate timeframe of concern for both patients and healthcare professionals. Moreover, in a context where patients with benign gynecological disease are eligible for a health insurance refund, it is important to identify the recommended time to allow them to benefit from that refund while minimizing the risk of postoperative complications."

849,"Overview This is a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, two-by-two factorial, interventional, parallel group, multicentre study with four study arms. All participants will receive two injections; either two placebo injections or two testosterone undecanoate (Nebido) injections given once in week 0 (baseline), then once in week 3. Those randomised to the resistance exercise training (RET) group will undertake an average of 2 × 40-min training sessions per week for 32 weeks, with weeks 11 to 22 representing a detraining period where all training cesses and all participants return to their habitual daily physical activity. The RET period will consist of two 10-week periods and RET is standardized to enable direct comparison between cohorts. The first training period commences immediately after the second injections, while the second RET period will begin 12 weeks after the first. The exercise sessions will be supervised by members of the study team. During both RET periods, the participants randomised to the saline placebo group will continue to receive two placebo injections as before. The participants randomised to the testosterone group will cease all injections after week 10. During weeks 11 to 22 they will continue to undergo supervised training while simultaneously remaining detrained (not receiving any additional injections). During weeks 23 to 32 the participants from the testosterone group will undergo a second period of structured training. Thus, during the 32-week study period, all participants will receive either two placebo injections or two injections of testosterone undecanoate. The study participants will be recruited from the general population through advertisements placed nationally.
1) To examine the effects of 10 weeks of testosterone undecanoate on muscular size, morphology, strength and power and muscular and metabolic function in healthy middle-aged men, and;
2) To determine the effects of 10 weeks of exercise training in conjunction with 10 weeks of testosterone undecanoate injection on the same muscular and metabolic parameters.

The participants will be recruited through public advertisements, as well as from existing community networks, sports clubs and via direct invitations to all eligible participants. There will be no restrictions on the type of exercise performed prior to participation or entry requirements regarding health or fitness. Prior to participation, all eligible participants will first receive a medical screen to ensure they are in good general health and meet all inclusionary and exclusionary criteria. All screening data will be used to confirm that participants have entered the study at an appropriate level of training and that they are able to safely participate in the study. Eligible participants will be randomised into one of the four study arms; testosterone + RET, testosterone + placebo, exercise training + RET, or exercise training + placebo. Once randomised to study arm then they will then undergo a medical examination and collection of blood and skeletal muscle samples, as well as completion of a range of physical fitness tests. For those allocated to the exercise training groups, they will then undergo a series of functional tests assessing their general fitness before and after the exercise training period. Participants will be advised to refrain from doing any strenuous physical activity during the week before all visits. They must also refrain from taking any over-the-counter or prescription pain killers the day before each visit and from doing any exercise (except normal daily activity) or from consuming alcohol (>21 units/week) on the day before each visit. During each visit, participants will complete an array of questionnaires on physical activity (PA), body image, quality of life (QoL), psychological functioning (including anabolic-androgenic steroid use and intention to use questionnaires), blood collection and body composition measures. A subset of the participants will also be invited to take part in brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) measures, as well as various muscle biopsy trials. The exercise training intervention consists of two 10-week periods and all participants will then undergo a 12-week detraining period. Thus, the exercise training period is standardized across all study participants, while the testosterone injection period is standardized across participants from the testosterone groups only.

Eligible participants will be selected from healthy, community-dwelling men based on the following inclusionary and exclusionary criteria: (1) Healthy (no apparent illness or disease); (2) Sedentary (i.e. exercise"
850,"1,487 people from 5 municipalities and 29 localities of the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires will be selected randomly and invited to participate in the survey.

Input: To study the seroprevalence of dengue in adolescents and adults of the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires, immunoglobulins G will be determined against the dengue virus using Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) for 1,487 randomly selected people using a probabilistic sampling strategy from 5 strata constructed by a functional relationship between the income quintiles obtained in the Annual Household Survey (AHS) and the variables that were surveyed in the census. To study the serotypes of detected seropositive cases and determine the possible cross-reactivity to other flaviviruses, neutralization tests will be performed for the Immunoglobulin G positive population to determine the specific dengue serotype among the positives as well as to confirm that non-serotype dengue antisera reactivity is due to other flaviviruses. In conclusion, in the present case, the intervention would consist of selecting individuals for the determination and confirmation of dengue infection.

To study the seroprevalence of dengue in adolescents and adults of the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires, immunoglobulins G will be determined against the dengue virus using Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) for 1,487 randomly selected people using a probabilistic sampling strategy from 5 strata constructed by a functional relationship between the income quintiles obtained in the Annual Household Survey (AHS) and the variables that were surveyed in the census. To study the serotypes of detected seropositive cases and determine the possible cross-reactivity to other flaviviruses, neutralization tests will be performed for the Immunoglobulin G positive population to determine the specific dengue serotype among the positives as well as to confirm that non-serotype dengue antisera reactivity is due to other flaviviruses.
Study the seroprevalence of heterotype dengue in adolescents and adults of the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires.

All participants who agree to participate by signing an informed consent form will undergo a finger prick for the determination of Immunoglobulin G antibodies measured by ELISA. In a subgroup of persons who test positive, they will be invited to have blood drawn for neutralization determination in order to study serotypes and the presence of other flaviviruses.
Inclusion Criteria: Age ≥18 at the time of signing the informed consent. Resident of the Buenos Aires metropolitan areaExclusion Criteria: To be ≤17 years old. Inability to give informed consent.
To be ≤17 years old. Inability to give informed consent.

To better understand the epidemiology and socio-economic determinants of dengue in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires. Thus, the immunological status of adolescents and adults will be investigated using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay and laboratory neutralization for serological dengue viral antigens.
1. Primary outcome: Seroprevalence. Percentage of the population with Immunoglobulin G antibodies against dengue fever."

853,"Rationale: Prediabetes and Diabetes: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic health conditions worldwide. It has long been associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The current prevalence is ~9% for people over 18 years of age in the USA (1). Moreover, prevalence rates are expected to continue increasing, as ~50% of adults in the USA are classified as having prediabetes, and approximately one third of diagnosed prediabetic individuals will progress to diabetes within 7 years (2). Additionally, several lines of evidence, including recent studies, indicate that prediabetes itself is a pathological state associated with increased risks of morbidity and mortality compared to patients who remain prediabetic (3).

Thus, there is urgent and high unmet need to develop new therapeutics that effectively treat or prevent the conditions of prediabetes and type 2 diabetes (T2D) for the millions of people suffering from them worldwide. This project will test the hypothesis that mitigators present in food can significantly improve glycemic control.

Our Unique Opportunities and Expertises: Our previous studies have identified dietary mitigators that impact glucose control in both healthy volunteers and patients with T2D (4-10) and those mitigators include different proportions of fat and fiber (especially oleic acid and pea fiber), vitamin D (11). In addition, we have shown that daily exercise can moderate the post-prandial glucose response (4,12). Our team is currently developing multi-omics analytic pipelines to correlate blood metabolomics with glucose control and have shown this in patients as part of other ongoing studies. These studies will build on decades of research at our group, and will expand the expertise of our group on gut microbiome-dietary interplay in diabetes.

Our Current Approach: Our current experimental approach is detailed in the flowchart that is provided by the clinicalTrials.gov website. Briefly, participants will be first screened for eligibility, those who qualify will undergo a glucose tolerance test, and will be asked to record all the meals for 7 days prior to joining the study. After they are enrolled, participants will be provided with the meals and a diet tracking app during the 10-day study. At the start of the study 100,000 blood will be collected through a finger prick device (Tasso) and will be collected at different time points as described above. Participants will undergo a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and a series of metabolic tests (steady state plasma glucose (SSPG), intravenous glucose tolerance test (IGITT)), and a isoglycemic intravenous glucose infusion (IIGI) as described in the protocol. We plan to enroll 25 participants who will all undergo a dietary intervention as described in detail above. In addition, we may recruit additional 25 participants who can repeat the protocols twice and they will be asked to repeat each protocol after a 3-week washout period to further improve the statistical power and the data robustness of the study. Thereafter, the blood will be processed and different analytes will be profiled by targeted and untargeted mass spectrometry-based proteomics (by Olink proteomics) and metabolomics methods. All the generated information will be analyzed, interpreted, and correlated with glycemic control. Furthermore, the participants will fill out a questionnaire and will be asked for feedback at the end of the study.

Study Plan and Potential Impact: The study will last for 11 months, starting from July 1^st^, 2021. In the meantime, we will make the appropriate preparations to guarantee the smooth running of the study. This will include procuring and preparing the different types of meals and materials that will be consumed and administered to the participants, recruiting the relevant administrative personnel for monitoring the study, recruiting additional personnel for administering the protocols and processing the generated samples, procuring and setting up the analytical equipment (LC-MS and Olink), as well as recruiting the collaborators who will help us conduct the metabolic studies (SSPG, IIGI and IIGITT), as described above. We will also use this preparatory time to create a participant recruitment plan, create and finalize the informed consent form, finalize the questionnaire that will be administered to the participants at the end of the study, prepare and finalize the study protocol, and identify all the safety and privacy concerns that"

854,"25% of all pregnancies are associated with excessive use of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis. This study will compare women receiving intervention to those receiving standard care to assess if the intervention is superior to standard care. It is hypothesized that the intervention will be superior to standard care on improving maternal drinking during pregnancy, infant birthweight, and maternal drinking while breastfeeding.

It is hypothesized that intervention will improve maternal drinking during pregnancy and decrease tobacco and cannabis use; and improve infant birthweight, maternal drinking while breastfeeding and infant anthropometry.
Prospective cohort study, 3 arms (Usual Care, Intervention, and Control)

Arm One: Usual CareThis group will receive the same standard of care, including routine visits. They will receive a basic referral to a relevant facility in terms of reducing their use of drugs. There will be no direct contact with the research team;

Arm Two: InterventionThe Intervention Arm consists of 12 weekly sessions and up to 3 monthly reminders in the first 12 weeks post pregnancy. The intervention includes weekly text messages based on cognitive behavioral therapy for pregnant women to encourage abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis use; incentives contingent on non-use of alcohol and non-use of tobacco and cannabis. All women will receive a R35.00 voucher for text messages (with R10.00 deducted per text) contingent on meeting their treatment goals for tobacco, alcohol, and cannabis for the week. The intervention will also include social support from a research assistant or nurse.

Arm Three: ControlArm Three will receive the same intervention and support as in the Intervention arm, but no vouchers will be used. This will include weekly text messages to encourage abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis use; incentives contingent on non-use of alcohol, non-use of tobacco, and cannabis; and social support from a nurse or research assistant. Women in the control group will only receive R10 per text, the 12-week control intervention will end at gestational week 20 or after delivery. This group will receive the same level of social support during the intervention, but will not receive the R35 incentive voucher for text messages.
Participants completed the World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0) immediately before and after the 12-week intervention in the three arms.

Participants completed the World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0) and the Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System Tool (PRAMS) by phone or face to face interview at 3-month postpartum.
1. The women in all arms of the study will be pregnant or breastfeeding with less than 12 months postpartum.

2. Test positive in alcohol use by urinalysis (i.e., EtG), test positive in tobacco or cannabis use by urinalysis (i.e., cotinine and THC), have a negative HIV test, plan to complete antenatal care at the current clinic and remain in the area for at least 3 months.
1. Women who report serious medical problems threatening their current pregnancy or current suicidal thoughts or attempts in the past month. These women will be provided necessary referrals.

855,"This project investigates the utility of Operant Conditioning therapy paired with Non-invasive Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technology, to reduce phantom limb pain (PLP) after limb amputation. The purpose of this research is to test whether the pain can be modulated through this non-invasive technology, which is a safe and risk-free method to induce this type of pain relief. This proposed study will develop a novel therapy to improve the sensory feedback of the amputated and phantom limbs. Through this technology we will be able to modulate the pain sensation and decrease the pain intensity and severity.
This project is expected to produce data that will change and improve the current clinical practices, and lead to significant improvements of phantom limb pain."

856,"In previous studies at our hospital, it was found that catheterization of the axillary vein has a relatively high success rate and was often chosen in patients with shock. It was noted that the axillary vein catheter had an advantage in patients who could not tolerate catheterization at the femoral or jugular venous puncture site, or in patients where the femoral or jugular veins were unsuitable. Ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization has been reported as a safe alternative means of central venous catheterization. But at present, there is no unified standard for puncture and operation. This study retrospectively analyzed the accuracy and safety of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in a trauma intensive care unit in a large tertiary hospital from Oct.1, 2021 to April 30,2023.
A.1 Member State Concerned: Spain - AEMPS
