Phase I/II Study of Niraparib (3M-170-48) Monotherapy in Combination with Docetaxel in Males with Metastatic, Hormone-Related Prostate Cancer and Whose Cancers have a Defect in Homologous Repair (HR), Defined by a Deleterious germline or somatic Genetic Alteration of HR-related Genes as Identified by Next Generation Sequencing or by a Defect in HR as Identified by PCR.

A Phase I/II Study of Niraparib (3M-170-48) Monotherapy in Combination with Docetaxel in Males with Metastatic, Hormone-Related Prostate Cancer and Whose Cancers have a Defect in Homologous Repair (HR), Defined by a Deleterious germline or somatic Genetic Alteration of HR-related Genes as Identified by Next Generation Sequencing or by a Defect in HR as Identified by PCR

Inclusion Criteria: Male prostate cancer patients at least 18 years of age. Patient has a measurable or evaluable lesion, defined as at least one lesion that can be accurately measured in at least one dimension (longest dimension to be recorded for non-nodal lesions, shortest dimension to be recorded for nodal lesions) as≥10 mm with conventional techniques or as≥15 mm with spiral computer tomography (CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and this lesion must be documented in medical records or on a new baseline scan performed during screening period. Patient has an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status of <2. Patients must have histologic or cytologic verification of prostate adenocarcinoma defined as a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma on a needle core biopsy, a trans-rectal prostate biopsy, or prostatectomy specimen. Evidence of metastases (M1), based upon either bone scan or radiographic imaging documenting the presence of metastatic disease. Patients eligible for this study must have a lesion that is amenable to biopsy. The lesion should be amenable to biopsy so that research tissue collection will be possible. Patient with a documented deleterious genetic alteration in a HR-related gene as identified through Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) or who has an identified HR defect as defined by PCR. Have measurable disease. Exclusion Criteria: Prior treatment with poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP)-inhibitor therapy or treatment with PARP inhibitors in combination with other therapeutics for the treatment of cancer. Receipt of prior treatment with radionuclide therapy within 4 weeks or within 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) of the first dose of study therapy. Receipt of treatment with chemotherapy or small molecules within 2 weeks or within 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to the first dose of niraparib or the first dose of docetaxel in combination with niraparib. Major Surgery within 2 weeks before the first dose of niraparib or within 4 weeks before the first dose of docetaxel in combination with niraparib with the following exceptions: Surgery for wound related complications and other procedures not expected to result in a systemic response such as insertion of a central line and/or percutaneous biopsy procedures. Have any of the following abnormal laboratory values: Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) <1.5 × 109/L. Platelet count <75,000/mm3. Hemoglobin level <9.0 g/dL. Total bilirubin >1.5 × ULN, unless due to hemolysis or Gilbert's Syndrome. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) >2.5 × ULN (or 5 × ULN if due to liver metastases). Serum creat"

858,"1. Purpose: This study aims to evaluate the effect of rehabilitative ultrasonography (RUSI) on muscles function among participants with abdominal adiposity. 2. Background: The core muscles play an important role in spinal posture, breathing, and body movements. The contraction of the core muscles stabilizes the trunk and improves spinal posture. It also enhances breathing movements and protects the spinal cord by preventing the intrusion of the abdomen into the spinal canal. The core muscles include the diaphragm, transverse abdominis, multifidus, and pelvic floor muscles. These muscles are located in the deepest layers of the abdominal muscles and are collectively known as ""core stability muscles."" The core muscles help maintain the stability and alignment of the spine during physical activities and provide a good foundation for all movements of the body. The most common method for evaluating the contraction of the diaphragm muscle is by ultrasound imaging which provides a dynamic assessment of muscle thickness and activity. However, the use of this imaging technique for evaluating muscle activity of other core muscles is limited by inadequate visualization of the affected area in some positions. Furthermore, the ability to evaluate the activity of all core muscles at the same time during a single intervention is challenging. 3. Methods: A randomized controlled clinical study was designed to investigate if ultrasound image-guided therapeutic exercise rehabilitation using a cavitation ultrasound device is more effective than a combination of both for the diagnosis of muscle function among patients with abdominal adiposity compared with a control group. A total of 45 subjects between the ages of 25-45 were included in the study. The main criterion was participants who had waist circumference between 102cm for men and 88cm for women. Subjects were randomly assigned to experimental (n=15) or control (n=15) group. The experimental group performed Ultrasound guided (RUSI) Rehabilitative Ultrasound Imaging (RUSI) treatment with the use of diaphragm (Breathing) or transverse abdominis (contraction) exercises. In order to compare the effectiveness of the applied methods, another group was treated with the same protocol using a cavitation ultrasound device as (RUSI) for the diagnosis of muscle function among patients with abdominal adiposity. The investigators aim at evaluating the effect of RUSI on subjects' diaphragm and transverse abdominis function by measuring diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio. The researchers also aim to evaluate abdominal adiposity through waist circumference and transverse abdominis thickness using the same technique. The investigator hypothesis is that ultrasound imaging-guided rehabilitative therapy using a cavitation ultrasound device is more effective than a combination of both for the diagnosis of muscle function in patients with abdominal adiposity."

859,"BACKGROUND: The relationship between atrial fibrillation (AF) and the left atrium (LA) substrate remains unclear. LA fibrosis is linked to the incidence of AF, but the AF incidence is also influenced by the amount of LA fibrosis. Moreover, a large proportion of atrial fibrillation episodes are short in duration (less than 30 seconds). The clinical impact of these silent AF episodes, with no clinical symptoms, remains uncertain. Finally, silent ischemic stroke may also result from small, embolic strokes. These strokes tend to be lacunar strokes (also known as silent infarcts), which have been linked to AF and to smaller vessel disease. Therefore, silent strokes are a potential risk factor for AF.

METHODS AND ANALYSIS: In this prospective pilot study, subjects aged 18 years and over, with cryptogenic ischemic stroke (with documented cerebral infarction by cerebral angioscan or cerebral MRI), who are undergoing cardiac magnetic resonance and scheduled for implantation of an implantable loop recorder device, will be included. A T2-wighted magnetic resonance imaging sequence will be performed to identify small ischemic lesions (lacunar strokes) in the brain territory. A magnetic resonance image of the left atrium will be performed as part of the cardiac magnetic resonance examination to assess the amount of LA fibrosis by means of late gadolinium enhancement technique. Magnetic resonance imaging features such as left atrial thrombus (in the patients without history/risk factors for AF) and left atrial appendage thrombus will also be recorded. 24 hours ECG monitoring will be performed using an external 12-lead holter. Patients with an interval greater than 2750 ms between QRS complexes and RR interval that will be identified will be excluded from the study. External monitoring for up to 24 hours is considered to be of limited value to detect short episodes of atrial fibrillation/flutter, so the patients will be followed up using implantable loop recorder for up to 3 years."

860,"---------------- This will be a multi-institutional open-label randomized phase 2 trial, comparing 3 therapy arms with the combination of capivasertib , goserelin/ fulvestrant and durvalumab to a control arm with goserelin/ fulvestrant with or without durvalumab in premenopausal patients with metastatic or locally advanced, ER positive breast cancer. A total of 200 patients will be randomized to the 3 treatment arms according to a 1:1:1 ratio to provide a meaningful comparison of capivasertib combined with goserelin/ fulvestrant with or without durvalumab vs the control arm of goserelin/ fulvestrant in premenopausal patients with ER positive metastatic or locally advanced breast cancer."
Readmission Risk Score - Pilot at University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC)
Patient Readmission, COPD, Chronic Obstructive, Heart Failure, Diabetes Mellitus Poor Control, Hypertension, Pneumonia
* Other: Standard of Care + Additional Educational Training

Inclusion Criteria: Patient is in Observation (and is expected to be admitted) or is admitted as an Inpatient Encounter. Consider eligible patients in any unit except Emergency Department. Patient has RecuR Score available 24 hours after start of data collection in EHR. Patient is at least 18 years of age. Participant is willing and able to provide informed consent for the trial. Participant has a RecuR Score greater than or equal to 3; OR Participant has a RecuR Score greater than or equal to 2 and length of stay greater than 10 days; OR Participant has a RecuR Score greater than or equal to 2 with admitting diagnosis of COPD, CHF, Diabetes with elevated HbA1c, Hypertension, or pneumonia; OR Participant has any RecuR Score AND current admission is a readmission where participant was not enrolled during any prior admission. Exclusion Criteria: Participants who were enrolled in the pilot during an earlier inpatient hospital encounter. Participants that have encounters having length of stay less than 48 hours or greater than 30 days. Participants who are not expected to be discharged home, e.g., patients who were admitted from skilled nursing facility (SNF) and are expected to be discharged to SNF. Participants who lack capacity to sign the consent and participate in the study. Participants who are not fluent English. Participants who are already receiving home health care. Participants who the nursing team believes will require home health care post- hospitalization. Post-Hoc Exclusion Criteria: Patients who leave against medical advice.

Interventional Model Description: This is a two-arm interventional study where participants will be randomized to receive either the Standard of Care or Enhanced Care treatment. Participants in the Standard of Care arm will receive the Transitional Care protocol most commonly used for patients at the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC). Participants in the Enhanced Care arm will receive the interventions in the Standard of Care arm plus the additional protocols unique to Enhanced Care arm (Social Determinants of Health Wheel assessment in the University of Maryland Medical System electronic medical record, coordination of home health services, and additional diagnosis education). These arms are designed to ensure that participants receive the same high quality of care that they would have received before the study while also focusing on some added interventions from the enhanced care arm to help determine if these additional interventions help improve patient outcomes.

Diagnosis education includes verbal 1:1 patient education by the Transitional Nurse Navigator (TNN) and a folder with Epic printed education and other handouts specific to that disease process. The Community Health Worker (CHW) or TNN will schedule the appointments for the PCP and other specialists within 1 week when available. Offer resources in the community post the 1:1 meeting with the patient to meet specific access to care challenges identified for that patient by the TNN or CHW. Provide weekly follow-up calls for one month by TNN or delegate. Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) assessment. Screenings by CHW regarding patients' SDOH and documentation in the EHR (Epic) of this SDOH assessment. If a patient demonstrates a need, a CHW will help identify and offer opportunities for the patient.

column1: Cooling and dilution therapy have been used extensively to protect the brain from injury in the setting of neurological events such as stroke. Cooling and dilution therapy has been shown to prevent the progression of injury to normal tissue by creating a state of relative ischaemia and may offer cardioprotection via a similar mechanism in cardiac disease. This proposed trial, the Cooling and Dilution for Cardioprotection During Revascularisation for ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (CoDi-STEMI) trial, is the first evaluation of the effect of such a therapy in a clinical setting.
The primary objective of this single-centre pilot randomised-controlled feasibility trial is to assess:
Recruitment rate: To assess the feasibility of the trial by measuring the number of patients recruited per month.
Feasibility: To assess the feasibility of the trial by measuring the number of studies where all the planned measurements have been collected compared to total studies.
Safety: To assess the safety of this intervention compared to standard care by measuring the number of adverse events in the treatment arm vs. control.
Secondary objectives of this trial are to measure the effect of cooling and dilution in the setting of primary percutaneous intervention in STEMI on:
The Index of microvascular resistance (IMR) 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Fractional flow reserve (FFR) 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Coronary flow reserve (CFR) 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Resistive reserve ratio (RRR) 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Myocardial blush grade 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) flow 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
ST segment resolution 10 mins after completion of percutaneous coronary intervention and study infusion.
Haemodynamic compromise from baseline to 12 hours.
Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) at 48 hours, 6 months.
Wall motion score index (WMSI) at 48 hours, 6 months.
Global longitudinal strain (GLS) at 48 hours, 6 months.
Peak high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T (hs-cTnT, ng/l) at 1-3 days.
N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP, ng/l) at 1-3 days.
First pass microvascular obstruction extent (FP MVO) at 6 months.
First pass microvascular obstruction extent (FP MVO) adjusted for area at-risk at 6 months.
Initial infarct size (LGE) adjusted for area at-risk at 6 months.
Final MSI (area-at-risk minus initial infarct size/area-at-risk) at 6 months.
Left ventricular end-diastolic volume index (LVEDVI) at 6 months.
1. Primary endpoint: Recruitment rate: To assess the feasibility of the trial by measuring the number of patients recruited per month.
1. Secondary endpoint: Primary endpoint: Recruitment rate: To assess the feasibility of the trial by measuring the number of patients recruited per month."

864,"1 in 10 women worldwide suffers from perinatal depression or anxiety (PDA). These are significant mental health disorders that have a negative impact on infant health, and may cause behavioral, physical, and cognitive deficits. The prevalence of PDA in the US, Europe, and other western countries are increasing, and the rising economic/health care burden is alarming. A potential source of improvement for PDA is gut dysbiosis. The purpose of this pilot study is to test the feasibility and acceptability of a novel, combined, gut-nourishing intervention that includes dietary modification, fish oil supplementation, and combination probiotic supplementation, as a means to improve mental health outcomes for high-risk pregnant women suffering from PDA. A total of 100 women will be recruited and will be randomized into four study groups. These include: Group A- fish oil/probiotics/dietary modification, Group B- fish oil/dietary modification, Group C-probiotics/dietary modification, and Group D- fish oil/placebo, control group. Data on maternal and infant dietary habits, gut microbiome, mental health status will be collected to assess the feasibility and acceptability of this approach, and to identify potential outcomes that could potentially be translated into effective nutritional interventions to improve maternal mental health outcomes. This study will help us understand the role of gut microbiome in the etiology of PDA, and if a combined gut- nourishing approach can improve outcomes for high-risk pregnancies."

865,"¡Viva! is an adaptive lifestyle weight loss program focused on supporting behavioral lifestyle changes to reduce weight for Latina breast cancer survivors. ¡Viva! is a SMART intervention that uses individualized, adaptive randomization to test a number of behavioral interventions within an individually tailored weight loss framework. Based on our Stage I proof of concept data, we hypothesize that ¡Viva! will improve weight loss outcomes through a SMART intervention design. We believe our adaptive design and individualized randomization will accelerate the adoption of evidencebased intervention and will better help practitioners implement behavioral weight loss interventions."

Much of fertility treatments and outcomes are based on retrospective studies, meta-analysis, or review papers. However, there are still some questions regarding optimal doses of gonadotropins in the stimulation cycle, in particular regarding the total dose delivered and, to some extent, the rate of dose escalation. Several studies have been published and even randomized clinical trials have been performed, comparing the use of gonadotropins in the stimulation cycle. The results of these studies vary dramatically, as does the methodology used. The aim of this retrospective study is to try to answer those remaining unanswered questions by combining the data from patients undergoing IVF/ICSI stimulated with follitropin delta who either received an individualized multiple dose regimen or a flat dose regimen over time. This approach allows us to evaluate what is the difference in the two groups in terms of outcome of the patient.

Are there differences in the number of good quality blastocysts, fertilization rates, clinical pregnancy rates, implantation rates between patients receiving high dosage follitropin delta during the first 3 days of stimulation, and patients receiving a standard dose protocol? How do differences vary depending of patient characteristics such as age, BMI and AMH?

Are there differences in the number of good quality blastocysts, fertilization rates, clinical pregnancy rates, implantation rates between patients receiving high dosage follitropin delta during the first 3 days of stimulation, in combination with a booster of highly purified hMG, and patients receiving a standard dose protocol?

Are there differences in cycle cancellation and cumulative cancellation rates between patients receiving high dosage follitropin delta during the first 3 days of stimulation, and patients receiving a standard dose protocol? How do these differences vary depending on patient characteristics such as age, BMI and AMH?
Data collection is planned to start in March, 2020. We plan to include approximately 1000 patients into the overall dataset.

We intend to include all patients undergoing IVF/ICSI treatment at our clinic who have received high dose follitropin delta from the end of 2015 through until further notice. After obtaining approval from the hospital ethics committee, IRB00007237—2019-007531 FREIA BioMedical, retrospective chart reviews will be completed with IRB-approved consent to use patient data. For each record reviewed, a corresponding anonymized record will be automatically created using FREIA BioMedical Clinical Trials Unit (CTU) software, the data from both patient records will be integrated and analyzed.
FREIA BioMedical CTU collects the following data in the electronic chart review.
PATIENT IDENTIFICATION NUMBER, PATIENT FIRST NAME, PATIENT LAST NAME
Age, height, weight, body mass index
Presence of body hair, if any
Presence of moles and other pigmented and hypopigmented skin lesions, if any
Dental health and condition of teeth
The reproductive profile will be assessed during the first clinical examination visit.

If available, all relevant information about the patients’ reproductive history are recorded. This includes questions on gynecological and medical surgery; endocrine and metabolic disorders; urogenital infections and complications, specifically sexually transmitted infections; drug and/or alcohol abuse; congenital, hereditary, and chronic illness, among others. Data on all previous IVF/ICSI treatments are also collected, including number of embryos transferred in each cycle, and any implantation and ongoing pregnancy achieved.
4.2.5 Medical condition at the start of the study"

867,"A prospective monocentric study was conducted on patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which consisted of a 2-year open-label intervention (patients were treated according to their personal medical background) followed by a 2-year randomized controlled trial (RCT). The trial involved half of the patients who were randomized to receive oral treatment and half who were randomized to receive continuous intravenous infusion (CIVI) treatment (treatment as usual). The primary aim was to evaluate the efficacy of oral MTX, in terms of disease activity levels compared with CIVI in patients with RA. Secondary aims evaluated whether the clinical efficacy was maintained over 2 years of treatment and whether CIVI treatment is non-inferior compared with oral MTX. The study also assessed the effect of gender on treatment efficacy to evaluate whether different effects may occur based on the patient's gender.

Disease activity change over the 2-year treatment period; Non-inferiority of disease activity change over the 2-year treatment period; Treatment satisfaction at 2 years; MTX resistance; Efficacy in patients with MTX resistance at 2 years; Patient global assessment; Time to loss of treatment efficacy; Gender differences in drug effects; Safety and side effects.

OBJECTIVE: The oral or injectable disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug methotrexate (MTX) is recommended for the first line treatment of patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), but efficacy can decrease over time. Oral drug administration may have some disadvantages, such as high cost and non-compliance, where continuous intravenous infusion (CIVI) treatment is effective and well tolerated. As the cost of CIVI treatment is considerable, its clinical utility must be evaluated. The primary objective of the present study was to examine whether patients with RA treated with MTX orally are equivalent to MTX-treated patients who receive continuous intravenous infusions (CIVI) over a period of 2 years. METHODS: Seventy-seven (M:F = 48:29; mean age 51, SD = 14) male or female patients with established RA were enrolled in this two-stage randomized controlled trial. All patients received oral MTX treatment for two years. In the second stage, half of the patients who met certain criteria were randomized to CIVI treatment (n = 38) while the others continued with MTX treatment (n = 39). The primary outcome was disease activity change after two years (measured by DAS28). Non-inferiority of CIVI treatment was also demonstrated. Secondary outcomes included treatment efficacy, patient global assessment, safety and side effects, time to MTX resistance, time to loss of treatment efficacy, and the presence of MTX resistance when a patient no longer responded to MTX treatment. We also performed a sex-specific analysis to see whether there was a difference in efficacy between the two genders, and how efficacy changes in patients with MTX resistance. RESULTS: All patients were included in the analysis; this included 73 patients receiving oral MTX treatment over two years and 39 patients receiving CIVI or oral MTX treatment (CIVI: n = 19, oral: n = 20) over two years. Disease activity change did not differ when comparing the entire cohort (n = 73) at 2 years (difference = 0.00; lower bound limit of 95% confidence interval: ‐0.57; upper bound limit of 95% confidence interval: 0.56) or when comparing the patients who received intravenous treatment during the second stage of the study (n = 38) at 2 years (difference = ‐0.16; lower bound limit of 95% confidence interval: ‐0.67; upper bound limit of 95% confidence interval: 0.35). The disease activity change over a period of 2 years did not differ when comparing intravenous and oral MTX treatment in female or male patients. Treatment efficacy (assessed by DAS28) in patients with MTX resistance, the time to MTX resistance, the time to loss of treatment efficacy, the MTX resistance rate, and the treatment satisfaction did not differ between the oral and intravenous treatments. The patients receiving intravenous treatment did not report any infusion reactions. CONCLUSIONS: Patients treated"
868,"24-Month Follow-up of Patients Treated for Chronic Coronary Syndrome with Ticagrelor and in Whom An Increase in High-Sensitivity Troponin T (HsTnT) has Occurred

The primary purpose of this study is to determine the prognostic value of a 12-month rise in high-sensitivity troponin T at 6-month for future cardiovascular events and deaths among patients with CKD and with chronic coronary syndrome treated with ticagrelor/aspirin.
The secondary objectives of this study are:

-To assess whether the prognostic value of hsTnT at 6-month is influenced by age, gender, the presence of diabetes, a history of myocardial infarction, CKD severity, statin therapy, smoking behavior, and clinical and procedural data at baseline or 6-month.
-To determine whether the prognostic value of a 12-month rise in high sensitivity troponin T is influenced by the type of CKD (e.g. diabetic vs. non-diabetic; hypertensive vs. non-hypertensive).

-To explore whether baseline troponin levels (hsTnT and NT-proBNP) are predictive of adverse events and mortality. Additional analyses regarding a possible dose effect of statin therapy will be performed.

-To determine whether a 12-month rise in high-sensitivity troponin T at 6-month is influenced by baseline troponin levels (hsTnT and NTproBNP). Additional analyses regarding a possible dose effect of statin therapy will be performed.

-To determine whether a rise in troponin at 6-month may be predictive for future cardiovascular events and mortality among patients without CKD. Additional analyses regarding a possible dose effect of statin therapy will be performed.

Cohort/GroupDescription:: The study population will be selected from among CKD patients participating in the PHOENIX TIMI 51 CCS Study. The PHOENIX Study will include patients treated with ticagrelor and in whom an increase in hsTnT has occurred at 6-month after a coronary event. This patient group has already been screened and identified from the PHOENIX study population. The selected patient group from the PHOENIX TIMI 51 CCS study represents all patients in whom a rise of at least 24% in hsTnT has occurred in the group who received ticagrelor compared to those who received placebo (intention2treat population). All patients included in the study population will be randomized 1:1 to receive either the first (Aim 1) or the second research questionnaire (Aim 2) to complete. The first questionnaire will focus on the clinical setting, while the second questionnaire focuses on social and economic issues.
BiospecimenCollection & Archiving:: Not collect nor archive

Study Population Description:: The cohort is the same as in the PHOENIX study population. The PHOENIX study had as primary aim to assess the efficacy and safety of ticagrelor vs. placebo in addition to aspirin for 30 days in patients with chronic coronary syndrome and renal dysfunction to prevent hospitalization and death. 2793 patients were randomly assigned to ticagrelor or placebo in addition to standard of care management (standard antiplatelet therapy).

The planned PHOENIX TIMI 51 analysis had as primary aim to assess the prognostic value of a 12-month elevation in hsTnT after treatment with ticagrelor for the first 30 days compared to placebo on top of aspirin on top of their usual background therapy in 1701 patients aged 65 years or more.
A total of 1875 patients were available for follow-up analysis to assess the association between a 12-month elev"

869,"This study is designed to address the following overarching question: Can we enhance socialization experiences in the preschool classroom for socially excluded students with language impairment to create an environment characterized by reciprocal, peer-based social interactions that supports their academic, social, and developmental milestones? This is a randomized, controlled, classroom-level trial involving 60 inclusive preschool classrooms and 250 children designed to address this question. The overarching goal of this study is to address how peer relationships might be fostered or enhanced in the preschool classroom using a peer-mediated, prosocial intervention to benefit students from traditionally under-served backgrounds who are socially excluded from the classroom social network. The specific research hypotheses include: 1. Children participating in teacher-implemented prosocial interventions to facilitate peer-mediated social inclusion experiences will demonstrate greater improvements in classroom-based outcomes over time than children who experience traditional schooling in inclusive preschool classrooms. 2. Facilitators trained to support peer-mediated social inclusion strategies within prosocial intervention programs will report greater positive attitudes about students with language impairment, as measured by the Children's Attitudes Towards Peers scale, than teachers with no experience in training peers for peer-mediated social inclusion in inclusive preschool classrooms. 3. Participation in peer-mediated social inclusion strategies will increase the social capital of target children, resulting in reduced social exclusion as measured by the Social Support Scale.

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
Experimental: Peer-mediated pivotal response intervention
Facilitators hold four 15-minute training sessions with the peer group to engage the target child. The facilitator explicitly identifies the buddy and asks the children to use four strategies to play with the child during center time: (a) offer your buddy some play options; (b) show and talk about how to play with your buddy; (c) compliment your buddy; and (d) show your buddy how to take turns. At each training session the facilitator will describe one strategy, provide examples, and practice the strategy through role play. After trainings, the facilitator provides ongoing support during center time to implement the strategies over 12 weeks during months 3-6 of the 9 months of study participation.

Measure Description

The PLS-5 is used to assess the auditory comprehension and expressive language skills of children from birth to age 7 years 11 months. For the present study, only the expressive language scale was administered, which is used to determine how well a child communicates with others. Specific skills assessed include naming, expressing quantity, describing, using specific prepositions, grammatical markers, sentence structures, and emergent literacy skills. An assessor indicates whether a child passes (1) or does not pass (0) each item. Raw Score Range: Minimum = 0/Max = 67. The Standard Score is found using a conversion table provided in the PLS-5 Handbook. Higher scores on the PLS-5 indicate greater language skills.

A 26-item psychometrically sound checklist assessing children's pragmatic skills (e.g., conversational abilities, giving information), and DPP scores have strong classification accuracy in differentiating children with LI from non-affected classmates. This profile identifies non-verbal and verbal pragmatic deficits that may negatively influence social and"

871,"50 patients will be recruited with cleft lip and/or palate at three hospitals in Sweden. 25 will be treated with a CLEFT-Q questionnaire twice (test-retest reliability), one to two weeks apart, to assess test-retest reliability. The questionnaire is on health related quality of life specific for patients with cleft lip and palate. We will also measure outcome on secondary surgeries performed during the patient´s lifespan, depending on the surgery: 1) secondary nasal surgery (50 patients) 2) secondary speech improving surgery (50 patients) 3) secondary lip surgery (50 patients) 4) jaw surgery (50 patients) - and to further interpret the questionnaire by interviewing health care professionals (20 health care professionals) from the three clinics. The aim of the project is to show if the questionnaire is an appropriate instrument when measuring quality of life in patients with cleft lip and palate, and which surgeries that affects quality of life."

872,"Primary: The primary objective of this study is to compare the effect of pelvic floor stretching exercises with core stabilization exercises on dysmenorrhea related symptoms severity and the quality of life in young girls with primary dysmenorrhea.
Secondary: the secondary objective is to compare the effect of core stabilization and stretching exercises on improving the quality of life of young women with primary dysmenorrhea."

873,"57% of all strokes occur in China, making China one of the world's leading countries for stroke. However, the current standard for cerebrovascular monitoring in China can only measure blood flow at a local level, while some patients can exhibit increased permeability, resulting in microbrain hemorrhages such as intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) leading to cognitive and functional difficulties. The investigators proposed a simple way to monitor cerebrovascular health. They developed a portable instrument called a neurovascular coupling (NVC) device. This NVC device uses a computer and web cameras to capture the color of blood in the artery of the ear and measures cerebrovascular volume and flow. This approach will provide both objective and real-time measurement of cerebrovascular status, and it will provide individualized real-time cerebrovascular monitoring data to facilitate the diagnosis, management, and prevention of cerebrovascular disease. The investigators hope that through international collaboration on the NVC device, they will provide a new and important method for cerebrovascular monitoring, which may ultimately benefit the healthcare of Chinese patients.
Patient population and selection critieria : Patients requiring non-invasive cerebrovascular monitoring after craniotomy due to stroke or other central nervous system (CNS) disorders.

Main objective : To characterize the NVC pattern of cerebrovascular blood flow volume (CBFv) and cerebrovascular blood flow (CBF) in patients after stroke and/or other central nervous system (CNS) disorders, under basal as well as during hypercapnic and/or hyperemic conditions.

Research design : A prospective, investigator-initiated, single center study that will be conducted in the department of Cerebrovascular Diseases and Brain Surgery, Institute of Neuroscience and Surgery, Chinese Preventive Medicine Association Hospital, China. The estimated period for the enrollment of patients into the study is 4 months, i.e., from January 1, 2024 to April 30, 2024. All subjects will be given a written informed consent after the nature, possible consequences and discomforts related the study have been explained to them.
Main outcome measures : The NVC pattern of cerebral blood flow volume (CBFv) and cerebral blood flow (CBF) will be compared under basal as well as during hypercapnic and/or hyperemic conditions.

The clinical effect of the NVC pattern on the outcome of cerebrovascular disease and other CNS disorders will be evaluated by neurological examination, NIHSS, MMSE, Barthel Index and modified Rankin Scale (mRS).

Research methods: This study will be conducted as a single center study. Once the patients are in stable condition, he or she will be assessed for the presence of stroke (within six months; cerebral hemorrhage and cerebral infarction) and/or other CNS disease (without any cerebrovascular diseases), including tumor or brain surgery within one month. After obtaining written informed consents, all participants will be evaluated by neurological examination, NIHSS, MMSE, Barthel Index and modified Rankin Scale (mRS). Then, the NVC pattern will be examined and graded in 3 stages (Stroke & Other CNS disorders, Neurological exam, Stable condition). The patients will breathe 100% room air, 5% CO2 for one hour and inject 5% glucose by injection for one hour (without taking the medication). The NVC pattern of CBFv and CBF will be compared during the three stable conditions. Each participant will be evaluated by NIHSS and MMSE after 1 and 6 months to evaluate their improvement in the functional status.

Pre-treatment tests, examinations and procedures(exclude inpatient treatment) : To make sure that all the participants are in stable conditions, each participant will have a normal and non-stressful status. This study will be only included patients who are in the state of pre-anaesthesia. Firstly, the participants will have a neurological assessment, including the evaluation of Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and mental status. After that, participants will be examined for other neurological disorders, including epilepsy, brain tumor, and other systemic disorders. If no other neurological disorders exist except stroke or other CNS disorder, it will be confirmed that the patient participates in the test group of our study"

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
No Intervention: Usual care (Control)
Participants randomized to the control arm will be assigned weekly PQ-ResPOND Surveys up to week 12. Participants in this arm will not have access to the full PediQUEST system, i.e. no reports will be generated. They will not meet the PPC team but can receive regular palliative care consultations following the site's usual referral procedures. Children in the usual care arm will receive standard care, which at Boston Children's Hospital usually involves several primary clinicians (primarily neurologists or Complex Care Service attending physicians) and access to psychosocial clinician care throughout the illness course. PPC referrals are typically made at the discretion of the primary clinician, often for decision making reasons and/or closer to end-of-life. If a child presents persistent distress, they will be cared through the usual mechanisms. The rationale for collecting weekly surveys is to minimize reporting bias and may increase adherence and retention.

Experimental: PQ-ResPOND (Intervention)
Participants in the intervention arm will (i) answer weekly PQ-ResPOND Surveys over 12 weeks, (ii) receive feedback reports (generated by the PediQUEST system to summarize parents answers), and (iii) engage with the pediatric palliative care (PPC) team. The interprofessional PPC team will focus on child's recurrent pain and related symptoms using a standardized approach and work on family activation strategies.
column3:

* PPC teams will have access to feedback reports and the PQ-ResPOND checklist (standardized framework to diagnosis and treatment of recurrent pain behaviors in children with severe neurologic impairment). Integration of the PPC team into care will be achieved through (i) initial consultation (goals: identify treatment goals, and address recurrent pain), and (ii) follow-up: the team will contact or visit the family in response to feedback reports or for treatment monitoring purposes.

Surveys' response rates and distribution of non-responses will be used to determine participant's adherence with study data collection procedures

876,"1.3 million people in Sweden suffer from cardiovascular diseases (CVD), and this number is increasing in accordance with the ageing population. Cardiac rehabilitation programmes are effective interventions for improving the prognosis of patients with established CVD, through increased exercise capacity and physical activity levels. Digital tools for supporting patient's physical activity are promising, but research on this topic is lacking (Anderson et al., 2019). This study aims at evaluating the effectiveness of the aktivplan digital intervention, which will be provided as a complement to the usual care in the rehabilitation programme phase II, and comparing the results between patients in the intervention and control groups. 102 patients will be enrolled in this study in Malmoe and Lund, Sweden. The intervention group will be introduced to the aktivplan digital intervention by a health professional at their discharge from the rehabilitation programme phase II. Usage is encouraged through automated messages and reminders. The control group will continue to receive the usual care without the addition of the aktivplan digital intervention. Data will be collected at baseline (before discharge from phase II), 4 weeks after this visit, and 10 weeks after. The primary outcomes are the recruitment rate and the drop-out rate. Secondary outcomes include the exercise capacity, physical activity behaviour, weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking habits, health-related quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and data completeness."

877,"1. Background and rationale of the randomized cross-over design: A previous study demonstrated that a single dose of oxytocin nasal spray was well tolerated and effective in inducing social responses in healthy participants. However no studies to date have investigated repetitive behaviours associated with ASD. Therefore the investigators will conduct a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, 2-period crossover study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of two 24 IU oxytocin doses given twice-daily (total 48 IU daily) over a period of 4 weeks in reducing repetitive behaviours associated with autism. This crossover design helps to diminish the bias of a placebo effect. 2. Hypotheses of the study: 1) Oxytocin in youth with ASD safely reduces repetitive behaviours. 2) Vagally-mediated heart rate variability (HRV), a surrogate marker of vagal tone (which has been shown to be decreased in ASD due to increased brain excitability) is increased with twice daily dose oxytocin nasal spray (24IU). 3) Oxytocin increases reciprocity during a computerized Emotional body language task compared to placebo. 4) Oxytocin will induce a probabilistic reversal learning response in ASD. 3. Novelty of this study for China: The use of oxytocin for the treatment of ASD has been largely understudied and few controlled trials have examined its clinical effects. The rationale for this study is that oxytocin has a beneficial therapeutic effect in ASD in terms of prosociality, sociability, and altruism in healthy individuals and other ASD populations, although this is still the subject of debate. In this study the investigators will use two oxytocin doses instead of a single dose, and evaluate a variety of ASD phenotypes and social responses in the target population. Furthermore, the design will also make it possible to compare oxytocin levels between the participants (using a finger prick blood test) to establish whether oxytocin levels in the blood correlate to the clinical response. If this is confirmed it will allow the development of a personalized oxytocin prescription for patients with ASD, with the potential to improve outcomes for this patient group, and reducing associated health burden and cost. 4. Sample size: This study was originally designed to recruit 80 participants, but due to the covid-19 pandemic the recruitment is taking longer than expected. The project has been reduced from two sites to one site during this period to prioritize data from a single site. The investigators therefore plan to reduce the target number of participants to 35 to minimize the risk that this study will not meet its recruitment target. The sample size needed to demonstrate a significant treatment effect (e.g. 30% reduction in repetitive behaviour) was based on literature (Jin et al. 2018: Effect assessment of oxytocin in autism by the CRT: a randomized-controlled trial). We hypothesize that a significant treatment effect can be achieved if the study is able to enroll and dose at least 35 participants. A recent study using the same outcome measurements as our study found a significant treatment effect with 31 participants. Moreover, this study was designed to demonstrate an interaction between oxytocin and the CRT. Given that 20 participants would likely be enough to demonstrate a significant treatment effect, we will plan for a recruitment target of 35 participants to ensure the demonstration of a significant effect and allow for variability and other study procedures. 5. Expected outcome: The target population for this study is youth with autism spectrum disorder aged 12 to 20 years. The prevalence of ASD in youth between 6-21 years old was estimated at 18 per 1000 individuals in China, with males more likely to develop autism. A new study conducted by researchers in Sichuan has shown that the prevalence in youth and young adults aged 10-29 years old was even higher (1/40-1/58). This study therefore represents an under-served and understudied target population in China for whom there currently are no validated pharmaceutical treatments. However oxytocin nasal spray is an attractive candidate for treatment of ASD due to its known efficacy and safety profile in healthy populations, and the fact that it can be self-administered. If this study is shown to demonstrate a significant reduction in repetitive behaviours and"
878,"24/7 urine collection in metastatic kidney cancer patients.

The patients receive standard treatment according to the GERK guidelines for metastatic renal cancer. They will undergo the assessment: 1/ daily urine collection over 5 days; 2/ a blood and urine sample at random time points; and 3/ at diagnosis and one year later, MRI abdomen, bone scintigraphy, CT-chest and biopsy of the kidney tumors. The urine will be tested with a liquid biopsy kit and analysed on DNA and RNA (gene expression). After one year of diagnosis patients will be followed with repeated exams and urine samples.
To assess biomarkers of early response to MET and VEGR targeted
drugs; to evaluate the role of urinary proteins in kidney cancer prognosis.
To associate the response to therapy with changes in the urine proteome
•	To evaluate a correlation between urinary molecular markers and clinical bi-dimensionnal response of patients to first line therapy;
•	To assess urinary protein markers for prognostication in metastatic renal cancer patients;
•	To correlate urinary proteins with the response to second line therapy,
•	To correlate urinary proteins with the response to immunotherapy,
•	To explore the expression of the gene involved in the biosynthesis of urinary proteins and the molecular basis of their involvement in the development of kidney cancer.
Primary Outcome: to associate the response to therapy with changes in the urine proteome;
Secondary Outcome: to evaluate a correlation between urinary molecular markers and clinical bi-dimensionnal response of patients to first line therapy;
to assess urinary protein markers for prognostication in metastatic renal cancer patients;
to correlate urinary proteins with the response to second line therapy,
to correlate urinary proteins with the response to immunotherapy,
to explore the expression of the gene involved in the biosynthesis of urinary proteins and the molecular basis of their involvement in the development of kidney cancer.

879,"116813 (Treatment N: 116813; Control N: 116813): Empowered Relief is a psycho-educational pain skills training delivered by trained nurses via webinar. The present study will evaluate the effects of ER compared to a wait-list control (WLC) on two primary symptom outcomes (change in chronic pain intensity, and self-reported catastrophizing of chronic pain) at post-intervention and 1-month follow-up. We will also use quantitative methods (correlations, regressions, and mediation) to determine the potential mechanisms of ER."

880,"The purpose of the study is to investigate how patients and healthcare professionals judge the mental effort of choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings under different conditions. Patients and healthcare professionals will be surveyed and asked to answer questions with regards to their experiences rating and interpreting the different scales used in chronic pain assessments and interventions. The results will provide information about the accuracy of the different scales in chronic pain assessments and interventions.
Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida
patients, healthcare professionals, pain intensity ratings, mental effort, importance"

881,"The goal of this study is to analyze the efficacy of intravenous transplantation of umbilical cord blood mesenchymal stem cells in post-transplantation complications with poor graft function by evaluating the safety and efficacy of cell transplantation in poor graft function of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in an effective and non-toxic way. The main purpose is to provide an effective way to prevent graft failure, and the key research points are: to investigate hemogram recovery after treatment, to reduce postoperative complications, to prolong patient survival and disease-free survival."

882,"3D-tissue is growing as a clinical tool to provide physicians with additional insight on the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. We hypothesize that multi-parametric (i.e., multi-omics) and patient-derived (xenograft) or humanized-mouse (PDX) 3D-tissue models can be useful tools for developing precision medicine for pediatric solid tumors. Thus, in this project we will study how to apply state-of-the-art 3D-tissue models to advance precision medicine, which will enable pediatric oncologists to choose the best therapy for each patient.
Cancer (Pediatrick, Solid Tumors), Brain and Nervous System Cancer

884,"099/N1849 is an open-label, phase 1/2 study of Botensilimab (an Fc-engineered anti-CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen 4) monoclonal antibody) in combination with Balstilimab (a human monoclonal immunoglobulin [Ig] G4 (IgG4) antibody, designed to block programmed death protein (PD-1) binding by PD-L1 and PD-L2), + Triplet Chemotherapy (consisting of Nab-Paclitaxel [Abraxane®] 125 mg/m2 + Gemcitabine [Gemzar®] 1000 mg/m2 + Cisplatin [Cisplatin®] 25 mg/m2), + Chloroquine Phosphate [Aralen®] 500 mg and Celecoxib [Celebrex®] 200 mg, in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer."

886,"121 older adults (≥ 75 years)  will undergo preoperative cognitive testing, randomization to inhaled vs. intravenous anesthesia, intraoperative and postoperative assessments, and follow-up visits through 12 months.

Cognitive testing (assessing subjective cognitive decline and screening for cognitive impairment) and baseline functional status are completed at preoperative baseline. Subjects are randomized to inhaled (sevoflurane) vs. intravenous (propofol) anesthesia and assessments of anesthesia and POD severity  and duration will be done on postoperative day 1. Anesthesia and POD severity (CAM-ICU-7, 3D-CAM, and other delirium scales) will be reassessed at any time during hospital admission. Follow-up cognitive and functional testing will be done on postoperative day 3, postoperative day 30 and 12 months postoperatively. Longitudinal samples of venous blood (plasma and serum) drawn before the surgery and on postoperative days 1 and 30.
Optimizing Anesthesia to Prevent Postoperative Cognitive and Functional Decline in Older Adults: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Neurocognitive Disorders, Anesthesia, Post-operative Delirium, Post-operative Cognitive Dysfunction

Inclusion Criteria: Men and women ≥ 75 years Sufficient vision and hearing to complete all tests Proficient in spoken and written English Scheduled for elective, inpatient, noncardiac surgery, with expected hospital admission ≥ 48 hours, no hospital admission within 3 months before or after surgical date, expected to last at least 120 minutes requiring general anesthesia Planned GI bypass, liver resection or any craniofacial, neurosurgical, ocular, or thoracic surgery Informant available (or close family member) with frequent (at least 1 hour/day or 1 day/week) contact with the subject to verify CDR rating. Exclusion Criteria: Urgent or emergent surgery Diagnosed dementia (or MoCA<19). History of stroke, Parkinson's disease, major psychiatric disease (Schizophrenia), or severe traumatic brain injury Ongoing alcohol or substance abuse (per DSM V criteria) Allergy to propofol or sevoflurane Personal or family history of malignant hyperthermia Planned postoperative intubation Brain surgery Surgery requiring intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) or general anesthesia (GAS) (i.e. cases involving neuromonitoring) Surgical procedure requiring general, regional, or neuraxial anesthetic occurring within 3 months (before or after) surgical date Any patient or perioperative factor considered a contraindication to randomization to either experimental group by the surgeon or anesthesiologist.

888,"This study evaluates the use of an MRI technique, CEST, in the treatment of brain cancer called gliobastoma multiforme.
Who is eligible for this study?
Adult patients at least 18 years of age with newly diagnosed brain cancer called glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) who require surgical treatment.
What will the study doctors do to help my child get well?

The standard of surgery for brain cancer is the removal of as much of the brain tumor as can be done without doing any damage to any other parts of the brain. The standard of care is to remove the part of the tumor that shows up as having activity on MRI images with the help of a dye called gadolinium. The researchers will give you the option of participating in an experimental study. During surgery, if you are part of the experimental group, they will identify the part of the tumor that is not surrounded by the gadolinium dye. This will be based on pH-weighted amine CEST imaging on a pre-operative MRI image.
This part of the tumor is called the necrotic regions.
Study doctors will use the 3D information obtained from the pre-operative MRI.
The doctor will take these regions into account when doing surgery. They will not remove these parts of the tumor.
Why is the study looking for participants?
The purpose of this research is to find a better way to resect brain tumors.
When is the study starting and how long is it expected to run?
We are currently enrolling for the screening portion of the study.

The purpose of the study is to see if removing more of the tumor that is found using a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study with a special technique, called CEST, will improve the overall survival of people who participate in this study compared with standard of care surgery.
Phase II Pilot Trial of CEST PH Tissue MRI Based Resection of Glioblastoma: Surgical Oncology Group 2018
* Combination Product: CEST PH MRI based resection of glioblastoma

Inclusion Criteria: Diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme 4-16 weeks from diagnosis Patient with imaging consistent with WHO Grade IV glioblastoma Age at least 18 years old Performance Status (KPS) ≥ 60 Exclusion Criteria: Uncontrolled bleeding/coagulopathy Uncontrolled active infection requiring antibiotics or other therapy Pregnant or breast feeding Patient with significant psychiatric illness making it unsafe for the patient to fully participate in the trial Patients who are currently taking any immunosuppression or immunomodulation therapy (ex. steroids) Previous involvement of eloquent areas Presence of mass effect and/or substantial midline shift AST or ALT levels greater than twice the upper limit of normal

column1: 889,"This study aims to examine the prevalence of childhood and adolescent asthma across three different asthma phenotypes (severe early-onset, mild childhood- or adolescent-onset, and late-onset asthma) in the study population. The investigators will use data collected from the National Children's Study (NCS), a prospective, longitudinal study of childhood health and development involving children aged 9-11 years old in the United States. Participants will be asked to complete questionnaires and provide data on their asthma symptoms, severity of asthma, asthma control, asthma medications, and asthma triggers, as well as family history of allergies, smoking history, and environmental exposures such as air quality and exposure to certain household products. The investigators will use statistical analyses to determine differences in asthma symptom scores, asthma control scores, and frequency of asthma exacerbations across the three asthma phenotypes."

890,"Background: Probiotics are a class of beneficial bacteria that have a positive impact on human health. They are usually consumed in the form of capsules and are available in stores and online. Research suggests that probiotics may benefit the intestinal barrier and help prevent certain diseases. One of the potential benefits of probiotics is their effect on food allergies. Some studies have found that probiotic supplementation can help reduce allergic reactions and improve gut health in people with food allergies. In addition, probiotics may also help to restore a healthy balance of gut bacteria, which can improve overall gut health. However, more research is needed to fully understand the potential benefits of probiotics for treating food allergies. Furthermore, probiotics may also benefit the intestinal barrier by reducing inflammation and increasing the production of beneficial immune factors. These positive effects of probiotics on the intestinal barrier may be particularly beneficial for people with allergic disorders, as they may help reduce symptoms and improve overall health. However, more research is needed to fully understand the potential benefits of probiotics for allergic disorders.
Intervention Description:: Participants will be enrolled for a single-center, blinded, placebo-controlled parallel study.

The intervention group will take two probiotic capsules daily for 12 weeks. Placebo capsules will also be taken daily for 12 weeks, and the group will be blinded to whether the participants have received placebo or probiotic product.
At the end of the 12-week experimental intervention, all participants will be told that they have received a placebo or a probiotic product.

At the start of the experiment and at 4-week intervals thereafter, participants will be advised to keep records of their food allergies, physical condition, and body mass index. The investigators hope to encourage them to report changes as soon as they occur, and not at any set time.
If allergic reactions are reported after the start of the experiment, the investigators will promptly inform the participants to discontinue the probiotic intake.
Arm Description:: Participants will receive the probiotic intervention, two probiotic capsules daily for 12 weeks.
Condition(s)/Problem(s):: * (E01-E90)Endocrine, nutritional and metabolic diseases(E04.9)Nutritional and metabolic disorders, unspecified
Description:: 1. Age ≥20 years and <=64 years old;
3. The investigators believe that the experimental subjects are generally healthy and without serious illnesses;
4. Able to take capsules by mouth;
1. Participants who are known to have serious liver, kidney or digestive system diseases;
2. Patients participating in other clinical trials;
4. Individuals who are known to have allergies to probiotics.
Outcome:: Eczema Area and Severity Index(EASI) score; Timepoint:: Before the intervention, 12 weeks later;
Outcome:: Quality of life questionnaire score(SCORAD); Timepoint:: Before the intervention, 12 weeks later;"

891,"The investigators hypothetized that a playful social interaction will yield greater beneficial effects on mood, emotional regulation, and mental wellness compared to conventional social interactions. Improving mood, emotional regulation, and wellbeing, is associated with fewer depressive symptoms and stronger positive affect toward oneself and others.  To test this hypothesis, the investigators conducted a four-armed randomized cross-over study and examined the effects of these interventions on mood, emotional regulation, and overall wellbeing in older participants. Additionally, the investigators examined age-related differences in the relationship between interventions and psychological outcomes. In a pre-post design, we tested whether playful social interactions are associated with lower levels of mood and emotion regulation disturbances compared to a non-playful social interaction. Participants were drawn from groups of older adults, from four different sites. During the study, 104 participants took part in four different activities: Playful interaction Playful interaction Practice Playful interaction Non-playful social interaction Practice Non-playful social interaction Practice. For younger participants (up to age 60), these activities took place immediately after each other, whereas for older participants, the activities were scheduled for a given day and the participants attended each activity according to an established order. At base line (T0), participants were assessed on self-reports that measured their depressive symptoms and their experience of playfulness. To examine the effects of activities, we administered these self-reports immediately after completing the experiments (Time 1: T1). Participants completed a brief version of the Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (IDS) and the Experience of Playfulness (EPS). Participants completed another IDS and EPS immediately after completing the activities (Time 2).

Interventional Model Description: Participants will be randomly assigned to four arms. At first they will randomly assign to one of two conditions (online or face to face). On the second and third session the participants will be randomly assigned to a playful or control interaction. The interactions will be separated in a week. A random half of the participants will be assigned to practice the playful interaction at the first week and control interaction in the second week, whereas for the other half this order will be reversed.

column1: 892,"******************** Sexual health education is essential for autistic individuals to develop sexual health literacy early and build self-advocacy skills that will enable them to seek health care, maintain sexual health and protect against exploitation. However, parents often struggle with this task due to their own lack of knowledge about sexual health topics and a lack of autism-specific expertise. Parents often report feeling overwhelmed and anxious around discussing sexuality topics with their children. As teens approach puberty and enter adulthood, families may lack the necessary skills to start conversations about sex and relationships, which can lead to sexual and reproductive health problems down the line. The proposed research seeks to develop an intervention to help strengthen the communication skills of parents talking to teens diagnosed with ASD about sexual health topics. This project will implement a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effect of an intervention developed to improve parent-child conversations about sexual health topics on parent skills, confidence, frequency, and teen knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors. Participants will be dyads of parents and teens with ASD. Our study will be the first to investigate the impact of an intervention designed to improve parent-child communication about sexual health topics to reduce risky sexual behavior outcomes.
Communication Training Around Sexual Health Topics for Parents of Youth With Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

Inclusion Criteria: Eligible dyads will: Have a parent of youth aged 13-17 with diagnosed ASD. Have a child aged 13-17 with ASD. The child must: have reciprocal communication skills and receptive communication skills be in mainstream classrooms for a minimum of one class during the school day Have access to a computer/mobile device connected to the internet. Exclusion Criteria: There will be no exclusionary criteria based on gender or race/ethnicity, however during recruitment and enrollment staff will try to ensure that the race/ethnicity demographics reflect those of the U.S. more generally, with a 10% oversampling for Black and Latinx participants, and the gender ratio is balanced. Parent participants will not be screened for or included/excluded on the basis of having ASD themselves.

column1: 893,"The main objective of our study is to examine if the plasma level of DDX17 and GSDMD are associated with vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis of sepsis.
Safety and Efficacy Evaluation of Xiangkai Pingyao Decoction Granules in Patients With COVID-19 and Mild Symptoms
The purpose of this study was to observe the clinical efficacy of Pingyao granules in the treatment of patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and mild symptoms.

Pingyao granules, extracted from Chinese herbal medicines, have the effect of eliminating wind, clearing heat, relieving muscle pain and removing toxic substances. It can be used as a complementary and alternative medicines. It has no drug dependence hazard and can be used continuously for 2-3 weeks. The clinical study of herbal medicine is strictly carried out, and at least 100 subjects are included in each group. After the clinical study is completed, the results of the single treatment should be analyzed with the control treatment group, and the clinical effect of Pingyao granules should be evaluated.
Safety and Efficacy Evaluation of Xiangkai Pingyao Decoction Granules in Patients With COVID-19 and Mild Symptoms

Inclusion Criteria: 145 positive patients were included in the study based on the criteria for diagnosing COVID-19 (Trial Version 6). 123 cases aged 18 to 75, male and female patients with mild symptoms. 15 cases aged 18 to 75, male and female patients with mild symptoms. 145 positive patients were included in the study based on the criteria for diagnosing COVID-19 (Trial Version 6). The patients' condition remained stable after admission (without fever and no symptoms, only cough), and the patients signed the informed consent. The basic information of the patients and the clinical data are consistent. Exclusion Criteria: Patients with serious underlying diseases. Patients who have participated in other clinical trials within 3 months, or who are known to be unable to cooperate with the study. In women, patients who are pregnant or lactating, females who may become pregnant in the next 6 months, and those who are unwilling to accept pregnancy tests. Those who are allergic to the drug or who have taken other similar drugs within 15 days. Patients with poor compliance and those who are difficult to follow up. Severe abnormalities of liver function. Abnormal coagulation function. Those who have received other traditional Chinese medicine treatments for COVID-19 prior to enrollment.

Interventional Model Description: According to standardized randomized, random, double-blind and placebo-controlled method, patients were evenly divided into control and observation groups (3-1 ratio), and the two groups were given different standard treatment methods.

A total of 21 bags of Xiangkai Pingyao Decoction granules will be administered for each patient for 28 days.

column1: The aim of this study was to evaluate non-invasive methods for early
detection of liver  dysfunction in 345 patients after liver
transplantation. The non-invasive tests used were Luminex ®, liver
function tests (LFTs), and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). The Luminex ® test was
most efficient for detection of early dysfunction, with a sensitivity of
89%  ± 10% confidence interval (CI;95% CI) and a specificity of 63%  ±
6.2% CI, whereas the AFP test alone showed the highest

Background and objective: Early postoperative complications, the most frequent being rejection  and loss of liver function (early allograft dysfunction - EAD),  have a negative effect on immediate survival following  liver transplantation as well as long-term outcome. Post-operative
treatment and recovery after liver transplantation are
influenced by non-specific symptoms including general
malaise, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. These symptoms, along
with mild jaundice, can lead to an additional stress to the patients. To avoid invasive
testing, such as liver biopsy, early detection of complications is
essential. This study compares three non-invasive tests,
Luminex ®, liver function tests (LFTs), and alpha-fetoprotein
(AFP) to identify patients with liver dysfunction or EAD. Methods: This
is a prospective, single-center study in which patients who had
received liver transplantation were recruited. At a certain time
before, 5, 6 and 8 weeks after transplantation, blood was
collected and tested with the following tests : Luminex ®, AFP, LFTs
including AST, ALT, bilirubin, total and direct
coagulation, electrolytes and creatinine. In case of
EAD or liver dysfunction diagnosed by the clinical
team, liver biopsy was performed. Patients who had undergone
bilateral sequential liver transplantation were excluded from this
study, since in such cases, EAD can develop 8-12 weeks after
transplantation, which is outside the measurement window for

345 patients who had received liver transplantation were enrolled in the study. Blood samples were taken from patients 6 weeks prior to transplantation and at post-operative time points of week 5, 6 and 8 after transplantation. Samples were tested for LFTs (AST, ALT, bilirubin, total and direct coagulation, electrolytes and creatinine). AFP was measured with AFP-DiaSyst® test (Braun Melsungen). The Luminex ® test, a multiplex assay capable of detecting 92 different

Immunoglobulin subtypes, was used to detect 14 cytokines and 62 chemokines. Clinical criteria for diagnosis of EAD were applied according to Olthoff criteria (bilirubina ≥ 10 mg/dL in 7th post-operative day, international normalized ratio (INR) ≥ 1.6 in 7th post-operative day, ALT or AST> 2000 IU/L during the first 7 days after liver
Single-center Prospective Study of Non-invasive Methods for the Diagnosis of Postoperative Complications in Liver Transplant Recipients
Rejection Acute Hepatic, Liver Failing, Transplant; Failure, Liver, Liver Dysfunction

Inclusion Criteria: Patients eligible for liver transplantation following National and International Guidelines Exclusion Criteria: No agreement or inability to give informed consent Re-transplant patients Liver transplant in fulminant hepatitis

895,"1. Background of the trial - glioblastoma(GBM) is the most common and malignant type of primary brain tumors. Despite the introduction of concurrent chemoradiation and adjuvant chemotherapy since 2005, the median survival time of patients with newly diagnosed GBM is still <15 months and the 5-year survival rate is only 10%. New treatment options for patients with GBM are urgently required. 2. Rationale of the trial Elemene, an anti-tumor agent extracted from the Chinese herbal medicine ""Wenyujin"", has been isolated as its monomeric constituent and has broad-spectrum anti-tumor effects in various cancers, such as lung cancer, breast cancer, leukemia, and ovarian cancer. Recent in vitro studies also have shown that Elemene could inhibit GBM cell proliferation, promote cell differentiation and induce cancer cell apoptosis. Several retrospective studies published in 5 Chinese Journals and several English Journals also have shown survival benefits with low toxicity of Elemene for newly-diagnosed GBMs. However, so far, there have been no clinical trials that test the efficacy and safety of Elemene in treating GBMs. 3. Hypothesis of the study - Elemene plus Stupp Protocol (the Ele-Stupp protocol) is superior in efficacy and safety compared with Stupp Protocol alone for treating newly-diagnosed GBMs. 4. Objective of the trial - To determine whether the combined use of Elemene (Elemene plus Stupp Protocol) is superior in efficacy and safety compared with Stupp Protocol alone, for newly-diagnosed GBMs. 5. Scientific questions to be addressed - Will Elemene be able to safely prolong the median survival time (MST) of patients with newly diagnosed GBMs compared with Stupp Protocol alone? Can the Ele-Stupp protocol prolong the median survival time (MST) of patients with newly diagnosed GBMs compared with Stupp Protocol alone? Can the Ele-Stupp protocol significantly improve the objective tumor response of patients with newly diagnosed GBMs compared with Stupp Protocol alone? Can the Ele-Stupp protocol significantly improve the progression-free survival (PFS) rate in the 6th month and the 12th month after treatment compared with Stupp Protocol alone? Can the Ele-Stupp protocol significantly reduce the incidence of severe adverse events during and after treatment compared with Stupp Protocol alone? 6. Innovation and Novelty of the study - This will be the first clinical trial comparing the efficacy and safety of the Ele-Stupp protocol (Elemene Plus Stupp Protocol) and Stupp Protocol Alone for newly diagnosed GBMs. 7. Ethical considerations - All patients enrolled in this study will receive best-practice standard-of-care treatment according to national guidelines. Written informed consent will be obtained from every GBM patient before randomization. All patients will be followed up closely during and after the treatment period according to the standard guidelines of follow up for patients with GBMs in our clinical practice. 8. Clinical relevance of the study - If the Ele-Stupp protocol proves to be superior in efficacy and safety, it will become a new standard treatment option for newly-diagnosed GBM patients, improving their clinical outcome. 9. Intervention - Patients in the Elemene group will be orally administered 20ml of Elemene, three times a day, for 28 consecutive days (as one cycle) along with best-practice standard-of-care treatments (surgery, radiotherapy, and adjuvant chemotherapy), for 6 cycles, during the phase of adjuvant chemotherapy. The placebo group will be orally administered 20ml of placebo (with the same appearance and flavor with Elemene), three times a day, for 28 consecutive days (as one cycle) along with best-practice standard-of-care treatments (surgery, radiotherapy, and adjuvant chemotherapy), for 6 cycles, during the phase of adjuvant chemotherapy. 10. Design of the trial - This will be a parallel-group, randomized trial with 1:1 allocation between the two groups. 11. Sample size calculation - Based on the data of our recent retrospective study, the MST of patients with newly-diagnosed GBMs in the Stupp Protocol alone group was approximately 7 months (mean: 4.45 months, range: 2 to 40 months). According to the data of a preliminary cohort"

896,"Inclusion of subjects will be performed by one investigator in order to obtain a uniformity in the enrollment process. Subjects will undergo the protocol as in Fig 1 and in the case of patient with PEEP>12cmH2O they will proceed for measurement of respiratory mechanics before starting the protocol. Respiratory mechanics will be assessed by bedside capnography, ventilator measurement of airway pressure, tidal volume and flow, and respiratory system compliance. For each measurement a stabilisation time of 20 seconds will be considered (if compliance or dynamic strain > 20% of the previous assessment, the measurement will be repeated). Lung recruitment will be tested for PaO2/FiO2 > 150 with a PEEP = 5 cmH2O. If PaO2/FiO2 is > 150 the following series of measurements will be recorded: Stable respiratory conditions for 10 min (i.e. PEEP 12 cmH2O, VT limited to 6 mL/kg and Plateau and Driving pressures ≤ 30 cmH2O and ≤15 cmH2O, respectively). This step is necessary to stabilise lung volumes, after being treated according with the standard weaning respiratory practice protocol. Arterial blood gases will be analysed to compute PaO2/FiO2 ratio to confirm the presence of the inclusion and the absence of exclusion criteria. Patients showing PEEP=12cmH2O PaO2/FiO2 < 200 will be enrolled. Each patient will perform a four-steps decremental PEEP trial (PEEP 12 cmH2O to 10 cmH2O to 8 cmH2O to 5cmH2O with a 20 mn pause at the upper setting). The rationale of the protocol is to explore whether prone position allows to obtain improvements in PaO2/FiO2 in the presence of an initial PaO2/FiO2 < 200.
