897,"64 eligible participants were recruited; 32 with TTH disorder (age group: 24-44 years) and 32 with migraine disorder (age group: 22-44 years). The participants were randomized to the intervention group. A 12-week progressive relaxation training intervention program was applied to an intervention group. 67 participants completed the 12-week intervention program. The participants were evaluated before the intervention (T0) and after the intervention (T12). Evaluations included demographic information, pain intensity, pain quality, pain parameters, pain treatment consumption and patient satisfaction. The mean age was determined as 33.86 ± 7.19. The mean duration of headache was determined as 20.53 ± 8.15 for TTH group and 17.28 ± 9.06 for migraine group. When the socio-demographic characteristics of the groups were compared, it was determined that there was a statistically significant difference in terms of having academic education and social status between the groups (p< 0.05). The results were interpreted in accordance with the recommendations of the American Psychological Association. No ethics committee approval was needed for this randomized clinical trial. The research was conducted with the approval of the ethics committee of the Gaziosmanli Vocational School (E- 2022/179). The research protocol was registered on April 15, 2022 (clinicaltrials.gov identification number: NCT05816) in the clinical trials registry (https://www.clinicaltrials.gov/).
The Effect Of Pregnancy Specific Exercise Of Pelvic Floor Muscles On The Urge Urinary Incontinence Of Primigravid Pregnant Women: A Randomized Clinical Trial
* Other: Progressive pelvic floor muscle training in addition to prenatal and childbirth training

Inclusion Criteria: voluntarily wanting to participate in the research, not attending pelvic floor training sessions, having healthy pregnancy except for pregnancy induced hypertension, singleton pregnancy, nulliparous women at 16-24 week gestation, aged 18-40 years old, have intact neuromuscular control Exclusion Criteria: preterm labor, preterm rupture of membranes, and high-risk pregnancy; medical diagnoses such as chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus and thyroid diseases; having a neurological or musculoskeletal disease or having genitourinary system pathologies

Progressive pelvic floor muscle training is 20 minutes of home exercises, and 20 minutes of pelvic floor muscle training exercises that we adapted from Pilates.[... click here for additional data file]Progressive pelvic floor muscle training is performed on a stable device in the sitting position 5 days a week, with an increase of 0.5-3 repetitions a day. Pelvic floor muscle training and prenatal and childbirth training were repeated in face-to-face group training, while the home exercise program was given as written and illustrated instructions.

column1: 898,"This observational pilot study will identify salivary exosomal RNA as a novel biomarker of exposure and withdrawal from in utero opioid exposure.

1. Compare salivary exosomal microRNA levels at birth among healthy controls, infants with neonatal opioid withdrawal (NOW), and infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) who require treatment for withdrawal symptoms.
2. Investigate the association of salivary exosomal microRNA level with maximum morphine dose required to control withdrawal symptoms in infants with NOW.
Study of exosomal RNA in saliva as potential biomarker, Neonatal abstinence syndrome, Neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome
1. Primary outcome: Neurodevelopmental Outcome Score measured by Ages and Stages Questionnaire-3. This will be measured 6 months post-discharge."

899,"The study aimed to increase the effectiveness of postoperative pain management in patients undergoing orthopedic interventions at the orthopedic trauma clinic of Bakirkoy Dr. Sadi Konuk Training and Research Hospital. This study was conducted to investigate the effect of patient education on pain management in postoperative patients with respect to pain level and fear of pain. The sample of the study was divided into intervention and control groups. Both groups consisted of 26 patients, with similar demographic characteristics. Patients in the intervention group received preoperative and intraoperative education on pain management, while patients in the control group received routine preoperative and intraoperative information. The study findings indicated that in both groups, there were significant changes in pain and fear of pain levels from baseline to the end of the study. Although there was no significant difference between the groups in terms of pain scores, the intervention group demonstrated a significant decrease in fear of pain scores compared to the control group. This study has important implications for the field of pain management. The findings suggest that preoperative and intraoperative education on pain management can play a significant role in reducing patient anxiety and improving pain management outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of including patient education in the standard clinical practice of pain management and emphasize the need for ongoing research and development in this field. This study should be replicated in larger and more diverse samples to confirm the findings. In addition, future studies could investigate the long-term effects of patient education on pain management outcomes and identify the most effective approaches to improving patient outcomes."

900,"The opioid epidemic disproportionally affects pregnant individuals, who have increased potential for death and adverse birth outcomes with opioid use disorder (OUD). OUD treatment during pregnancy is currently suboptimal due to a high rate of withdrawal from or discontinuation of medication assisted treatment (MAT). Treatment during pregnancy is imperative because untreated OUD is associated with higher rates of preterm delivery, infections, and low birth weight. Although treatment increases live births, women who initiate MAT may relapse or discontinue treatment, potentially because of the withdrawal effects associated with buprenorphine induction. As such, a new transdermal buprenorphine matrix patch (TPD) was recently developed as an alternative to the standard 8-12 hour interval regimen when initiating buprenorphine induction for pregnant patients with OUD. The TPD is an FDA approved patch formulation of buprenorphine with a lower dose of remoxipril; it allows for longer exposure to buprenorphine, minimizes withdrawal symptoms, and reduces the number of doses needed during induction. We aim to test the feasibility of using the buprenorphine TPD for the treatment of opioid use disorder (OUD) during pregnancy via a randomized clinical trial. Patients with OUD will be randomized to one of the two arms, with patients in the experimental arm receiving the buprenorphine TPD during induction. In the control arm, the standard sublingual (SL) regimen will be followed, with patients being given 2-4 mg of SL-buprenorphine every 2-6 hours per standard induction dosing schedule. The number of induction SL-buprenorphine doses required and number of withdrawal symptoms will be compared between the two arms during an in-person induction. The impact of using the TPD during buprenorphine induction on subsequent buprenorphine adherence, pregnancy outcomes, birth outcomes, and postpartum outcomes will be assessed. The outcomes of this RCT will directly inform clinical practice regarding the safe and effective use of TPD for the treatment of OUD during pregnancy. This clinical trial will use an existing patient population (the BROOD Study, 900+ pregnant patients) with a proven track record of retention while receiving buprenorphine treatment. Patients will be recruited at the study site. Our interdisciplinary study team has successfully utilized novel randomized trial designs, including one of the first double-blind placebo controlled studies to include pregnant patients and infants for OUD treatment, to ensure that the study design is feasible and safe while yielding meaningful results. If successful, the use of the buprenorphine TPD will expand access to evidence-based treatments for pregnant patients with OUD, improving their chance of a successful pregnancy outcome.

column1: 901,"In the context of a diagnostic consultation of the upper extremity for a suspected thoracic outlet syndrome, an additional oxymetry test will be proposed. This test allows a simultaneous assessment of arterial, venous and capillary circulation and to determine the ischemia time of the extremity. The results obtained during this examination will be compared to the standard method of imaging and will determine the type of vascular compression (venous, arterial, both) and will assess the correlation between the severity of the vascular compression and the DROPmin, that is to say, the ischemia time evaluated by means of this additional examination.

The results obtained will help to refine the indications for a surgical procedure aimed at the removal of a first rib, which is the most common procedure performed in the presence of venous compression. It also makes it possible to identify patients with an arterial compression alone or associated with a venous compression, who are not indicated for a surgical procedure. The results of this test also make it possible to assess the functional severity of a venous compression in a more sensitive way and therefore to evaluate the impact on the therapeutic assessment of these patients.

By participating in this study you are not exposed to any physical sequelae (other than the standard examination that is performed during the consultation), or any psychological or social disorders. Patients will not have to pay for the realization of the additional examination."

902,"Chronic Pancreatitis (CP) is a complex condition, with patients suffering from constant, distressing, adverse symptoms. There is no effective medical/surgical treatment. There is, however, a mobile health app called SmartCP, which may help to lessen symptoms and the need for urgent and inpatient treatment.
We want to conduct a study to determine if a SmartCP is feasible in the management patients with chronic pancreatitis, complementing current specialist clinical care.
To do this we aim to
See if the mobile app is easy for patients to use
Determine how many patients prefer our app to usual care
Evaluate if patients accept usage of our mobile app
Determine if patients feel the mobile app is useful
Determine if the mobile app is safe to use
Collect user statistics to improve the app
Use a questionnaire to collect information about how much the mobile app helps patients

Patients (> 18 years of age) with the diagnosis or suspicion of chronic pancreatitis and who fulfil the eligibility criteria specified in the Study Design section will be considered for inclusion in this study.
The following inclusion criteria will be used to determine who can take part in this study:
Patient whose smartphone is incompatible with the SmartCP app
Patients whose smartphone is incompatible with the SmartCP app
Patient whose smartphone is incompatible with the SmartCP app
Patients whose smartphone is incompatible with the SmartCP app
Occurrence of crisis events: Crisis phone-calls  3 months
Occurrence of crisis events: Accident & Emergency  3 months
Occurrence of crisis events: Urgent clinic  3 months
Symptoms: The nature and frequency of each symptom recorded using the daily symptoms tracker while using the app  2 months
Symptoms: Number of Alerts created by the app  2 months
Symptoms: Number of Red-Flag alerts created by the app  2 months
Quality of life (QoL): Short Form-12  2 months
Hospitalisation: Length of hospital stay  3 months
Use of communications features: Number of times per week patients use app communications features  2 months
Use of educational features: Number of times per week patients view app educational/informational features  2 months"

903,"50 patients aged more than 50 years old, suffering from benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) will undergo 12 weeks treatment with Ropinirole in addition to placebo, in addition to patients not receiving anti-cholinergic medication will serve as a control group and receive only placebo. Ropinirole is assumed to control prolactin levels and as we do know that benign pro-static hyperplasia (BPH) increases prolactin levels through unknown mechanism, the investigators are assuming that it can play a role in its development and that by controlling prolactin levels and decreasing its effect on BPH, BPH’s symptoms will be alleviated. The investigators will monitor the effects of Ropinirole on serum prolactin at baseline and at the end of 12 weeks.
Intervention Description:: Ropinirole in doses 0.5-1.5 milligrams orally per day

column5: 904,This trial is designed to answer the following questions:

column1: To investigate the effectiveness of PRF membrane application to the donor areas to prevent graft site morbidity
To compare the results of PRF membrane vs no PRF membrane control groups
To demonstrate how successful the procedure is and investigate if a statistically significant difference (p<0.05) between the two groups is achieved.

This study was planned as a randomized prospective controlled study. However, due to practical difficulties, it was converted into a parallel experimental study. Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who needs root coverage surgery in the Department of Periodontology are included in the study. The subepithelial connective tissue graft was obtained in each patient using the single incision technique from the region between the mesial of canine and the mesial of first molar in the palate. Connective tissue dimensions were approximately 10 x 5 x 2 mm. Finally, the incision line was sutured with 5/0 synthetic, nonabsorbable, sterile monofilament suture in the control group while L-PRF membrane was placed to the donor site in the test group before the suturing. Patients were evaluated using an ultrasonography device (MyLab™ Seven, Esaote, Genoa, Italy) at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology. USG measurements were performed on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30 and 90 for palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization by an oral and maxillofacial radiologist with at least six years of experience. A 6-18 MHz intraoral probe was used in intraoral USG examinations. Sterile gel was applied to the intraoral probe and covered with a stretch film. Then, it was placed directly on the mucosal surface of the donor site in the palatal area.

The main objective of the study is to evaluate the healing process in connective tissue graft harvesting operations in which platelet-rich fibrin (L-PRF) membrane was applied to the donor site after a surgical intervention. Therefore, the effect of the PRF membrane on tissue healing in the palatal donor regions will be investigated. It should be noted that the control group consisted of a group of individuals who had no PRF membrane application after intraoral connective tissue graft harvesting. The power analyse of the study was performed for sample size calculation. Sample size was calculated using a statistical program (G*Power; Universitat, Dusseldorf, Germany) for α = 0.05 and effect size = 0.26. The analyses revealed that 10 subjects per group achieved a power of 80 % with 95% confidence.

The surgical procedure was performed under local anesthesia with lidocaine (1.8 mL / 1: 80 000 Lidocaine, Sinusofarmak, Istanbul, Turkey). The L-PRF membrane was prepared as described in a similar study (21). The venous blood samples were taken from the antecubital vein of the patient's right or left arm in one attempt. The blood was gently transferred to glass-coated plastic tubes free from anticoagulant agents without wasting time. 20-mL blood was collected. The tubes were immediately centrifuged at 2800 rpm for 12 min with a centrifuge device (IQ 2, MED LAB PRODUCTS LTD., London, UK). After the subepithelial connective tissue graft harvesting from in the palate, obtained L-PRF was placed into donor site at the palate then incision line was sutured with 5/0 synthetic, non-absorbable, sterile monofilament suture. In our study, we followed a surgical protocol similar to the one used for the application of free gingival graft (FGG) (22-25, 27-30). Intraoral connective tissue graft harvesting was performed using a modified single incision technique (MTSICIT) (31-33). The subepithelial connective tissue graft dimension was approximately 10 × 5 × 2 mm. The connective tissue graft was harvested from the mucosa between the mesial of canine"

905,"This is an observational study to demonstrate the feasibility, acceptability and capability to collect data on the ARRC III trial. This data will form the basis of patient-level data for a future definitive trial of ARRC. Previous iterations of the ARRC study have shown considerable improvements in patient-centred outcomes, reduced length of hospital stay, reduced need for hospital readmissions, fewer in-hospital complications and improved resource utilisation when ARRC is compared to usual ward care. This data will form the backbone of a future definitive trial to provide high level evidence regarding the comparative performance of ARRC using clinical endpoints. A registry will provide a mechanism to monitor the performance of ARRC with regular audits and benchmarking."

906,"21/03/2021 The implementation of oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) has not been evaluated in men who mainly have sex with women and who may be at high risk of HIV acquisition due to high HIV prevalence in partners or particularly risky behaviours. Research to fill these data gaps is required to facilitate their inclusion in PrEP guidelines. Furthermore, with increasing PrEP options, recommendations to users and providers in high-burden / resource constrained settings is a key focus of the Sustainable Development Goal target to end AIDS by 2030. To date, HIV prevention research has largely focussed on adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in low and middle income countries and men who have sex with men (MSM) in high income countries. Research on the user experience and choice of oral PrEP or CAB-LA PrEP amongst vulnerable heterosexual men is required. Men consistently fare worse than women in levels of HIV testing and ART initiation with significant challenges in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) for engagement and persistence in HIV treatment programmes well described. Despite this, heterosexual men represent the largest unaddressed gap in HIV services in SSA. Indeed, the failure of Treatment As Prevention trials (TASP) to show effect was in the main due to the failure to test and treat young men. Men who are mobile for work or through looking for work, are viewed by the WHO as a key population at high risk for HIV. As Africa's large youth bulge moves into young adulthood, the search for work and consequent mobile lifestyles will further increase. In order to improve uptake, persistence, and effective use of all forms of PrEP, there is a need for simplified and differentiated delivery of PrEP that is person- and community-centred specifically for men. Effective use requires that all sex acts are covered by an effective prevention intervention such as PrEP. Given the importance of flexibility due to travel in this group, our hypothesis is that both oral (Truvada) PrEP and Long acting injectable cabotegravir (CAB-LA) PrEP will be highly acceptable to men in two high-burden, resource limited, African countries. The programme will provide the evidence and cost-effectiveness analysis which is critical to decision making by African governments and donors on how to prioritise prevention resources and inform guidelines. STUDY OBJECTIVES Effective use is defined as PrEP uptake and persistence, retention in care, and HIV exposure coverage with adequate drug tissue levels. Overall Objective To assess effectiveness and implementation of CAB-LA and oral TDF-FTC (both daily and on-demand) through comparison of uptake, retention in care, coital coverage, and participant choice Primary Objective Primary user effectiveness objective: To compare short term (9 months) and longer term (18 months) PrEP persistence patterns across different PrEP modality (oral and injectable) amongst men who are mobile for work in South Africa and Uganda. Primary implementation objective: To compare adoption (uptake and choice) across the different PrEP modality (oral and injectable) amongst men who are mobile for work in South Africa and Uganda. Adoption is defined as 1) uptake: do people accept and use the intervention they're randomised to, and 2) choice: based on the post-randomised period, i.e., months 9-18, what PrEP do they choose) Secondary clinical objectives To compare the effective coital coverage of oral daily/on-demand oral TDF-FTC versus CAB-LA To describe the safety, tolerability and acceptance of all methods, as determined by self-reported adverse side effects, AEs and reasons for PrEP pause or discontinuation. Secondary implementation objectives: To understand the Reach of PrEP for mobile men and understand the barriers to and facilitators of uptake amongst those at risk who do and do not accept oral or LA PrEP. To describe adoption: To identify characteristics of men who adopt oral PrEP versus CAB-LA To describe patterns of use of daily, on-demand, and long-acting PrEP amongst different groups of mobile men. To understand the implementation of on-demand and long-acting PrEP for mobile men amongst service providers to inform scale-up. To understand the feasibility and fidelity of delivering on-demand and long-acting PrEP in different settings. To describe how on-demand and long-acting PrEP are delivered in practice. To describe the service-level needs to implement on-demand and long-acting PrEP. To evaluate acceptabiltiy and implementation"

907,"50 patients of an outpatient department at a university hospital in northern Italy. The patients were diagnosed with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) according to the RDC/TMD. The aims of the present study were to determine the prevalence of temporomandibular disorders (TMD) in patients of Spondyloarthritis (SpA), comparing the SpA-TMD group to control group matched in age and sex, and to establish the impact of TMD on psychological parameters."
908,"Preliminary Results: These are exploratory research results on preterm infants.

The purpose of the present study was to investigate the effect of therapeutic touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers using structural magnetic resonance imaging, functional magnetic resonance imaging, proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and mass spectrometry (NMR and MS) in preterm infants. One hundred twenty preterm infants, between 32.0 and 33.6 weeks gestational age, were randomized into three groups for a single intervention: osteopathic manipulative treatment, a standardised affective touch intervention and a standardised static touch intervention. We compared preterm infants receiving therapeutic touch for the first time with infants receiving sham touch (static touch) and with infants not receiving any touch intervention. Two hours after the intervention, all infants were evaluated. Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF-proNGF2 and BDNF-mNGF2) levels were increased in infants receiving osteopathic manipulative therapy. Additionally, 1H-NMR showed increased levels of glutamate in urinary samples in infants receiving osteopathic manipulative therapy. Furthermore, a more balanced functional network was observed in the infants that received the therapeutic touch intervention with improved functional connectivity in the brain. Affective touch increased functional connectivity between the primary somato-sensoric cortex and the secondary somato-sensoric cortex bilaterally, whereas therapeutic touch did not change the functional connectivity in the brain. The findings from the present study suggest that the therapeutic touch intervention is associated with increased BDNF levels and improved metabolism in the infants, and improved functional connectivity. The findings offer a new and positive direction in terms of the treatment of preterm infants, because they can be applied as a low-cost and low-risk intervention during the hospitalization of preterm infants."

SCD is a rare but life-long inherited disorder. Blood cells become sickle shaped because of a defective anemia-producing gene, which is passed to children. Episodes of sudden, severe pain, a complication called sickle cell crisis, will develop as people age. The most common cause of death is infection. Current medications only treat complications of the disease. Briquilimab is an investigational medication. In this study, participants will receive briquilimab, which will lower the immune system. The purpose of this study is to learn whether briquilimab and abatacept can prevent graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in participants undergoing haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for curative treatment of their sickle cell disease. The study will also determine if the combination of briquilimab, abatacept, alemtuzumab, sirolimus and the haploidentical PBSC will achieve the desired treatment outcomes after haploidentical HCT. The study will take place in Baltimore, Maryland, at the National Institutes of Health (NIH)."

910,"30 healthy participants of all genotypes of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) A*02:01 (AL01+), who are aged between 18 and 70 years, will take part in a study to identify and characterize immune cells in their peripheral blood samples. This study is designed to investigate the role of immunosuppressants in preventing transplant rejection in patients with AL01+ recipients. Volunteers will provide blood samples and complete a survey about their medical history and other potentially relevant personal information at three time points: before taking the immunosuppressants, while taking the immunosuppressants, and after completing the immunosuppressants. Participants who are taking immunosuppressants and have AL01+ (B cell receptor) are being treated for lymphoma are also invited to participate in this study. The study aims to assess the safety and tolerability of immunosuppressants in AL01+ (B cell receptor) individuals, as well as the effects of these drugs on the immune system over time.

A randomized group of 60 patients, who have had an early recurrence of high-risk hepatocellular carcinoma, will be included in the study. One group will receive standard radiotherapy as the current recommendation; the other group will receive immunotherapy in addition to radiotherapy. All patients will undergo regular follow-up visits and provide blood samples for analysis.The primary goals of this study are to prevent early tumor recurrence after curative radiofrequency ablation in patients with early postoperative recurrence of high-risk hepatocellular carcinoma. Tumor recurrence can be caused by residual tumor cells after radiofrequency ablation. By adding immunotherapy to standard radiotherapy, it is hoped that the body's immune system will be able to recognize and eliminate any remaining cancer cells.Another goal is to identify molecular changes in the tumor and immune cells that occur during the development of hepatocellular carcinoma. By understanding the molecular mechanisms of hepatocellular carcinoma development, it may be possible to develop more effective treatments in the future, potentially improving the overall prognosis and survival rate of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.The study will also investigate the safety and tolerability of combining immunotherapy and radiotherapy in this patient population. Based on the results of this study, it is hoped that doctors will be able to make more informed decisions about treatment options for high-risk hepatocellular carcinoma in the future. By providing new insights into the molecular mechanisms of hepatocellular carcinoma, this study also aims to contribute to a better understanding of the disease and advance the field of cancer research.
A Randomized Study of Standardized Dose of Radiotherapy and Immunotherapy for Patients with Early Recurrence of High-Risk Hepatocellular Carcinoma After Curative Radiofrequency Ablation

Inclusion Criteria: 18 to 70 y/o Patients who had experienced early recurrence (< 3 mo. after radiofrequency ablation) of high-risk hepatocellular carcinoma Patients who cannot undergo radical hepatic resection or liver transplantation Patients without any severe disease that can have an impact on survival Exclusion Criteria: severe liver failure, pregnancy, severe infections, etc.

column3: Intervention/Treatment

Drug: Cemiplimab
* Cemiplimab, 30mg per week, as intravenous infusion over 30 min, until disease progression.
* Other names: LIBTAY"

column1: 911,"Objectives Allergic rhinitis is the most common type of allergy worldwide. It is known as Hay fever that causes sneezing, runny nose, headaches and itchy, watery eyes. These symptoms occur when someone is exposed to pollen or to something else he/she is allergic to. The prevalence of allergic rhinitis is on rise worldwide. The disease prevalence in Korea is reported to be 9.7% with an annual incidence of 0.54%.1,3,5-9 The increased prevalence of allergic rhinitis is believed to be a result of environmental changes as well as socio-economic factors. AR is often seasonal, with pollen being the primary trigger for symptoms during spring, summer and fall. However, it can be perennial if triggered by household allergens such as dust mites, pet dander, or mold spores. Allergic rhinitis is more common among children and can often persist into adulthood if left untreated. Common treatments for AR include antihistamines, decongestants, and allergy shots. In recent years, many new treatments have been developed, including nasal sprays, sublingual drops, and monoclonal antibody therapies. Early diagnosis and treatment of allergic rhinitis is important in order to reduce the impact of the disease on quality of life.
Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) Single Nucleotide Gene Polymorphism and Nerve Growth Factor as Risk Factors That Increase Severity of Allergic Rhinitis
5 ml biood withdrawen by venipuncture in EDTA tube

Five  ml of blood has been withdrawn by venipuncture in EDTA tube. the whole blood has been separated from plasma. the DNA extraction will be done after centrifucation. the DNA was used for  Genotyping. Quantatitive Real-time polymerase chain reaction assay is performed using QuantiFast Probe PCR Kit (QIAGEN) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Primer specificity has been verified by the detection of a single peak, and assay performance has been documented by a coefficient of correlation greater than 0.996 when comparing run/run and run/batch (n=20). Standard curves and calibration curves were used to evaluate the amplification efficiency of each assay.The lower detection limit was 4.6 fg for CYP1A2 VIC/FAM, 5 ng for TNF-alpha FAM/FAM and 2.1 ng for BHK-21 FAM/FAM (R2 >0.992, linear equation). The intra- and inter-sample variation was also tested by repeating the quantitative assays on the same sample.
The chronic AR patients will be recruited by advertisements in local newspapers, internet forums, and social media.
The chronic AR patients on anti-allergic therapy will be excluded.

column1: 913,"1. Background: Over 3 million people in low and middle-income countries (LMIC) are infected with Mycoplasma genitalium (MG; hereinafter referred as MG), a sexually transmitted pathogen, which can cause symptoms of sexually transmitted infection (STI) including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), urethritis and cervicitis. These symptoms are often associated with other pathogens such as Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) and the diagnosis and treatment of patients with these symptoms can be challenging as MG is often misdiagnosed. The prevalence of MG in LMIC is very high in men who have sex with men (MSM) and heterosexual men, and also in people living with HIV (PLHIV). MG can be transmitted directly through sexual activity or indirectly via common genital fomites. As the disease burden of MG is extremely high especially in MSM and PLHIV, MG is now considered as an emerging STI in the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline. However, the prevalence of MG in Hong Kong is still unknown. Infection MG results in the emergence of gene mutations and strains with resistance to fluoroquinolone (FQ) and macrolide (M). The incidence of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) in MG is as high as 30-40% in HIV-infected populations in LMIC, and as high as 76% in our previous MG isolates. In addition, drug resistance in MG results in prolonged treatment and more frequent development of treatment-resistant bacterial infections. Nevertheless, there are currently no FDA- or CE-approved commercial diagnostic tests for MG ARGs, which are critical for drug susceptibility assessment and antimicrobial stewardship. MG ARGs are mostly confined to the flaB gene. In addition, some MG strains harbor multiple ARGs on the genome. Sequence data of MG ARGs has to be generated by sequencing the whole genome of MG or its 16S rRNA gene. However, the sequencing technique is complicated, the cost is high, and the turn-round time is relatively long. Therefore, a simple and low-cost ARGs detection technique to determine the status of MG strains is essential for clinical management and public health surveillance, but it is currently not available. 2. Objectives of our proposed study: We propose to develop a sensitive, rapid and cost-effective assay that can detect MG ARGs associated with resistance to M/FQ. The aim of our study is: To measure the prevalence of MG infection and the rate of infection of MG resistance mutations to M/FQ among HIV-infected male in Hong Kong To develop a new ARGs detection technique on pharyngeal and rectal MG samples to measure the prevalence of MG ARGs associated with resistance to M/FQ among HIV-infected male in Hong Kong To assess the clinical significance of the newly developed assay 3. Study design: Participants will be recruited from the HIV specialist clinic. The HIV specialist clinic attends approximately 1,000 patients monthly. Study participants will receive a self-sampling kit comprised of urine, pharyngeal and rectal swabs, patient information sheet, consent form and pre-paid envelope. Once a return envelope is received from a participant, the study team will retrieve his medical records and demographic information. This procedure will be repeated every three months. Samples collected from all the recruited participants will undergo nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for the detection of MG and NG / CT infections and MG ARGs detection by Sanger sequencing and in-house designed real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay. In addition, the total number of cases of other STI (syphilis, Hep C virus [HCV], etc.) diagnosed in the clinic will be obtained from patients' medical records to measure the overall prevalence of STI. The sensitivity and specificity of our newly developed assay will be compared with the conventional sequencing technique. The clinical and treatment responses to the prescribed antimicrobial regimens among the patients with MG infection (confirmed by the in-house designed ARGs detection method) will also be assessed The study period will be 1 year. Anticipated outcome measures: The prevalence of MG infection in the study population will be calculated by the proportion of cases confirmed by"

914,"18F-FES and FDG PET/CT will be used to evaluate the ER expression of metastatic breast cancer (MBC), specifically the tumor lesions that can be identified as ER+ in PET/CT (with 90% sensitivity and 95% specificity). We hypothesize that the ER expression levels of progressive MBC lesions will be significantly lower than that of non-progressive MBC lesions. This hypothesis will be tested using PET/CT imaging. The primary endpoint of this study is to investigate whether tumor lesions that can be identified as ER- in PET/CT before Dalpiciclib treatment are more likely to progress at an early stage. The secondary endpoint of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the investigational regimen. The treatment efficacy and disease control will be evaluated according to the RECIST 1.1 standard.
Input Text: The Prognostic Value of Predicting Recurrence of Colorectal Cancer in China

The goal of this study is to determine a novel prognostic parameter for recurrence. It's important that we will design and perform this study. A new model for predicting recurrence that takes into account the location of the tumor-the new model has both objective data and subjective data -is created. Then a new method is developed to find an answer to questions like are tumors on the left side more likely to recur than tumors on the right side? For this study, each person will complete a form during their medical visit. This form will have their name, medical record (chart) number, date of birth, and demographic information, such as their sex. It will also ask them to describe their disease symptoms. This information will only be available to our study team at the beginning and end of the study and after the patient's clinical records have been collected and de-identified. In addition, a subsample of the patients will be asked to fill out other forms to determine their physical and mental health. We will use laboratory data from patient records over the course of the disease to determine the predictive factors for disease recurrence. This information will be used to construct a model for predicting recurrence by location within the colon.

Objective We propose a nested case-control study of patients with CRC, who are being followed in the outpatient clinic at our center. Patients will be subdivided into the following subgroups based on the anatomical location of the tumor and the side of the colon: proximal non-cancerous (PNC), PNC with cancerous (PNC) and proximal non-cancerous colorectal with cancerous (PNCC). PNC are patients who were diagnosed with CRC in the proximal colon for whom the tumor was discovered on the same side of the colon. PNC with cancerous are patients diagnosed with CRC in the proximal colon who also have a history of at least one cancerous lesion located on the same side of the colon. Patients in the PNC subgroup will not be further subdivided due to the small sample size in this cohort. We will perform statistical analysis on the data using the statistical analysis software SPSS version 26. We anticipate enrolling approximately 200 patients from each of the above three subgroups, leading to a total of 600 enrolled patients; 100 cases per group. We hypothesize that patients with CRC on the right side (ascending and/or transverse colon, PNC) will have a lower incidence of recurrence than patients with CRC on the left side (splenic flexure, distal transverse colon, descending and sigmoid colon, PNC with cancerous, and PNCC). Study Population Patients enrolled in the study will be followed up during the first year after surgery. If there are recurrences during this period, these recurrences will be recorded as a case; otherwise, these cases would be considered as a control. Participation Criteria Inclusion Criteria -Patients who have been diagnosed with CRC in the proximal colon and have had their tumor resected surgically in our institution. All of these patients are under the care of our GI Oncologist in the GI Oncology Clinic Exclusion Criteria -Patients who have not had their tumor completely removed (R2 resection), or have not had pathological staging of the tumor. These patients are excluded from the study. The main exclusion criteria are as follows: Pathologic R2 resection No record of pathological staging of tumor Patients will also be excluded from the study"

915,"1.Objective:FISSION protocol is a single-arm, multicenter, first-line Phase II trial for patients suffering from resectable HER-2 negative or HER-2 status unknown recurrent gastric cancer/gastoesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.The purpose is to provide evidence-based therapy for patients with recurrent gastric cancer/gastoesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. 2.Background: Gastric cardia junction adenocarcinomas account for about 90% of all gastric cancers.In recent years, due to the improvement of endoscopy technology and the rapid development of minimally invasive techniques, the diagnosis and prognosis of patients with gastric cancer are constantly improving.The recurrence rate of patients with gastric cancer after surgical treatment is still high, which seriously affects the efficacy of surgery.Retroperitoneal metastatic, which can lead to unresectable lesions, often occurs in patients with recurrent stomach cancer, but there are still few clinical studies in the world.We hope to use Fruquintinib and Sintilimab combined with XELOX to reduce the recurrence rate of patients with gastric cardia junction adenocarcinomas on the one hand, and to increase the survival rate of patients after operation at the same time. 3.Eligibility: ① Patients meet the following criteria:-Gastric cardia junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis and histological or cytological examination to be HER-2 negative or unknown HER-2 gene status;-The primary foc or regional lymph node metastasis is 16a2,16b1,16a1,16b2 metastasis, and the main foc and regional lymph node metastasis can be cut off or the boundary can be cut off, and ≤5 lesions can be cut off;-In this study, the definition of transferring oligonucleotides is as follows: ② Aged 18-75 years; ③ ECOG PS score 0-1; ④ There is no previous treatment with VEGFR-targeted drugs or PD-1/PD-L1 antibodies; Expected survival time ≥3 months; ⑤ The main viscera function is good, namely liver, spleen, kidney and heart function indexes (within 14 days before check index meet the following requirements): 660 ml/min（Cockcroft-Gault formula); 7≤Fractional Excretion of sodium（FENa）≤13%; 8Total bilirubin≤2.5×Upper Limit Normal(ULN); 9Serum alanine aminotransferase(ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase(AST)≤5×ULN; 10Left ventricular ejection fraction(LVEF): ≥50%; 11Thyroid function indexes: thyroid stimulating hormone(TSH) and free thyroxine(FT3/FT4)were in the normal range or only mildly abnormal, without related clinical symptoms; 12A body weight of 40 kg or more, or a body mass index(BMI)： ≥18.5; ⑤ Exclusion Criteria: 1.Patients were diagnosed with other malignant tumors in the past or at the same time, but have been cured of early tumors, including basal cell carcinoma of the skin and carcinoma in situ of the cervix, stage I lung cancer, stage I colorectal cancer and other tumors that do not affect the patient's life in the short term according to the investigator's judgment; 2.Patients who received chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy 4 weeks before the start of treatment (6 weeks for nitrosoureas and mitomycin-C); 3.Multigen or multidrug combination immunotherapy, tumor vaccine, monoclonal antibody therapy, immunomodulatory drug therapy <4 weeks prior to randomization, or small molecule targeting immunotherapy drugs <2 weeks prior to randomization; 4.Participated in other clinical"

916,"Inactivity is a primary risk factor for global mortality and is associated with a range of chronic diseases (e.g., heart disease, diabetes). But inactivity does not receive as much attention as tobacco use and obesity. Inactivity leads to more hospitalizations and more visits to healthcare providers. Inactivity also costs the US healthcare system an extra $117 billion each year. Inactivity is a particularly serious issue for older adults.

But older adults are difficult to inspire to become more active and exercise. They are often retired, living alone, and experiencing mobility restrictions. Some are worried about falling and injuring themselves. This is why the investigators want to design incentives that are most likely to motivate more older adults to become more physically active. In this randomized controlled trial (RCT), the investigators will use smartphones and apps to track step count. Using behavioral economic principles, the investigators will offer two types of incentives to older adults to walk more: (1) a food donation to the Feeding America food bank on behalf of the participant - with the participant having the option of donating to a food bank in another community; and, (2) a personal financial incentive. If the intervention is successful, the investigators will be able to make a case that food-based incentives are an effective way to encourage physical activity in older adults who often rely on food banks. The investigators will also be able to make a case that financial incentives that accrue over time are a better way to motivate more older adults to increase their physical activity. A proof-of-concept study would enable the investigators to expand their research into a larger NIH-funded trial. This research aims to change physical and social norms around physical activity for older adults. In addition, this research will establish new approaches and innovative methods of behavioral activation that can be used by non-profit organizations, such as YMCA, that engage with older adults on a daily basis.

If the intervention is successful, the investigators will be able to make a case that food-based incentives are an effective way to encourage physical activity in older adults who often rely on food banks. 917,"In Kenya, 37% of all newborn deaths occur in the first week of a baby's life. 18.3% of all newborn mortalities are due to an infection, accounting for an average of 22,000 newborn deaths each year in the country. Newborns who are admitted to a hospital's neonatal ward have a survival rate of >90%, however, most infections and complications emerge around the time of discharge, i.e., after they have been transferred to the mother's bed to complete the kangaroo mother care (KMC) process. This implies that there may be a window of opportunity for earlier detection of physiological deterioration and treatment of the newborn prior to discharge.

The MTRH neonatal ward is arranged in 8 sub-units which comprise our comparison sub-groups. Newborns admitted from 1st April 2021 to 31st October 2022 comprise a pre-intervention period where they will receive the standard-of-care monitoring. During this period, a total of 1235 newborns will be monitored with the current standard-of care, to establish a baseline and reference point. Newborns admitted from 1st November 2022 onwards will be monitored using the neoGuard wireless vital signs monitor. Our hypothesis, therefore, is that the intervention will be able to identify and track physiological changes in the vital signs of the newborn better than the current standard-of-care, and that this will translate to better preventative care and/or treatment of newborn complications, resulting in fewer newborn deaths. The measurement of effectiveness will be performed at three levels: (1) device's ability to detect abnormal physiological signals and provide alerts/alarms that notify the nurses to check on a patient's status and; (2) alarms/alerts from level one that resulted in a necessary intervention being administered to the patient (valid alarms), versus all the alarms/alerts that did not necessitate an intervention (invalid alarms); (3) the month-to-month difference in newborn complication rates and treatment outcomes between the intervention group and comparison group."

918,"To date limited studies have been undertaken in frail patients, in particular in elderly patients with soft tissue sarcomas (STS). While STS is rare, in elderly patients, its incidence is significantly higher than in younger people. Therefore these patients often undergo conservative treatments (surgery with or without radiotherapy) which are ineffective in metastatic situations. In young people (< 60 years), the rate of locoregional recurrence is about 30% while surgery followed by neo-adjuvant irradiation could reduce this rate to 10%. With our protocol, we aim to better evaluate the impact of neo-adjuvant or adjuvant hypofractionated radiation therapy on these frail patients. This post-marketing phase II study (V1.1A03-1256) will be performed at the Rennes University Hospital Center, the Lyon University Hospital Center, the Avicène Hospitals of Grenoble (with a dedicated radiotherapy suite delivered by PREARTIS), the Nimes Hospital Center, the Aix-Marseille University Hospital Center, the University of Strasbourg Hospital Center, the Brest University Hospital Center, the Lyon Est University Hospital Center, the Nice-Cimiez University Hospital Center, the Caen University Hospital Center, the Amiens University Hospital Center, the Clermont-Ferrand University Hospital Center and, the Rouen University Hospital Center. For the moment we need 32 patients for each cohort (for a total of 64 patients) to demonstrate that neo-adjuvant or adjuvant irradiation is well tolerated."

919,"The purpose of this study was to determine the association between the use of anesthesia and the risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw, post exposure to chemotherapy and radiation therapy. A previous study reported that cancer treatment can cause osteonecrosis of the jaw. However, no study to date assessed if general anesthesia plays a role in this condition. This study compared two groups of breast cancer patients with and without osteonecrosis of the jaw. The study was conducted according to the Declaration of Helsinki and all the patients gave written consents for the study. Patients were retrospectively divided in two groups - patients with osteonecrosis of the jaw and control group without osteonecrosis. General anesthesia was not associated with a risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients undergoing radiation therapy and chemotherapy. A subgroup analysis revealed that general anesthesia was associated with a decrease in the risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw in those patients undergoing radiation only (relative risk=0.5). The authors hypothesized that a possible explanation for this protective effect may be associated to the decrease in salivary flow following the use of general anesthesia."

920,"18% American Indian and Alaskan Native youth and young adults have experienced post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and nearly 30% with PTSD report moderate to severe symptoms. Yet, a lack of culturally-specific treatment options have rendered PTSD treatment inaccessible. In our preliminary pilot work, a group of 22 AI/AN youth aged 12-21 years, who self-reported PTSD symptoms, were randomly assigned to either an online PTSD intervention designed to be relevant to AI/AN youth (i.e., TREAT) or a waitlist control (i.e., WRITE). Qualitative data suggest that TREAT may be particularly effective at improving symptoms, such as trauma-related upsetting memories and anger. The intervention showed promise on several key PTSD symptoms, with the exception of sleep-disordered breathing - a symptom prevalent in youth with PTSD in both a non-tribal and AI/AN context. Accordingly, in this study, the researchers will adapt and expand TREAT to target sleep-disordered breathing and develop a culturally-tailored and evidence-based treatment program for AI/AN youth.

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
Experimental: Online intervention
This study will examine the effectiveness of a cognitive-behavioral therapy delivered via a virtual (online) delivery method called Treating PTSD in American Indian and Alaskan Native Youth (TREAT) with the addition of a cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) informed sleep module (TREAT+Sleep). TREAT+Sleep will be delivered to 100 youth identified as meeting a post-traumatic stress disorder diagnosis via the Posttraumatic Diagnostic Scale - Child Version via online modules and will be delivered to youth who report problematic perceptions of sleep via the Sleep Disturbance Inventory for Children and Adolescents.
column3:

* TREAT is an intervention for youth with an 8-session format, 12 week duration, with optional biweekly booster sessions. Modules will be delivered via a virtual (online) delivery method called Treating PTSD in American Indian and Alaskan Native Youth (TREAT) with the addition of a cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) informed sleep module (TREAT+Sleep). TREAT+Sleep will be delivered to 100 youth identified as meeting a PTSD diagnosis via the Posttraumatic Diagnostic Scale - Child Version via online modules and will be delivered to youth who report problematic perceptions of sleep via the Sleep Disturbance Inventory for Children and Adolescents.

60 children and adolescents between the ages of 12 and 24 years of age that self-report positive responses to the PTSD screen of the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Disorders (SCID-5-CV). Participants who complete the TREAT intervention will be further assessed at post-intervention, 3-month, 6-month, 9-month, and 12-months post-intervention. Participants who complete the waitlist control will be further assessed at post-intervention, 3-months, 6-months, and 12-months post waitlist control.

column1: 921,"UPlift (Upadacitinib in Practice) is multi-country, post-marketing study of upadacitinib in participants with moderate to severe CD for up to three years. UPlift will assess speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in routine clinical care. UPlift will assess the proportion of participants achieving CR-PRO or HBI remission (if achieving CR-PRO) after upadacitinib initiation among those achieving CR-PRO during upadacitinib induction therapy. UPlift will also evaluate the proportion of participants who are upadacitinib treatment naïve and continue upadacitinib after upadacitinib induction therapy until Week 52."

922,"The goal of this study is to compare the effect of nab-paclitaxel plus Gemcitabine (NP+G) vs. Gemcitabine monotherapy (G) on 5-year pancreatic cancer-specific survival rate as first line treatment in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) patients.

Inclusion Criteria: Histologically confirmed PDAC Age 18 years or above ECOG Performance Status 0, 1 Adequate performance status to complete daily assessments of neuropathy, daily administration of oral medications, self-administration of subcutaneous medication and ability to fill out a diary card Adequate renal function defined as serum creatinine of 1.5 times the upper limit of normal Adequate hepatic function with serum total bilirubin ≤1 x UNL Alkaline phosphatase and AST no greater than 2.5 times UNL Absolute neutrophil count of ≥ 1.5 x 10^9/ Liter Platelets ≥ 100,000/uL Hemoglobin ≥ 9g/dL Adequate hemostatic function with international normalized ratio (INR) < 1.5 and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) < 1.5 x UNL Absence of a malignancy of another organ in the preceding 5 years, but excluding skin cancer and carcinoma in situ without evidence of extension or recurrence. Exclusion Criteria: Any other prior malignancy, other than skin carcinoma, breast cancer in situ, or cervical carcinoma in situ Patients should be recovered from all prior treatment (chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgery) before study enrollment. For patients who received chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgery, the cut-off time is 4 weeks. For patients who received hepatic artery embolization/infusion and/or stents, the cut-off time is 14 days Evidence of interstitial lung disease, active or previous pulmonary fibrosis or clinically significant interstitial lung disease, defined as: History of radiation pneumonitis that required steroids. History of drug-induced pneumonitis. Abnormal baseline chest computed tomography (CT) scan with evidence of extensive interstitial disease or pneumonia

column3: Intervention/Treatment

column2:
Experimental: NP+G
Pancreatic cancer patients will receive two pre-medications (antiemetics and steroids) on the morning of therapy (day 1 of 5-day cycle) by IV followed within 30-minutes by nab-paclitaxel (125mg/m2 weekly intravenously for 3 weeks; day 1, 8, and 15) and Gemcitabine (1000mg/m2 weekly intravenously on day 1). There will be no therapy after cycle 16 at investigator discretion. DEX is optional for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV).
column3:
Procedure: Nab Paclitaxel
* Patients will receive 2 IV pre-medications for CINV prophylaxis. The regimen includes dexamethasone 16mg po IV, administered over no more than 15 minutes on day 1 of treatment plus the oral regimen 5-HT3 antagonist (granisetron or palonosetron) + NK1 antagonist, either aprepitant (125 mg/day) or fosaprepitant 150 mg IV on initial day only or oral 5-HT3 antagonist"

column1: 923,"18–65-year-olds discharged from an inpatient psychiatric treatment facility in the previous 4 weeks will participate. At baseline and 18-months, participants will be interviewed to collect demographic, socioeconomic, clinical, recovery (e.g., social networks support), and service use data. A sample of participants will also be followed up over a 24-month period."

Vascular trauma accounts for an estimated 6% of trauma deaths, but in the UK most vascular trauma does not result in vascular death  but requires operative intervention and subsequent monitoring and/or treatment. However, there is little data about the long-term outcomes and how they are affected by variations in treatment pattern, or by trauma characteristics. The Vascular Trauma Study is a longitudinal, population-based cohort study of 1200 patients with any vascular injury identified as part of a UK trauma audit. The aim of the study is to determine the long-term outcomes of patients with vascular trauma. Methods and analysis

This study is funded and supported by the NIHR Surgical Reconstruction and Microbiology Research Centre. The cohort study will include patients with any vascular injury resulting from trauma (blunt or penetrating), registered to the Western Trauma Audit (WTA). The Trauma Managed Referral Vascular (TMR-V) project identified patients with vascular trauma following any of the following:
•	Injury to the common carotid, internal carotid artery, subclavian or external iliac arteries
•	Injury to the popliteal, superficial femoral, femoral profunda or common femoral artery
•	Surgical exploration of vascular structure without identification of an injury.

The study aims to develop detailed data on long-term outcomes (defined as survival and vascular complications) in all patients suffering trauma affecting any major artery (with the exception of the carotid artery) who survive the initial (hospital) phase of their injury. The aim is to identify factors, whether related to the injury, the treatment or the patient, which contribute to these outcomes.  The aim is to determine, and hence be able to predict, the proportion of patients likely to develop vascular complications following vascular trauma at differing timeframes (0–1, 1–5, >5 years). The first aim is to undertake a secondary analysis that will describe the cohort in more detail, including assessment of the quality of records submitted to the WTA, a comprehensive overview of the patterns of vascular trauma, an analysis of the initial assessment undertaken in hospital, with the aim of better understanding the injury severity, management, and prognosis. The findings of the secondary analysis will highlight the specific strengths and weaknesses of the WTA.
The primary objectives are as follows

1.	To determine the rates of (A) death and (B) vascular complications among patients in the cohort. The data will be collected by review of clinic notes and, where appropriate, imaging, blood samples and medical records
2.	To determine the time to (A) non-vascular related death and (B) vascular death, and, where available, to identify the cause of death

3.	To describe and determine the rates of any vascular complications requiring further treatment from a non-vascular death related to an ATRA-related complication in the subset of patients still alive  at time of follow-up  (1, 3, 5 and 10 years)
The exploratory objectives of this cohort study are to establish
•	The timeframes for the development of any vascular complications requiring further treatment
•	The prevalence and incidence of the various complications likely to be identified among the cohort
•	Risk factors for the development of any vascular complications requiring further treatment.
•	To evaluate factors associated with in-hospital mortality and major and minor vascular complications
•	Estimate the prevalence of each of the vascular injuries identified as part of the study over different time horizons
•	Assess the quality of data recorded for each injury recorded
•	Compile a comprehensive record of the diagnostic tests and therapeutic interventions provided for each patient
•	Identify factors that contribute to outcomes for patients with trauma involving specific vascular structures
•	Evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the various screening and monitoring strategies in the management of trauma involving the specific vascular structures
The following hypothesis will be tested through the secondary analysis
1.	The rate of mortality is independent of the type of vascular injury
2.	The rate of vascular complications is independent of the type of vascular injury (except where the treatment provided involves the specific vascular structure)
3.	The rates of morbidity and mortality following vascular trauma are associated with the severity of the injury and the type of treatment provided by the responsible clinician

Aging populations and increased frequency of distal radius fractures will significantly burden healthcare systems in the coming years. Studies have shown the efficacy of physical therapy following distal radius fracture surgery in order to restore pain-free and functional motion. These fractures commonly occur in elderly patients and affect the strength, mobility and quality of life in their post-operative recovery.

Distal Radius fractures are one of the most frequently occurring fractures in the US. They affect 250,000 people in the US per year, and often accompany other fractures in elderly osteoporotic patients such as wrist, arm or shoulder fractures. Furthermore distal radius fractures are common in geriatric patient population as up to 60% of fractures occur in women over the age of 60. Fractures of the wrist and hand and their subsequent surgeries can cause severe damage to quality of life due to the lack of function. Proper rehabilitation following the procedure can help restore wrist and hand strength and functionality of the patients.
Hypothesis: Blood Flow Restriction can accelerate bone mineral density (BMD) after ORIF of a distal radius fracture

The study will be a prospective randomized control trial consisting of adults aged over 18 years who experience an isolated distal radius fracture and require operative fixation of the fracture. Subjects will be randomized by block to either the intervention or control group in a 1:1 fashion immediately post operative. This study will involve 90 patients in total in which 45 patients will receive blood flow restriction treatment and 45 will be part of the control group.

* Patients in the active treatment arm will receive additional physical therapy treatment with the use of a blood flow restriction cuff. During this time patients will be taught at-home exercises. The therapy will also include the use of hand therapy devices such as parallel bars, hand weights and grip strengthening devices to optimize patient recovery. Patients will be educated on how use of this equipment will accelerate their recovery. The BFR cuff will be monitored and regularly updated to the appropriate Blood Flow Restriction pressure. The pressure within the cuff will be monitored throughout each exercise session to determine the individual patients' occlusion pressure.

column1: 926,"This is a randomised parallel-group trial. The outcomes will be assessed at all points of follow-up (T0, T1, T2). Both groups will be measured at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months. The experimental group will receive the computer prompt Stand Up for Your Health® plus educational information, while the control group will receive only educational information. The same measurements will be completed in both groups during the 6-month follow-up period: sedentary behaviour (Actigraph accelerometers and the Occupational Sitting and Physical Activity Questionnaire (OSPAQ); musculoskeletal symptoms (pressure pain algometer/VAS and the Nordic Questionnaire of Perception of Musculoskeletal Symptoms); and cardiometabolic markers/HbA1c and anthropometric measurements/waist and hip circumference. Barriers and facilitators will be determined by applying the Theory of Planned Behaviour in a subgroup of participants. This information may help to evaluate the efficacy of the intervention and to inform public health practice."

927,"The effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) training, in combination with creatine supplementation on peripheral and central adaptations to eight weeks of training in previously resistance trained women. This study is a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized control trial. It compares four groups: (1) placebo and BFR; (2) placebo and no-BFR; (3) creatine and BFR; and (4) creatine and no-BFR. Participants will be randomized with stratification based on time since resistance training. Blood samples will be collected at baseline, eight and fourteen weeks after the eight weeks of training. The researchers will measure mood states, body composition, endothelial function and lower-body strength throughout the study."

929,"4. PROSPECTIVITY: The study aims to increase the ability to observe complications that occur after pleural procedures. PROSPECT has been designed to improve understanding and reporting of all complications at a patient care level and to develop a platform for prospective and longitudinal studies using data collected during routine clinical practice. The objectives of PROSPECT are to: (i) assess variation in complications associated with common pleural interventions across multiple centres, (ii) create a system to facilitate prospective observation of complications following pleural procedures, (iii) establish a collaborative group to assess the data provided and (iv) determine the effect of the procedural experience and expertise (clinician level and specialist centre) on patient outcomes by analysis of available radiological images. PROSPECT is designed as a prospective observational study.

Pleural diseases, Pleural mesothelioma, Pneumothorax, Pleural effusion, Pleural infection, Pleural neoplasms, Pleural Metastases, Pleural effusion, Malignant, Procedural Complication, Complications, Pulmonary

1. Primary outcome: Complications will be objectively defined in terms of major and minor complications. The primary objective is to determine variation in the occurrence of pleural procedure induced complications including symptomatic complications (such as haemothorax/ pneumothorax) and minor complications such as short-lasting pain or dyspnoea.

2. Secondary outcome 1: The secondary objective is to assess changes in dyspnoea and chest pain as measured by a patient reported outcome measure (PROM) at four time points: pre-procedure, post-procedure, and then 4 weeks and 6 months later where appropriate.

3. Secondary outcome 2: The secondary objective is to assess changes in the dyspnoea and chest pain as measured by a patient reported outcome measure (PROM) at four time points: pre-procedure, post-procedure, and then 4 weeks and 6 months later where appropriate.

4. Secondary outcome 3: PROSPECT is a multi-centre study which will assess variation in the occurrence of both major and minor complications over time and across multiple centres. We will create a system to facilitate prospective observation of complications following pleural procedures, and establish a collaborative group to assess the data provided.

5. Secondary outcome 4: The secondary objective is to provide an audit tool to facilitate review of data collected by the study and allow for an analysis of procedural experience and expertise (clinician level and specialist centre) on patient outcomes."

930,"The incidence of atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD) is increasing worldwide. Although coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) is a highly sensitive and non-invasive imaging technique for ruling-out obstructive CAD, it does not provide information useful for further risk stratification of patients with non-obstructive CAD. We propose an AI-based analysis that can integrate the CAD characteristics and other potential prognostic factors to create a novel AI-based prognostic model that can identify patients with non-obstructive CAD and stratify their risk of developing major adverse cardiovascular events. The overall specific aim is to develop a novel predictive and prognostic model for CAD based on AI-based risk stratification that incorporates imaging- and non-imaging biomarkers, and assesses its predictive accuracy in high-risk sub-populations. The proposed study will encompass a retrospective cohort and a prospective cohort. The retrospective cohort will provide sufficient data for training and validating the AI-based model based on coronary vessel wall characteristics, pericoronary adipose tissue characteristics, coronary topography features, other imaging characteristics and clinical parameters. The prospective cohort will provide additional insights about the potential effect of AI-based risk stratification on the overall management approach, clinical outcomes and healthcare costs.

The incidence of atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD) is increasing worldwide. Although coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) is a highly sensitive and non-invasive imaging technique for ruling-out CAD, it does not provide information useful for further risk stratification of patients with non-obstructive CAD. We propose an AI-based analysis that can integrate the CAD characteristics and other potential prognostic factors to create a novel AI-based prognostic model that can identify patients with non-obstructive CAD and stratify their risk of developing major adverse cardiovascular events.

1 To create and validate an Artificial Intelligence-Based (AI-based) prognostic model to predict cardiac death or MI within 12 months in patients with stable CAD undergoing a coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA).
2 To assess if AI-based risk stratification influences patient management in patients with stable CAD undergoing a cCTA.
Retrospective and prospective cohort study including outpatients with stable CAD who have undergone a cCTA at our center in the past 12 months.
Patients will be stratified into two groups, based on the AI-based prognostic model risk score: those at a lower risk; those at a higher risk.
The AI-based prognostic model will be then evaluated in terms of risk-stratification accuracy and clinical outcomes.

The proposed study will: I. provide the basis for the development of a novel AI-based prognostic model for CAD in high-risk sub-populations; II. assess the influence of AI-based risk stratification in modifying patient management and determining the clinical and economic impact of AI-assisted risk stratification in patients with stable CAD."

According to the results of safety evaluation, the second dose level group will be included. 2) In the second dose level group: 62.5 mg edaravone D2W dextromethorphan concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical treatment in patients with cerebral hemorrhage will be included, and efficacy and safety will be evaluated by the independent monitoring committee (DMC). 932,"1,733 patients discharged from Wuhan Yintan Hospital between January 7 and May 29, 2020, and 15% of the patients reported persisting symptoms 2 months after infection. Foreign researchers conducted a follow-up study on 16,091 adult patients with novel coronavirus in the United States from February 5, 2021 to July 6, 2022, and 15% of the patients reported persisting symptoms 2 months after infection. Therefore, how to effectively delay symptoms and promote recovery is one of the key concerns in the research field of novel coronavirus infection. 933,"30 healthy volunteers will undergo an experimental procedure for 6 minutes in an MRI scanner to compare 2 different methods of performing fMRI. The overall aim is to compare the use of 'in-house' developed method of 'single-shot' EPI acquisition with the 'standard' 'multi-shot' gradient-echo EPI acquisition to assess whether the standard method results in increased signal noise and reduced acquisition efficiency. The study will aim to characterise the differences in image quality, signal noise, acquisition efficiency and subject comfort in performing the MRI procedure.

MRI scanning at a single time-point with no intervention. Participants will be allocated to one group of subjects receiving one type of scan (e.g., 'in-house' single-shot EPI acquisition and 'standard' multi-shot gradient-echo EPI acquisition).

'Exposure': Single MRI scan of 6 minutes in an MRI scanner using a ‘standard’ multi-shot gradient-echo single-shot EPI acquisition (approximately 200 single slices acquired, total time approximately 2.5 mins). Control: Single MRI scan of 6 minutes using ‘in-house’ developed single-shot EPI acquisition (approximately 100 single slices acquired, total time approximately 2.5 mins).
To identify whether a novel single-shot MRI sequence provides the same signal quality, acquisition efficiency and subject comfort compared to commonly used 'standard' MRI sequences.

30 healthy volunteers will be recruited aged 18 to 80. Volunteers should be free from neurological disease. The number of participants needed to achieve a statistically significant result can be calculated with a power calculation.

Abnormal neurological examination, a history of neurological disease, or a history of relevant metal or magnetic-sensitive implants, tattoo in or on the skin in the head region, head-wear, etc, in the MRI scanner area.

column1: Neutrocheck is a patient-oriented mobile application that provides information about a patient's neutrophil count and risk and advice to the patient on the basis of their neutrophils. NeutroCheck will be a platform to help patients and clinicians manage neutropenia. NeutroCheck is funded by an international foundation, The D'Ont and Henrik Thörn foundations. The overall objective is to identify the main user-centred design problems in NeutroCheck. To investigate whether user characteristics such as age, gender, past experience with blood test devices, and past experience with mobile applications correlates with errors, close calls or difficulties when using Neutrocheck. To assess the usability of Neutrocheck when different educational levels, age categories and past app usage are considered. To analyse and prioritise usability and user experience needs to improve Neutrocheck. To investigate the key safety information for usage of Neutrocheck. To compare Neutrocheck against paper instructions in terms of task completion rate.
Rare Disease, Blood, Inflammation and Immune System
Primary outcomes are identification of use errors, close calls and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios, and participant's perceived root causes.

Secondary outcomes are administration of a questionnaire to assess the effectiveness of key information for safety and comparison of descriptive statistics for task completion between two study groups, one using paper instructions and the other using app instructions, and administration of a questionnaire to measure user satisfaction with the use of Neutrochat.

CARE-DINING increased time spent on activities for both participants and the nursing home staff compared to usual care and this increased time spent on CARE-DINING was evenly distributed between the participants and the nursing home staff.

This randomized controlled trial evaluated the effectiveness of the CARE-DINING system on increasing time spent on activities in nursing home residents with cognitive impairment. There were no specific health problems or conditions studied. The CARE-DINING system aims to increase time spent on activities by prompting staff and residents to engage in purposeful interactions throughout their daily routines.
Nursing home staff and residents used the CARE-DINING system throughout their daily routines (meal time & bathroom breaks) for six months. The CARE-DINING system consists of the following components:
CARE-DINING sensor: a wearable wrist sensor that is linked to a central server;
Smart tablet: a personal tablet for each resident, mounted at the resident's bedside;
Activity Monitor: a tablet connected to a TV at each nursing unit;
Personalized Care Plans: based on the resident's assessment, including their strengths, preferences, and priorities for care;
Personalized Care Plans: based on the resident's assessment, including their strengths, preferences, and priorities for care; and
CARE-DINING app: an app for the nursing home staff that shows them a real-time overview of the resident's CARE-DINING activities and their progress over time.
Implementing CARE-DINING in line with the Dutch protocol;
Capacity to receive electronic data from the data coordinating centre (DCC).

Living in nursing homes in the Netherlands;
Being part of the regular care in nursing homes;
Not being able to express consent (no written or verbal consent provided);

936,"The objectives of this study are to: (i) evaluate the feasibility of the laughter yoga programme in adolescents with mild and moderate intellectual and physical disabilities and (ii) to examine the effect sizes of the laughter yoga programme on the mood, anxiety and loneliness levels of adolescents with disabilities.
This is a pre-post single-blind pilot randomized controlled trial with parallel, active control arm.

Study population: Participants include adolescents with mild and moderate intellectual and physical disabilities who are aged between 10 to 19 years old. Study will be conducted in a Special School located in Hong Kong.

Study design and procedure: The laughter yoga programme will be performed in 8 sessions for 4 weeks, an approximate of 15 minutes per session. After completing the 4-week, post-test assessment will be performed on both intervention and control groups.

Mood Scale, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6), and Loneliness Scale for adolescents will be applied to assess the effects of intervention on the mood, anxiety and loneliness levels, respectively."

937,"1 in 2 South Asian women is undiagnosed for cervical cancer. South Asian women have poorer uptake of cervical screening by around a quarter compared to Chinese women. Women who are not eligible for the free national cervical screening program, do not have a regular general practitioner or don't have a local cervical screening provider have even greater cervical screening gaps. The investigators aim to develop and evaluate screening decision aids including mobile app decision aids, that support South Asian women to make informed decisions on cervical screening by addressing their barriers and concerns, and promote screening uptake."
