Input Text: A New Method Compared to the Classic Vestibular Rehabilitation Exercises for Balance Rehabilitation After Concussion : a Randomized Controlled Trial

Concussion is defined as a complex pathophysiological process induced by biomechanical forces. The consequences of this injury are wide-ranging and may include temporary alteration of brain function. It should be distinguished from the traumatic brain injury (TBI) that can cause significant neurological deficits or personality changes. These may persist for weeks, months or even years. Balance impairment is frequently observed in concussion. Postural control is the ability to maintain equilibrium in the presence of perturbations resulting from postural instability. Postural balance control uses various sensory information - vision, vestibular, proprioception - to control the body's movement. The posture is therefore affected when the cerebral cortex that controls balance is injured. Several vestibular rehabilitation exercises have already been developed to improve postural control in people with postural disorders. This study compares our new method to a classic manual therapy method to treat people suffering from a vertiginous episode after concussion.

Recruitment of patients and control subjects, a medical and motor examination will take place to characterize the study population, to classify the presence of signs of vertigo, to quantify the degree of balance disorder, and to quantify the presence of other motor or sensory disorders (proprioception, visual field). Exposure of patients to one single therapy modality ( vestibular rehabilitation exercises or postural control exercises ) and to a conventional treatment ( analgesics, hot/cold treatments, stretching, etc ). The therapist who will perform the postural exercises will be a physiotherapist who will be trained in our new method, which will ensure objectivity in the delivery of this type of treatment. Data related to the functional evolution of patients over the course of treatment will also be collected ( postural disorder, visual problems, etc.). This information will be entered on a computer and analyzed using appropriate software.
A Study Evaluating the Efficacy of Balance Rehabilitation Exercises After Concussion: a Randomized Controlled Trial.

Inclusion Criteria: A clinical or paraclinical (Computed Tomography- Ct, Magnetic resonance imaging- mri) examination has been performed and is available; Age between 18 and 70 years. Exclusion Criteria: Patient with a post-concussion syndrome diagnosed according to standard diagnostic criteria ; Patient with a brain pathology (neoplasm, stroke, etc.) ; Patient who underwent vestibular rehabilitation exercises in the past; Patient having taken drugs that act on the vestibular system; Patient with vestibular problems prior to the accident.

Gluten related disorders pose major challenges in diagnosis and management. Even though gluten free diet is a mainstay of management and the only effective treatment, currently available studies are mainly based on co-morbid conditions in patients with celiac disease and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The objective of our study is to evaluate the severity and the impact in the quality of life of patients having gluten related disorders, to explore the co-morbidities associated with celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. To evaluate whether patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity have better symptoms control following a gluten free diet. To identify the impact of nutraceuticals on patients with celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.

Inclusion Criteria: The patients of both the genders in the age group of 18-65 years with diagnosis of gluten related disorders including celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity and wheat allergy, patients who can understand and communicate in English or in the local vernacular and who provide a written consent. The patients with celiac disease or non-celiac gluten sensitivity, who are on a gluten free diet for at least 3 months and are symptomatic despite a gluten free diet will be recruited. 20 patients with gluten related disorders ( celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity and wheat allergy) with or without co-morbidities such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and systemic conditions such as iron deficiency anemia, dermatitis herpetiformis, osteopenia/osteoporosis and thyroid disease Exclusion Criteria: History of malabsorption other than gluten related disorders (e.g. tropical malabsorption syndromes, Whipple's disease, cystic fibrosis, celiac sprue), Small bowel bacterial overgrowth, Chronic gastrointestinal diseases (e.g. cancer of gastrointestinal tract, celiac disease, peptic ulcer, inflammatory bowel disease), Pregnancy, Diagnosed as malignancy, Taking gluten as part of treatment for non-celiac gluten sensitivity as per dietitian's advice or under nutritional support protocol. Active/inadequately treated psychiatric illness including depression or psychosis (as per Diagnostic and Statistical Manual-IV [DMS-IV) criteria), Inability to comply with the follow up schedules and gluten free diet, Unwillingness of subjects to provide written informed consent.

Celiac Disease, Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity, Wheat Allergy

940,"1. Introduction: The shoulder is the second most frequent location of musculoskeletal pain after the spine. Shoulder pain is a common problem, with a prevalence of 7.5% in the general population. Among working age adults, this prevalence rises to 26.9%. Rotator cuff injury, a common cause of shoulder pain, results in reduced function and quality of life. The treatment goal is to restore function and decrease pain with minimal long-term disability. However, the relationship between rotator cuff tear size and shoulder function is not well understood, and current treatment approaches often fail to achieve adequate outcomes. Therefore, it is important to understand how shoulder function is affected by rotator cuff injury and tear size. Potential confounding factors, such as differences in participant demographics, must also be considered to ensure accurate and comprehensive results. 2. Rationale and objectives: Rotator cuff injury is a common problem, and its treatment goal is to restore function and decrease pain with minimal long-term disability. However, current treatment approaches often fail to achieve adequate outcomes. The relationship between rotator cuff tear size and shoulder function is not well understood. There is currently a lack of data on how shoulder muscle activation patterns are altered by rotator cuff tear size. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to determine whether there is a relationship between scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation and rotator cuff tear size, and whether any differences in activation patterns can be linked to tear size and/or potentially predict treatment outcome. 3. Methods: Prospective, open-label cohort study evaluating scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation and tear size as potential prognosticators for successful rotator cuff surgery. Data will be collected using surface electromyography (sEMG) to measure muscle activation amplitude and functional tasks to assess shoulder function. 4. Objectives: The primary objective of this study is to investigate the relationship between scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation patterns and rotator cuff tear size. The study will also provide preliminary data on potential prognosticators, such as muscle activation amplitude, for successful rotator cuff surgery. 5. Relevance: Current treatment approaches for rotator cuff injury often fail to achieve adequate outcomes. Identifying potential prognosticators, such as muscle activation amplitude, and understanding the relationship between scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation patterns and rotator cuff tear size can help improve the treatment of rotator cuff injury, resulting in better patient outcomes and improved quality of life. 6. Conclusion: This study will improve the existing knowledge on the effects of rotator cuff tear size on shoulder function and muscle activation patterns. It may also lead to the development of future clinical trials that examine the treatment outcome prediction. Such studies would be valuable for improving our understanding of rotator cuff injury and developing more effective treatment approaches."

The prevalence of malnutrition in elderly (≥ 65 years) is higher than 5% 1. Furthermore, its incidence is increasing every year especially in those who need an emergency healthcare 1. Consequently, malnutrition is associated with worse clinical outcomes and with an increased risk of mortality 2–3.

For this reason, nutritional assessment in older adults is essential but is often neglected. In many countries, diagnostic assessments are recommended only in cases of clinical malnutrition, but several studies have reported that the screening process for malnutrition can significantly reduce the incidence of malnutrition and improve outcomes in the elderly.
Along with the screening of malnutrition, nutritional intervention are necessary in the diagnosis, as a part of a multifactorial rehabilitation of elderly patients.

The most recommended evidence-based nutritional protocols are those developed by Italian and Australian researches. These nutrition protocols are highly based on proteins, energy and water needs and are often recommended in literature 5–6. As well, the inclusion of fruit and vegetables, as also shown by the Mediterranean diet, has become mandatory in recent years both for its benefits from nutritional point of view and for its sustainability.

Food sustainability, according to the definition of Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations, is defined as that which meets the needs of current and future generations from an economic, social and environmental 7 perspective.

During the last decades there has been a significant shift of attention to sustainable dietary patterns. Thus, it is mandatory to study strategies and actions regarding the food chain, from production to consumption and waste, in order to feed and nourish the population, while also protecting the planet and our health.
This study has been designed to investigate and evaluate sustainable nutritional protocols aimed at preventing and treating malnourished older adults.
The sustainable nutritional intervention is highly effective in improving malnourishment in older adults.

The primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post- intervention between experimental and control group measuring body weight and strength (handgrip) changes in body weight and handgrip.

The secondary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post- intervention between experimental and control group measured in blood biomarkers, diet composition, phase angle and gait speed changes.
Primary and secondary outcomes will be assessed by independent researchers with mixed linear models and independent sample t-tests.

The primary outcome will be measured comparing the experimental and control group. The secondary outcomes will be measured comparing the experimental and control groups at three timepoints. Moreover, the change in nutritional status within the experimental and control group will be evaluated at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months.
The baseline assessment will be conducted by trained nurses or nutritionists.
The inclusion criteria are age ≥ 65 years old, malnutrition (GLIM diagnosis), and admission to two Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institutions in Pavia, Italy.

The exclusion criteria are dysphagia, prior nutritional medical treatment, current oncological treatment, serious dementia or severe confusion (MMSE score < 24/30), active severe acute and chronic respiratory failure, terminal diseases (such as cancer or terminal organ failure), and history of gastric bypass, anorexia nervosa and liver failure.
All participants will participate on a voluntary basis following detailed description of the project and will sign an informed consent form prior to study entry.

After inclusion in the study, participants will be automatically randomized (1:1 allocation) into the experimental or control arm using computer-generated block randomization and according to a randomization sequence list generated by the sponsor.
The randomization sequence will be kept in a confidential file and will be accessible only to a qualified staff.

All analyses will be performed using R. Data set descriptions and statistical method of analysis, a detailed Data Analysis Plan and the statistical software that will be used will be submitted by a qualified staff for approval to principal investigator and statisticians.

A statistical analysis plan will be written before database locking and will be also submitted to the aforementioned staff to check its consistency and coherence. Only after these analyses, the database will be unlocked.
The primary analysis will compare the experimental and control"

Fish has a positive effect on our health and the immune system, in particular. This is because fishes provide nutrients rich in proteins, vitamins, minerals, fatty acids, as well as several other biological factors that support a well-functioning organism. Omega-3 fatty acids in particular have been linked to improving immune functioning. Vitamin D is a very important vitamin for many reasons. It is produced by the body when exposed to sunlight, but it can also be found in some foods, such as salmon and tuna. Many people are deficient in vitamin D, which can lead to numerous health issues. People deficient in vitamin D are more likely to suffer from a weakened immune system. Vitamin D deficiency is also associated with an increased risk of developing respiratory conditions, autoimmune diseases, cardiovascular diseases, and diabetes. In this randomized, double-blinded, multi-center study, the effectiveness of fish oil, vitamin D3, and omega-3 fatty acid supplementation on immunological factors will be compared with those of a placebo. In addition, the effects of three-month supplementation will be determined.

The objective of this randomized, double-blinded, multi-center study is to determine the effect of three-month supplementation with 2 grams of fish oil, 1500 IU of vitamin D3, both, or a placebo on the following: Blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) Blood levels of vitamin D Natural killer cell function (using Flow Cytometry) The study will include 18 patients who will be randomized to receive either 2 grams of fish oil, 1500 IU of vitamin D3, both, or a placebo. The study will be conducted over a three-month period. Patients will be asked to complete a questionnaire at the beginning and end of the study. Blood will be collected at the beginning and end of the study to determine blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) and vitamin D. Natural killer cell function will be assessed using a validated Flow Cytometry method. The sample size for the study is n = 27 in each arm.
Influence of Fish Oil, Vitamin D3 and Omega-3 Fatty Acids Supplementation on Immune Function in Children With Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases-A Randomised Controlled Trial Study

Inclusion Criteria: primary immune deficiency diseases Exclusion Criteria: chronic use (last 6 months) of oral fish oil supplements allergic to fish and its derivatives currently taking daily oral vitamin D supplements of more than 1000 IU/day, as well as any other contraindication to oral vitamin D supplementation treatment with more than 1000 IU vitamin D per day in the previous month during pregnancy

Input Text: Metabolic and Behavioral Treatments for Youth with Overweight/Obesity and High Rates of Impulsiveness

Childhood obesity is a very challenging public health problem. Behavioral treatments are effective in promoting health in children and adolescents with overweight and obesity, but adherence to treatment is relatively low in clinical settings. Metabolism is altered in obesity, and these adaptations may interact with behavioral regulation. There is growing evidence to suggest that impulsive eating behavior is associated with obesity and weight gain, and may be a mechanism for reduced adherence to dietary treatment regimens. The present study aims to develop and test the efficacy of a transdiagnostic multimodal intervention that combines cognitive behavioral treatment with an intervention based on metabolic control and to assess treatment adherence. In a prospective multi-center randomized controlled trial overweight and obese children with high levels of impulsive eating behavior will be randomized to intervention groups (n = 136) or inactive control groups (n = 136), which will also receive the cognitive behavioral therapy. This sample size will allow us to detect between-group reductions in BMI of at least 0.5 points and at least 0.2 kg/m2 in body composition. Measures of feasibility, acceptability, adherence, and potential mediators and moderators of treatment effectiveness will be measured.

This study represents an intervention model that includes three areas of intervention: i) behavior change, by incorporating evidence-based strategies for overweight, obesity and eating disorders (cognitive-behavioral therapy, diet and physical activity) into a single intervention that is based on a dynamic model for behavior change; ii) metabolic control, by developing and testing an intervention based on metabolic control, and iii) impulsive eating behavior, by incorporating strategies specifically designed to reduce impulsive eating behavior in overweight and obese children. The transdiagnostic intervention is based on the hypothesis that overweight and obesity arise from multiple causes that need to be addressed by the intervention. The metabolic intervention has been developed by a multidisciplinary research team. It includes a pharmaco-nutritional component (the composition of the meals will be determined in a clinical trial that will be performed parallel to this study). The impulsive eating intervention will be developed in collaboration with a team of experienced nutritionists. We have previous experience with this type of transdiagnostic multimodal treatment. Pilot studies have shown that the impulsive eating intervention produces measurable and clinically relevant improvements in impulsiveness, self-esteem and adaptive eating behavior. The interventions will be delivered by clinicians at participating clinical centers. All interventions are designed by a group of specialists and will be provided in the context of clinical practice. The proposed research will improve the efficacy and acceptability of behavioral treatment and reduce drop-out rates in overweight and obese children. Our research represents an innovative approach to the development of transdiagnostic multimodal interventions for behavior change. It will be a first step towards a long-term goal of developing novel treatment approaches that target the cognitive, metabolic and behavioral levels in obesity and eating disorders.
Metabolic and Behavioral Treatments for Youth With Overweight/Obesity and High Rates of Impulsiveness: a Randomized Controlled Trial
Body Weight (BWM ≥ 95% Percentile to BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2), Impulsive Eating

The purpose of this study is to investigate whether the type of cooking oil used affects the levels of metabolic risk markers (such as blood glucose, cholesterol and blood pressure) in Chinese adults. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: those who consume cooking oil containing a mixture of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids, and those who consume cooking oil containing a mixture of fatty acids. The fat composition of the two cooking oils will be the same, but the amount of saturated fatty acids will be different (0% vs 15% saturated fatty acids). The amount of oil and the number of meals eaten during the study will be determined based on individual body mass index (BMI) and daily energy expenditure. Participants will consume their usual diet, but any changes in fat intake will be measured."

947,"BACKGROUND: Upper extremity coordination while walking is believed to play a role in dynamic balance, gait stability, and gait initiation. When the upper extremities swing back and forth with the legs when a person walks, this movement helps to increase the body's stability and is known as arm swing. Individuals who have difficulty maintaining stability while walking as well as those with reduced arm swing have been noted to have reduced walking performance. There are limited data on objective arm swing measurements in individuals with neurological disorders and no known investigation on the arm swing in Early MS participants. The hypothesis of the current study is that arm swing will be abnormal in patients who have impaired walking speed and that this abnormality will be more prominent in Early MS participants. OBJECTIVE: The current study tested the hypothesis that arm swing will be abnormal in patients who have impaired walking speed and that this abnormality will be more prominent in Early MS participants. METHODS: 45 participants with MS and 45 healthy controls will be recruited from the MS clinic at the Cleveland Clinic and the MS Society in Cleveland, Ohio. Evaluation of the arm swing during walking will be conducted with the help of the Kinovea video player in both groups and functional tests such as Two Minute Walk Test and Timed Up and Go will also be performed in those participants to test their walking performance. The arm swing amplitude will be calculated and compared in each group. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION: The arm swing measurements and functional tests will give a better understanding of the changes that neurological disorders cause to an individual's balance as well as the changes that occur early in the course of Multiple Sclerosis."

949,"The main purpose of this study is to evaluate the performance of a new 3D printed device (the Bionic Ear 3D printed hearing aid (3D Bionic)) that has better power handling capability at lower frequencies than a conventional, custom made hearing aid, and to evaluate subjective and objective outcomes that are achieved with the 3D Bionic.

This study will assess the performance and outcome measurement data provided using a 3D printed hearing aid device. This study will specifically look at the performance and outcome data of those fitting a 3D printed hearing aid in relation to the outcome data provided for those fitting a conventional or custom made hearing aid. We hypothesize that the 3D printed hearing will provide better power handling to deliver speech and music into the ear canal with increased fidelity. The outcome data from the 3D printed hearing aid will be compared to that of a traditionally made hearing aid in order to compare the overall performance and outcome data. This study is needed to compare the results of 3D printed hearing aid to those provided by the traditionally made hearing aid.
An Evaluation of the Bionic Ear 3D Printed Hearing Aid Compared to the Performance and Outcome Measures of a Conventional and Custom Made Hearing Aid

Inclusion Criteria: Ages 18 or older Adult participants with moderate or severe hearing loss (range of 40-90 dB) who wear a bilateral pair of hearing aids and have been fitted with the 3D Bionic (3D Bionic) or traditional hearing aid (Conventional) for 2 weeks or more. Exclusion Criteria: Patients with severe medical illnesses as well as patients with ear pathologies such as a chronic ear infection, a perforated eardrum, or otitis externa. Patients with mental disabilities or dementia, such as the disease of Alzheimer.

column1: The PACHA program consists of 4 components: a 85-minutes web-based training to prepare the pharmacist for delivery of the intervention, a standardized consultation guide based on motivational interviewing to guide AET consultations (by phone or in person), web sheets describing (non)pharmacological strategies to cope with side effects and other AET-related concerns (e.g. sexuality) and, finally, access to resources (web resources, printed materials in pharmacy, telephone numbers for local and national cancer support networks) for women with AET.
The study includes 3 components: a pilot randomized controlled study and a qualitative evaluation for feasibility and acceptability of the PACHA program.

The pilot study will examine whether the PACHA program has an effect on pharmacists and women's knowledge, attitude, social support, perceived control and intent to adhere to AET. Our main hypothesis is that the 2 groups will not evolve differently in the studied outcomes.
The qualitative component will examine pharmacists and women's perception and experience of participating in the feasibility study and the acceptability and perceived benefits of the PACHA program.

Inclusion Criteria: Healthy men and women, aged 35-65 years BMI 18-30 Kg/m2 Exclusion Criteria: Signs of liver, kidney, thyroid or gastrointestinal dysfunction Evidence of allergy to excipients, including soy protein hydrolysate (SPH) used as a carrier of the active substance Sensitivity to alcohol, drugs or plant remedies, including melissa (L. lemonii) or its main component MelissaOfficinalis (L. lemonii) and MelissaPhytosome Excessive physical activity or excessive intake of alcohol or caffeine 30 days before the study period History of psychiatric illness, depression, anxiety or epilepsy History or evidence of sleep apnea Syndrome or other sleep disorders (i.e. restless leg syndrome. periodic leg movement syndrome) Smoking or other habits that would affect the subjective data collected during the study Pregnancy, lactation, or desire to become pregnant during the study.

Interventional Model Description: A total of 8 blocks with 4 subjects per block, each block composed by a sequence of four treatments (A, B, C, D), will be randomised as 4 sequences, which will be created by sampling the sequences: ABCD; CBDDA; DABC; DCBA. Each subject will be randomly assigned to one of the four treatment sequences. The study design is therefore a two-by-two factorial design, with subjects self-administered the active ingredient or placebo for 2 weeks followed by a 6-day washout period. Following the treatment sequence, a further 7 days washout will be interposed. This crossover design will be repeated a second time. To further investigate dose-response effects, three different doses of test drug (MelissaPhytosome®) will be administered: 200 mg, 400 mg and 800 mg per tablet. The three different doses will be administered according to a Latin square design to ensure that the number of subjects receiving each of the treatment sequences will be equal.

954,"Phase 1 (R21): The purpose of this project is to develop a technology-based intervention to increase social connections among isolated older adults in senior housing. We will use the social engagement model (SEM) and apply it to the target population to identify barriers to social connection and effective intervention components that target the intervention barriers. Phase 2 (R33) will use the findings from Phase 1 to develop a socially-engaging intervention for older adults and determine whether it will be sufficiently feasible, acceptable, and efficient for use in senior housing.
Funds confirmed by the NIMH, Office of Extramural Research

Interventional Model Description: Phase 2 (R33): Recruit older adults who live in senior housing and who complete the baseline assessment protocol. Randomly assign 10-20 adults to the socially-engaging intervention or to usual care. All participants will complete the baseline assessment protocol. Assess intervention feasibility/acceptability: Participants in the intervention group will complete the follow-up assessment protocol. Participants in the intervention group who complete greater than 2/3 of the sessions in the study protocol will be determined feasible targets for future intervention studies. Participants in the intervention group who report negative side effects or a negative effect on social behaviors will be determined unfeasible targets. Assess intervention efficacy: Use mixed methods approaches (e.g., qualitative analysis of audio recordings, EMA, and surveys) to examine changes in social behaviors pre- and post-intervention.

956,"80% of chronic low-back pain are referred to as Nonspecific Low-back Pain (NSLBP) which are often idiopathic in nature. The underlying mechanism of NSLBP has not been fully understood. In patients with NSLBP, a 24 hour Holter electro-myography (sEMG) analysis has revealed that there are several spinal muscles activation patterns. These patterns are observed to be highly varied with no clear pattern observed which could predict whether patients can recover from the pain, or who progress and develop into chronic low-back pain. Recently, a link between the activation patterns and chronic low-back pain symptoms have also been identified. This study proposes to identify and characterize these different activation patterns in order to better assess and predict chronic low-back pain symptoms development in subjects with NSLBP. The overarching aim of this study is to better understand how certain muscle activation patterns are linked to NSLBP and its associated chronic back pain symptoms. Ultimately, the findings from this study will provide clinicians with a better understanding of low back pain and its progression to chronic low back pain, allowing more tailored and targeted intervention in the form of targeted exercise prescription for patients with NSLBP.
Identification and Characterization of Abnormal Low Back Muscle Activation Patterns in Nonspecific Low-back Pain.
Low Back Pain, Nonspecific Low-back Pain

column5: 958,There will be two research studies with the same sample of participants, and each study will include two different phases:

column1: Phase 1: At least 50 participants will be recruited, and they will include non-Hispanic Black/African-Americans, Hispanics/Latinos and White/Caucasians. There is a minimum age of 50 years and a maximum age of 90 years. Potential participants will be asked to provide several of their medical records (about three months of medical records) so the research staff can get a clear picture of the participant's medical history. The medical history is extremely important because the participant's medical history impacts how he/she responds to the vaccines. Participants will be asked to provide details about their past and current health status, including information about any chronic conditions, surgeries, and medical procedures they have experienced. The research staff will also ask about any current and/or anticipated care needs. It is also important for the participant to complete a survey about their family background, including their ethnicity, heritage, national ancestry, and any information about their ancestral background. The research staff will ask questions about the participants' family tree, including details about the dates and locations of their ancestors' births, deaths, and migrations.

Potential participants will also be asked to participate in a telephone interview to collect additional demographic information about their race/ethnicity, education level, and income. This is extremely important because these factors can impact the participant's health outcomes. Participants will also have the opportunity to participate in a videoconferencing session with the research team so that the researchers can collect more information about their current health status, medical history, and health-related behaviors, including smoking, alcohol use, diet, exercise, and sleep patterns. The research team will also collect information about the participant's mental health, including any history of depression, anxiety, or other mental health disorders. During the videoconferencing session, the research team will also assess the participant's cognitive function. This will help the researchers to determine the participant's ability to understand and follow the research protocol. Participants will also have the opportunity to ask questions about the study or share any concerns they may have. This is an extremely important step in the research process because it helps to build trust between the research team and the participant.

Phase 2: The team hopes to recruit 300 participants, but may be able to enroll up to 400 participants depending on the study's progress. The study team will review the collected information, such as the participant's symptoms and history, to determine if they may be a good fit for the study. Participants who meet certain criteria, such as having a certain medical condition, may be invited to participate in the study. The study team will use this information to create a list of potential participants. They will then contact the participants by email or phone to invite them to participate in the study. The research team will give a detailed explanation of the research study and answer any questions the potential participants may have. The potential participants will be given time to think about their decision and ask any questions they may have. The research team will then schedule a time for the potential participants to come to the clinic for a pre-screening visit. During this visit, the potential participants will undergo a variety of medical tests and exams to determine if they are eligible to participate in the study. This visit will take approximately 1-2 hours and will be required before the potential participant can be enrolled in the study."

959,"Lumbar radiculopathy occurs when a lumbar spine nerve root is compressed or irritated by an intervertebral disc herniation, spondylotic stenosis, fracture, tumour, or infection. The main pain mechanism of lumbar radiculopathy is the activation of the nociceptors in the peripheral or central nervous system, and this process has been shown to trigger an increased release of neuropeptides from nociceptive terminals. It has also been shown that the presence of disc herniation in a lumbar spine nerve root increases nociceptive discharge. The most common clinical symptom of lumbar radiculopathy is pain. The most common areas of pain with lumbar radiculopathy are located in the thigh with L4 and L5 radiculopathy and in the buttock or proximal part of the lower limb with L3 radiculopathy. In addition to mechanical hypersensitivity, the perception of cold in the lower limbs, inability to understand the hotness, paresthesia and pins and needles can occur. Other symptoms such as neurogenic sexual dysfunction and bladder function disorders caused by nerve root compression can also occur. These symptoms occur between weeks 6-8 after the onset and are known as sensory or motor symptoms depending on whether they affect the sensory or motor systems. Sensory symptoms include hypoesthesia, hyperesthesia, sensory loss, impaired proprioception and impaired vibration sense, and motor symptoms include weakness, muscle atrophy, loss of reflex, clonus, fasciculation and increased muscle tone secondary to spinal cord muscle reflexes. Lumbar radiculopathy is a condition that causes disability in individuals and significantly impairs their daily activities. If not treated, severe radiculopathy cases may be observed in the long term. In individuals experiencing pain due to radiculopathy, the analgesic effect of opioids is poor. In literature findings, it has been reported that treatment modalities are insufficient in 1-2% of individuals who have been tried pain medication, physical therapy, therapeutic exercise, epidural injection, radiofrequency treatment, and surgery for radiculopathy. Recent research has shown that pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) can be used in the management of radiculopathy to enhance the patient's self-management capacity and to control the nerve root irritation with a therapeutic and rehabilitative effect. PRF has been found to have efficacy only in patients who have not responded to non-invasive treatment methods such as physical therapy and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in a study conducted by Jain et al. When the evidence is examined on the effect of PRF on pain, disability, and functional activity in individuals with lumbar radicular pain, there is not enough evidence to suggest the existence of a therapeutic effect. However, a study conducted by Yüksel et al. (2019) suggests the existence of a treatment effect of PRF on pain and disability in patients with lumbar radicular pain. In the literature, to the best of our knowledge; The study that can be most similar to the present study is the study of Rongen et al. (2017) on the effect of radiofrequency thermoneurolysis on nerve root irritation. However, the study has short-term and long-term results that can evaluate efficacy. In this study, they examine the short-term effect on nerve root irritation 1-6 weeks after treatment. Another difference from our study is that they examine the 16-week effect of radiofrequency treatment with a short-term follow-up. It has been shown that there are differences in terms of the amount of nerve root irritation and the onset-to-relief time immediately after the procedure. Our study differs from this study in that it was designed as a case control study and that it determined the effect on the cured cases. In the literature, there are studies examining the effect of lumbar interlaminar PRF on pain and functioning in patients with lumbar radicular pain. However, these studies had a small sample size, were observational studies, and did not analyze the effect of PRF on proprioception, which is one of the primary symptoms of lumbar radicular pain.

961,"10799 - A Randomized Trial to Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Dupilumab in the Treatment of Adult Patients With Uncontrolled Asthma

Intervention Description:: Experimental: Dupilumab 200 or 300 milligrams subcutaneous every other week (q2w) for 20 weeks and 100 mg q2w for the last 10 weeks. Maintenance treatment during maintenance phase will be given based on the treatment responders. The treatment responders are defined as asthma patients treated with dupilumab who have at least a 50% improvement of 13-Week AQLQ score of the baseline from Week 24 to Week 27. Other: Placebo
Arm Description:: Dupilumab 200mg s.c. q2w up to 27 weeks followed by Dupilumab 100mg maintenance treatment.
Arm Description:: Dupilumab 300mg s.c. q2w up to 27 weeks followed by Dupilumab 100mg maintenance treatment.

Condition(s)/Problem(s):: * (J00-J06)Diseases of the respiratory tract, unspecifiedExclusion Criteria:: - Patients with clinical characteristics or laboratory abnormalities that place them at unacceptable risk of treatment complications or of interfering with the interpretation of study results- Patients with known hypersensitivity to the investigational drug or any of the excipients- Patients who are pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning a pregnancy during the study period- Patients who are currently enrolled or have withdrawn from participation in other investigational drug study within 3 months of Visit 1- Patients with active malignancy (disease-free interval 5 years)

1. Outcome:: To assess the safety and tolerability of Dupilumab in the treatment of uncontrolled asthma. Measure Description:: The occurrence of treatment-emergent adverse events including serious adverse events(SAEs) is reported and assessed during the trial.

2. Outcome:: To evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab by assessing the change from baseline to Week 27 in AQLQ total score. Measure Description:: Adult asthma patients will evaluate the change from baseline to Week 27 in Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire (AQLQ) total score. The Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire (AQLQ) is a disease-specific questionnaire with well-documented validity. The recall period for the AQLQ is week, and the questionnaire is composed of 33 items assessing both the physical and emotional components of asthma and yielding 4 domains: 1) symptoms, 2) activity limitation, 3) emotional function, and 4) environmental stimulus. The total score ranges from 1 to 7, and a lower score indicates a worse asthma symptom.

1. Outcome:: To assess the efficacy by comparing treatment groups in lung function [forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC)] assessments. Measure Description:: Lung function tests (FEV1 and FVC)are used to assess the disease in asthma patients. Maximal volume of air that can leave the lungs after a full expiration is called forced expiratory volume (FEV1). Forced vital capacity (FVC) is the total amount of air that can forcibly exhale.
2. Outcome:: To evaluate the efficacy in asthma patients based on assessments of clinical parameters. Measure Description:: We will collect"

962,"3,825 persons will be included in the study. They will receive a COVID-19 message through a standard SMS sent from 16 national health authorities in European countries. This SMS will be sent in order to remind the participants to continue to follow social distancing and hygiene recommendations. To identify the participants in this study, the individuals have a unique user ID. The SMS message will be sent in English, French and Spanish. In addition, the researchers have identified 10,000 persons on the Danish civil register who in January 2022 are on sick leave due to one or more of the following main reasons: flu, coronavirus or cold. The message text in addition to the previously mentioned texts will be ""Have you been vaccinated against the coronavirus?"". The recipients will also be invited to answer additional questions in a self-administered questionnaire. In the questionnaire, it will be possible for the participants to register whether they have notified themselves as having had the flu or corona according to the SMS.

963,"Laryngectomy is a surgery that removes the larynx, a structure that facilitates swallowing, respiration and speech. People with a total laryngectomy must therefore change their voice, their way of eating and of life. Often isolated in their pathology, it is essential to provide them with a therapeutic space of exchange, to facilitate this important life change. By doing this, we hope to help laryngectomized patients live with their condition. We expect to be able to offer support groups to laryngectomized patients from our department, which will be organized by a speech therapist
Exenatide extended-release in improving glycaemic control and reducing weight in patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity (T2DXER study)

Exenatide has proven efficacy in weight loss and also improves the metabolic control in Type 2 Diabetes patients. In this study it is evaluated whether an addition of 5μg exenatide once weekly with the standard treatment in type 2 diabetes patients results in a better glycmic control (Hb A1c), in more weight loss and better quality of life after 1 or more years of treatment.

Open-label trial in type 2 diabetes and obese patients at primary care to demonstrate the efficacy of Exenatide Extended Release (ER) in glycemic control and weight losses with the addition of 5 μg ER to the treatment, once weekly, in real-life conditions. This study is an open-label, 1-year trial including patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and obesity at primary care. 642 patients will be randomised into 2 groups, Group A with Exenatide ER 5 µg once weekly (from 0.57 mg initial load) and Group B with Exenatide ER 5 µg twice weekly (from 2.3 mg initial load). Patients' background therapies will be modified during trial according to the Spanish Society of Primary Care (SEMERC) Guidelines. After the second visit (Week 2), the patient will be provided with Exenatide ER for the entire duration of the trial. The main objective is to assess the glycemic control at M3. Secondary Objectives are to assess the percentage of dropouts due to hypoglycaemia and treatment discontinuation after 1 year; the percentage of patients with weight reduction after 1 year; to evaluate the frequency and incidence of hypoglycaemic events; to monitor quality of life.

Exenatide Extended Release in Improving Glycaemic Control and Reducing Weight in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes and Obesity. A Prospective, Non-Randomised, Multicentre Trial Among 642 Participants (T2DXER Study)

Inclusion Criteria: Patients having the following diagnoses: Type 2 Diabetes with an Hb A1c between 6.1% and 12.0%, both inclusive; Obesity, body mass index (BMI) ≥30 Kg/m2 and/or body weight (BW) ≥100 Kg and/or waist circumference (WC) ≥102 cm. Male or Female between 18 and 75 years old. Patients under primary care who are initiating or continuing antihyperglycaemic treatment except Metformin for Type 2 Diabetes and Obesity. Patient previously prescribed Exenatide ER with standard treatments, having abandoned the treatment for whatever reason. Stable lifestyle for the previous three months, defined as the absence of change in nutrition habits and/or physical activity level. Willingness and ability to participate in the study for the whole trial period, as judged by the investigator. Exclusion Criteria: Participation in any other study in which the patient could be inadequately exposed or have interference in safety, efficacy or pharmacokinetic of the treatment being administered. Known or suspected immunodeficiency. History of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2. History of pancreatitis. Kidney dysfunction/Kidney failure"

column1: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a common, hormonal disorder that impacts the reproductive system, the ovaries, and other organs in up to 10% of individuals assigned female at birth.

Thought to be a genetic condition, PCOS can have a wide range of effects. There’s no cure, but symptoms can be managed with medication, lifestyle changes (like diet and exercise), and weight-loss surgeries, if needed. Many people with PCOS also have insulin resistance, which can lead to problems with blood sugar and increased risk of conditions like obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.

The PCOS Challenge Study is collecting important information that may help advance research and improve care. The information people provide may include details about their weight, their medical history, and their medication use, as well as their thoughts about living with PCOS. This study does not provide any medical assessments. It is designed to collect information only.

As a participant, you can decide to take the surveys at your own pace and how comprehensive you would like the information to be. Participants will be notified of their enrollment status (accepted or declined) by email. Participants who are accepted to enroll in the study will be invited to complete the first survey in the study. This survey will take an initial 3-4 hours to complete. After this, you will receive ongoing emails with opportunities to provide feedback and answer surveys based on the PCOS Challenge study’s themes. This survey will be revisited every 3 months.
All participants will have 24/7 access to an online dashboard where they can view all of the information that they provided, as well as personal recommendations.

In order to share your information with the healthcare community (including with healthcare services and researchers), your non-identifiable answers to surveys are shared as part of the larger PCOS Challenge Study population in research reports and publications.
The PCOS Challenge Study: For the Collection of Information to Advance Research and Improve Care for PCOS Patients

Inclusion Criteria: Diagnosed with PCOS by a healthcare provider Self-diagnosed with PCOS Individuals with PCOS symptoms Willing to sign the consent form Able to understand the registry surveys or what is being asked Exclusion Criteria: Unable to understand the surveys or what is being asked Unwilling to sign the consent form

column5: 967,9726029 Acquired brain injury: 9726031 Inspiratory muscle training Inspiratory muscle training using threshold IMT: 9726023 Older people Musculoskeletal system Inflammatory muscular diseases Acquired brain injury is the most common cause of long-term disability and reduced life expectancy during adulthood. It is often the result of traumatic events such as a stroke or severe head trauma. Patients are at greater risk of long-term impairments because of reduced strength and endurance of the respiratory muscles. Respiratory muscle training is a fundamental part of pulmonary rehabilitation, but its efficacy has not been well studied in adults with acquired brain damage. Currently, there is no effective method for evaluating the effectiveness of this training. The use of threshold devices has emerged as one of the most efficient ways of performing respiratory muscle exercises. Although the devices are widely used internationally to evaluate lung function, the protocols to be used in older adults or in respiratory muscle training are not well defined. The goal of this study is therefore: to compare the two most commonly used training protocols (IMT and PEP): to compare muscle strength before and after 8 weeks of respiratory muscle training. We hypothesize that patients with acquired brain injuries who perform respiratory muscle training will see improvements in their respiratory muscle strength and endurance.

968,"1. Primary objective: The primary objective of this study is to assess the effect of technological rehabilitation on the balance of patients with multiple sclerosis. To this end, we will use the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), which is a standardized rating scale that assesses static and dynamic balance and range of motion in multiple sclerosis. 2. Secondary objectives: The secondary objectives of this study are: assess the effect of technological rehabilitation on fatigue in patients with multiple sclerosis, using the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) and the Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive function (FSMC); evaluate the effect of technological rehabilitation on walking in patients with multiple sclerosis, using timed Up and Go test (TUG), Ambulation Index (AI), Walking handicap scale (WHS), Functional Ambulation Classification (FAC), 10 Meter Walk Test (10mWT), Six-minute walk test (6MWT), Multiple Sclerosis Walking Scale (MSWS-12), Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale (MSIS-29); assess the effect of technological rehabilitation on anxiety in patients with multiple sclerosis, using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-Y1 and Y2) and the Stroop Color-Word Test (SCWT). 3. Exploratory objectives: The exploratory objectives of this study are to assess the effect of technological rehabilitation on cognitive impairment in patients with multiple sclerosis, using the Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT) and to assess the effect of technological rehabilitation on quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis, using the EuroQol 5-Dimension 5-level (EQ-5D-5L) questionnaire. 4. Patients: 14 patients will be included in the study. Patients included must have multiple sclerosis, characterized by an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score between 1 and 6, stable clinical and therapeutic conditions for at least 3 months prior to inclusion, absence of clinical and/or therapeutic relapses in the last 3 months prior inclusion to the study, absence of neurological deterioration in the 3 months prior to inclusion to the study, good physical and intellectual skills, presence of adequate communication skills in Italian at the time of inclusion to the study."

969,"Thrombotic microangiopathies (TMAs), including thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic uremic syndrome, and atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome, are a diverse group of syndromes characterized by systemic thrombosis and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). Diagnosis is challenging in small community hospitals due to a less frequent occurrence than in tertiary centers and the lack of a 24/7 laboratory/hematological guard service. The aim of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of an automated algorithm for alerting and referral of suspected TMA patients, in order to test whether this algorithm can reduce mortality in small hospitals. We will measure the time of diagnosis, time of appropriate treatment, and in-hospital and 30-day mortality, as well as complications, length of stay, and readmissions. The algorithm will consist of the input of routine laboratory and/or clinical findings combined with a standardized algorithm for assessment of TMA in small hospitals.
Tobacco use cessation and the risk of cardiovascular disease: the CALM project.

BACKGROUND: Evidence suggests that smoking cessation is associated with a reduction in the rate of first myocardial infarction. However, the association between smoking cessation and a decreased risk of recurrent cardiovascular events remains controversial. It is unclear whether the effects of cessation on these events differ according to the method of cessation.METHODS AND DESIGN: The current study is embedded within the Norwegian County Trial: smoking cessation with nicotine replacement therapy (NCT). We study individuals from this trial who were free of cardiac problems at study start. Participants will be followed for recurrent cardiovascular events for up to five years. In order to identify new or recurrent cardiovascular events, a questionnaire will be filled in by the participants every five months during follow up, in addition to being informed to contact the research team if any cardiovascular event occur during the study. Relevant information will be retrieved from hospital registries in order to validate the selfreported events.RESULTS: For the presently ongoing study (up to five months of follow up), 733 (76%) individuals (522 women) at risk for smoking related disease (mean age at entry 49.9, SD 13.8) are included.(18)CONCLUSION: CALM investigates the effects of smoking cessation on the incidence of cardiovascular events in nicotine replacement therapy‐treated and untreated smoking cessation candidates, as well as investigating potential differences between smoking cessation by means of nicotine replacement therapy and behavioral modification."

This study was conducted to evaluate the Access-H2O® faucet for quadriplegics. A fountain feature was included on the faucet in order to enable hands-free access to water in a manner similar to public drinking fountains. The faucet incorporates electro-mechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. A proximity sensor and voice recognition function allow users to control the faucet through a smart speaker. These features enable precise dispensing of water at the desired temperature and volume, while a camera and other sensors enable hands-free operation. The primary function of the faucet is to allow quadriplegics to drink water independently without the need for additional assistance."

971,"Physical activity (PA) is currently recognized as an important component within healthy lifestyles. However, adolescence is a crucial time where physical inactivity levels increase and stay at unhealthy levels throughout adulthood, showing high risk of PA non-achievement. One way to address this problem is to incorporate PA interventions in Health Education or Physical Education contents in order to promote PA and PA-related attitudes among adolescents.

Current physical education programs tend to provide a physical and functional development perspective with a particular focus on sports. This education approach fails to provide adolescents with the necessary knowledge, competence, and autonomy (i.e., intrinsic motivation) to make PA a life-long habit. Given this reality, the investigators propose a novel physical education intervention that integrates health psychology-based principles to foster PA-related self-determined motivation. According to Self-Determination Theory 11, motivation to change health or PA-related behaviors is associated with personal competence and autonomy. The investigators proposed intervention intends to increase the students' perceptions of competence and autonomy in order to improve self-determined motivation and develop PA habits in the intermediate long term.

The investigators developed a 8 weeks long, intermittent teaching unit to be used in physical education classes at the secondary education level. This teaching unit integrates health psychology-based strategies in order to improve the perception of competence and autonomy as well as the perception of positive psychological states to motivate PA-related attitudes and behaviors. The teaching unit was developed using a formative action research procedure that involved the co-creation of both physical educators and adolescent students. The teaching unit will be developed in three steps: first, through a literature review of the current evidence, second, through focus groups with adolescents, and third, through semi-structured interviews with teachers. The developed teaching unit will be pilot-tested with a small group of young adolescents and it will be revised in order to improve its suitability and feasibility. The teaching unit will be evaluated through two randomized controlled trials (RCTs). The investigators hypothesized that the intermittent teaching unit will promote PA engagement and PA-related attitudes through the promotion of healthy PA habits, the improvement of relatedness perception, the enhancement of the motivation to do PA in one´s free time, and the improvement of the self-determined PA motivation and intention in the intermediate long-term. The investigators also hypothesized that the teaching unit will be perceived as effective, motivating, interesting, and relevant by the participants.

972,"Accuracy testing of non-invasive blood pressure monitoring is essential to clinical application to prevent adverse events from inaccurate measurements. We aim to investigate the precision, accuracy and responsiveness of the Task Force® CORE/CARDIO device against the SphygmoCor® atriaX2 device in AFT to establish the feasibility of the novel device."

974,"The investigators designed a placebo-controlled randomized controlled parallel arm trial which is divided into two stages. The investigators aim at determining whether an AV2 Salicylic Acid (SA) combination therapy is more efficacious in clearance of HPV-induced cutaneous warts on the one hand and whether AV2 reduces the recurrence rate on the other hand by direct antiviral activity in the index wart. The investigators will also identify the genotype-specific distribution of wart-associated HPV types in the Belgian population. Furthermore, the investigators will explore whether mucosal HPV types are prevalent in cutaneous warts. Moreover, the investigators aim at measuring the safety of Omnivirol (AV2-SA) combination therapy, as well as the acceptability of the treatment amongst the participants.

Study will take place in Belgium, at Ghent University Hospital. All Belgian patients with treatment refractory HPV-induced warts will be recruited via hospital consultation rooms or direct contact with the patient's healthcare providers (i.e., dermatologists). The cutaneous warts need to be large enough to allow visual quantification of the wart, and the wart has to remain localized on one sole site (i.e., the elbow, back of hand, or knee area) for at least 12 weeks. The investigators will exclude patients who suffer from another infectious disease, have received any other medication to treat their wart(s) or have had other cutaneous diseases causing wart-like lesions (i.e., lichen planus, psoriasis, or eczema) during the previous 12 weeks. Patients with concurrent chronic diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, epilepsy, gout, and thyroid disorders) can enroll only if they receive standard medication for their disease and have no known signs of allergic or adverse responses towards the investigational product or salicylic acid (SA). Furthermore, patients with allergic reactions to either avocado or argan oil can not participate in the study. The investigators will obtain a written informed consent from all eligible patients prior to enrollment. All collected data will be encrypted, stored, and processed in a safe and secure manner only to be used for the purposes of this research project. At enrollment, the investigators will assign all patients to a treatment arm after randomization. The investigators will perform the randomization by selecting sealed envelopes, each containing an opaque film marked with the treatment code (EU101679B-1 = AV2), EU101679B-2 = SA). Selected patients will be treated by either the AV2-SA combination therapy or the standard salicylic acid (SA) therapy. The selection of the treatment arm will be done by an independent third party in random, concealed, and permuted blocks of variable block lengths via an electronic randomization module. Patients in both treatment arms will be treated up to 12 weeks, followed by a 6-month follow-up period. All patients will follow the same treatment protocol, except the AV2-SA combination therapy will be applied as described below:

During the first week of treatment, the index wart will be treated with salicylic acid (SA) 39% (Flexderm®; Helsinn Group AG, Lugano, Switzerland) daily by application of one drop (approximately 3 mg) of SA per day on the index wart. If an acute pain occurs, a maximum dose of 2 times per day might be used, but never exceeding 4 mg per day at the end of the first week. Throughout the treatment regimen, wart psoriasis (EPSA) cream (10% d-carvone and 0.5% salicylic acid; Helsinn Group AG) will be used once per week on the index wart, as well as once per week on a neighboring wart (if present). In the following 11 weeks, the index wart will be treated with AV2-SA combination therapy, i.e., one drop (approximately 3 mg) of AV2 (100% FDA GRAS-label approved blend of organic compounds) diluted in 0.3 mL of mineral oil and 1 drop (approximately 3 mg) of SA (SA 39%) diluted in 0.3 mL of mineral oil. Both drops will be applied on the index wart and pressed carefully into the wart. The application with AV2-SA will occur during the day (e.g., lunch or dinner time) and once per week during"
975,"3 groups each comprising about 30 patients. They will receive either methotrexate, letrozole twice a day or letrozole daily for about 2 weeks and then will be followed up monthly ."
976,"Psycho-social benefits for adult with Sensory Processing Disorders who wear weighted clothing/tactile stimulation/deep pressure: a pilot qualitative mixed method study

There is a prevalence of children and young people presenting with Sensory Processing Disorders (SPD) within the UK. There is a dearth of research evidence that supports treatment methods for children or adults presenting with SPD. The main aims of the study are to explore the effect of weighted clothing/tactile stimulation on sensory hypersensitivity, anxiety and quality of life for an adult in the community who is experiencing SPD. The study would also explore the effects for the family and friends of the adult with SPD to determine any benefits it may have.

SPD is a condition that can often be associated with stress and anxiety. This can be as a result of the adult not being able to regulate their responses to everyday situations, which in turn may lead to avoidance and isolation from certain social interactions. Anecdotal evidence has shown that some individuals within the community have been known to wear weighted clothing (e.g. vests and jackets). Studies have suggested that deep pressure and tactile stimulation have been shown to be beneficial for people with sensory hypersensitivity, anxiety and quality of life however there is no substantial empirical evidence to support this. The study will be conducted with one adult in the community who identifies they have symptoms of SPD. The researcher, who is a qualified Occupational Therapist, with extensive experience in the area, will explain the study to the adult and provide them with the choice of participating in the study. The adult will be provided with weighted clothing to be worn. A series of video diary's/interviews will be conducted following onset of weighted clothing. It is anticipated that the weighted clothing will be worn at least twenty hours a week to determine any benefits from wearing it. The study will be carried out in a single site at the University of Hertfordshire. The proposed study is an exploratory study. The researcher will be analysing the data during and after the study to ensure data saturation has been achieved. Ethical considerations The study will be run in accordance with guidelines and recommendations by both the Faculty of Science and Technology (FAST) Research and Ethics Committee (REC) and the University of Hertfordshire REC. The study will also be in accordance with UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) framework governing research using human participants and will adhere to the UK Policy Framework for Health and Social Care Research. It is important to clarify from the outset that the study will only be carried out following formal ethical approval. The study will be conducted according to the International Ethical Guidelines for Biomedical Research Involving Human Subjects (CIOMS 2002). Recruitment, consent and ethical issues The study will be run in accordance with the UKRI framework for ethical research and the University of Hertfordshire Ethical Policy Framework for Health and Social Care Research. The study will be carried out by a single Occupational Therapist. The study will not involve the use of a trial drug or other invasive investigation therefore risk to participants is minimal. The study will be monitored by a steering group to monitor any adverse events or withdrawals.
Psycho-social Benefits for Adult with Sensory Processing Disorders who wear weighted clothing/tactile stimulation/deep pressure: a pilot qualitative mixed method study

977,"BRAF is a critical serine-threonine kinase in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, which is frequently mutated in papillary thyroid cancers (PTCs). It has been reported that mitochondria play an important role in the BRAF signaling pathway. Our group described TERT mitochondrial translocation in response to oxidative stress in a subset of PTCs and recently showed that therapeutic BRAF and MEK inhibitors trigger intracellular TERT localization to mitochondria. We hypothesized that mitochondrial TERT up-regulates oxidative stress generation via increased antioxidant enzymes, subsequently inducing BRAF oncogene addiction. The investigators aimed to demonstrate the key role of mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of PTCs.

The study design was a cohort of histologically diagnosed PTCs to explore oxidative stress generation and TERT mitochondrial localization in thyroid tissues. Moreover, we examined the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and tyrosine kinase inhibitors on mitochondrial TERT up-regulation in cell lines. The investigators aim to reveal the role of mitochondrial TERT in PTCs using multiple molecular biological analysis techniques and this research will provide the foundation for more effective treatment strategies."

The primary target group for this first-in-human pTTL trial will be adults with stage IV CRC with documented metastatic disease refractory to standard therapy or patients with no suitable standard therapy options (e. g. due to toxicity, progressive disease and/or inaccessible areas of disease, or scheduled pause in palliative palliative standard treatment). The inclusion criteria for patients entering this trial include CRC confirmed by histological or cytological examination, as well as measurable disease according to RECIST1.1.

Each patient will receive a single administration of pTTL, after pre-conditioning chemotherapy with Fludarabine (CAS 2504-40-2;30 mg/m2 body surface area) x 3 and Cyclophosphamide (CAS 50-27-8;300 mg/m2 body surface area) x 3 on days -7 to -5. T cell activation due to TCR crosslinking, during pTTL production and expansion, promotes a highly active, functionally competent T cell subset known as central memory T cells, with a high potential for persistence and expansion. Central memory T cells are thus considered the optimal T cell subset for adoptive cell therapy. pTTL will usually be infused on day 1 (5 days after last chemotherapy) with the option of administering it on day -3 if judged preferable based on the T cell expansion kinetics during pTTL production. pTTL is administered as a fresh product directly after production. Dose escalation will be implemented. Cohort 1 will receive 1 million (with an accepted range of down to -5%) viable cells per kg body weight. Cohort 2 will be infused with 2.5 million (down to -5%) viable cells per kg body weight and Cohort 3 will receive 5 million (down to -5%) viable cells per kg body weight. Cohort 4 will receive a maximum of 1 billion viable cells based on pre-defined criteria. As is currently the practice with regard to autologous CAR-T cell therapy manufacture in Sweden, the dose is not administered as one batch of cells, but in smaller doses (e.g., 125 ml per dose) on consecutive days. No more than 1,000 ml in total will be given intravenously. The production process and product quality are monitored throughout. pTTL contains in vitro expanded T cells obtained from the starting material (i.e., antigen-specific T cells). The starting material, in turn, is obtained from the inguinal lymph nodes (or possibly other lymph nodes) that are surgically removed in conjunction with other tumour-specific procedures during the patient's primary treatment. A minimum of four to six identifiable enlarged lymph nodes must be retrieved for processing and subsequent cryopreservation, although at least four will be used for pTTL production. The number of collected lymph nodes may be higher. These lymph nodes will be thawed and activated. The activated T cells are then cryopreserved and subsequently in vitro expanded using the patient's specific HLA and neoantigen profile, which has been determined in advance through exome sequencing of the patient's cancer. A single dose of pTTL, containing between approximately 0.5 to 3 million neoantigen-reactive T cells, will be administered to the patient after pre-conditioning therapy and before the patient is treated with the next standard cancer therapy. Patients who do not receive further cancer treatment after being treated with pTTL will be followed up for 6 months at the Investigator's discretion. This also applies to patients who do not receive further cancer treatment during the pTTL production process, but whose pTTL product nonetheless results in an infusion of pTTL.

The objective of this Phase I / IIa trial is to assess the safety and feasibility of the trial and determine the recommended pTTL dose (if any) to be used in a subsequent confirmatory Phase II, randomised trial in the context of a solid phase II clinical trial protocol. The trial is considered complete if no safety issues are reported and the number of patients that can be treated at all before the Phase II stage is determined.

In the future (Phase II), if additional cancer indications are to be evaluated in clinical trials in addition to CRC, the dosing will start from a higher dose than what is evaluated in CRC, based on current knowledge about the effects of previous standard cancer therapy (in CRC, most often treatment with chemotherapy and / or radiation /"

980,"The investigators propose a prospective, monocentric, observational study in newly diagnosed patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and a control group of healthy blood donors that would serve as a control for systemic inflammation without any sarcoidosis-specific immune activation. The proposed project has the potential to establish a new role of SAA concentration as one of the key biomarkers in the management of intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The findings of our study will help tailor the treatment to patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and guide therapeutic decisions to either start with corticosteroid or anti-TNF therapy and to discontinue therapy when the disease is quiescent. The study has the potential, also, to develop new biomarkers for sarcoidosis, by identifying correlations of SAA with other inflammatory markers such as CCL18, CXCL10 and CXCL9. The results presented in this proposal may lead to the development of a test that could be used to predict the outcome of untreated granulomatous diseases, thereby helping clinicians manage their patients more effectively.
Input Text: Predictors of Sarcoidosis-related Ocular Complications

The objective of this study is to find predictors of ocular involvement in sarcoidosis, a disease characterized by tissue granulomas and a high incidence of eye-related symptoms. One hundred and thirty participants will be recruited in a tertiary care center, in which ophthalmological assessment includes both uveitis and dry eye syndrome. Clinical data, including demographics, systemic comorbidities, sarcoidosis history and treatments, ophthalmological exams, laboratory assessments, inflammatory biomarkers, and medications will be collected for 11 months. The main outcomes of the study are to detect changes in ocular symptoms and signs, and inflammatory and immunological markers before and after the treatment and in patients with sarcoidosis-related ocular involvement. We will develop a predictive model to describe the association between sarcoidosis-related ocular complications and its systemic and clinical predictors. The long-term goal of this study is to find predictors of sarcoidosis-related ocular involvement, which will provide further insight into the disease.

Introduction: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease of unknown etiology. It is characterized by the tissue granulomas, the clinical presentation of which can be very diverse. The most prevalent manifestations are pulmonary (60%) and cutaneous (23%), and these are often also associated with arthralgia, erythema nodosum, or uveitis. Ocular symptoms are not uncommon in sarcoidosis (8-40% of patients), and can take the form of dry eye or recurrent eye infections, as well as the potentially blinding manifestations of bilateral granulomatous uveitis (BGU). Currently, in order to reduce mortality and morbidity, most experts recommend routine treatment of all sarcoidosis patients with ocular involvement. However, this approach can come at considerable expense and is not universally accepted, especially in the era of drug-resistant sarcoidosis. Although the association between the various clinical signs and ocular symptoms in sarcoidosis has been recognized for a long time, the actual pathogenesis of ocular involvement remains unclear. While some symptoms seem to be directly related to active sarcoidosis, others persist despite treatment and are attributed to dry eye. Despite the fact that some inflammatory markers, most notably C-reactive protein (CRP), are associated with disease activity, the correlation between these markers and disease outcome remains weak. To date, no studies have attempted to identify non-invasive predictors of sarcoidosis-related ocular involvement. Material and methods: This observational, one-year follow-up study enrolls 130 participants who have previously been diagnosed with sarcoidosis and who present to the University Eye Clinic for ophthalmological evaluation. The participants visit on two occasions - the first visit (baseline) and the second visit (after 11 months). At the baseline visit, the medical history, laboratory tests, and ophthalmologic evaluation are assessed. At the second visit, the following assessments are made: the history of the disease; any medications in use or within the last 3 months; laboratory tests and measurements of inflammatory markers; and ophthal"

981,"The benefit of an uterine lavage by blank embryo culture medium before transfer of the thawed embryo will be evaluated by a randomised, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial on two groups of women (N = n * 220 = 440 couples), having first undergone a fresh cycle or a fresh-frozen cycle as part of their first IVF programme and then a frozen cycle. The primary criterion will be the occurrence of a clinical pregnancy (defined as a positive pregnancy test ≥ 100 IU/ml and presence of at least one fetal sac on dating ultrasound) between the groups. Secondary criteria include: first biochemical pregnancy (positive beta HCG test ≥ 10 IU/l and < 100 IU/l), second biochemical pregnancy (positive beta HCG test ≥ 100 IU/l and negative on dating ultrasound), early miscarriage (a pregnancy defined by a positive beta HCG test ≥ 100 IU/l at D14 and the absence of an evolving clinical pregnancy ), first live birth (at least 24 weeks' gestational age at birth) The study will test the hypothesis that uterine culture of the uterus by blank culture medium performed prior to transfer of thawed embryo improves the clinical pregnancy rate in patients undergoing their first Frozen-thaw cycle after a first IVF failure due to a failed fresh cycle. It will also be shown whether there is a correlation between the occurrence of pregnancy and patient and cycle characteristics."

984,"258 index clients (new patients presenting to the clinic) will be randomized to either receive CONSORT referrals for HIV testing (CONSORT intervention group), receive physical invitation cards for HIV testing (card referral intervention group), or the standard care approach (standard care intervention group, controls).

The primary endpoint will be the referral uptake during the 30 days after the initial referral, measured by the number of unique individuals presenting for HIV testing in the study intervention sites per 100 index clients. Secondary endpoints will include: total number of index clients referred per 100 index clients, numbers of eligible but ineligible index clients, numbers of total and unique referrals per number of unique client presentations for HIV testing, and HIV prevalence among referred clients who test for HIV. A sub-study will collect observational data on social interactions between clients and clients’ social network members, and on client communication and testing preferences and experiences.

Inclusion Criteria: New clients presenting for a consultative HIV test Exclusion Criteria: Age less than 18 years Known participation in another HIV-related intervention Existing HIV status Knowledge of HIV-positive status in a partner, family member, or close friend
