985,"This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study, including patients who are diagnosed with septic shock and using a minimum dose of norepinephrine (0.01 mcg/kg/min) for less than 48 hours. Our hypothesis is that the use of paroxetine in this patient profile is safe and is associated with reduced vasopressor support and cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) score variation between baseline daily until 120 hours later. Paroxetine has a short elimination half-life, so we expect that the use of this drug may be quickly effective. Another hypothesis for the use of this drug is associated with reduction of vasopressor dose, reducing the risk of acute vasospastic myocardiopathy and cardiomyopathy, in addition to reducing the length of stay in the ICU. The primary outcome will be comparing the use of paroxetine for 48 hours or until clinical recovery from shock versus a placebo."

986,"42% of primary care consultations are dedicated to depression. Depression management in the GP office is not standardised and the patients do not follow their prescribed treatments. The aim of the study is to use a nurse-supervised psychoeducation program to support GPs in the management of moderate depression. Participants will be randomised to receive either the program or usual care from their GP. Participants will complete questionnaires, and the effect of the program on self-efficacy, compliance with treatment, and depression severity will be evaluated. The investigators hypothesis is that a multidimensional nurse-supervised program will increase patients' self-efficacy, reduce depression symptoms and promote adherence to treatment."

988,"1. Background: Postulated as a pain-free procedure, most eye surgeries require the use of topical local anaesthetics like tetracaine drops or ointment, lignocaine-containing eye drops for mydriasis before surgery (mydriasis is a procedure to enlarge the pupil by application of mydriatic drops, injections or oral medications). Alternatively, the use of 10.1 mg lignocaine/metylparahydroxybenzoate (EMLA cream 5g) is still considered as a standard of care for venous cannulation prior to eye surgery (intravenous cannulation is required for any pre and post-operative investigations or blood transfusion that might be required in case of severe bleeding). The application of thick layers of EMLA cream will produce numbness and pain relief on the area of application for at least 30 minutes. Nevertheless, despite the use of thick layers of EMLA cream, most patients still reported moderate to severe level of pain if venous cannulation is performed during such observation period.  Another form of topical local anaesthetics that has been reported is lidocaine-embedded microneedle patches which had demonstrated promising outcomes when used for topical local anaesthesia in some skin wounds like venous puncture or IV cannulation that require a small volume of blood. In order to further improve the pharmacokinetic (PK) properties of the topical anaesthetics, the novel maltose microneedle (MAN) arrays can be used to increase the skin penetration of lignocaine and reduce the pain sensation during peripheral venous cannulation. Additionally, compared to EMLA, which requires at least 30 minutes for the lignocaine to reach peak plasma concentration (Cmax), the use of maltose MAN array need only 30 minutes for the lignocaine to be effective. Furthermore, the shortened duration of action of lignocaine when administered via MAN array could reduce the possibility of systemic intoxication even if EMLA cream was used to cover the MAN patch applied on the back of the participant. The aim of this study is to determine the efficacy of MAN patch containing 12.5mg lignocaine in terms of pain relief and time to onset of anaesthetic action when compared to the current standard of care – EMLA (5%). Objectives: 1) To observe the change in the pain intensity in patients who received venous cannulation with and without the use of either EMLA cream or MAN patch containing 12.5 mg lignocaine. 2) To observe the change in the pain intensity in patients who received venous cannulation with a MAN patch containing 12.5 mg lignocaine within a time period of 30 minutes. 3) To evaluate the safety of MAN patch containing 12.5 mg lignocaine on adult patients undergoing cataract and glaucoma surgery. Design: This will be a three-period crossover study with a washout period of 9 to 14 days to prevent carry over effects between treatments. Patients who are recruited in this study will serve as their own control and will be switched between treatments. Subjects population for the study will be adult patients scheduled for cataract and glaucoma surgeries in HUKM which are of Malaysian ethnicity. Statistical analysis: This will be a randomized trial. Participants will be assigned to a treatment sequence in a 1:1:1 ratio using stratified permuted blocks with a varying block size. The primary outcome will be analyzed using an adjusted General Linear Model (GLM). The GLM model will assess the change of each outcome parameter. Multiple comparisons between the observed data of lignocaine-embedded MAN patch, standard EMLA cream and their corresponding mean comparisons and differences will be analyzed using adjusted multiple means. Sensitivity and Specificity analysis will be performed using ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) analysis on specific data sets (EMLA only, MAN patch only and both MAN patch and EMLA cream)."

989,"Psychopharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments have been suggested as a gold standard and are considered effective in treating perinatal depressed/anxious patients. However, as per the literature in the domain of psychological treatment (for depressed/anxious women), only very few Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are registered and even fewer have been conducted and implemented. Aim of The Proposed Study: A Randomized Intervention Trial (RIT) to assess the clinical utility of psychopharmacological intervention versus Cognitive Behavioral Couple Therapy (CBCT) versus their combination in perinatal distressed couples. Methodology of The Proposed Study: The Proposed Study is aiming to enroll approximately 120 couples who will be allocated randomly to one of the five conditions to participate in the research. Couples will be administered with standardized measures to assess symptom severity (for depression, anxiety, stressors) and social and environmental factors (social support, wellbeing; couple's relationships). The treatment outcome will be assessed on the basis of the change in the symptom severity at pre- and post-treatment assessments. Assessment for clinical outcome and clinical benefit (adherence, acceptability, tolerability) will be done. Qualitative methods will also be employed to ascertain couples' opinions and perceptions regarding the effectiveness and acceptability of the proposed treatments.

Inclusion Criteria: The fourth month of pregnancy till the seventh month of the antenatal period. One week after delivery/birth till one year of a child in the postnatal period. Screened by PPDS as high-risk couples (for the level of severe symptomology) for Major Depressive Disorder (cut-off score 29 to 42) and/or Generalized Anxiety Disorder (cut-off score 17 to 24), and their Comorbidity. Dose requirements in any one of the antidepressant and/or anxiolytic, such as escitalopram (5-10 mg), sertraline (12.5-25 mg), and/or alprazolam (0.25-0.50 mg) per day. Wives accompanied by their husbands. Willingness to participate as a couple in the study. No physical disorder is present. No disability is present. Exclusion Criteria: Unwilling couples to participate in the study. Wife and/or couple is in an emergency. Wife accompanied by close relatives other than a spouse. Wife in the first week of delivery. Dose requirements in any one of the antidepressant and/or anxiolytic, such as escitalopram (above10 mg), sertraline (above 25 mg), and/or alprazolam (above 0.50 mg) per day. Couples screened with depressive disorder and/or anxiety disorder having psychotic features. Couples screened with depressive disorder and/or anxiety disorder having suicidal ideation. Couples screened with depressive disorder and/or anxiety disorder having mania/hypomanic features. Couples having diabetes. Couples having cardiovascular disorders. Any intellectual, visual, or hearing disability present in either spouse of a couple.

Interventional Model Description: The first group receives psychopharmacological intervention. The second group received CBCT (with or without Zikr). The third group receives a combination of psychopharmacological medication and CBCT The fourth group receives a combination of psychopharmacological medication, CBCT, and with or without Zikr. The fifth group receives either a placebo or no CBCT intervention

column1: 990,"53 participants with Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism defined by a biochemical defect leading to an accumulation of blood phenylalanine (Phe) due to a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). Individuals with PAH deficiency cannot convert the essential amino acid phenylalanine (Phe) to the non-essential amino acid tyrosine. If left unchecked, this condition will lead to intellectual disability and other detrimental symptoms.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836 in adults with PKU.

This is a Phase 1/Phase 2, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose expansion trial for the treatment of adults with phenylketonuria (PKU). This study is designed to assess the safety and efficacy of SAR444836 in adults with PKU who have a Phe level greater than or equal to (≥) 600 μmol/L, despite dietary Phe restriction. SAR444836 is a single dose of AAV-mediated gene therapy for the treatment of PKU. The active drug will be delivered by an infusion pump system containing a single dose of either the 1 × 10^12 or 6 × 10^12 vg/kg formulation. In a Phase 1 trial of PKU participants with a biochemical profile and age similar to participants in this trial, the SAR444836 dose was shown to be well tolerated. No participants developed a detectable anti-adeno-associated viral (AAV) antibody response. All participants achieved meaningful levels of sustained biochemical control for 9 months with a 68% median reduction in dietary Phe intake. Participants achieved plasma Phe levels below the target of 600 μmol/L by an average of 364 μmol/L. No PKU-related toxicities were observed in participants who received SAR444836.

A Phase 1/Phase 2, Open-label, Dose-escalation, and Dose Expansion Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of a Single Intravenous Administration of SAR444836 in Adult Participants With Phenylketonuria

Inclusion Criteria: Adult males, and females of non-child bearing potential, 18-65 years of age at the time of informed consent. Participants who have the diagnosis of PKU due to PAH deficiency. One historical plasma Phe value ≥ 600 μmol/L in the preceding 24 months while on Phe restricted diet therapy. Two plasma Phe values ≥ 600 μmol/L drawn at least 72 hours apart during the screening period while on Phe restricted diet therapy in the absence of an acute illness. Participant has the ability and willingness to maintain their present diet for the duration of the trial, unless otherwise directed as per protocol. Body mass index (BMI) ≤ 35 kg/m2 Willingness to use effective methods of contraception. Capable of giving signed informed consent which includes compliance with the requirements and restrictions listed in the informed consent form (ICF) and in this protocol. Exclusion Criteria: Presence of neutralizing antibodies against the AAV SNY001 capsid. Abnormal liver function laboratory testing evidenced by alanine aminotransferase (ALT)>1.5X upper limit normal (ULN), aspartate transaminase (AST)>1.5X ULN, alkaline phosphatase >1.5X ULN, Total and direct bilirubin >1.5X ULN (bilirubin levels above the laboratory's normal range are acceptable in individuals with a documented history or laboratory evidence of Gilbert's Disease) Any significant underlying liver disease or any of the following documented diagnoses, indicative of significant underlying liver disease Presentation of"

991,"1. The investigators will perform a post hoc analysis of a MCI patients cohort from a previous longitudinal prospective study for which both pCASL acquisitions and FDG-PET acquisition has been performed. The pCASL sequences are performed in fast, repetitive sequences as compared to the conventional ASL sequences.

2. The investigators will evaluate the correlations of brain perfusion indices measured with pCASL with FDG-PET findings within pre-specified regions of interest (ROIs). The investigators aim to correlate the perfusion indices values and FDG-PET values. The investigators expect a substantial correlation between pCASL and FDG-PET findings in regions of interest associated with typical Alzheimer's disease pathology or associated with cognitive domains.
3. The investigators will correlate baseline pCASL brain perfusion findings, and 1 year and 2 years after with neuropsychological test scores.

4. The investigators intend to analyze differences in brain perfusion patterns among subjects with various CSF biomarker findings. They expect more hypoperfusion in subjects with biomarker signatures associated with Alzheimer's pathology.

5. The investigators will analyze differences in brain perfusion patterns among subjects with various clinical subtypes of MCI. They expect to observe that brain perfusion patterns differ according to clinical subtype of MCI.

6. The investigators will evaluate the ability of brain perfusion indices to predict the conversion to dementia within the period of time of 1 year and 2 years after recruitment. They expect to observe substantial accuracy of prediction for a subset of brain perfusion indices.
7. The investigators will correlate pCASL perfusion indices with various blood biomarkers collected at baseline.
8. The investigators will correlate pCASL perfusion indices with subjective measures of cognitive decline during the preceding 12 months."

994,"Background. Low back pain is a big problem for all people in the world. Nowadays e-learning back to educational institutions. However this change in learning methods is associated with an increased prevalence and intensity of low back pain. In this study, the proposed intervention (an active break) is based on the understanding that young people with low back pain spend a large part of their daily life at school, studying during hours, and sitting without rest. Additionally, an intervention such as active break is very beneficial for young participants who live in an environment that has a high sedentary lifestyle. Research aim. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of an active break on reduce LBP and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with LBP. Methods. This will be a randomized controlled study with pre and post-intervention assessment. The participants will be randomly assigned to the intervention group consisting of an active break (n = 25) or the control group (n = 25). The proposed intervention will be based on the implementation of an active break with the proposed lumbar and hip extension exercises. The researchers hypothesize a reduction in musculoskeletal discomfort in the experimental group.

Rationale. The investigators considered the physical therapist's role as the gatekeeper of health and rehabilitation in relation to nonspecific low back pain (LBP). Physical therapists are the primary healthcare providers who provide a wide range of interventions. These interventions include assessment, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and health maintenance and promotion. Low back pain has been associated with prolonged sitting and a sedentary lifestyle. Currently, the most recommended action to overcome the negative effects of prolonged sitting is to replace it with some form of movement in order to restore the integrity of the passive tissues of the spine. Additionally, the investigators consider that young people need to be more active in their daily lives. Currently, young people spend most of their time in sitting position while studying (in the school class, during homework), and using the electronic devices (using the computer, laptop, mobile phone, tablets or watching TV). Moreover, during the COVID-19 pandemic, many countries switch their teaching programs into e-learning, where students spend long hour using electronic devices. Now e-learning back to educational institutions. However this change in learning methods is associated with musculoskeletal dysfunction including low back pain. Low back pain was one of the most common musculoskeletal disorders and today it is known that the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the prevalence and intensity of LBP. This may be explained by the prolonged sitting time, next to reduced level of physical activity. Most people sit for a long hours in a slumped sitting posture. Prolonged sitting causes changes in the passive structures of the spine and induces a low back compressive load significantly higher than that observed in standing. Physiotherapists recommend many different sitting positions to prevent and treat negative effects of prolonged sitting. However, there is debate regarding what is an optimal sitting posture. Periodic rest breaks have been identified as a way to reduce self-report discomfort at the low back. A standing breaks may be beneficial for the passive tissues of the spine. A combination of sitting and standing is beneficial for reducing musculoskeletal discomfort. Research aim. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of an active break on reduce LBP and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with LBP.

Study Design. This will be a randomized controlled study with pre and post-intervention assessment. The participants will be recruited from students (from middle school and high school) from the city of Timisoara, Romania. The participants will be randomly assigned to the intervention group consisting of an active break (n = 25) or the control group (n = 25). Participants with low back pain will be asked to fill out a questionnaire. Data will be analyzed using descriptive, bivariate, and multivariate statistics, for both populations. In order to compare the results between groups, the researchers will perform a Mann-Whitney test. In the experimental group, the post-intervention assessment will be collected immediately after the intervention ends (after 12 weeks of training). In the control group, the post-intervention assessment will be collected immediately after they receive a booklet with self-care recommendations (after 12 weeks of intervention). The investigators hypothesize a reduction in musculoskeletal discomfort in the experimental group.
Outcomes. Primary outcome will be average pain intensity, disability measured using the Oswestry Disability Index and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting (Borg scale"

995,This study has the purpose to provide an evidence base that demonstrates the potential of vaginal administration of vitamin E (Vitamin E Vaginal Ovules) to restore and maintain eubiosis and to provide preliminary evidence on its ability to treat vaginal atrophy and associated symptoms. The results will support a potential role of Vitamin E Vaginal Ovules in improving patients’ well-being during the menopause.

996,"The main goal of the current study is to assess the effect of exercise on cardiorespiratory performance during exercise, in addition to assessing its impact on ghrelin levels and its role in cardiopulmonary rehabilitation outcomes. The purpose of this study was to assess the role of exercise on cardiorespiratory fitness and to determine its impact on the circulating concentrations of ghrelin and its metabolites (increased activity) and the circulating concentrations of ghrelin and its metabolites (decreased activity) in patients with Coronary Heart Disease (CHD), type 1 diabetes (T1D), gestational diabetes (GDM) and obesity. To evaluate the changes that occur in the plasma of these hormones after exercise, the investigators designed protocols for three different cohorts (i.e., obesity, GDM, and CHD). The investigators recruited 20 participants for each cohort at different stages of the illness. The investigators performed an intravenous infusion of ghrelin and its metabolites to determine the changes that occur in the plasma of these hormones after exercise.

997,"10 patients will be recruited and their symptoms of cough, difficulty breathing, and blood pressure will be measured. Blood oxygen levels and heart monitors will be removed 30 minutes before starting the tests. Subjects will be asked to provide a written informed consent form before testing."

Palliative care is an interdisciplinary, patient-centered medical approach to treat terminally-ill patients optimally concerning the relief of physical, psychological, social and spiritual suffering. The central goal of supportive care in patients with advanced-stage disease is to increase patients' quality of life as far as possible. A major focus lies on the treatment of pain. Yet, pain problems remain unresolved in over 50% of patients with cancer in outpatient and inpatient settings. Furthermore, symptoms like anxiety, emotional distress, depression and existential distress can persist or even increase during the progression of the disease.

Safety guidelines are recommended for patients receiving opioids (opioids, anti-convulsants, beta blockers). They recommend tapering opioids before surgical procedures and discontinuing opioids for a minimum of 48 hours prior to surgery or other interventions that may require general anaesthesia. The dosage of opioids should be reduced prior to surgical procedures or to increase the speed of recovery from anaesthesia.
LSD effects can be used to treat palliative patients who still experience pain, anxiety, depression, and existential distress in spite of available therapies.
Scientific background and evidence for the therapeutic benefit of LSD:

During the past decades, pharmacological and toxicological data regarding LSD have been accumulated. LSD has been used primarily in psychiatric research and for psychotherapy since the 1960s, and more recently in studies of neuroplasticity and neurodegenerative diseases. LSD is a chemical analogue of serotonin, which influences synaptic circuits essential for mood and cognition. Animal studies have indicated that LSD affects various serotonin receptors and monoamine oxidase (MAO)-B in the brain. MAO-B is a monoamine-degrading enzyme with the highest activity in the human brain. The inhibitory effect of LSD on MAO-B can lead to increased levels of neurotransmitters, which presumably enhances the release of dopamine in the brain, triggering various beneficial effects (such as alleviating psychotic symptoms in patients with schizophrenia). A study by Morgenson and coworkers has shown that single doses of LSD can inhibit pain transmitted through the spinal cord in people without underlying pain disorders, possibly via stimulatory effects on the descending pain modulatory system. According to animal experiments, LSD also appears to act as an adaptogen and neuroprotectant. Several studies have reported that LSD can trigger a long-lasting enhancement of affect and neuroplastic effects. Experts from the medical and pharmaceutical field as well as other areas of society have been calling for research into the medical benefits of LSD for centuries.

Within the last two years, the US Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) has granted approval for five pilot studies in the USA involving LSD. Two of these studies were conducted to evaluate LSD effects in healthy volunteers (NCT03939352 and NCT0393671). One of these studies, conducted by the leading investigator of this study (Dr. Liechti), has been completed and has revealed a number of potential indications for LSD. The other pilot studies have been designed to evaluate whether LSD can help patients who are experiencing depressive symptoms (NCT03940880). Furthermore, one US pilot study is investigating the use of LSD and psilocybin in the treatment of cluster headaches (NCT03959375). Finally, a German pilot study is looking into the potential benefits of LSD in the treatment of anorexia nervosa (NCT03638605).

The investigators' scientific team intends to take clinical studies in patients with palliative care needs to the next level. The investigators propose the following therapeutic indications for LSD for patients with palliative care needs:
Reduction of pain, anxiety, and existential suffering during their remaining time of life (approximately 12 months for most of the patients);

To enable patients to spend the remaining months of their lives in their family environment rather than being in a nursing home, and to avoid the use of opioids in patients with pain, anxiety, and existential suffering.

Patients will be randomized to receive either low or high dosage of LSD. The dosage of LSD will be chosen according to each participant’s individual drug sensitivity, as measured during an initial dosing session. The dosage will"

999,"1) Background: The investigators recently conducted a pilot randomized control trial that enrolled 261 pregnant persons. This study demonstrated the feasibility of using SmartMom during pregnancy, and a number of important research questions about SmartMom that remain to be answered. The investigators will therefore conduct a large randomized control trial to test the efficacy of SmartMom for the promotion of healthy behaviours during pregnancy, and the effect of SmartMom on perinatal health outcomes for women and their babies. 2) Objectives: The investigators conduct a prospective randomized controlled intervention study with 1200 Canadian pregnant persons. The investigators will determine if SmartMom has the potential to promote healthy behaviours during pregnancy and, in turn, lead to improved perinatal health outcomes compared to control messages. 3) Hypotheses: The investigators expect that the rates of perinatal outcomes, including self-reported pregnancy weight gain, prenatal care attendance, and rates of adverse outcomes such as cesarean birth, gestational diabetes, and neonatal morbidities and mortalities will be better in SmartMom recipients than in control group recipients. At 1 year postpartum, the investigators expect that participants who received SmartMom will have been more successful at continuing breastfeeding and achieving adequate infant development milestones. The investigators also expect participants who received SmartMom to be more likely to experience fewer mental health challenges (fear of childbirth, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms). 4) Study Design: The investigators will conduct this study as a prospective randomized controlled trial in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Tri-Council Policy Statement. 5) Recruitment: Pregnant persons will be recruited by the research team through partnerships with community agencies, hospitals and health care providers. We will also use social media, television and radio advertisements to reach a wide range of prospective participants. 6) Eligibility Criteria: Pregnant persons at 15 weeks gestation or earlier who are able to read and understand English at a grade 8 level and can speak, read and/or understand digital communications are eligible. If the participant is less than 18 years of age, we will also obtain consent from a parent or guardian. 7) Interventions: SmartMom recipients will receive a minimum of 299 text message between weeks 15 – 38, at a frequency of three messages per week from 15-28 weeks, two messages per week from 28-30 weeks, and one message per week from 30-38 weeks. Control group recipients will receive a minimum of 104 text messages between weeks 15-38, at a frequency of one message per week throughout the period of the trial. 8) Study Endpoints: Rates of adverse pregnancy outcomes, including hospital admission for preterm birth, stillbirth; emergency cesarean birth; gestational diabetes; small for gestational age (SGA) status at birth. We will also assess health literacy through pregnancy and use self-reported outcomes at the end of the pregnancy to assess the impact of the trial on mental health (anxiety, depression, fear of childbirth), health behaviors (prenatal care attendance, smoking cessation, substance use and abstinence, dietary intake of recommended foods), and physiological birth outcomes (rates of instrumental births, episiotomies and use of anesthesia at birth). We will also assess if participants who received SmartMom messages are more likely to be successful at avoiding planned caesarean births in women with a prior caesarean birth. At one-year postpartum, we will also measure the proportion of breastfeeding women who are fully successful, who partially succeed, or who fully fail. All outcomes will also be compared using self-reported data collected during routine prenatal clinic visits (e.g. weight monitoring) and data collected from linkages to health administration databases (e.g. data related to hospital birth records, delivery method and information). Finally, the investigators will calculate the incremental costs per incidence of adverse pregnancy outcomes and inadequate prenatal care avoided. 9) Sample Size: Using a 2-group superiority test with 2-tailed alpha = 0.05 and power = 80%, the investigators will need to recruit a minimum of 600 participants (300 in each study arm), and conduct at least one additional analysis using 800 participants (400 in each study arm)."
